translated: Or, the counter-inference is: the self is not an aggregate because it is not for the sake of another.

analyzed: saṅghāta deha paratvena anumitasya ātmanaḥ saṅghāta rūpa tve pratyakṣa bādham api āha yogya anupalambhe ti
translated: He also states the contradiction by perception of the self, which is inferred to be for the sake of the aggregate body, if it has the form of an aggregate, in in the non-apprehension of what is possible.

original: yadvā anumānabalātprasaktamapi saṅghātatvamātmanaḥ pramāṇāntaraviṣayīkārato nivartsyatītyāha yogyānupalambhe ti /
analyzed: yat vā anumāna balāt prasaktam api saṅghāta tvam ātmanaḥ pramāṇa antara viṣayīkārataḥ nivartsyati iti āha yogya anupalambhe ti
translated: Or, he says in the non-apprehension of what is possible that even the nature of being an aggregate, which is inferred by the force of inference, will be averted by being the object of another means of knowledge.

analyzed: śarīram saṃhata parārtham
translated: The body is an aggregate for the sake of another.

analyzed: saṅghāta tvāt khaṭvā ādi vat iti atra śarīra bhinna tvam upādhiḥ ca
translated: Because it is an aggregate, like a bed etc. Here, being different from the body is the distinguishing feature.

analyzed: na ca pakṣa bhinna tvasya upādhi tve numāna vilopa prasaṅgaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that if being different from the subject is a distinguishing feature, then inference would be contradicted.

original: yatra pakṣe sādhyābhāvaḥ pramāṇāntareṇa niścitaḥ tatra vahneranuṣṇatvānumāna iva pakṣabhinnatvasyopādhitvasaṃbhavāt /
analyzed: yatra pakṣe sādhya abhāvaḥ pramāṇa antareṇa niścitaḥ tatra vahneḥ anuṣṇa tva anumāne iva pakṣa bhinna tvasya upādhi tva saṃbhavāt
translated: Because, where the absence of the probandum is ascertained by another means of knowledge in the subject, there, like the inference of the non-hotness of fire, being different from the subject is possible as a distinguishing feature.

original: prakṛte 'pi śarīrātmavādināṃ tadatiriktātmavādināṃ vā saṃhataparārthatvābhāva evopeyate śarīrasyeti tadbhinnatvasyopādhitve na doṣa ityabhimatam
analyzed: prakṛte pi śarīra ātma vādinām tad atirikta ātma vādinām vā saṃhata parārtha tva abhāvaḥ evā upeyate śarīrasya iti tad bhinna tvasya upādhi tve na doṣaḥ iti abhimatam
translated: Even in the case of the body, whether one holds that the body is the self or that there is a self distinct from the body, the absence of being for the sake of another is accepted as applying to the body. So it is intended that there is no fault in the distinction from that being the reason.

analyzed: saṅghāta tvasya saṃhata parārtha tvena na vyāptiḥ
translated: The reason being an aggregate is not pervaded by being for the sake of another.

analyzed: anavasthā āpādaka tvāt iti āha saṅghāta antare ti
translated: Because it would lead to an infinite regress, it is said in another aggregate.

analyzed: tasya api sādhya ghaṭakasya api saṅghātasya
translated: Of that, which is also a component of the probandum, the aggregate.

analyzed: tathā saṅghāta antara artha tvam  tatas nyasya api sādhya ghaṭaka saṅgāt anumitasya
translated: In the same way, being for the sake of another aggregate.🔽Then of another, which is also inferred as an aggregate, a component of the probandum.

analyzed: saṅghāta antarasya api
translated: Of another aggregate.

analyzed: tathā saṅghāta antara artha tvam
translated: In the same way, being for the sake of another aggregate.

original: na ca vyavasthāyām iti /🔽saṅghātatvasya parārthatvena vyāptau iṣyamāṇāyāṃ vyavasthāyāṃ saṃbhavatyāṃ saṃhataparārthatvena tasya vyāpterāśrayaṇamanavasthāprayojakatvānna
analyzed: na ca vyavasthāyām iti  saṅghāta tvasya parārtha tvena vyāptau iṣyamāṇāyām vyavasthāyām saṃbhavatyām saṃhata parārtha tvena tasya vyāpteḥ āśrayaṇam anavasthā prayojaka tvāt na
translated: And it is not that there is no such arrangement.

analyzed: yuktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If the pervasion of being an aggregate by being for the sake of another is accepted, then the reliance on the pervasion of that by being for the sake of another, when such an arrangement is possible, is not proper, because it does not lead to an infinite regress. This is the idea.

analyzed: nanu bhūyas sahacāra darśana adhīnaḥ hi vyāpti grahaḥ
translated: But the apprehension of pervasion depends on seeing frequent co-occurrence.

analyzed: sa ca saṃhata parārtha tvena eva saṅghāta tvasya bhavet
translated: And that would occur only by the pervasion of being an aggregate by being for the sake of another.

original: khaṭvādau tathā darśanādityata āha na ca saṅghātasye ti /🔽parasya saṃhatatvamantaraiva saṅghātaprayojyaniyatabhogarūpātiśayabhāktvena taṃ prati
analyzed: khaṭvā ādau tathā darśanāt iti atas āha na ca saṅghātasya iti  parasya saṃhata tvam antarā eva saṅghāta prayojya niyata bhoga rūpa atiśaya bhāj tvena tam prati
translated: Since the same is seen in a bed etc., he says And the aggregate is not....🔽The other's state of being an aggregate is possible as the state of being the other, characterized by being the remainder, in relation to that, which is the possessor of a special form of definite enjoyment caused by the aggregate.

original: śeṣitvalakṣaṇaṃ paratvaṃ prādhānyaṃ saṃbhavatīti parārthatvaniyamasya saṅgāta upapatteḥ
analyzed: śeṣi tva lakṣaṇam paratvam prādhānyam saṃbhavati iti parārtha tva niyamasya saṅgātaḥ upapatteḥ
translated: Since the restriction of being for the sake of the other is possible for the aggregate,

analyzed: sapakṣa dṛṣṭam api parasya saṃhata tvam na avinābhāva graha upayogi
translated: even the seen state of being an aggregate of the other does not serve the purpose of grasping the invariable concomitance.

analyzed: saṃhata parārtha tve sādhye saṅghāta tva hetoḥ aprayojaka tvam iti ca bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in proving the aggregate to be for the sake of the other, the reason of being an aggregate is not a proper reason.

original: sapakṣe darśanamātreṇa vyāptyanupayogisarvagharmoparāgeṇa sādhyasya pakṣe 'numāne 'numānāprāmāṇyaprasaṅgaśvetyāha vyāptyanupayogino 'pī ti
analyzed: sapakṣe darśana mātreṇa vyāpti anupayogi sarva gharma uparāgeṇa sādhyasya pakṣe numāne numāna aprāmāṇya prasaṅgaḥ ca iti āha vyāpti anupayoginā iti
translated: He says that even the useless for the purpose of the invariable concomitance of mere seeing in the similar instance, by the superimposition of all properties, there would be the undesirable consequence of the invalidity of inference in the inference of the probandum in the subject.

analyzed: pakṣe parvate sapakṣa dṛṣṭa mahānasīya tva kārīṣa tva ādi uparakta hneḥ anumāne prāmāṇya prasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there would be the undesirable consequence of the invalidity of the inference of the smoke characterized by being of a great mountain, being of a forest, etc., in the subject, the mountain, by mere seeing in the similar instance.

analyzed: dharma mātrasya a kṛtsnasya dharmasya
translated: The mere property is the entire property.

analyzed: anurodhena vyāpaka tā avacchedaka koṭi ghaṭanena
translated: By conforming, by including in the class defined by the pervader.

analyzed: anumānam pakṣe tāvat ākāra uparakta sādhya anumānam
translated: Analogy, in the case of the probandum, is the inference of the probandum tinged with the form of the probans.

analyzed: sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgaḥ anumāna mātra prāmāṇya vilopa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: There would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all inference, the undesirable consequence of the annihilation of the validity of inference alone.

original: śiṣṭaṃ spaṣṭam /🔽evamahaṃ jānāmītyāderahaṃpratyayasya pratyakṣarūpasya dehātiriktaviṣayatvaṃ vyavasthāpitaṃ tarkeṇa /
analyzed: śiṣṭam spaṣṭam  evam aham jānāmi ityādeḥ ahaṃpratyayasya pratyakṣa rūpasya deha atirikta viṣaya tvam vyavasthāpitam tarkeṇa
translated: The rest is clear.🔽Thus, by reasoning, it has been established that the perception of 'I', in the form of perception, such as 'I know', has an object other than the body.

original: tathā cāhaṃpratyaya eva dehabhedapratyayarūpa itīdaṅkāragocare dehe ātmabhedo 'pi pratyakṣasiddha ityavarṇi /
analyzed: tathā ca ahaṃpratyayaḥ eva deha bheda pratyaya rūpaḥ iti idaṅkāra gocare dehe pratyakṣa siddhaḥ iti avarṇi
translated: And it has been stated that the perception of 'I' itself is in the form of the perception of difference from the body, so the difference of the self from the body, which is the object of the perception of 'I', is also established by perception.

analyzed: asphuṭa tve pi bhedasya śarīre tad asaṃbhavāt
translated: Even though the difference is not clear, it cannot be in the body.

analyzed: tad guṇa antara vaidharbhyāt api jñānam na tad guṇaḥ
translated: Knowledge is not a quality of that [body] because it lacks the other qualities of that [body].

original: sarva eva kāryadravyagataviśeṣaguṇaḥ kāraṇaguṇapūrvaka iti kathamatatpūrvakaḥ śarīre caitanyaguṇaḥ saṃbhavet / /
analyzed: sarvaḥ eva kārya dravya gata viśeṣa guṇaḥ kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakaḥ iti katham a tad pūrvakaḥ śarīre caitanya guṇaḥ saṃbhavet
translated: All specific qualities in an effect substance must have a quality of the cause as their antecedent. How could the quality of consciousness in the body be possible without that [antecedent]?

original: yattu bārhaspatya vacanam pṛthivyāpastejo vāyuriti tattvāni /
analyzed: yat tu bārhaspatya vacanam pṛthivī apaḥ tejaḥ vāyuḥ iti tattvāni
translated: As for the statement of the followers of Brihaspati that the principles are earth, water, fire, and air,

analyzed: tebhyaḥ caitanyam
translated: and consciousness arises from them,

analyzed: kiṇva ādibhyaḥ mada śakti vat iti
translated: like the power of intoxication from yeast and so on,

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: śakteḥ aviśeṣa guṇa tvena tathā upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is logically possible in that way, since potency is a quality without distinction.

original: sarvadravyeṣu tattatkāryasamadhigabhyaḥ tatpratiyogī śaktayākhyo guṇaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ /
analyzed: sarva dravyeṣu tad tad kārya samadhigabhyaḥ tad pratiyogī guṇaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ
translated: The quality called potency, which is the counter-correlate of each effect in all substances, is common.

analyzed: na evam caitanyam
translated: But consciousness is not like that.

analyzed: deha eka guṇa tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is accepted as a quality of the body alone.

analyzed: kārya tve sati ekavidha pratyakṣa siddha tayā ca viśeṣa guṇa tvāt
translated: And because it is a special quality, being an effect and being established by one kind of perception.

analyzed: dravya antara saṃyoga samāsādita mada śaktibhiḥ akārya bhūtaiḥ paramāṇubhiḥ nija guṇa puraskāreṇa sva kārya dravyeṣu mada śaktay utpādaḥ pi na anupapannaḥ
translated: The production of potency in the effects, the substances, by the atoms which are not effects and which are devoid of potency, by bringing forward their own qualities, is also not illogical.

analyzed: tāmbūla rāgaḥ tu pūrva dravya avayava vibhāga anantaram dravya antara saṃyoga janita raktima guṇaiḥ kāraṇaiḥ kriyate
translated: But the redness of betel is produced by the causes which are the qualities of redness generated by the conjunction of another substance after the separation of the original substance.

analyzed: dṛśyate hi tatra avayaveṣu api pratyekam raktima guṇaḥ
translated: For the quality of redness is seen in each of the parts there.

original: naca śarīrāvayaveṣu pratyekaṃ caitanyaguṇaḥ prajñāyate pratijñāyate vā /🔽tadupagame ca ekaśarīra evānekacetanāpātādaṅgāṅgitvābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na ca śarīra avayaveṣu pratyekam caitanya guṇaḥ prajñāyate pratijñāyate vā  tad upagame ca eka śarīre eva aneka cetanā pātāt aṅga aṅgi tva abhāvaḥ
translated: And the quality of consciousness is not known or recognized in each of the parts of the body.🔽And if it were accepted, there would be the absence of the relation of whole and parts, and the destruction of the usage of recollection,

analyzed: pratisandhāna vyavahāra lopaḥ ca
translated: if there were many consciousnesses in one body.

analyzed: devadatta dṛṣṭaḥ iva yajñadatta ādeḥ
translated: Like the cognition of Yajnadatta, which is not the effect of the qualities of Devadatta.

original: yattu akāraṇaguṇapūrvakaṃ citrarūpaṃ paṭe iti / tanna /
analyzed: yat tu akāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam citra rūpam paṭe iti tat na
translated: As for the variegated form in the cloth, which is not preceded by variegated causes, that is not so.

analyzed: nānā rūpa tā hi citra tā
translated: For variegation is the state of having many forms.

original: sā ca nānārūpaiḥ tantubhiḥ kriyata iti kimanupapannamiti /
analyzed: sā ca nānā rūpaiḥ tantubhiḥ kriyate iti kim anupapannam iti
translated: And that is produced by threads with many forms. What is not established in that?

original: pratyekamavidyamānamapi taccitrarūpaṃ tantuṣu saṃhateṣu dṛśyata eva citrā ime tantava iti /
analyzed: pratyekam a vidyamānam api tat citra rūpam tantuṣu saṃhateṣu dṛśyate eva citrāḥ ime tantavaḥ iti
translated: Even though that variegated form does not exist individually, it is seen in the threads when they are combined, that these threads are variegated.

analyzed: saṃbhūya ca teṣām paṭa ārambhaka tvam
translated: And they collectively produce the cloth.

analyzed: evam tad kāraṇeṣu api tat iti na kvacid vdyabhicāraḥ
translated: Thus, in the causes of that also, that [variegation] is seen. There is no inconstancy anywhere.

analyzed: na ca eka rūpa niyama abhāvena avayavinaḥ cākṣuṣa tvam
translated: And the whole is not imperceptible due to the absence of restriction to a single form.

analyzed: mahat cva eka artha samavāyinā rūpavat tvena eva cākṣuṣa tva siddheḥ
translated: For perceptibility is established by the presence of form in what inheres in many for the sake of one [whole].

analyzed: astu vā citram nāma ekaḥ rūpa viśeṣaḥ
translated: Or let there be a single special form called variegated.

original: sa tu rūpaireva kāraṇagatairnānāvidhairārabhyata iti dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: sa tu rūpaiḥ eva kāraṇa gataiḥ nānāvidhaiḥ ārabhyate iti dṛṣṭam
translated: But that is produced by the variegated causes themselves, which are forms. That is seen.

analyzed: na ca evam avayava vartibhiḥ eva caitanyaiḥ avayavini śarīre caitanya viśeṣa ārambhaḥ
translated: And in the same way, the production of a special consciousness in the body, which is a whole, is not by the consciousnesses that exist in the parts alone.

analyzed: citi tanmātrasya eva teṣu asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because mere consciousness is not possible in them.

analyzed: atas na deha guṇaḥ caitanyam
translated: Therefore, consciousness is not a quality of the body.

analyzed: etena sukha ādayaḥ pi śarīra guṇāḥ pratyuktāḥ
translated: By this (argument) the qualities of the body, such as pleasure, etc., are also refuted.

original: api ca dṛḍha eva śarīre virodhiguṇāpātamantareṇa kusumavilepanagandha iva nivartamānaḥ caitanyasukhādirna tadguṇo bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: api ca dṛḍhe eva śarīre virodhi guṇa āpātam antareṇa kusuma vilepana gandhaḥ iva nivartamānaḥ caitanya sukha ādiḥ na tad guṇaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: Moreover, consciousness, pleasure, etc., which cease like the fragrance of flowers and unguents in a firm body without the occurrence of opposing qualities, cannot be its qualities.

analyzed: na khalu tad viśeṣa guṇāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ tathā nivartante
translated: For the specific qualities of that (body), such as form, etc., do not cease in the same way.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ pareṣām ca śarīra guṇāḥ pratyakṣa yogyāḥ
translated: The qualities of the body are perceptible to oneself and others.

analyzed: bāhya indriya grāhyāḥ ca
translated: And they are also grasped by the external senses.

original: na ca tathā jñānādiriti nāso tadguṇaḥ /
analyzed: na ca tathā jñāna ādiḥ iti tad guṇaḥ
translated: But knowledge, etc., are not so, therefore they are not its qualities.

original: atha deha ātmabhedasyāpratyakṣatve 'pi tasyānātmatvamacetanatvalakṣaṇamanu mānāt setsyatītyāha asphuṭatve 'pī ti /
analyzed: atha dehe ātma bhedasya apratyakṣa tve pi tasya anātmatvam acetana tva lakṣaṇam anu mānāt setsyati iti āha asphuṭa tve pi iti
translated: Even if the difference between the self and the body is not perceptible, its non-self nature characterized by insentience will be established by inference, he says Even if it is not clear.

original: yadvānanu saṅghātarūpo 'pi deha evātmopeyate lāghavāt /🔽dehabhinnasaṅghātatvameva bhavatu parārthatvavyāpyamityatrāha asphuṭatve ti /
analyzed: yat vā ananu saṅghāta rūpaḥ dehaḥ evā ātmā upeyate lāghavāt  deha bhinna saṅghāta tvam eva bhavatu parārtha tva vyāpyam iti atra āha asphuṭa tve ti
translated: Or, for the sake of simplicity, the body itself is accepted as the self, even though it has the form of an aggregate.🔽Let the mere fact of being an aggregate different from the body be pervaded by being for another's purpose, he says Even if it is not clear.

analyzed: prathama avataraṇikāyām bhedasya ātma bhedasya śarīre sphuṭa tve apratyakṣa tve pi iti arthaḥ
translated: In the first introduction, the meaning is: Even if the difference, i.e., the difference between the self and the body, is not clear, i.e., not perceptible, in the body.

analyzed: dvitīyasyām ca parārtha tvena śarīre ātma bhedasya aprasiddha tve pi iti arthaḥ
translated: And in the second, the meaning is: even though the difference between the body and the self is not well-known as being for the sake of another.

analyzed: tad asaṃbhavāt tasmin śarīre asaṃbhavaḥ udaya ayogaḥ tad asaṃbhavaḥ tasmāt
translated: Because of its impossibility, there is impossibility in that body, i.e., the impossibility of arising. Because of that.

analyzed: yat vā śarīre iti madhya maṇi nyāyena ubhaya anvayi
translated: Or, the word body is construed with both [body and self] according to the middle term method.

analyzed: tad asaṃbhavāt jñānasya asaṃbhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of the impossibility of knowledge.

analyzed: atra ca tad śabdayoḥ avairūpyam sahyam
translated: And here, the dissimilarity of the two words that is to be tolerated.

original: tadguṇāntare tyatra tadruṇa ityatra ca tacchabdena śarīrasya
analyzed: tad guṇa antare iti atra tad ruṇaḥ iti atra ca tad śabdena śarīrasya
translated: Because in that quality and in that quality, the word that refers to the body.

analyzed: parāmarśanīya tvāt
translated: Because it is to be referred to.

original: śarīre jñānaguṇasyotpatterayogāccharīraviśeṣaguṇāntaravaidharmyācca na jñānaṃ śarīraviśeṣaguṇa iti kārikārthaḥ ////
analyzed: śarīre jñāna guṇasya utpatteḥ ayogāt śarīra viśeṣa guṇa antara vaidharmyāt ca na jñānam śarīra viśeṣa guṇaḥ iti kārikā arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the verse is: because the arising of the quality of knowledge in the body is impossible, and because of the dissimilarity of the body's special qualities, knowledge is not a quality of the body's special qualities.

original: śarīre jñānasyāsaṃbhavaṃ tāvadupapādayati sarva eve ti /
analyzed: śarīre jñānasya asaṃbhavam tāvat upapādayati sarve eva iti
translated: And here he explains the impossibility of knowledge in the body first of all.

analyzed: kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakaḥ sva sajātīya sva āśraya samavāyi samaveta guṇa asamavāyi hetukaḥ
translated: [It is] preceded by the quality of the cause, having a cause that is not conjoined with a quality that is conjoined with a homogeneous substance and its substratum.

analyzed: saṃbhave d iti
translated: If possible.

analyzed: śarīra avayaveṣu jñānasya abhāvāt
translated: Because knowledge does not exist in the parts of the body.

original: bhāve vā ekasminneva dehe 'nekacetanaprasaṅgāt na kāraṇaguṇapūrvakaṃ śarīre caitanyaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: bhāve vā ekasmin eva dehe neka cetana prasaṅgāt na kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam śarīre caitanyam bhavet
translated: Or, if it exists, then in one body alone there would be many conscious beings, so consciousness in the body would not be preceded by the qualities of the cause.

analyzed: viśeṣa guṇa tvāt akāraṇa guṇa pūrvakatvam api dehe jñānasya asaṃbhavi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is impossible for knowledge in the body to be preceded by a quality that is not a quality of the cause, because it is a specific quality.

analyzed: śakteḥ iti
translated: In the case of potency.

analyzed: sāmānya guṇa tvena śakteḥ akāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvam upapadyate
translated: Potency, as a general quality, can be said to be preceded by a quality that is not a quality of the cause.

analyzed: sarva dravya vṛtti tvāt ca sāmānya guṇa tvam
translated: And it is a general quality because it occurs in all substances.

original: dṛśyatattatkāryeṇānumeyaḥ tatprati yogī tattatkāryeṇa nirūpyasvarūpaḥ prayojakatvena
analyzed: dṛśya tad tad kāryeṇa anumeyaḥ tat prati yogī tad tad kāryeṇa nirūpya svarūpaḥ prayojaka tvena
translated: The quality called potency, which is to be inferred by the various effects that are seen, which has its own nature determined by the various effects that correspond to it, which is the cause as the enabler,

original: śaktayākhyo guṇaḥ sarvasminnapi dravye tattatkāryapratiniyato 'stīti ca śaktyaḥ sarvabhāvānāmacintyajñānagocarāḥ
analyzed: śaktayā ākhyaḥ guṇaḥ sarvasmin api dravye tad tad kārya pratiniyataḥ sti iti ca śaktyaḥ sarva bhāvānām acintya jñāna gocarāḥ
translated: exists in all substances, restricted to each particular effect. And it is understood from the words of the jewel of the Puranas that the potencies of all things are the domain of inconceivable knowledge.

analyzed: iti purāṇa ratna vacanataḥ vagamyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: na evam iti
translated: It is not so.

analyzed: na evam na sāmānya guṇaḥ jñānam  kintu śarīre eva upagamāt viśeṣa guṇaḥ
translated: Knowledge is not a general quality in this way.🔽But it is a specific quality because it is accepted to be in the body alone.

analyzed: dravya tva nyūna vṛtti guṇa tvam ca tattvam
translated: Its nature is to be a quality that occurs in fewer substances than substance itself.

analyzed: siddhānta prakriyayā idam
translated: This is according to the principles of the established doctrine.

analyzed: siddhānte paratva ādi ca na guṇa antaram
translated: In the Siddhānta, paratva etc. are not separate qualities.

analyzed: kṣaṇa saṃbandha ādhikya ādinā eva
translated: By the mere excess of the relation with the moment etc.,

analyzed: paratva ādi vyavahāra nirvāhāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the usage of paratva etc. is accomplished. This is the idea.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika prakriyayā api āha kārya tve sati ti
translated: Even by the Vaiśeṣika method, he says 'being an effect'.

original: jñānaṃ viśeṣaguṇaḥ kāryatve sati ekavidhapratyakṣaviṣayatvādrūpādivat /🔽saṅkhyāderdvīndriyagrāhyatvāttatra vyabhicāravāraṇāya ekavidheti pratyakṣaviśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: jñānam viśeṣa guṇaḥ kārya tve sati ekavidha pratyakṣa viṣaya tvāt rūpa ādi vat  saṅkhyā ādeḥ dvi indriya grāhya tvāt tatra vyabhicāra vāraṇāya ekavidhā iti pratyakṣa viśeṣaṇam
translated: Knowledge is a special quality, being an effect, being the object of one kind of perception, like color etc.🔽In order to avoid the fallacy in number etc. which are grasped by two sense organs, the qualification 'one kind' is given to perception.

analyzed: prabhā bhitti saṃyoge vyabhicāra vāraṇāya ekavidha pratyakṣa viṣaya jātimat tvam vaktavyam
translated: In order to avoid the fallacy in the conjunction of light and wall, the property of having the genus of the object of one kind of perception should be stated.

analyzed: saṃyoga tva jāteḥ dvi indriya grāhya tvāt na doṣaḥ
translated: There is no fault because the genus of conjunction is grasped by two sense organs.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ mānasa pratyakṣa viṣaya tvāt tatra vyabhicāra vāraṇāya kārya tve sati iti
translated: In order to avoid the fallacy in the self which is the object of mental perception, 'being an effect' is stated.

analyzed: evam api prabhā tva jāti svīkāre prabhāyām
translated: Even so, if the genus of light is accepted, in light,

original: vāyoḥ spārśanopagame vā vāyau vyabhicāravāraṇāya ekavidhapratyakṣagrāhyajātīyaguṇatvāditi vaktavyam /
analyzed: vāyoḥ spārśana upagame vā vāyau vyabhicāra vāraṇāya ekavidha pratyakṣa grāhya jātīya guṇa tvāt iti vaktavyam
translated: or if air is accepted as tangible, in order to avoid the fallacy in air, 'being a quality belonging to the genus which is grasped by one kind of perception' should be stated.

original: guṇatvapraveśe ca kāryatve satīti cintyaprayojanamiti bodhyam /
analyzed: guṇa tva praveśe ca kārya tve sati iti cintya prayojanam iti bodhyam
translated: And when it enters the category of qualities, it should be understood that the purpose is to be considered as being when it is an effect.

original: viśeṣaguṇalakṣaṇe ca jñānādibhinnatvaṃ na dātuṃ śakyaṃ jñānāderviśeṣaguṇatve prāmāṇike satīti ca bhāvaḥ /🔽saṅghātaviśeṣāvayavivāde tu avayaveṣu caitanyābhāvādeva dehasya
analyzed: viśeṣa guṇa lakṣaṇe ca jñāna ādi bhinna tvam na dātum śakyam jñāna ādeḥ viśeṣa guṇa tve prāmāṇike sati iti ca bhāvaḥ  saṅghāta viśeṣa avayavi vāde tu avayaveṣu caitanya abhāvāt eva dehasya
translated: And in the definition of special qualities, it is not possible to give the qualification being different from knowledge etc. because knowledge etc. are special qualities, if they are authoritative.

analyzed: caitanyam na saṃbhavati iti ca anusandheyam atra
translated: But in the debate on the composite whole being a whole, it should be understood here that consciousness cannot arise in the body because consciousness is absent in the parts.

original: nanu rasaviśeṣo gandhaviśeṣo vā mādako madaśabdavācyaḥ /
analyzed: nanu rasa viśeṣaḥ gandha viśeṣaḥ vā mādakaḥ mada śabda vācyaḥ
translated: Now, a particular taste or a particular smell, which intoxicates, is called madya (intoxicant).

original: sa ca viśeṣaguṇo na kāraṇaguṇapūrvaka iti kāryadravyaviseṣaguṇasya kāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvaniyamo durvaca ityatrā'ha dravyādīnā mīti /
analyzed: sa ca viśeṣa guṇaḥ na kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakaḥ iti kārya dravya viseṣa guṇasya kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tva niyamaḥ durvacaḥ iti atra āha dravya ādīnām mī iti
translated: And that special quality does not have a quality of the cause as its antecedent. Therefore, the rule that a special quality of an effect substance has a quality of the cause as its antecedent is difficult to state. In this context, he says of substances etc.

analyzed: kiṇva ādīnām sammardana ādinā avdi aṇuka paryanta nāśe svatantraiḥ paramāṇubhiḥ dravya antara avayava saṃśleṣa janita madaiḥ ārabdhe surā dravye kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka
translated: By the crushing etc. of yeast etc., the destruction of the atoms up to the whole is produced. In the substance sura (alcohol), which is produced by the independent atoms with the intoxicants produced by the combination of the parts of other substances, the quality has a quality of the cause as its antecedent.

analyzed: eva guṇaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the idea.

analyzed: atha tāmbūla rasa rāge na aikāntyam ukta niyamasya pariharati tāmbūle ti
translated: Now, to avoid the non-uniqueness of the stated rule in the case of the passion for betel nut juice, he says in betel nut etc.

analyzed: spaṣṭaḥ ūrthaḥ
translated: The meaning is clear.

analyzed: na ca śarīre ti  prajñāyate upalabhyate
translated: And it is not in the body.🔽It is cognized, i.e., perceived.

analyzed: pratijñāyate sādhyate
translated: It is established, i.e., proved.

original: dehāvayaveṣu caitanye sādhakābhāvamuktvā bādhakamapyāha tadupagama iti /
analyzed: deha avayaveṣu caitanye sādhaka abhāvam uktvā bādhakam api āha tad upagamaḥ iti
translated: Having stated the absence of proof in the sentience of the body parts, he also states the refutation, saying in accepting that.

analyzed: aṅga aṅgi tva abhāvaḥ niyāmya niyāmaka bhāva lakṣaṇa guṇa pradhāna bhāva abhāvaḥ
translated: The absence of primary and secondary relationship is the absence of the quality of being regulated and the quality of being the regulator, which is characterized by the relationship of primary and secondary.

analyzed: eka cetana niyāmya tve hi śarīra avayavānām vyavahāra avisaṃvādaḥ ghaṭate
translated: For if the body parts are regulated by a single sentient being, then the agreement of usage is possible.

original: teṣāmeva cetanatve tu parasparāniyamyatayā parasparavārtānabhijñatayā ca vyavahāravisaṃvādaḥ prasajyata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām eva cetana tve tu paraspara aniyamya tayā paraspara vārttā anabhijña tayā ca vyavahāra visaṃvādaḥ prasajyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But if they themselves were sentient, then due to being regulated by each other and due to being ignorant of each other, the disagreement of usage would result - this is the idea.

original: pratisandhāne ti /🔽yamadrākṣaṃ taṃ spṛśāmītyādipratisandhānasya tanmūlavyavahārasya ca vilopaḥ prasajyate /
analyzed: pratisandhāne ti  yam adrākṣam tam spṛśāmi ityādi pratisandhānasya tad mūla vyavahārasya ca vilopaḥ prasajyate
translated: In the case of recognition.🔽The recognition I see what I touched and the usage based on that would be destroyed.

analyzed: avayava caitanye draṣṭuḥ spraṣṭuḥ ca anya anya tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: For in the sentience of the parts, the seer and the toucher would be different, this is the idea.

analyzed: aniṣṭa āpattiḥ iṣṭa hāniḥ ca atra ukte pada dvayena
translated: The undesirable consequence and the abandonment of the desired are stated here by the two words.

analyzed: nānā rūpa tā vibhinna jātīya rūpa samavīyi tā
translated: The state of being of the same nature as the forms of different kinds that are differentiated by various forms.

original: vijātīyarūpeṣu tantuṣu saṃhateṣu citrapratītimāha pratyekam iti /
analyzed: vijātīya rūpeṣu tantuṣu saṃhateṣu citra pratītim āha pratyekam iti
translated: In variegated forms, in woven yarns of different colors, he says individually.

analyzed: evam iti
translated: Thus, in that way.

analyzed: tad kāraṇeṣu api citra paṭa kāraṇeṣu tantuṣu api
translated: Even in the causes of that, in the yarns that are the causes of the variegated cloth.

analyzed: tat citram rūpam
translated: That variegated form.

analyzed: eka rūpa niyama abhāvena i ti
translated: Due to the absence of a single form being restricted.

analyzed: avyāpya vṛtti nānā rūpavati citra paṭe vyāpya vṛtti eka rūpa abhāvena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in a variegated cloth that has many forms that do not pervade, due to the absence of a single form that pervades.

analyzed: mahā tva eka arthe ti
translated: Due to the greatness being the same object.

original: laukikaviṣayatayā dravyacākṣuṣe sāmānādhikaraṇyena mahattvaviśiṣṭodbhūtarūpasya samavāyena hetutvasaṃbhave hetutāvacchedakakoṭau vyāpyavṛttitvaviśeṣaṇe
analyzed: laukika viṣayatayā dravya cākṣuṣe sāmānādhikaraṇyena mahat tva viśiṣṭa udbhūta rūpasya samavāyena hetu tva saṃbhave hetu tā avacchedaka koṭau vyāpya vṛtti tva viśeṣaṇe
translated: When the manifest form qualified by greatness is possible as the cause by inherence in the visual perception of substance, due to the common locus with greatness, in the definition of the cause, the qualification of pervasiveness,

analyzed: prayojana abhāvaḥ
translated: there is no purpose.

original: tathā ca citrapaṭasya na cākṣuṣatvānupapattiriti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca citra paṭasya na cākṣuṣa tva anupapattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, there is no impossibility of the variegated cloth being perceived by the eye. This is the idea.

analyzed: rūpasya vyāpya vṛtti tva niyame pi āha astu vā iti
translated: Even when form is restricted to pervasiveness, he says Let it be so.

analyzed: na ca evam iti
translated: And it is not so.

original: tantugatavividharūpaiḥ paṭe citrarūpārambhavadavayavagatairanudbhūtacaitanyairdehe udbhūtacaitanyārambho 'stviti ca na śaṅkyam /
analyzed: tantu gata vividha rūpaiḥ paṭe citra rūpa ārambha vat avayava gataiḥ anudbhūta caitanyaiḥ dehe udbhūta caitanya ārambhaḥ astu iti ca na śaṅkyam
translated: And thus, just as the variegated form in the cloth is produced by the various forms in the yarns, let the manifest consciousness be produced in the body by the unmanifest consciousnesses in the parts. This should not be suspected.

original: cititanmātrasyaivacaitanyasāmānyasyaiva mānābhāvena dehāvayaveṣvasaṃbhavāt /🔽śarīrasya caitanyetadavayaveṣu caitanyakalpanā / tatkalpa
analyzed: citi tanmātrasya eva caitanya sāmānyasya eva māna abhāvena deha avayaveṣu asaṃbhavāt  śarīrasya caitanī etad avayaveṣu caitanya kalpanā
translated: And because consciousness, which is mere cognition, is not established as a universal, it cannot exist in the parts of the body.🔽If consciousness were imagined in the body and its parts, then consciousness would be established in the body itself by that imagination.

analyzed: śarīre caitanya siddhiḥ iti anyaḥ nya saṃśrayāḥ ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there would be mutual dependence.

analyzed: etena ti
translated: By this,

original: jñānasyeva sukhāderapi viśeṣaguṇasya na śarīradharmatvasaṃbhava iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: jñānasya iva sukha ādeḥ api viśeṣa guṇasya na śarīra dharma tva saṃbhavaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the idea is that like consciousness, pleasure etc. also cannot be properties of the body as they are special qualities.

analyzed: evam śarīre tad asaṃbhavām diti vyākhyātam
translated: Thus, the impossibility of them in the body has been explained.

original: atha tadguṇāntaravaidharmyā dityetadvivṛṇoti api ce ti /
analyzed: atha tad guṇa antara vaidharmyāt iti etat vivṛṇoti api ca iti
translated: Now, to explain the phrase due to the dissimilarity from other qualities of that, he says Moreover...

analyzed: virodhi guṇa āpātam antara apūrva guṇa nivartaka guṇa prasaṅgam vinā
translated: without the occurrence of contradictory qualities, there is the occurrence of qualities that remove previous qualities.

analyzed: kusuma vilepana gandhaḥ strak candana gandhaḥ
translated: The fragrance of flowers and unguents is the fragrance of garlands and sandalwood.

analyzed: na khalu te diti
translated: Indeed, that is not so.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ agnisaṃyogena rūpaparāvṛttāvapi tadaprasaṅge rūpasya yāvaddravyabhāvitvaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ agni saṃyogena rūpa parāvṛttau api tad aprasaṅge rūpasya yāvaddravyabhāvi tvam dṛṣṭam
translated: The idea is this: even when color changes due to contact with fire, the persistence of color as long as the substance exists is seen.

analyzed: na ca jñāna ādi sthiram evam
translated: But consciousness etc. are not permanent in this way.

analyzed: na ca uttara uttara viśeṣa guṇaḥ eva pūrva pūrva jñāna ādi virodhi iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that only the subsequent special qualities contradict the previous consciousness etc.

analyzed: evam api antyasya ciram avasthāna prasaṅgāt iti
translated: Even so, there is the contingence of the last one remaining for a long time.

analyzed: ayāvaddravyabhāvittvam jñāna ādeḥ śarīra viśeṣa guṇa antarataḥ vaidharmyam iti uktam bhavati
translated: It is said that the non-co-existence with the substance is a difference in property from the knowledge etc. and the special qualities of the body.

analyzed: atha vaidharmya antaram dvidhā āha ātmanaḥ iti
translated: Now, he states another difference in property in two ways, beginning with from the self.

original: svātmamātragrāhyatvaṃ manomātragrāhyatvaṃ ca jñānādeḥ śarīraviśeṣaguṇāntaravaidharmyamiti phalitam /
analyzed: sva ātma mātra grāhya tvam manaḥ mātra grāhya tvam ca jñāna ādeḥ śarīra viśeṣa guṇa antara vaidharmyam iti phalitam
translated: The conclusion is that the difference in property of knowledge etc. from the special qualities of the body is the fact that it is apprehensible by its own self alone and by the mind alone.

analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ hi śarīra guṇāḥ sva para grāhyāḥ bahis indriya grāhyāḥ ca
translated: For form etc., which are qualities of the body, are apprehensible by self and others and apprehensible by external sense organs.

analyzed: na ca tathā jñāna ādiḥ ti
translated: And knowledge etc. are not like that.

original: atra prayogaḥjñānaṃ na śarīraviśeṣaguṇaḥ ayāvaddravyabhāvitvānmanomātragrāhyatvādvā yannaivaṃ tannaivaṃ yathā rūpādīti /
analyzed: atra prayogaḥ jñānam na śarīra viśeṣa guṇaḥ ayāvaddravyabhāvi tvāt manaḥ mātra grāhya tvāt vā yat na evam tat na evam yathā rūpa ādi iti
translated: Here the argument is: Knowledge is not a special quality of the body, because it does not co-exist with the substance, or because it is apprehensible by the mind alone. What is not so is not so, like form etc.

original: evaṃ jñānasya śarīradharmatvābhāvasādhanena śarīrasyātmatvaṃ pratikṣiptaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: evam jñānasya śarīra dharma tva abhāva sādhanena śarīrasya ātma tvam pratikṣiptam bhavati
translated: Thus, by establishing the absence of the body being a quality of the self, the body being the self is refuted.

analyzed: yathā dehaḥ na ātmā ājñātṛ tvāt dhaṭa ādi vat iti
translated: Just as the body is not the self because it is not the knower, like a pot etc.

analyzed: kiñca autpattimat tvāt sanniveśa viśeṣataḥ
translated: Moreover, because it is produced, because of the particular arrangement,

analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt bhūta tvāt dehaḥ na ātmā ghaṭa ādi vat
translated: because it has form etc., because it is an element, the body is not the self, like a pot etc.

analyzed: sa chidra tvāt adehi tvāt deha tvāt mṛta deha vat
translated: Because it has holes, because it is not the self, and because it is the body, like a dead body.

analyzed: ityādi sādhanaiḥ nyāyyaiḥ niṣedhyā varṣmaṇaḥ citiḥ
translated: The consciousness of the body should be negated by such proper reasons as having holes, being non-embodiment, and being embodied like a dead body.

analyzed: evam pratyakṣa virodhāt
translated: Thus, due to contradiction with perception,

analyzed: anvaya mukhena sādhyam upasthāpadbhiḥ udīrita sādhanaiḥ apahṛta viṣaya tayā indriya āśraya tva ādi vyatireki hetavaḥ na sādhyam upasthāpayitum īśate
translated: the reasons that are different from being the basis of the senses, etc., which are stated by the proofs that present the probandum through the method of agreement, are not able to present the probandum, because their scope has been taken away.

analyzed: iti deha ātma vāda nirāsa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the refutation of the doctrine of the identity of the body and the self.

analyzed: santu tarhi indriyāṇi eva ātmā
translated: Let the senses be the self, then.

analyzed: na ca tāni idantayā prathante  yena dehavat aha
translated: And they are not well known in that way.

analyzed: ṅkāra gocarāt bahiṣkriyeran
translated: By which they would be excluded from the sphere of the thought of I, like the body.

analyzed: nā api tathā udbhūta rūpa ādi guṇāni sthūlāni
translated: Nor are they gross, having such qualities as manifest form, etc.

analyzed: yena tad pratibhāse iva indriya gocara tve haṃpratyayasya rūpa avayava ādi pratītiḥ prasajyeta
translated: By which, if the appearance of the senses were like the appearance of the senses, the cognition of the parts of form, etc. would be implied in the cognition of I.

original: tavdyāpāraphalaṃ ca jñānaṃ tadgāmi yuktaṃ snānādhyayanādiphalavat /
analyzed: tad vyāpāra phalam ca jñānam tad gāmi yuktam snāna adhyayana ādi phalavat
translated: And the result of its operation is knowledge, which is properly directed to it, like the result of bathing, studying, etc.

analyzed: atas eva satya patāḥ draṣṭuḥ cakṣuṣaḥ iti
translated: For this very reason, the followers of truth say of the seer and the eye, etc.

analyzed: iti indriya ātma tva pūrvapakṣa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the prima facie view of the senses being the self.

analyzed: tat na vikalpa asaha tvāt
translated: That is not so, because it cannot withstand analysis.

analyzed: tathā hi kim pratyekam indriyāṇi cetanāni
translated: For example, are the sense faculties individually conscious?

analyzed: saṃbhūya vā
translated: Or collectively?

analyzed: yadi pratyekam
translated: If individually,

analyzed: indriya antara dṛṣṭasya indriya antareṇa pratisandhānam na syāt
translated: then one sense faculty would not remember what was seen by another sense faculty.

original: asti ca tat yamahamadrākṣaṃ tamahaṃspṛśāmīti /🔽ata eva na saṃbhūyāpi cetanatvam /
analyzed: asti ca tat yam aham adrākṣam tam aham spṛśāmi iti  atas eva na saṃbhūya api cetana tvam
translated: But this does happen, as when one says I saw that, I touched it.🔽For this very reason, consciousness does not belong to the sense faculties collectively either.

original: na hi pañcabhirindriyaiḥ saṃbhūyaikaṃ vastvanubhūyate 'nusandhīyate vā /
analyzed: na hi pañcabhiḥ indriyaiḥ saṃbhūya ekam vastu anubhūyate nusandhīyate vā
translated: For no single object is experienced or remembered by the five sense faculties collectively.

analyzed: eka indriya vigame ca prāyaṇa prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: And if one sense faculty were lost, there would be death.

original: indriyacaitanye ca tattadindriyāpāye tattadindriyārthasmaraṇamapi na bhavet /
analyzed: indriya caitanye ca tad tad indriya apāye tad tad indriya artha smaraṇam api na bhavet
translated: And if the sense faculties were conscious, even the memory of the objects of the individual sense faculties would not occur upon the loss of those sense faculties.

analyzed: na ca tad vyāpāra phalatayā tad samavāyi tvam jñānasya
translated: And consciousness cannot be a property of the sense faculties as the result of their operation.

analyzed: śastra ādi vyāpāra janmanaḥ pi pāpa ādeḥ para samavāyi tvāt
translated: Because even the sin etc. arising from the operation of weapons etc. is a property of others.

original: anyathā ca praṣṭurmṛtyupapattiṃ śaraṇāgataparityāgasya nṛśaṃsatāṃ cā'locya satyatapasastathā vacanam /
analyzed: anyathā ca praṣṭuḥ mṛtyu papattim śaraṇa āgata parityāgasya nṛśaṃsa tām ca ālocya satya tapasaḥ tathā vacanam
translated: And Satyatapa spoke thus, considering the death of the questioner and the cruelty of abandoning one who has sought refuge.

analyzed: iti indriya ātma vāda nirāsa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the refutation of the doctrine that the sense faculties are the self.

analyzed: astu tarhi manaḥ eva cetanam
translated: Then let the mind alone be conscious.

original: tathā sati hi pūrvoktā doṣāḥ parihṛtā bhavanti /
analyzed: tathā sati hi pūrva uktāḥ doṣāḥ parihṛtāḥ bhavanti
translated: For if that were so, the previously mentioned faults would be avoided.

analyzed: tat hi sarva indriya adhyakṣam prajñāyate pratijñāyate ca
translated: For that is perceived as the predominant factor of all the senses, and is declared to be so.

analyzed: upapadyate ca indriya antareṇa pratisandhānam
translated: And the recollection of other sense organs is also possible.

analyzed: darśana anusandhāna ādhārasya manasaḥ eka tvāt
translated: Because the mind, which is the basis of the continuity of perception, is one.

analyzed: tad tad indriya apāye smaraṇam api upapadyate eva
translated: Even when a particular sense organ is absent, memory is also possible.

analyzed: manasaḥ nitya tvāt
translated: Because the mind is eternal.

analyzed: iti manaḥ ātma tva pūrvapakṣa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the prima facie view that the mind is the self.

analyzed: tat api na karaṇa tvāt cakṣuḥ ādi vat
translated: That is also not so, because it is an instrument, like the eye etc.

analyzed: bāhya antara sakala viṣaya saṃvedana karaṇa tayā hi manaḥ prakalpyate
translated: The mind is conceived as the instrument of the experience of all external and internal objects.

original: bāhyendriyeṣu yathāyathaṃ nijaviṣayasannikarṣabhāgiṣvapi yato na yugapadeva sarve viṣayāḥ pratīyante /
analyzed: bāhya indriyeṣu yathāyatham nija viṣaya sannikarṣa bhāgiṣu api yatas na yugapad eva sarve viṣayāḥ pratīyante
translated: Even when the external sense organs are engaged in contact with their own objects, all objects are not perceived simultaneously.

analyzed: atas vagacchāmaḥ asti
translated: Therefore we understand that🔽there is

analyzed: kiñcid aparam api sādhanam
translated: some other means also.

analyzed: yat sāhāyaka virahāt na sarve prakāśante
translated: Due to the absence of its assistance, all do not manifest.

analyzed: kaścid eva ekaḥ pratīyate iti
translated: Only one is perceived.

analyzed: tathā sukha ādi saṃvedanāni api karaṇavanti
translated: Similarly, the experiences of pleasure etc. also have instruments.

analyzed: kriyā tvāt
translated: Because they are actions.

analyzed: saṃvedana tvāt vā
translated: Or because they are experiences.

analyzed: rūpa ādi jñāna vat iti
translated: Like the knowledge of form etc.

original: tadevaṃ jñānakaraṇatayāvagatasya manasaḥ kathamiva jñāne kartṛtvam //
analyzed: tat evam jñāna karaṇatayā avagatasya manasaḥ katham iva jñāne kartṛ tvam
translated: How then can the mind, which is known to be the instrument of knowledge, be the agent in knowledge?

analyzed: svātantrya lakṣaṇam hi tat
translated: For that [agency] consists in independence.

analyzed: tat ca svacchanda anurodhena sādhya siddhi anuguṇa upakaraṇa saṃpādana sāmarthyam
translated: And that is the power to accomplish the means conducive to the attainment of what is to be accomplished in accordance with one's own will.

analyzed: sva samavetam eva vā guṇa antaram tantrīkṛtya pravṛttiḥ
translated: Or else, taking as the means [to the attainment of the end] some other quality inherent in oneself, one acts.

original: karaṇatvaṃ tu parādhiṣṭhānādhīnavyāpāratārūpapāra tantryaniyataṃ sādhakatamatvamiti kathamivaikatra manasi parasparaviruddha tadubhayadharmasaṃbandhaṃ 🔽pratipadyemahi / /
analyzed: karaṇa tvam tu para adhiṣṭhāna adhīna vyāpāra tā rūpa pāra tantrya niyatam sādhakatama tvam iti katham iva ekatra manasi tad ubhaya dharma saṃbandham  pratipadyemahi
translated: But instrumentality is the state of being the most effective, which is determined by dependence on the operation of something else that is controlled by it. How then can we understand the connection of both of these mutually contradictory properties in one thing, the mind?

original: atha tadapi manaḥ karaṇāntareṇa smaraṇādiṣu kartṛbhāvamanubhavati /
analyzed: atha tat api manaḥ karaṇa antareṇa smaraṇa ādiṣu kartṛ bhāvam anubhavati
translated: If, moreover, that mind experiences the state of being the agent in memory and other [mental] activities through another instrument,

analyzed: tathā sati saṃjñā mātre vivādaḥ
translated: then there is a dispute only about the name [of the self].

original: ya eva hi cakṣurādibhī rūpādin āntarakaraṇena ca sukhādīṃścetayate / sa evā'tmā /
analyzed: yaḥ eva hi cakṣuḥ ādibhiḥ rūpa ādin āntara karaṇena ca sukha ādīn cetayate saḥ eva ātmā
translated: For he who cognizes forms etc. through the eyes etc. and pleasure etc. through the internal organ, he alone is the self.

analyzed: tasmin eva ced manaḥ saṃjñā niveśyate
translated: And if the name 'mind' is applied to him alone,

analyzed: kāmam niveśyatām
translated: let it be applied.

analyzed: na naḥ kiñcid hīnam
translated: We do not lose anything.

analyzed: kintu tadā sarva laukika vyavahāraḥ bādhyeta iti alam anena
translated: But then all worldly conventions would be contradicted. Enough of this.

analyzed: iti manaḥ ātma vāda khaṇḍana prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the refutation of the doctrine of the mind as the self.

analyzed: āha kim idam manaḥ nāma
translated: It is said: What is this so-called mind?

analyzed: nanu uktam āntaram jñāna karaṇam dravyam iti
translated: Isn't it said that the internal instrument of knowledge is a substance?

analyzed: kim punar asya sādhanam
translated: What, then, is its proof?

analyzed: nanu uktam yugapad jñāna anutpattiḥ manasaḥ liṅgam iti
translated: Isn't it said that the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions is the mark of the mind?

analyzed: uktam nāma tathā api katham tattva antara siddhiḥ
translated: It is said, but even so, how is the establishment of a separate reality?

analyzed: kalpayitvā api hi tat yugapad smaraṇa anutpatti upapattaye vaśyā āśrayaṇīyam eva nimitta antaram
translated: For even if it is imagined for the sake of explaining the non-simultaneous arising of recollections, a separate cause must necessarily be relied upon.

analyzed: santi hi yugapad asya smartṛ rnānā artha anubhava bhāvitāḥ saṃskārāḥ
translated: For there are impressions in the experiencer of many objects simultaneously,

analyzed: atha ca na sarve smaryante
translated: and yet not all are remembered.

analyzed: kiñcid eva kadācid smaryate  saṃskāra unmeṣa hetu upanipāta kramāt tathātvam iti ced
translated: Sometimes only something is remembered.🔽If it is said that it is so due to the order of the occurrence of the causes of the manifestation of impressions,

analyzed: evam api praṇidhāna mātra udbodhanīya saṃskārasya smṛti yaugapadyam āpadyeta
translated: even so, the simultaneous recollection of an impression that is to be awakened by mere resolve would occur.

original: yāvadanubhūtasakalaviṣayasusmūrṣayā sarvataḥ pratyāhṛtacetasaḥ sādhāraṇyena praṇidadhayo 'pi na sarva evārthāḥ smṛtimadhirohanti /
analyzed: yāvat anubhūta sakala viṣaya susmūrṣayā sarvatas pratyāhṛta cetasaḥ sādhāraṇyena praṇidadhayaḥ api na sarve eva arthāḥ smṛtim adhirohanti
translated: Even when the minds of all are withdrawn from all objects, with the desire to remember all the objects experienced, not all objects are remembered in the same way.

analyzed: yadi tu śubha aśubha rūpa tayā smaraṇānām adṛṣṭa vaśa avdi avasthā
translated: If the order of memories is determined by unseen forces, based on the nature of good and bad,

original: kramajñānasvābhāvyādvā🔽ātmanaḥ / tathā sati bahirindriyeṣu ca yathā
analyzed: krama jñāna svābhāvyāt vā  ātmanaḥ tathā sati bahis indriyeṣu ca yathā
translated: or based on the nature of the self's knowledge,

original: yathaṃ svaviṣayasaṃprayukteṣu tathaiva yugapajjñānānutpattirupapadyata iti kṛtamindriyāntareṇa /
analyzed: sva viṣaya saṃprayukteṣu tathā eva yugapad jñāna anutpattiḥ upapadyate iti kṛtam indriya antareṇa
translated: then in the case of external senses too, the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions with their respective objects is possible in the same way, so there is no need for another sense faculty.

analyzed: syāt matam kādācitkasya sukha ādeḥ ātma samavāyinaḥ bāhya viṣaya adṛṣṭa ādi nimitta kāraṇasya asamavāyi kāraṇena bhāvyam
translated: It may be argued that for occasional pleasure etc., which inhere in the self, and have external objects, unseen forces etc. as causal conditions, there must be an inherent cause.

analyzed: tat ca ātma manaḥ sannikarṣaḥ iti manaḥ dravya siddhiḥ iti
translated: And that is the contact of the self and mind. Thus the substance mind is established.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha ādi pūrva kāla janmanaḥ bhimata anabhimata viṣaya saṃparka ja jñānasya ātma samavāyinaḥ eva asamavāyi kāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because knowledge born before pleasure, pain etc., born from contact with desired and undesired objects, is the inherent cause itself.

analyzed: tasya ca viṣaya saṃprayukta indriya saṃprayogaḥ eva ātma samavetaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam
translated: And the contact of that with the sense-organ associated with the object is itself the non-inherent cause subsisting in the self.

analyzed: tad hetuḥ api indriya vyāpāraḥ prayatnam adṛṣṭam ca ātma samavetam apekṣamāṇāt ātma indriya sānnikarṣāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt
translated: And that cause of the sense-organ's operation, requiring effort and unseen potency subsisting in the self, is the non-inherent cause from the contact of the self with the sense-organ.

analyzed: prayatnasya tu sva pūrva kṣaṇa varti kartavya tā jñānam
translated: But for effort, the knowledge of what is to be done in the preceding moment is the cause.

original: prayatna eva tvadṛṣṭasyāpīti nātmaviśeṣaguṇānāṃ buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādīnāmasamavāyikāraṇasāpekṣatayāpi dravyāntaraparikalpanaṃ nyāyyam /
analyzed: prayatnaḥ eva tu adṛṣṭasya api iti na ātma viśeṣa guṇānām buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā ādīnām asamavāyi kāraṇa sāpekṣa tayā api dravya antara parikalpanam nyāyyam
translated: And for unseen potency also, it is effort itself. Thus it is not reasonable to imagine another substance even on the basis of the inherent cause of the specific qualities of the self, such as cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, etc.

analyzed: yat tu nitya dravya viśeṣa guṇasya dravya antara saṃyogaḥ eva asamavāyi kāraṇam
translated: But for the specific quality of a permanent substance, the contact of another substance itself is the non-inherent cause.

analyzed: pārthiva paramāṇuṣu agni saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt rūpa utpatteḥ iti
translated: Because the production of color in earth atoms is from the contact with fire, which is the non-inherent cause.

analyzed: tat api sthavīyaḥ
translated: That too is too much.

analyzed: pārthiva paramāṇuṣu rūpa ādayaḥ dahana saṃyogāt iti kṛtaḥ
translated: It is understood that color, etc. in earth atoms are produced from the contact with fire.

analyzed: kārya dravye tathā darśanāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is so because it is seen in the case of an effect substance,🔽then it is not so.

original: iha vā tahri kiṃ na dṛśyate iṣṭāniṣṭaprāptyavagamānantaraṃ sukhādirjāyata iti //
analyzed: iha vā tahri kim na dṛśyate iṣṭa aniṣṭa prāpti avagama anantaram sukha ādiḥ jāyate iti
translated: Or, why is it not seen here? Pleasure, etc. arise after the understanding of the attainment of the desired and undesired.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa kāraṇa vyabhicāre hi kāraṇa antara anumāna avasaraḥ
translated: For when there is a deviation from the seen cause, there is an opportunity to infer another cause.

analyzed: na ca iha asti vyabhicāraḥ
translated: But here there is no deviation.

original: ataḥ prasiddhakāraṇabhāveṣveva yatra kāryasamavāyaḥ tat samavāyikāraṇam /
analyzed: atas prasiddha kāraṇa bhāveṣu eva yatra kārya samavāyaḥ tat samavāyikāraṇam
translated: Therefore, it is proper to rely on the established rule that whatever is the inherence of the effect in the well-known causes, that is the inherent cause.

analyzed: yat tu tat pratyāsannam tat asamavāyi
translated: But what is proximate to that is the non-inherent.

analyzed: yat anyat tat nimittim iti vyavasthā āśrayaṇam ucitam
translated: What is different from that is the instrumental.

analyzed: na tu anapekṣita aprasiddha dravya antara saṃyoga abhyupagamena tasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tva āśrayaṇam
translated: But it is not proper to rely on its being an inherent cause by accepting the conjunction of an unseen other substance that is not dependent.

analyzed: kāraṇa antara anupalabdheḥ
translated: Because another cause is not perceived.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa anusārāt ca aṇugata rūpa ādau tathā abhyupagamaḥ
translated: And because it is seen, it is accepted in the case of color, etc. that inheres in atoms.

analyzed: iha tu tad viparyayaḥ pradārśitaḥ eva
translated: But here the opposite of that has been shown.

analyzed: evam api vyāpti balena yadi dravya antara saṃyogaḥ numātavyaḥ
translated: Even so, if the conjunction with another substance is to be inferred by the power of pervasion,

original: sa tarhi sparśavaddravyasamaveto bhautika eva copalabdha iti prasiddhadehādisaṃyoga evānumānaparyavasānānna navama🔽dravyasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: sa tarhi sparśavat dravya samavetaḥ bhautikaḥ eva ca upalabdhaḥ iti prasiddha deha ādi saṃyogaḥ eva anumāna paryavasānāt na navama 🔽
translated: then it is perceived to be conjoined with a tangible substance and to be material only. Therefore, the conclusion of inference is only the conjunction with the well-known body, etc. Thus the ninth substance is not established.

analyzed: atha ucyeta bhautika tve hi manasaḥ pṛthivī ādi anyatama tvena bhavitavyam
translated: Now, if it is said that the mind is material, it must be one of earth, etc.

analyzed: tat ca anumāna antaraiḥ vyatirekam āpādayadbhiḥ pratyāsiddham
translated: And that is refuted by other inferences that establish the exclusion [of the mind from the elements].

analyzed: tathā hi na pārthivam manaḥ rasa avagama nimitta indriya tvāt rasanā vat
translated: Thus, the mind is not earthy, because it is a sense organ for the perception of taste, like the tongue sense organ.

analyzed: na pāthasīyam
translated: It is not watery.

analyzed: gandha grahaṇa nimitta undriya tvāc ghrāṇa vat
translated: Because it is a sense organ for the perception of smell, like the nose sense organ.

analyzed: evam ataijasa tva ādi api tad tad indriya agocara grahaṇa nimitta tayā śakya adhyavasānam iti abhautika tvam manasaḥ iti
translated: In the same way, it can be inferred that it is not fiery, etc., because it is a sense organ for the perception of the objects of those [elements], so the mind is not material.

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: dharmi viśeṣa viparīta sādhanāt
translated: Because it proves the opposite of the specific property of the subject.

analyzed: rasa avagama nimitta indriya tvam apārthiva tvam iva pāthasīya tvam api samarthayati
translated: The property of being a sense organ for the perception of taste proves both non-earthiness and wateriness, as if [the inference] were contradicting the other elements.

analyzed: evam sādhana antarāṇi api bhūta antara vyatikeram iva amīya bhūta bhāvam āpādayanti  atha śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandheṣu yat guṇa grāhi yat indriyam
translated: In the same way, the other proofs establish the state of being composed of the elements as if contradicting the other elements.

analyzed: tat eva tad guṇaka bhūta ārabdham
translated: Now, if a sense organ is that which perceives a particular quality, it is composed of the elements that possess that quality.

original: hanta tarhi tadeva taditarabhūtavyatirekitayāpyavagatamiti na tadavagamakatāmātreṇābhimatavyatirekasiddhiḥ /🔽api ca śabdādiguṇāvagamasādhāraṇasādhanatayā śarīramiva pāñcabhautikam /
analyzed: hanta tarhi tat eva tad itara bhūta vyatireki tayā api avagatam iti na tad avagamaka tā mātreṇa abhimata vyatireka siddhiḥ  api ca śabda ādi guṇa avagama sādhāraṇa sādhanatayā śarīram iva pāñcabhautikam
translated: Well then, that [body] itself is understood as distinct from the other elements, so the establishment of the intended distinction is not merely by the fact of its being understood.

analyzed: eka dvitra ādi mayam vai itara bhūta saṃsṛṣṭam astu manaḥ
translated: Moreover, like the body, the mind may consist of the five elements, or of one, two, three, etc., mixed with the other elements, by virtue of being the common means of apprehending the qualities of sound, etc.

original: yathā'mnāyate annamayaṃ hi somya mana iti /🔽tanna tatprakṛtitvapratipādanaparam /
analyzed: yathā āmnāyate anna mayam hi somya manaḥ iti  tat na tad prakṛti tva pratipādana param
translated: As it is stated: Verily, O Somya, the mind is made of food.🔽But that [statement] is not intended to establish that [mind] as having that [food] as its material cause.

analyzed: apitu tad adhīna vṛtti tā mātra pradarśana artham āpaḥ mayaḥ prāṇaḥ ityādi vat
translated: Rather, it is merely to show that its functioning depends on that, like the statement The life-breath is made of water, and so on.

analyzed: atas eva apavarga daśāyām api manaḥ nuvṛttiḥ
translated: For this very reason, the mind continues to function even in the state of liberation.

original: darśitaṃ hi tatraivāṣṭame manasaitān kāmān paśyan ramate mano 'sya daivaṃ cakṣuriti /
analyzed: darśitam hi tatra eva aṣṭame manasā etān kāmān paśyan ramate manaḥ sya daivam cakṣuḥ iti
translated: For it is shown there in the eighth chapter itself: Seeing these desires with the mind, he delights. The mind is his divine eye.

original: tathā parasyāśca devatāyāḥ so 'nyaṃ kāmaṃ manasā dhyāyīteti mahopaniṣadi /
analyzed: tathā parasyāḥ ca devatāyāḥ saḥ kāmam manasā dhyāyīta iti mahā upaniṣadi
translated: Similarly, in the Mahâpâna-Upaniṣad: He should meditate on another desire with the mind.

analyzed: manasā eva jagat sṛṣṭim iti ca purāṇe
translated: And in the Purâṇa: The creation of the world is by the mind alone.

analyzed: ucyate satyam evam
translated: It is said: This is true.

analyzed: dravya antara parikalpanātaḥ varam evam vā āśrayaṇam iti uktam
translated: It is said that it is better to adopt this [view] than to postulate a separate substance.

analyzed: paramārthataḥ tu na bhautikam
translated: But in reality, it is not material.

analyzed: na api navamam dravyam
translated: Nor is it a ninth substance.

analyzed: kva tarhi idānīm manaḥ śabdaḥ
translated: Then where, indeed, is the word 'mind' now?

analyzed: buddhau eva
translated: In the intellect itself.

original: ata eva hi buddhimān manasvīti vyapadiśyate /
analyzed: atas eva hi buddhimān manasvī iti vyapadiśyate
translated: For this very reason, he is called 'intelligent' and 'possessing mind'.

analyzed: manasaḥ vasthā bhaidāḥ ca drāk evā a parokṣyante kṣubhitam me manaḥ
translated: And the states of the mind are directly perceived, such as 'my mind is agitated',

analyzed: prasannam me manaḥ iti
translated: 'my mind is serene'.

original: evaṃ ca manasaḥ karaṇatayā vyapadeśo buddhyahaṅkārayoriva vṛttibhedapradarśanaparaḥ pūrveṣāmiti /
analyzed: evam ca manasaḥ karaṇa tayā vyapadeśaḥ buddhi ahaṅkārayoḥ iva vṛtti bheda pradarśana paraḥ pūrveṣām iti
translated: And thus, the designation of the mind as an instrument, like the intellect and ego, is meant to show the difference in functions of the earlier ones.

analyzed: ucyate yadi buddhiḥ eva manaḥ
translated: It is said: If the intellect itself is the mind,

analyzed: yadi vā dravya antaram
translated: or if it is a different substance,

analyzed: ubhayadhā api tasya na cetana tvam iti kim anena apratijñāta svarūpa vimarśena
translated: in both cases, it is not conscious. So what is the point of discussing its unpromised nature?

analyzed: iti prāsaṅgika manaḥ tattva vimarśa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the incidental discussion of the truth of the mind.

analyzed: astu tarhi prāṇaḥ eva ātmā
translated: Let the life-breath then be the self.

analyzed: tathā sati tad anvayini śarīre sātmaka tva pratītiḥ
translated: If that is so, the cognition of the body being endowed with a self when it is connected with that,

analyzed: tad virahiṇi nirātmaka tva pratītiḥ ca upapadyeyātām
translated: and the cognition of it being without a self when it is not connected with that, would be reasonable.

analyzed: dehāt utkrāntiḥ loka antara gamanam deha antara sañcāraḥ ca upapadyantetarām
translated: The departure of the soul from the body, the going to another world, and the movement to another body would be quite reasonable.

analyzed: gatvara svābhāvyāt prāṇasya
translated: Because the life-breath has the nature of moving.

original: itarathā paramamahato mahataśca sparśavirahiṇaḥ parispandānupapatterutkrāntigatyāgatiśrutayo bhāktāḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: itarathā parama mahataḥ mahataḥ ca sparśa virahiṇaḥ parispanda anupapatteḥ utkrānti gati āgati śrutayaḥ bhāktāḥ syuḥ
translated: Otherwise, the statements about going out, going, and coming would be contradicted, since the supreme and the great are devoid of touch and cannot move.

analyzed: iti prāṇa ātmatva pūrvapakṣa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the prima facie view that the life-breath is the Self.

analyzed: idam api asat
translated: This is also wrong.

analyzed: vāyu tvāt eva bāhya vāyu vat prāṇasya caitanya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the life-breath, being just air like the external air, cannot be conscious.

original: vṛttihīne 'pyātmani suṣuptau prāṇasya vṛttimattvācca /🔽tadvṛttyā hi suptasyāpi saptadhātubhāvenāśitapītadravyapariṇāmaḥ /
analyzed: vṛtti hīne pi ātmani suṣuptau prāṇasya vṛttimat tvāt ca  tad vṛttyā hi suptasya api sapta dhātu bhāvena aśita pīta dravya pariṇāmaḥ
translated: And because the life-breath has activity even when the Self is without activity, as in deep sleep.

analyzed: śvāsa praśvāsau ca
translated: For, even in deep sleep, there is transformation of the food and drink consumed into the seven bodily constituents, and there is inhalation and exhalation.

analyzed: tanutara tejaḥ banna anuviddhaḥ kauṣṭhya mārutaḥ hi prāṇaḥ
translated: The life-breath is the internal air influenced by the subtlest elements of fire, water, and earth.

original: sa ca kaṇṭhamukhanāsābhyantare bahiśca recitaḥ tvacā spṛśyamāno ghaṭādiriva sphuṭamanātmatayā cakāsti /
analyzed: sa ca kaṇṭha mukha nāsā abhyantare bahis ca recitaḥ tvacā spṛśyamānaḥ ghaṭa ādiḥ iva sphuṭam anātma tayā cakāsti
translated: And that, when moved within the throat, mouth, and nose, and externally, is clearly perceived by the skin as non-Self, like a pot, etc.

original: atraiva sādhye sādhanāntarāṇi cāha utpattimattvā dityādikārikādvayena /
analyzed: atra eva sādhye sādhana antarāṇi ca āha utpattimat tvāt ityādi kārikā dvayena
translated: In this very matter to be established, he states other means of proof by the two verses beginning with because of origination, etc.

analyzed: pārārthyam
translated: Being for another's purpose means being for the purpose of another.

analyzed: tat ca saṅghāta tvāt
translated: And that is because of being a composite.
Being a substance is having a specific quality perceptible by an external sense organ.

analyzed: etaiḥ hetubhiḥ śarīre cetana bhinna tvam sādhyam
translated: By these reasons, the conclusion to be proved is that the body is different from the conscious self.
By the proper [reasons], which have the nature of the five parts such as the proposition, and are endowed with the five [parts] such as the reason.

analyzed: varṣmaṇaḥ śarīrasya
translated: Of the body, the physical form.

analyzed: citiḥ jñānam
translated: Consciousness is knowledge.

analyzed: samarthitam etāvatā dehasya anātma tvam pratyakṣa anumānābhyām
translated: So far, it has been established by perception and inference that the body is not the self.

original: etadvādhitatvamāha dehe ātmatvaṃ sādhayatāṃ kevalavyatikeriṇām evam iti /🔽anvayamukhena anvayavyāptyā /
analyzed: etat vādhita tvam āha dehe ātma tvam sādhayatām kevala vyatikeriṇām evam iti
translated: He says that this is contradicted by those who prove that the body is the self, thus.🔽By the positive pervasion, through positive concomitance.

analyzed: apahṛta viṣaya tayā a bādhita sādhyaka tayā
translated: By having a negated object, by having a negated probandum.

analyzed: upasthāpayitum vyavasthāpayitum
translated: To establish, to determine.

analyzed: atha indriya ātma vādam upakṣipati santu tarhi iti
translated: Now he introduces the theory that the sense organs are the self, saying Then let them be, etc.

analyzed: deha ātma tva pakṣa uktāni dūṣaṇāni
translated: The objections stated in the view that the body is the self

original: nātra pakṣe prasajyanta ityāha na ca tānī tyādivākyadvayena /
analyzed: na atra pakṣe prasajyante iti āha na ca tāni tyādi vākya dvayena
translated: do not apply to this view, he says in two sentences beginning with And those are not applicable here, etc.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvam uktvā sādhakam api āha pakṣe ti
translated: Having stated the absence of counter-evidence, he also states the proof, saying In this view, in your operation, etc.

analyzed: jñānam indriya dharmaḥ
translated: Knowledge is a property of the sense organs.

analyzed: indriya vyāpāra phala tvāt
translated: Because it is the result of the operation of the sense organs.

analyzed: yat tat tat niṣṭham
translated: The result of an operation is dependent on that.

original: yathā snānādhyayanādivyāpāraphalaṃ śaucākṣararāśigrahaṇādi snātradhyetṛsamavetamiti prayogo bodhyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā snāna adhyayana ādi vyāpāra phalam śauca akṣara rāśi grahaṇa ādi snātṛ adhyetṛ samavetam iti prayogaḥ bodhyaḥ
translated: For example, the result of the operation of bathing, studying, etc. is the collection of purity, syllables, etc., which inheres in the bather, the student. This usage should be understood.

analyzed: indriyasya vyāpāraḥ artha sannikarṣa artha indriya pravṛttiḥ
translated: The operation of a sense organ is the activity of the sense organ for the purpose of contact with an object.

analyzed: arthena indriyasya sannikarṣaḥ eva vā
translated: Or simply the contact of the sense organ with the object.

analyzed: hetau dravya bhinna bhāva tve sati iti viśeṣaṇam deyam
translated: The qualification when it is a property different from substance should be added in the reason.

analyzed: tena ghaṭa tad dhvaṃsa anukūla vyāpāravataḥ daṇḍa ādeḥ ghaṭavat tva ādi abhāve pi na kṣatiḥ
translated: Thus, there is no harm even in the absence of the nature of a pot, etc. in a stick, etc. which is favorable to the operation of a pot and its destruction.

original: indriyātmatve 'numānamuktvā'ptavākyamapi saṃvādarūpaṃ nirdiśati ata eve ti /
analyzed: indriya ātma tve numānam uktvā āpta vākyam api saṃvāda rūpam nirdiśati atas eva iti
translated: Having stated the inference of the self being the sense organs, he also points out the authoritative statement in the form of corroboration with For this very reason...

analyzed: indriyāṇām ātma tvam nirasyati tat na iti
translated: He refutes the self being the sense organs with That is not so...

analyzed: vikalpa asaha tvam nāma vikalpa dharmiṇaḥ saṃbhāvita yāvat koṭi vikalpena vikalpita yāvat koṭi anyatama koṭi saṃbandhasya api anarha svarūpa tvam
translated: Incapability of being subjected to alternatives means the nature of not being fit to be related to any of the alternatives, even when subjected to alternatives with as many possible ends as are possible for something having the property of being subject to alternatives.

analyzed: kṣoda kṣama tva abhāvaḥ iti yāvat
translated: It means the absence of being able to bear scrutiny.

analyzed: pratyakṣa bādhā abhāve pi yauktika bādhaḥ sti indriya ātma tve iti hārdam
translated: Even in the absence of direct contradiction, there is logical contradiction in the view of the self being the sense organs, so he thinks.

original: pratyekendriyacaitanyapakṣe nānāsvāmika iva grāma ekasminneva dehe nānācetanādhiṣṭānānnityakalahādi prasajyate iti dūṣaṇaṃ hṛdi nādhāya dūṣaṇāntaramāha
analyzed: pratyeka indriya caitanya pakṣe nānā svāmikaḥ iva grāmaḥ ekasmin eva dehe nānā cetanā adhiṣṭānāt nitya kalaha ādi prasajyate iti dūṣaṇam hṛdi na ādhāya dūṣaṇa antaram āha  /
translated: In the view of individual sense organs being conscious, just as in a village with many owners, there would be constant quarrels etc. in a single body due to being controlled by many conscious beings, so he thinks, without considering this fault in his mind, he states another fault.

analyzed: indriya antare ti
translated: He says in another sense organ etc.

analyzed: indriya saṅghāta ātma tva pakṣe pi idam sādhāraṇam
translated: This is common even in the view of the collection of sense organs being the self.

analyzed: tat āha atas eva iti
translated: He says for this very reason etc.

analyzed: atas eva nirukta pratisandhāna anupapatteḥ eva
translated: For this very reason, because the connection of memory is not possible.

analyzed: tām eva upapādayati nahi iti
translated: He explains that very thing with for etc.

analyzed: indriya saṅghātaḥ na anubhavitā
translated: The collection of sense organs is not an experiencer.

analyzed: na api anusmartā
translated: Nor is it a rememberer.

original: tathā hi saṅghāto yadi saṃyogo bahutvasaṅkhyā vā /
analyzed: tathā hi saṅghātaḥ yadi saṃyogaḥ bahu tva saṅkhyā vā
translated: For, if the collection is a conjunction or the number many,

analyzed: tarhi guṇa tvāt eva na jñātṛ tva saṃbhavaḥ
translated: then due to being a quality itself, the possibility of being a knower does not exist.

analyzed: yadi saṃyuktānām bahūnām eva saṅghāta tvena vivakṣā
translated: If the collection is intended as the many themselves when conjoined,

original: tadāpi na bahūnāmindriyāṇāṃ cākṣuṣāśrayatā spārśanāśrayatā vā /
analyzed: tadā api na bahūnām indriyāṇām cākṣuṣa āśraya tā spārśana āśraya tā vā
translated: then also many sense organs cannot be the substratum of the visual or the substratum of the tactile.

analyzed: tathā ca draṣṭuḥ spraṣṭuḥ ca anya anyatvāt ukta pratisandhāna anupapattiḥ eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And in that case, because the seer and the toucher are different, the impossibility of the connection of memory stated is the idea.

analyzed: indriya saṅghātasya ātma tve doṣa antaram āha eka indriye ti
translated: In the case of the aggregate of sense organs being the self, he states another fault: In the case of a single sense organ, etc.

original: saṅghātasya tāvataiva vinaṣṭatvānnirātmakatvena dehasya maraṇaprasaktiriti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: saṅghātasya tāvatā eva vinaṣṭa tvāt nirātmaka tvena dehasya maraṇa prasaktiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that since the aggregate is destroyed by that alone, the body is devoid of self and is subject to death.

analyzed: pratyeka saṅghāta pakṣa dvaya sādhāraṇam doṣa antaram āha indriye ti
translated: He states another fault common to both the views of the aggregate of each sense organ: In the case of the sense organ, etc.

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ cakṣuṣaḥ vināśe mayā idam dṛṣṭam iti smṛteḥ anupapattiḥ
translated: And if the seeing eye is destroyed, the memory I saw this is not possible.

analyzed: vidyamānasya a draṣṭṛ tvāt
translated: Because what exists cannot be a non-seer.

analyzed: anya dṛṣṭasya anyena smṛti ayogāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that what is seen by one cannot be remembered by another.

analyzed: indriya caitanye
translated: In the case of the sense organs being conscious,

analyzed: bādhakāni uktāni
translated: the refutations are stated.

original: atha tatsādhakamanumānaṃ dūṣayati na ca tavyadyāpāre ti /
analyzed: atha tad sādhakam anumānam dūṣayati na ca tad vyadyāpāre ti
translated: Now he refutes the inference that proves that: And in the operation of that which is to be done, etc.

analyzed: pāpa ādeḥ iti ādi padena dvaidhībhāvaḥ api grāhyaḥ
translated: By the word etc. in sin, etc. the state of being cut in two should also be included.

analyzed: tayoḥ chettṛ chaidya gata tayā śastre samaveta tva avdyabhicāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that since those two belong to the cutter and the sword, there is a fallacy of non-applicability to the weapon.

analyzed: atra vipakṣe bādhaka virahāt aprayojaka tvam api bodhyam
translated: Here, the lack of a refutation in the case of the opposite should also be understood as not being a reason.

original: atha satyatapaso vacanaṃ karaṇe kartṛtvopacāreṇa pravṛttamanyaparaṃ nendriyacaitanye pramāṇamityāha anyathā ce ti /
analyzed: atha satyatapasaḥ vacanam karaṇe kartṛ tva upacāreṇa pravṛttam anya param na indriya caitanye pramāṇam iti āha anyathā ca iti
translated: Now, the statement of Satyatapa, which is engaged in the figurative use of the agent in the sense of the instrument, is not a valid means of knowledge regarding the sentience of the senses, with a different purport, he says otherwise.

original: svāśramapraviṣṭavanamṛgānveṣaṇapravṛttavyādhakṛtapraśrottararūpaṃ satyatapaso vacanam draṣṭuścakṣuṣo nāsti jihvā ityādi /
analyzed: sva āśrama praviṣṭa vana mṛga anveṣaṇa pravṛtta vyādha kṛta praśra uttara rūpam satya tapasaḥ vacanam draṣṭuḥ cakṣuṣaḥ na asti jihvā ityādi
translated: The statement of Satyatapa, in the form of an answer to a question asked by a hunter engaged in searching for forest animals who have entered his own hermitage, that the eye of the seer has no tongue, and so on.

original: etasminnarthe śloko 'yamanugṛhīto 'smadgurucaraṇaiḥ yā paśyati na sā brūte sā na paśyati /
analyzed: etasmin arthe ślokaḥ yam anugṛhītaḥ smat guru caraṇaiḥ yā paśyati na sā brūte sā na paśyati
translated: In this matter, this verse has been favored by the feet of our teacher: That which sees does not speak, it does not see.

original: dṛṣṭirvakti kathaṃ vyādha vāṇī vā vīkṣate katham //
analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ vakti katham vyādha vāṇī vā vīkṣate katham
translated: How can the sight speak, O hunter? Or how can speech see?

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: anena praṣṭā vyādhaḥ iti gamyate
translated: By this, it is understood that the questioner is a hunter.

original: akathane 'śanāyāpīḍitasya vyādhasya maraṇaprasaṅgaṃ /🔽kathane ca śaraṇāgataparityāganibandhanaṃ mahatpāpaṃ paryālocya evaṃ
analyzed: a kathane śanāyā pīḍitasya vyādhasya maraṇa prasaṅgam  kathane ca śaraṇa āgata parityāga nibandhanam mahat pāpam paryālocya evam
translated: In the case of not speaking, there is the possibility of the hunter, afflicted by hunger, dying.🔽And in the case of speaking, having considered the great sin arising from abandoning one who has sought refuge,

analyzed: vaktā uktiḥ kṛtā mahā ṛṣiṇā iti bodhyam
translated: the statement of the great sage was made thus. This should be understood.

original: atha mana ātmatvapakṣamupakṣipati astu tarhī ti /
analyzed: atha manaḥ ātma tva pakṣam upakṣipati astu tarhi iti
translated: Now, he introduces the view that the mind is the self, saying Let it be so, then.

analyzed: tadvī ti
translated: That refers to the mind.

original: mano hi pradhānāṃ sarvendriyaprerakaṃ ca gamyate pramāṇato /
analyzed: manaḥ hi sarva indriya prerakam ca gamyate
translated: For the mind is understood to be the principal instigator of all the senses by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: vyavahliyate ca tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: And it is also connected in the same way, that is the meaning.

original: indriyātmatvapakṣoktānāṃ smṛtipratisandhānānupapattinānātmaprasaṅgādidoṣāṇāṃ nātra pakṣe prasaṅga ityāha upapadyate ce tyādivākyadvayena /
analyzed: indriya ātma tva pakṣa uktānām smṛti pratisandhāna anupapatti nānā ātma prasaṅga ādi doṣāṇām na atra pakṣe prasaṅgaḥ iti āha upapadyate ca ityādi vākya dvayena
translated: He says that the faults such as the impossibility of memory and association, the consequence of plurality of selves, etc., mentioned in the view of the self being the sense organs, do not apply in this view, with the two statements beginning with and it is also possible.

original: manasa ātmatvaṃ dūṣayati tadapi ne ti /
analyzed: manasaḥ ātma tvam dūṣayati tat api na iti
translated: He refutes the view of the mind being the self, with That also is not so.

original: karaṇatvā diti sarvatra jñāne karaṇatvānmanaso na tatra kartṛtvamāśrayatvaṃ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: karaṇa tvāt iti sarvatra jñāne karaṇa tvāt manasaḥ na tatra kartṛ tvam āśraya tvam saṃbhavati
translated: Because of being an instrument, everywhere in cognition, the mind is an instrument, so its agency, its being a basis, is not possible there.

analyzed: manaḥ hi na pratyakṣa viṣayaḥ
translated: The mind is not the object of perception.

analyzed: kintu yugapad jñāna anutpatti liṅgena sakala jñāne karaṇa viśeṣa tayā anumīyate
translated: But it is inferred as a particular instrument in all cognitions by the mark of the non-simultaneity of cognitions.

original: tasya ca na jñātṛtvaṃ cakṣurāderiva saṃbhavatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca na jñātṛ tvam cakṣuḥ ādeḥ iva saṃbhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And it is not possible for it to be a knower, like the eye etc., this is the idea.

analyzed: etat eva upapādayati bāhya indriyeṣu iti
translated: He explains this with Among the external sense organs.

analyzed: yad sāhāyaka virahāt yad sahakāra virahāt
translated: Because of the absence of the help of that, because of the absence of the cooperation of that.

analyzed: sahāyasya karmasāhāyakam  yad sannikarṣa virahāt iti yāvat
translated: The help of an action is🔽the absence of the contact with that, that is the meaning.

analyzed: tad tad artha grāhaka indriyasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is of the sense organ that apprehends that and that object.
