analyzed: evam bāhya artheṣu yugapad jñānānām anutpatti liṅgena sarva indriya sahakāri tvena aṇu bhūtasya
translated: Thus, in the case of external objects, due to the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions, the atom-sized [mind] acts as a cooperative cause for all the sense faculties.

analyzed: manasaḥ karaṇa viśeṣasya anumānam uktvā āntara sukha ādi sākṣātkāreṣu karaṇatayā api manasaḥ
translated: Thus, having stated the inference of the mind, which is atomic and is the special instrument by the reason of the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions with regard to external objects, through its being the cooperative cause of all sense organs, he states the inference of the mind as the instrument in the direct perception of internal pleasure etc.

original: 'numānamāha tathā sukhādī ti /🔽nanu karaṇatayānumitasyaiva manaso jñānādau kartṛtvamapyastu lāghavā
analyzed: numānam āha tathā sukha ādiḥ iti  nanu karaṇatayā anumitasya eva manasaḥ jñāna ādau kartṛ tvam api astu lāghavā
translated: Thus, pleasure etc.

analyzed: d iti ced tatra āha tat evam iti
translated: If it is argued that the mind, which is inferred as the instrument, should also be the agent in cognition etc. for the sake of simplicity, he says thus.

original: karaṇasya kartṛtvaṃ na saṃbhavati /🔽karaṇatvakartṛtvayorvirodhāt svātantryapāratantryalakṣaṇayoriti bhāvaḥ /🔽kartṛtvakaraṇatvasvarūpabhedaṃ vivṛṇoti svātantrye tyādinā /
analyzed: karaṇasya kartṛ tvam na saṃbhavati  karaṇa tva kartṛ tvayoḥ virodhāt svātantrya pāratantrya lakṣaṇayoḥ iti bhāvaḥ  kartṛ tva karaṇa tva svarūpa bhedam vivṛṇoti svātantrye tyādinā
translated: The instrument cannot be the agent.🔽The meaning is that the instrument and the agent are contradictory, characterized by independence and dependence.🔽He explains the difference in the nature of agency and instrumentality with the words independence etc.

analyzed: kartṛ tvam nāma sva icchā adhīna sva pravṛttika tva rūpa svātantrya niyatam sva icchayā eva sādhya siddhi aupayika sāmagrī saṃpādana sāmarthyam
translated: Agency is the power to accomplish the means to the attainment of the desired object by one's own will alone, which is determined by independence in the form of one's own activity being dependent on one's own will.

analyzed: karaṇa tvam ca para icchā prayātna adhīna sva vyāpṛtīkatva lakṣaṇa pāratantrya niyatam parasya ripsita kriyā niṣpattau prakṛṣṭa upakāraka tva lakṣaṇam
translated: And instrumentality is determined by dependence characterized by the activity of one's own being being dependent on the effort of another's will, and by the character of being a most helpful means in the accomplishment of the action desired by the other.

analyzed: na ca etayoḥ ekatra samāveśaḥ saṃbhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the idea is that these two cannot coexist in one place.

original: yadyapi cetanasyaikatra kartṛtvaṃ karaṇatvaṃ ca saṃbhavennāmā'kārabhedataḥ /🔽athāpi manasaścaitanye dṛḍhatarapramāṇābhāvāt lokasiddhavyāptyā ca cakṣurādivatparasya cetanasya sukhādyanubhavakaraṇatayaiva siddherna manaso
analyzed: yadi api cetanasya ekatra kartṛ tvam karaṇa tvam ca saṃbhavet nāma ākāra bhedataḥ  atha api manasaḥ caitanye dṛḍhatara pramāṇa abhāvāt loka siddha vyāptyā ca cakṣuḥ ādi vat parasya cetanasya sukha ādi anubhava karaṇatayā eva siddheḥ na manasaḥ
translated: And although the instrumentality and agency of a conscious being may be possible in one place, by way of difference of mode,

analyzed: jñātṛ tvam
translated: nevertheless, because of the absence of a very firm means of knowledge regarding the consciousness of the mind, and because of the well-known pervasion, like the eye etc., it is established that the other conscious being is only the means of experiencing pleasure etc., not the mind.

analyzed: vastutas tu atyanta atīndriyeṣu artheṣu śāstram eva pramāṇam
translated: But in reality, in matters that are extremely supersensible, the scriptures alone are the means of knowledge.

original: tataśca mano vijñānamayasya jīvasyopakaraṇatayaiva siddhyatīti hārdam /🔽nanu rūpasukhādibāhyāntarapadārthānubhaveṣu mana eva kartṛ /
analyzed: tatas ca manaḥ vijñāna mayasya jīvasya upakaraṇa tayā eva siddhyati iti hārdam  nanu rūpa sukha ādi bāhya antara padārtha anubhaveṣu manaḥ eva kartṛ
translated: And therefore, the mind is established only as an instrument of the individual soul consisting of consciousness. This is the heart of the matter.🔽But in the experiences of external and internal things like form, pleasure etc., the mind itself is the agent.

original: āntarasukhādyanubhave karaṇaṃ tvāntaramanyatkalpyata iti śaṅkate atha tadapi ti /
analyzed: āntara sukha ādi anubhave karaṇam tu āntaram anyat kalpyate iti śaṅkate atha tat api ti
translated: In the experience of internal pleasure etc., another internal means is imagined. This is suspected in If that also...

original: pariharati tathā satī tī /🔽evaṃ sati asmadiṣṭasya jñātaryantaḥ karaṇabhedasya na kāpyanupapattiḥ /
analyzed: pariharati tathā satī  evam sati asmad iṣṭasya jñātari antar karaṇa bhedasya na kā api anupapattiḥ
translated: He answers: Thus, in that case.🔽In that case, there is no inconsistency at all in the difference of internal organs in the knower, which is what we assert.

original: saṃjñā tu aicchikīti nārthe vivāda ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: saṃjñā tu aicchikī iti na arthe vivādaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But the name is optional, so there is no dispute about the meaning, that is the point.

analyzed: jñātuḥ ātmanaḥ manaḥ saṃjñāyām vyavahāra virodham āha kintu iti
translated: He states the contradiction in usage if the self, the knower, is called mind: But, however.

original: mana iti nātmano vyavahāro laukikānāṃ vaidikānāṃ ca /
analyzed: manaḥ iti na ātmanaḥ vyavahāraḥ laukikānām vaidikānām ca
translated: The usage of the self as mind is not for the worldly or the Vedic people.

analyzed: atas manaḥ saṃjñā ātmani vyavahāra visaṃvādāt apārthā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the designation of the self as mind is meaningless due to contradiction with usage, that is the idea.

original: athātra paramācāryo 'yaṃ vimarśakabhūmikāmāsthitaḥ prasaṅgāt manasastattvavicāraṃ prakramate āhe ti /
analyzed: atha atra parama ācāryaḥ yam vimarśaka bhūmikām āsthitaḥ prasaṅgāt manasaḥ tattva vicāram prakramate āhe ti
translated: Now, this supreme teacher, occupying the stage of inquiry, begins the investigation of the truth of the mind from the beginning, he says: He says.

analyzed: kaścid vimarśakaḥ ityādiḥ
translated: Some inquirer, etc.

analyzed: vimarśaḥ ca ayam tārkika abhimatānām manaḥ sādhaka yuktīnām kṣoda kṣamatva abhāva pradarśana arthaḥ
translated: And this inquiry is for the purpose of showing the inability of the arguments accepted by logicians to establish the mind.

analyzed: kim idam iti
translated: What is this?

analyzed: kim iti svarūpa praśnaḥ
translated: What is a question about the nature.

analyzed: kim punar iti pramāṇa praśnaḥ
translated: What again is a question about the means of knowledge.

analyzed: manasi pramāṇam ākṣipati uktam nāma ityādinā
translated: He raises the question of the means of knowledge regarding the mind with What is said, etc.

analyzed: yugapad jñāna anutpatti liṅgena dravya antaram āntaram karaṇam na siddhi ati
translated: By the mark of the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions, an internal organ as a different substance is not established as a means.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa ādi sahakāra viraheṇa eva yugapad jñāna anutpatti upapatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions is explained just by the absence of unseen and other cooperating factors.

analyzed: yugapad smaraṇānām anutpattaye dṛṣṭa sahakāra virahaḥ vaśyam eva śaraṇīkaraṇīyaḥ svīkṛte iti āha
translated: In order to prevent the non-simultaneous arising of recollections, the absence of unseen cooperating factors must necessarily be resorted to, even if an internal organ is accepted. He says

analyzed: kalpayitvā api iti
translated: Even if it is imagined.

analyzed: nānā artha anubhava bhāvitāḥ nānā artha anubhava janitāḥ
translated: They are produced by the experience of many objects. They are produced by the experience of many objects.

analyzed: saṃskāre ti  saṃskārasya unmeṣa hetuḥ udbodhakaḥ
translated: In the impressions.🔽The cause of the manifestation of the impression is the awakener.

analyzed: saṃskāra udbodhaka samavadhāna kramāt smṛtīnām ayaugapadyam
translated: The non-simultaneity of recollections is due to the sequence of the conjunction of the awakener of the impression.

analyzed: udbuddha saṃskārasya eva smṛti hetu tvāt
translated: Because only the awakened impression is the cause of recollection.

analyzed: udbodhasya krama bhāvi tvāt ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And because the awakening occurs in sequence. This is the idea.

analyzed: evam api iti
translated: Even so.

analyzed: cintanam
translated: Volition is the mental concentration and contemplation.

original: yeṣāmarthasaṃskārāṇāṃ sādhāraṇamudbodhakaṃ praṇidhānaṃ kṛtamanubhūtayāvadarthasmṛtīcchayaikadaiva tadāpi na yāvadarthasmṛtayo yugapat jāyante
analyzed: yeṣām artha saṃskārāṇām sādhāraṇam udbodhakam praṇidhānam kṛtam anubhūta yāvat artha smṛti icchayā ekadā eva tadā api na yāvat artha smṛtayaḥ yugapad jāyante
translated: Even when volition, which is the common awakener of those impressions of objects, is performed with the desire to remember as many objects as experienced at once, the recollections of as many objects as experienced do not arise simultaneously.

analyzed: tat sati api nānā artha smṛtiṣu dṛṣṭa kāraṇe dṛṣṭa sahakāra virahāt eva na smṛti yaugapadyam
translated: Even though that [adṛṣṭa] is the cause of the recollection of many objects, due to the absence of unseen auxiliary [causes], there is no simultaneous recollection.

analyzed: kintu ekasya eva ekadā bhavati smṛtiḥ adṛṣṭa sahakārāt iti eṣitavyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But it should be concluded that only one recollection occurs at one time due to unseen auxiliary [causes].

analyzed: śubha aśubha rūpa tayā asukha duḥkha janaka tayā
translated: [The objects] are of the nature of good and bad, because they produce pleasure and pain.

original: nanvevamapi sukhahetvarthānāṃ śubhādṛṣṭabalādyugapatsmaraṇāni syuriti cettatrāha krame ti /
analyzed: nanu evam api sukha hetu arthānām śubha adṛṣṭa balāt yugapad smaraṇāni syuḥ iti ced tatra āha krame ti
translated: If it is argued that even so, the recollections of the causes of pleasure, etc. would occur simultaneously due to the power of good unseen [causes], then he says [in the next verse] in succession [etc.].

analyzed: kramika jñāna bhāktva lakṣaṇa ātma svabhāva balāt adṛṣṭa sahakāra virahāt ca smṛti yaugapadyasya iva
translated: Due to the power of the nature of the self characterized by the experience of successive cognitions and the absence of unseen auxiliary [causes], just as the simultaneity of recollections,

analyzed: bāhya artha jñāna yaugapadyasya api pariharaṇa saṃbhavāt na aṇu bhūtam manaḥ bāhya indriya sahakāri
translated: the simultaneity of external object cognitions is also possible to be avoided. Therefore, an internal sense organ that is an atom and a cooperative cause of the external sense organ

analyzed: karaṇa antaram āntaram kalpanīyam iti samudita āśayaḥ
translated: does not need to be imagined as another instrument. This is the combined intention [of the author].

analyzed: manasi pramāṇa antaram upakṣipati syāt matam iti
translated: He introduces another means of knowledge regarding the mind [in the next verse] with It may be argued [etc.].

analyzed: atra prayogaḥ sukha ādi sa asamavāyi hetukam bhāva kārya tvāt kārya rūpa ādi vat iti
translated: Here is the argument: Pleasure, etc. have a non-inherent cause, because they are effects produced by causes, like the effect, form, etc.

analyzed: asamavāyi hetuḥ ca sukha ādau ātma manaḥ saṃyogaḥ eva
translated: And the non-inherent cause of pleasure, etc. is only the contact of the self and the mind.

analyzed: anyasya asaṃbhavāt iti hṛdayam
translated: The heart is that there is no other [cause].

original: ātmetyādi bāhyetyādi ca ṣaṣṭhyantaṃ padadvayaṃ bahuvrīhivṛttaṃ sukhāderviśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: ātma ityādi bāhya ityādi ca ṣaṣṭhī antam pada dvayam bahuvrīhi vṛttam sukha ādeḥ viśeṣaṇam
translated: The two words beginning with ātman and beginning with external ending in the sixth case are bahuvrīhi compounds, and are qualifications of pleasure, etc.

analyzed: pada dvayena ca sukha ādau ātmanaḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tvam adṛṣṭa ādeḥ nimitta hetu tvam ca uktam
translated: And by the two words, it is said that pleasure, etc. are the inherent causes of the self, and that unseen [forces], etc. are the instrumental causes.

analyzed: etat nirasyati tat asa t ityādinā
translated: This [view] is refuted by [the words] that is not so and so on.

analyzed: sukhe ti
translated: In pleasure, etc.

original: anukūlaviṣayasya pratikūlaviṣayasya ca jñānasyaivātmani niyatapūrvavṛtteḥ sukhe duḥkhe ca kāraṇasya tatrāsamavāyihetutvaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: anukūla viṣayasya pratikūla viṣayasya ca jñānasya eva ātmani niyata pūrva vṛtteḥ sukhe duḥkhe ca kāraṇasya tatra asamavāyi hetu tvam yuktam
translated: The knowledge of a favorable object and the knowledge of an unfavorable object, which always occur before [pleasure and pain], are the inherent causes of pleasure and pain.

analyzed: na tu ātma manaḥ saṃseyogasya aprasiddhasya
translated: But not of the contact of the self with the mind, which is not well-known.

original: tattadviṣayasannikṛṣṭendriyātmasaṃyoga eva ca tattajjñāne 'samavāyikāraṇam /🔽kṛtisādhyatājñānameva prayatne tathā cikīrṣādvārā /
analyzed: tad tad viṣaya sannikṛṣṭa indriya ātma saṃyogaḥ eva ca tad tad jñāne samavāyi kāraṇam  kṛti sādhya tā jñānam eva prayatne tathā cikīrṣā dvārā
translated: And the contact of the self with the sense organs that are in proximity to each of the objects is the inherent cause of each of the cognitions.🔽The knowledge that an action is to be accomplished is the inherent cause of effort, and so on, through the desire to act.

original: kāryatājñāne ca smṛtirūpe udbuddhasaṃskāraḥ /🔽anubhavarūpe ca liṅgajñānādi tathā /
analyzed: kārya tā jñāne ca smṛti rūpe udbuddha saṃskāraḥ  anubhava rūpe ca liṅga jñāna ādi tathā
translated: And in the knowledge of the object to be accomplished, which is in the form of memory, the awakened impression [is the inherent cause].🔽And in the form of experience, the knowledge of the mark, etc. are [inherent causes] in the same way.

analyzed: saṃskāre ca anubhavaḥ tathā
translated: And in the impression, experience [is the inherent cause] in the same way.

analyzed: prayatnaḥ eva adṛṣṭasya api asamavāyi hetuḥ
translated: And effort is the inherent cause of the unseen [forces] as well.

analyzed: idam upalakṣaṇam
translated: This is an illustration.

analyzed: icchām prati iṣṭa jātīya tvasya iṣṭa sādhana tvasya vā  jñānam tathā
translated: In regard to desire, the knowledge of the object being of a desirable kind or being a means to the desirable.

original: dveṣaṃ prati cāniṣṭatvasya tatsādhanatvasya vā jñānaṃ tathā /
analyzed: dveṣam prati ca aniṣṭa tvasya tad sādhana tvasya vā jñānam tathā
translated: Similarly, in regard to aversion, the knowledge of the object being undesirable or being a means to the undesirable.

original: ātmaviśeṣaguṇānāṃ kutrāpyasamavāyihetutvaṃ nāstīti pravādastu na śraddheya iti manuditāśayaḥ /
analyzed: ātma viśeṣa guṇānām kutra api asamavāyi hetu tvam na asti iti pravādaḥ tu na śraddheyaḥ iti manudita āśayaḥ
translated: The statement that the specific qualities of the self are not the inherent causes of anything is not to be believed, as stated by Manu.

analyzed: icchā ādīnām iti ādi padena dveṣa prayatna adṛṣṭa saṃskārāṇām grahaṇam
translated: The word 'etc.' in 'desire etc.' includes aversion, effort, unseen force, and impressions.

analyzed: atra viṣaya indriya saṃyoga hetu bhūtasya indriya vyāpārasya prayatna vat ātma saṃyoga asamavāyi hetuka tva kathanam prasaṅgāt
translated: Here, the statement that the activity of the sense organs, which is the cause of the conjunction of the object and sense organs, is caused by the conjunction of the self with effort, is made incidentally.

original: kutrāpi jñānādau ātmaviseṣaguṇe mano 'pekṣā nāstīti hārdam /
analyzed: kutra api jñāna ādau ātma viseṣa guṇe manaḥ upekṣā na asti iti hārdam
translated: The idea is that in any cognition etc., the specific qualities of the self do not require the mind.

original: sādhanāntaraṃ manasi śaṅkate yattu nitye ti /
analyzed: sādhana antaram manasi śaṅkate yat tu nitye ti
translated: He suspects another means in the mind, saying 'but in the eternal'.

original: atra prayogaḥ sukhādirdravyasaṃyogāsamavāyihetukaḥ kāryatve sati nityadravyaviśeṣaguṇatvāt pākajaparamāṇurūpavaditi /
analyzed: atra prayogaḥ sukha ādiḥ dravya saṃyoga asamavāyi hetukaḥ kārya tve sati nitya dravya viśeṣa guṇa tvāt pāka ja paramāṇu rūpa vat iti
translated: Here the argument is: Pleasure etc. are caused by the conjunction of a substance that is not an inherent cause, because they are the specific qualities of eternal substances when they are effects, like the color of cooked atoms.

original: dravyāntarasaṃyogasya sukhādau asamavāyihetutvāsaṃbhavānmanaḥsaṃyogasyaiva tathātvena pariśeṣānmanasaḥ siddhiriti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: dravya antara saṃyogasya sukha ādau asamavāyi hetu tva asaṃbhavāt manaḥ saṃyogasya eva tathātvena pariśeṣāt manasaḥ siddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that since the connection with another substance cannot be the non-inherent cause in pleasure etc., and since the connection with the mind alone is thus, the mind is established by elimination.

analyzed: etat dūṣayati tat api iti
translated: He refutes this with That also...

analyzed: sthavīyaḥ sthūlataram
translated: sthavīyaḥ means larger.

analyzed: a vimṛśya bhāṣitam iti yāvat
translated: It means spoken without reflection.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ anvayavyatirekasahacāradarśanādeva hi sarvatra kāraṇatvādhyavasāyaḥ /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ anvaya vyatireka sahacāra darśanāt eva hi sarvatra kāraṇa tva adhyavasāyaḥ
translated: The idea is this: The ascertainment of causality is only from the observation of positive and negative concomitance everywhere.

original: pārthivāṇurūpādau dahanasaṃyogasya hetutvamapi tato dehāvayavādau rūpādiparāvṛtterddaṣṭatvāddṛṣṭānusārādeva kalpyate /
analyzed: pārthiva aṇu rūpa ādau dahana saṃyogasya hetu tvam api tatas deha avayava ādau rūpa ādi parāvṛtteḥ ddaṣṭa tvāt dṛṣṭa anusārāt eva kalpyate
translated: Even the connection with fire as the cause in the form of the earth atom is imagined only by following what is seen, because the transformation of form etc. is seen in the body parts and so on.

analyzed: iha ca anukūla jñāna ādeḥ eva sukha ādau hetu tvam dṛṣṭam
translated: And here, the cause of pleasure etc. is seen to be only favorable knowledge etc.

original: samavāyikāraṇa ātmani pratyāsannatvāttasyaivāsamavāyihetutvaṃ ca yuktaṃ tatreti nādṛṣṭadravyāntarasaṃyogasya tathātvena kalpanāvasara iti /
analyzed: samavāyi kāraṇe ātmani pratyāsanna tvāt tasya eva asamavāyi hetu tvam ca yuktam tatra iti na adṛṣṭa dravya antara saṃyogasya tathātvena kalpanā avasaraḥ iti
translated: And it is proper that it alone be the non-inherent cause in the self, which is the inherent cause, because of its proximity. Therefore there is no occasion to imagine the connection with an unseen substance as such.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa kāraṇe ti
translated: In the seen cause...

analyzed: dṛṣṭa hetoḥ abhāve pi kārya utpatteḥ darśane hi kāraṇa antara kalpanā avasaraḥ
translated: When the effect is seen to arise even in the absence of the seen cause, there is an occasion to imagine another cause.

analyzed: na ca dṛṣṭa hetoḥ vyabhicāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no deviation from the seen cause.

analyzed: atas iti
translated: Therefore.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa hetuṣu eva tad tad lakṣaṇa yogena samavāyi hetu tva ādi vyavasthāpyam
translated: In the very seen causes, the nature of being an inherent cause etc. should be established by the connection with that and that characteristic.

analyzed: jñāna ādi dṛṣṭa hetu bhinnasya anapekṣitasya aprasiddhasya dravya antara saṃyogasya hetu tva kalpanāyām tu kḷpta kḷpta parikalpanā ca
translated: But in the postulation of the cause of the conjunction of another substance, which is different from the seen causes like knowledge etc., which is not required, and which is not well-known, there is the abandonment of what is established and the postulation of what is not established.

analyzed: jñāna ādeḥ asamavāyi hetu tve bādhakasya anupalabdheḥ tad bhinna tvasya asamavāyi hetu lakṣaṇe niveśaḥ narthakaḥ ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Since there is no apprehension of an objection to the non-inherent cause like knowledge etc., the inclusion of the property of being different from that in the definition of the non-inherent cause is purposeless. This is the idea.

analyzed: ihe ti
translated: Here.

original: sukhādau tu tadviparyayaḥ kāraṇāntaropalambharūpaṃ dṛṣṭāntato vaiṣamyaṃ prādarśīti yāvat /
analyzed: sukha ādau tu tad viparyayaḥ kāraṇa antara upalambha rūpam dṛṣṭāntataḥ vaiṣamyam prādarśi iti yāvat
translated: But in pleasure etc., the opposite of that is shown by the example in the form of the apprehension of another cause, the inequality. This is as far as it goes.

analyzed: etāvatā pūrvokta anumāne prayojaka tvāt dyāpya tva asiddhiḥ ūktā
translated: By this much, in the previously stated inference, the non-establishment of the pervaded property and the non-conclusiveness are stated.

analyzed: vyāpti svīkāre ca artha antaram iti āha evam api iti
translated: And when the pervasion is accepted, it is a different matter. He says thus.

analyzed: sa tarhi ti
translated: Even so.

analyzed: tarhi saḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The word he is to be connected with then.

original: dṛṣṭānte saḥ dravyāntarasaṃyogaḥ bhautikaḥ bhūtārabdhaḥ bhautikapratiyogika
analyzed: dṛṣṭānte saḥ dravya antara saṃyogaḥ bhautikaḥ bhūta ārabdhaḥ bhautika pratiyogika
translated: In the example, that conjunction of another substance is material, composed of elements, and has a material counter-part.

analyzed: eva dṛṣṭaḥ iti prakṛte bhautika deha ādi pratiyogika ātma anuyogika saṃyogaḥ eva anumāna paryavasānāt na kāṇāda abhimata navama dravya rūpa ābhautika manaḥ siddhi pratyāśā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even in the present case, due to the conclusion of inference being only with respect to the conjunction between the self and the body etc. which are made of elements, there is no hope of establishing the non-material mind which is a ninth substance accepted by the Kaṇāda school.

analyzed: sparśavat dravya samavetaḥ iti nidarśana abhiprāyeṇa
translated: The phrase inhering in a tangible substance is meant to illustrate.

analyzed: sparśavat nitya dravya viśeṣa guṇam prati eva kārya bhūtam dravya antara saṃyogasya hetu tvam dṛṣṭa anusārāt kalpyam
translated: The causality of conjunction with another substance is to be assumed only with respect to the qualities of eternal tangible substances, which are the effects, following the observed regularity.

analyzed: na tu asparśa nitya dravya viśeṣa guṇam prati api iti vyajyate nena
translated: This indicates that it is not with respect to the qualities of eternal intangible substances either.

original: evaṃ sukhādāvasamavāyihetutvena dravyāntasaṃyogasya sādhanaṃ na saṃbhavatītyuktam /
analyzed: evam sukha ādau asamavāyi hetu tvena dravya anta saṃyogasya sādhanam na saṃbhavati iti uktam
translated: Thus it is said that the proof of conjunction with another substance as the non-inherent cause in pleasure etc. is not possible.

original: atha tatsādhanābhyupagame 'pi vivakṣitamabhautikaṃ manastattvāntaraṃ na setsyatīti prapañcayati /
analyzed: atha tad sādhana abhyupagame vivakṣitam abhautikam manaḥ tattva antaram na setsyati iti prapañcayati
translated: Now, even if the proof of that is accepted, the desired non-material mind as a separate reality will not be established. This is elaborated.

analyzed: tatra śaṅkā atha ucyete ti
translated: There, the doubt is stated as If it is said...

analyzed: pratyāsiddham pratiṣiddham
translated: Repudiated means refuted.

analyzed: pāthasīyaṃjalīyam
translated: Belonging to the water-pot.

analyzed: śakya adhyavasānam śakya niścayam
translated: Capable of being ascertained means capable of being determined.

original: mano na pārthivaṃ taijasādi vā rasāvagamanimittendriyatvādrasanāvat /
analyzed: manaḥ na pārthivam taijasa ādi vā rasa avagama nimitta indriya tvāt rasanā vat
translated: The mind is not of the earth, fire, etc., because it is a sense organ for the purpose of perceiving taste, like the tongue.

analyzed: manaḥ na gandha grāhaka indriya tvāt ghrāṇa vat iti bhautika tva niṣedhaḥ
translated: The mind is not of water, because it is a sense organ for perceiving smell, like the nose. Thus, it is denied that it is a material substance.

analyzed: yugapad jñāna anutpatti liṅgena aṇu tvena siddheḥ na vibhu dravya antarbhāvaḥ
translated: Since it is established as atomic due to the sign of the non-simultaneous arising of cognitions, it is not included within the all-pervading substances.

analyzed: atas navama dravya tva siddhiḥ manasaḥ iti abhimānaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is believed that the mind is established as the ninth substance.

analyzed: pariharati tat anupapannam ityādinā
translated: He refutes this with That is not correct and so on.

analyzed: dharmī ti
translated: The property means

analyzed: manasi pakṣe bhimataḥ yaḥ viśeṣaḥ bhautika tva rūpaḥ
translated: in the mind as the subject, the intended particularity is in the form of being non-material.

analyzed: tad viparīta sādhaka tvāt ukta hetunām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because it proves the opposite of that, by the stated reason.

original: rasagrāhakendriyatvaṃ jalīyatvaṃ gandhagrāhakendriyatvādi pārthivatvādi ca manasaḥ sādhayediti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: rasa grāhaka indriya tvam jalīya tvam gandha grāhaka indriya tva ādi pārthiva tva ādi ca manasaḥ sādhayet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it would prove that the mind is a sense organ for perceiving taste, which is of water, and for perceiving smell, which is of earth, and so on.

analyzed: atra śaṅkate atha śabde ti
translated: Here he raises the doubt with If it is said that sound and so on.

analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu madhye gandha mātra grāhaka tvam pārthiva tva sādhakam
translated: Among form and so on, the property of being of earth is proved by the property of being a perceiver of smell alone.

analyzed: evam rasa mātra grāhaka tva ādi ca jalīya tva ādeḥ
translated: Similarly, the property of being of water and so on is proved by the property of being a perceiver of taste alone and so on.

analyzed: tathā ca manasaḥ pārthiva tva ādi sādhaka hetoḥ asiddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, the reason that proves the mind to be of earth and so on is not established. This is the meaning.

original: atrottaraṃ hanta tarhī ti /🔽yadbhūtaguṇamātragrāhakaṃ yadindriyaṃ tadeva bhūtāntaravyatiriktatvena saṃpratipannamiti
analyzed: atra uttaram hanta tarhi iti  yat bhūta guṇa mātra grāhakam yat indriyam tat eva bhūta antara vyatirikta tvena saṃpratipannam iti
translated: The answer to this is as follows: “If that were so, then, etc. etc.”🔽If the sense-organ apprehends only the qualities of the elements, then, it is admitted that it is different from the other elements.

analyzed: bhūta antara guṇa grāhaka tā mātreṇa na tad tad bhūta guṇa grāhakasya manasaḥ tad tad bhūta vyatireka siddhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: So that, the fact of the Mind apprehending the qualities of the various elements cannot prove the difference of the Mind from those elements.
The fact of the Mind not apprehending odour, etc. is the only reason that can prove that it is not made up of the Earth, etc.

analyzed: tat ca manasaḥ bhautika anumāne pakṣe manasi asiddham iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And this reason is not available in the case of the Mind, which is the subject in the argument putting forward the non-elemental character of the Mind.

analyzed: apārthiva tva ādi anumāne tad tad bhūta guṇa agrāhaka tvam upādhiḥ iti ca uktam bhavati
translated: What is meant is that in the argument putting forward the non-elemental character of the Mind, the reason adduced is ‘because it does not apprehend the qualities of the various elements’, and this is a fallacious reason.

original: evamabhautikatvānumānaṃ pradūṣya manaso bhautikatvānumānamupasthāpayati api ca śabdādī ti /🔽manaḥ pāñcabhautikaṃ pañcabhūtaguṇāvagamasādhanatvāddeha
analyzed: evam abhautika tva anumānam pradūṣya manasaḥ bhautika tva anumānam upasthāpayati api ca śabda ādī ti  manaḥ pāñcabhautikam pañca bhūta guṇa avagama sādhana tvāt deha
translated: Having thus refuted the argument for the non-elemental character of the Mind, the Author puts forward the argument for the elemental character of the Mind: [see verse 21 above]

analyzed: vat iti prayogaḥ
translated: The argument may be formulated as follows: The Mind is made up of the five elements, because it is the means of apprehending the qualities of the five elements, like the Body.

original: pañcabhūtopādanakatve gauravājjātisāṅkaryabhītyā ca pakṣāntaramāha ekadvī ti /
analyzed: pañcabhūta upādanaka tve gauravāt jāti sāṅkarya bhītyā ca pakṣa antaram āha iti
translated: On the ground of the great difficulty involved in the assumption of the Mind being made up of the five elements, and also of the confusion that would be caused in the ‘Universal’, the Author puts forward another view: [see verse 22 next]

analyzed: dehasya iva eka bhautikasya bhūta antara upaṣṭabdha tvāt bhūta antara guṇa upalambha sādhanatva upapattiḥ manasaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that just as the body, which is composed of one element, is supported by another element, so the mind is capable of being the means of perceiving the qualities of another element.

original: asya pārthivatve śrutimapi saṃvādarūpeṇodāharati annamayaṃ hī ti /🔽śruterānyaparyaṃ śaṅkate tanne ti /
analyzed: asya pārthiva tve śrutim api saṃvāda rūpeṇa udāharati anna mayam hi iti  śruteḥ ānyaparyam śaṅkate tat na iti
translated: In support of its being of the nature of earth, he cites a Vedic text in the form of an agreement: For it is said...🔽He doubts that the Vedic text refers to something else: That is not so...

analyzed: nanu ityādiḥ
translated: But... and so on.

analyzed: tat nirukta śruti vacanam
translated: That refers to the statement in the Vedic text.

analyzed: tad adhīne ti  anna rasa āpyāyitasya eva manasaḥ saṅkalpanā ādi vyāpāra kṣama tayā anna maya tvam śrūyate nna rasa paripoṣita tva lakṣaṇam
translated: Dependent on that...🔽The mind, which functions in imagination etc. only when nourished by the essence of food, is said to be of the nature of food, characterized by being nourished by the essence of food.

analyzed: vāyu viśeṣasya prāṇasya iva ām maya tvam jala rasa āpyāyita tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the mind is of the nature of food, like the vital breath, which is a particular type of air, because it is nourished by the essence of water.

analyzed: manaḥ bhautika tve śruti arthāpattim api āha atas eva iti
translated: He states an inference from the meaning of the Vedic text that the mind is not composed of elements: For this very reason...

analyzed: yadi bhautikam manaḥ
translated: If the mind is composed of elements,

analyzed: tarhi muktau na anuvarteta deha ādi vat iti
translated: then it would not continue in liberation, like the body and so on.

original: muktau mano 'nuvṛttau śrutimāha tatraive ti /🔽chāndogya evāṣṭame prapāṭhake /
analyzed: muktau manaḥ nuvṛttau śrutim āha tatra eva iti  chāndogye eva aṣṭame prapāṭhake
translated: In the continuation of the mind in liberation, he cites a Vedic text: In that very...🔽In the eighth section of the Chandogya Upanishad.

analyzed: anna mayam hi iti tu ṣaṣṭhe
translated: For it is said to be of the nature of food... is in the sixth section.

original: muktasya manoyogamuktvā nityamuktasvabhāvasyeśvarasyāpi tatra pramāṇamudāharati tathe ti /
analyzed: muktasya manaḥ yogam uktvā nitya mukta svabhāvasya īśvarasya api tatra pramāṇam udāharati tathā iti
translated: Having spoken of the liberation of the mind of the liberated one, he cites a proof for the Lord, who is of the nature of eternal liberation, with the word tatha (thus).

analyzed: purāṇe śrīvaiṣṇave pañcameṃśe
translated: In the fifth section of the venerable Vishnu Purana.

analyzed: tat na ityādinā uktam ākṣepam ardha aṅgīkāreṇa pariharati ucyate iti  satyam iti ardha aṅgīkāre
translated: He answers the objection stated by tan na etc. with partial acceptance.🔽Sat yam (true) is the partial acceptance.

analyzed: śruteḥ ānyaparye abhyupagamaḥ
translated: The acceptance of the Veda being about something else.
The non-acceptance in the case of the mind being a separate reality.

analyzed: evam vā āśrayaṇam bhautika tva āśrayaṇam vā
translated: Such reliance or the reliance on being made of elements.

analyzed: vākāraḥ na āsthāyām
translated: The word va (or) is for non-acceptance.

original: ata eva svāśayaṃ prakaṭīkaroti manoviṣaye paramārthatastu ityādinā /
analyzed: atas eva sva āśayam prakaṭīkaroti manaḥ viṣaye paramārthataḥ tu ityādinā
translated: For this very reason, he reveals his own intention with manah-visaye (in the sphere of the mind) etc.

analyzed: buddhau eva i ti
translated: Buddhau eva (only in the intellect).

analyzed: buddhau eva manaḥ śabdaḥ vācaka tvena vartate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the word manas (mind) is used as a name only in the intellect.

analyzed: muktasya īśvarasya ca buddhimat tvāt eva samanaska tva vācoyuktiḥ
translated: The reason for saying that the liberated Lord has a mind is because of His being intelligent.

analyzed: tayoḥ amanaska tva vacanam tu karma kṛta buddhi vṛtti niṣedha abhiprāyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the statement about His being without a mind is with the intention of prohibiting the functioning of the intellect created by karma.

original: buddhereva manastve laukikavyavahāramuktvā laukikapratyakṣamapi pradarśayati manasaḥ iti /
analyzed: buddheḥ eva manaḥ tve laukika vyavahāram uktvā laukika pratyakṣam api pradarśayati manasaḥ iti
translated: Having spoken of the worldly usage in the case of the mind being only the intellect, he shows the worldly perception also with manasah (of the mind).

analyzed: manaḥ prasannam ityādi adhyakṣam pratyakṣa buddhi ālambanam eva saṃbhavati
translated: The mind being clear, etc., is possible only as a direct perception, as an object of direct cognition.

analyzed: na tu atīndriya manaḥ gocaram iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not an object of the mind which is beyond the senses.

analyzed: buddhi śabdena jñānam vivakṣitam
translated: By the word 'buddhi' (intellect), knowledge is meant.

original: nanu buddherjñānasyaiva manastve 'ntaḥkaraṇatvoktistasya kathaṃ saṅgacchata ityatrāha evaṃ ce ti /
analyzed: nanu buddheḥ jñānasya eva manaḥ tve ntaḥkaraṇa tva uktiḥ tasya katham saṅgacchate iti atra āha evam ca iti
translated: If the mind is only the intellect, the knowledge, how is the statement of its being the internal organ (ant:karana) reconciled? In answer to this, he says 'Thus, etc.'

analyzed: viṣaya smṛti ādi hetu bhūta vyāpāravat tva pradarśana artham buddheḥ antaḥkaraṇa tva vyapadeśaḥ
translated: The designation of the intellect as the internal organ is for the purpose of showing that it has the function of being the cause of the memory of objects, etc.

original: adhyavasāyādihetuvyāpāravattvapradarśanārthaṃ buddhyādivyapadeśa iva manaso 'tirekavāde 'pīti bhāvaḥ /🔽atra vimarśakena sukhādisākṣātkārakaraṇatvena manaso 'numānaṃ tārkikābhimataṃ na vimṛṣṭam /
analyzed: adhyavasāya ādi hetu vyāpāravattva pradarśana artham buddhi ādi vyapadeśaḥ iva atireka vāde pi iti bhāvaḥ  atra vimarśakena sukha ādi sākṣātkāra karaṇa tvena manasaḥ numānam tārkika abhimatam na vimṛṣṭam
translated: The designation of the mind, etc. is for the purpose of showing that it has the function of being the cause of determination, etc., even in the doctrine of non-difference (of the internal organ from the intellect), as in the case of the designation of the intellect, etc. This is the meaning.🔽Here, the critic has not considered the inference of the mind as the cause of the perception of pleasure, etc., which is accepted by the logicians.

analyzed: ayam atra āśayaḥ indriya sauṣṭhava upaghātayoḥ eva sukha duḥkha rūpa tvāt tayoḥ ca atīndriya tvāt na tad sākṣātkāra kāraṇatayā manaḥ numeyam
translated: The idea here is this: Since the impairment of the excellence of the senses is of the nature of pleasure and pain, and since they are beyond the senses, the mind cannot be inferred as the cause of their perception.

analyzed: yat vā jñāna viśeṣa rūpa tvāt tayoḥ jñāna svayam prakāśa tva balāt eva tad pratibhāsa upapattiḥ iti
translated: Or, because they are of the nature of a particular kind of knowledge, the appearance of the self and the mind is logically possible by the power of the self-luminosity of knowledge itself.

original: āhe tyādinā vimarśakenātiriktamanonirāse kṛte siddhāntīsvāśayamāviṣkaroti ucyata ityādinā /
analyzed: āhe tyādinā vimarśakena atirikta manaḥ nirāse kṛte siddhāntī sva āśayam āviṣkaroti ucyate ityādinā
translated: When the critic has refuted the existence of a separate mind by saying It is said, etc., the proponent reveals his own position by saying It is said and so on.

analyzed: a pratijñāte ti  manasaḥ na ātma tvam eva pratijñātam prakṛtam
translated: Not being a thesis means🔽that the non-selfhood of the mind itself is the thesis and the subject matter.

analyzed: manaḥ svarūpa tattva vicārasya aprakṛta tvāt na asmābhiḥ idānīm atirikta manaḥ sādhane pravartyate iti āśayaḥ
translated: Since the consideration of the true nature of the mind itself is not the subject matter, we are not now engaged in establishing a separate mind. This is the intention.

original: astu vā muktānāmīśvarasya ca mano buddhirūpameva /
analyzed: astu vā muktānām īśvarasya ca manaḥ buddhi rūpam eva
translated: Or let the mind of the liberated and of God be of the nature of intellect alone.

original: baddhānāṃ tu mana āhaṅkārika mantaḥkaraṇaṃ śrutibalādabhyupagantavyameva /
analyzed: baddhānām tu manaḥ āhaṅkārika mantaḥkaraṇam śruti balāt abhyupagantavyam eva
translated: But for the bound souls, the internal organ consisting of the mind and ego should be accepted on the strength of the scriptures.

analyzed: smṛti ādi karaṇatayā ca tat abhyupagama arham
translated: And it is worthy of acceptance as the instrument of memory, etc.

original: paraṃ tu tasya na cetanatvaṃ śakyamadhyavasitumiti hārdam //🔽prāṇātmavādamupakṣipati astu tarhī ti /🔽prāṇavati dehe jīvatīti /
analyzed: param tu tasya na cetana tvam śakyam adhyavasitum iti hārdam  prāṇa ātma vādam upakṣipati astu tarhi iti  prāṇavati dehe jīvati iti
translated: But it is the heart's conviction that the sentience of that [internal organ] cannot be ascertained.🔽He introduces the doctrine of the life-breath as the self by saying Let it be so, etc.🔽Because there is the usage that one lives when the body has life-breath,

original: tadrahite ca mṛta iti vyavahārātprāṇa eva jīvanakartṛtvājjīva iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tad rahite ca mṛte iti vyavahārāt prāṇaḥ eva jīvana kartṛ tvāt jīvaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: and is dead when devoid of it, the life-breath itself is the living agent, and hence is the self. This is the idea.

analyzed: itarathā ti
translated: Otherwise, it is said.

analyzed: parama mahataḥ
translated: It is extremely large.

analyzed: a mahataḥ ca
translated: And it is not large.

analyzed: iti padacchedaḥ
translated: This is the word division.

analyzed: a mahā tvam aṇu tvam
translated: Non-largeness is minuteness.

original: niḥsparśatvādātmani na kriyā vibhutve 'ṇutve vā saṃbhavatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: niḥsparśa tvāt ātmani na kriyā vibhu tve ṇu tve vā saṃbhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that action is not possible in the self due to its being without touch, whether it is all-pervading or minute.

analyzed: pratikṣipati vādam enam idam api asa t iti
translated: He rejects this argument, saying this is also wrong.

analyzed: atra prayoga trayam prāṇaḥ na ātmā
translated: Here there are three arguments: The life-breath is not the self.

analyzed: suṣuptau vyāpāravat tva rūpāt ātma vaidharmyāt
translated: Because it lacks the property of being active in deep sleep, unlike the self.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ na ātmā
translated: The life-breath is not the self.

analyzed: tvāca pratyakṣa grāhya tvāt dhaṭa ādi vat
translated: Because it is perceptible by the skin sense organ, like a pot, etc.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ na ātmā vāyu tva avdi ajana pavana vat iti
translated: The life-breath is not the self, because it is air, like the wind that fans a lamp.

analyzed: tad vṛttyai iti
translated: By its function,

original: prāṇavyāpārasya bhuktapītāhārapariṇāmahetutvam ahaṃ vaiśvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṃ dehamāsthitaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇa vyāpārasya bhukta pīta āhāra pariṇāma hetu tvam aham vaiśvānaraḥ bhūtvā prāṇinām deham āsthitaḥ
translated: the function of the life-breath is the cause of the transformation of eaten and drunk food. This is established by the Gita smrti: Having become the all-pervading fire, I enter the bodies of beings,

analyzed: prāṇa apāna samāyuktaḥ pacāmi annam caturvidham  iti gītā smṛti siddham  tanutare ti
translated: united with inhalation and exhalation, I digest the four kinds of food.

analyzed: alpatara pṛthivī jala tejaḥ oṃśa uttambhitaḥ jaṭhara gataḥ vāyu viśeṣaḥ prāṇaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: It is supported by the extremely small earth, water, and fire elements. The meaning is that the life-breath is a particular type of air located in the stomach.

analyzed: kiñca nirastaḥ deha caitanya pratiṣedha prakārataḥ
translated: It is refuted by something, by the method of refuting the sentience of the body.

analyzed: prāṇa ātma vādaḥ na pṛthak prayojayati dūṣaṇam
translated: The doctrine of the life-breath as the self does not require a separate refutation.

original: avibhutvenāsyā'tmanaḥ sparśavirahiṇo 'pi prayatnādṛṣṭapreraṇānuguṇyena manasa ivotkrāntigatyādayo yujyanta iti na tannirdeśānāmamuravyārthatā
analyzed: avibhu tvena asya ātmanaḥ prayatna adṛṣṭa preraṇa ānuguṇyena manasaḥ iva utkrānti gati ādayaḥ yujyante iti na tad nirdeśānām amuravyā artha tā
translated: Even for this non-pervading self devoid of touch, departure, motion, etc. are possible through the favor of effort, unseen force, and mind, just as in the case of the mind. Thus, their description does not have a non-existent object.

analyzed: parimāṇa nirūpaṇe pi etat bhaviṣyati iti alam adhunā
translated: This will also be the case in the determination of size. Enough for now.

analyzed: iti prāṇa ātma vāda nirāsa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the refutation of the doctrine of the life-breath as the self.

analyzed: bhavatu tarhi saṃvid eva ātmā a jaḍa tvāt
translated: Let the self then be consciousness itself, because it is not inert.

analyzed: jaḍa tva pratibaddham hi anātbhyam ghaṭa ādiṣu dṛṣṭam
translated: For non-selfhood is seen in pots, etc. to be bound by inertness.

original: jaḍatvaṃ ca saṃvido nivartamānaṃ tadapi nivartayati /🔽ajaḍatvaṃ ca saṃvidaḥ sattayaiva prakāśamānatvāt /
analyzed: jaḍa tvam ca saṃvidaḥ nivartamānam tat api nivartayati  ajaḍa tvam ca saṃvidaḥ sattayā eva prakāśamāna tvāt
translated: And inertness, ceasing in consciousness, makes that cease as well.🔽And consciousness is not inert, because it shines by its own existence.

analyzed: na hi satī saṃvid dhaṭa ādiḥ iva a prakāśamānā avatiṣṭhate
translated: For consciousness, being existent, does not remain unmanifest like a pot, etc.

analyzed: yena para āyatta siddhiḥ āsthīyeta
translated: By which its establishment through dependence on another could be accepted.

analyzed: iti saṃvid ātma tva pakṣa upasthāpanam
translated: Thus ends the presentation of the view that consciousness is the self.

analyzed: syāt matam jātāyām api saṃvidi viṣaya mātram prathate
translated: It may be thought: Even in arisen consciousness, only the object shines.

original: na khalunīlamidamiti pratiyantaḥ tadaivānīlamanidaṃrūpamapi saṃvedanaṃ pratīmaḥ /
analyzed: na khalu nīlam idam iti pratiyantaḥ tadā eva a nīlam an idam rūpam api saṃvedanam pratīmaḥ
translated: When we perceive this as blue, we do not at the same time perceive the cognition as having the form of non-blue.

original: ataḥ svarūpasatyaiva saṃvidā indriyasannikarṣeṇeva viṣayaḥ prakāśyate /
analyzed: atas sva rūpa satyā eva saṃvidā indriya sannikarṣeṇa iva viṣayaḥ prakāśyate
translated: Therefore, the object is illuminated by cognition, which is real in its own form, just as by sense contact.

analyzed: tatas ca tad gata āgantuka prakāśa atiśaya darśanena paścāt saṃvid anumāsyate iti
translated: And then, by seeing the excess of adventitious illumination in it, cognition will be inferred later.

analyzed: iti saṃvid anumeya tva pakṣeṇa tad ajaḍa tva ākṣepaḥ
translated: Thus, in the view that cognition is to be inferred, the objection that it is not non-intelligent is raised.

original: tanna / jñānavyatirekiṇor'thadharmasya prakāśasya nipuṇamapi nirīkṣamāṇānāṃ rūpādivadanupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: tat na jñāna vyatirekiṇā ṛtha dharmasya prakāśasya nipuṇam api nirīkṣamāṇānām rūpa ādi vat anupalabdheḥ
translated: That is not so. Even when we carefully examine the illumination of an object, which is different from cognition, we do not perceive it, like color etc.

analyzed: ubhaya abhyupeta saṃvidā eva sakala vyavahāra upapattau ca tad kalpanā anupapatteḥ
translated: And when all practical usage is possible with cognition, which is accepted by both, the postulation of that is not possible.

analyzed: vitti veditṛ pratibhāsa śūnyāyām ca viṣaya vittau abhyupagamyamānāyām ghaṭaḥ tāvat ayam
translated: And when the cognition of an object is accepted as devoid of the appearance of the knower and the known, then it would be said this is a pot,

analyzed: aham tu jānāmi na vā iti
translated: but I know or do not know would not be known.

original: na jñāyate iti ca kadācitpratibhāsaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na jñāyate iti ca kadācid pratibhāsaḥ syāt
translated: And sometimes there might be the appearance it is not known.

analyzed: na ca evam asti
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: atīta anāgata viṣaya grahaṇa smaraṇeṣu vyāhāra vyavahārayoḥ abhāve
translated: In the apprehension and recollection of past and future objects, there is no usage of speech and practical activity.

analyzed: bhāve pi
translated: Even if there were,

original: tataḥ prāgeva viditatvapratīteḥ nānumānikī tatra viṣayaprakāśa
analyzed: tatas prāk eva vidita tva pratīteḥ na ānumānikī tatra viṣaya prakāśa
translated: Therefore, since the cognition of being known already exists, the manifestation of the object there is not inferential.

analyzed: siddhiḥ natarām tad pūrvikā tatra buddhi siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, since the cognition of the object is already known beforehand, the establishment of the manifestation of the object there is not by inference. Even less is the establishment of the cognition there preceded by that.

original: tathāhi kenacitpreritaḥ praṇidhāya smṛtvānantarameva prativadati smṛtamadya mayeti / na cāya
analyzed: tathā hi kenacid preritaḥ praṇidhāya smṛtvā anantaram eva prativadati smṛtam adya mayā iti na ca āya
translated: For example, someone, impelled by another, having directed his mind and remembered, immediately replies, I remember it now. And this

analyzed: mā iva vyāhāraḥ tatra liṅgam
translated: utterance itself is not the reason there.

analyzed: tad pūrvaka tvāt
translated: Because it is preceded by that.

analyzed: anyonya āśrayaṇa āpatteḥ ca
translated: And because of the fallacy of mutual dependence.

original: svavyāhāreṇa svajñānānumānaṃ ka iva nirapatrapaḥ pratijānīta / /
analyzed: sva vyāhāreṇa sva jñāna anumānam kaḥ iva nirapatrapaḥ pratijānīta
translated: What shameless person would admit that one infers one's own cognition from one's own utterance?

analyzed: iti saṃvid anumeya tva nirāsaḥ
translated: Thus, the refutation of the inferability of consciousness.

analyzed: anyat ca yat saṃbandhāt artha antare yaḥ vyavahāraḥ dharma bhedaḥ vā
translated: Moreover, the usage or difference in properties with regard to another thing due to its connection with something else,

analyzed: sa tasmin upalabhyamānaḥ tad sva rūpa prayuktaḥ
translated: when perceived in that, is employed in its own nature.

analyzed: na tu tad saṃbandha nibandhanaḥ
translated: But it is not based on the connection with that.

analyzed: yathā sattā saṃbandhāt pṛthivī ādiṣu sat vyavahāraḥ
translated: For example, the usage of existent with regard to earth etc. is due to the connection with existence.

analyzed: rūpa saṃbandhāt ca cākṣuṣa tvam sattāyām rūpe ca
translated: And the visibility is due to the connection with form, both in existence and in form.

original: evaṃ saṃvitsaṃbandhātpravartamāno ghaṭādiṣu prakāśata iti vyavahāraḥ prakāśamānatvaṃ vā dharmaḥ saṃvidi tu paridṛśyamāno na saṃvitsaṃbandhāpekṣaḥ /
analyzed: evam saṃvid saṃbandhāt pravartamānaḥ ghaṭa ādiṣu prakāśate iti vyavahāraḥ prakāśamāna tvam vā dharmaḥ saṃvidi tu paridṛśyamānaḥ na saṃvid saṃbandha apekṣaḥ
translated: Thus, the usage or property of being manifest in pots etc. is due to their functioning in relation to consciousness, or their being illuminated. But in consciousness, which is perceived, it does not depend on a relation with consciousness.

original: api tu tatsvarūpaprayukta iti svayaṃprakāśatvāt saivā'tmeti /
analyzed: api tu tad svarūpa prayuktaḥ iti svayam prakāśa tvāt sā eva ātmā iti
translated: Rather, it is due to its own nature. Thus, because it is self-luminous, it is the self itself.

analyzed: kiñca saṃvidaḥ saṃveditāram abhyupagacchati
translated: Moreover, even one who accepts a knower separate from consciousness

analyzed: abhyupagacchati eva asau saṃvidam
translated: must accept consciousness.

analyzed: na hi asatyām eva saṃvidi saṃvetti iti upapadyate
translated: For it is not tenable to say that one knows without consciousness.

original: evaṃ cet / ubhayavādisaṃpratipannatayā saiva varaṃ veditrī bhavatu /
analyzed: evam ced ubhaya vādi saṃpratipanna tayā sā eva varam veditrī bhavatu
translated: If so, it is better that consciousness itself be the knower, since it is accepted by both parties.

analyzed: kim anyena kalpitena
translated: What is the use of postulating something else?

analyzed: iti saṃvidaḥ svayamprakāśa tva ātma tva sādhanam
translated: Thus, the proof of consciousness being self-luminous and being the self.

analyzed: nanu aham jānāmi iti jñāna atiriktaḥ tad āśraya bhūtaḥ yam ātmā pratīyate
translated: But it is cognized that this self, which is the substratum of that [consciousness], is separate from consciousness, since it is cognized as I know.

original: satyam / sa tu vikalparūpatayā sākṣātpratyakṣa iti na śakyaḥ saṃśrayitum /
analyzed: satyam sa tu vikalpa rūpa tayā sākṣāt pratyakṣaḥ iti na śakyaḥ saṃśrayitum
translated: True, but that [self] cannot be accepted, since it is directly perceived in the form of an option.

analyzed: bheda jñāna siddhavatkāreṇa pṛthak vastu tayā gṛhīta avyabhicāreṇa saha upalambha niyamena
translated: By the rule of the establishment of the knowledge of difference, it is grasped as a separate entity, and by the invariable concomitance of simultaneous apprehension.

analyzed: aprakāśa ātmanaḥ ca svabhāva virodhāt eva prakāśa ayogāt
translated: And because the nature of the non-luminous cannot be luminous, due to the contradiction of its nature.

original: prakāśasvābhāvye ca saṃvedanatvamityādinā vā prakāśātmano 'hamityaṃśasya tattvameva durupagamam /
analyzed: prakāśa svābhāvye ca saṃvedana tvam ityādinā vā prakāśa ātmanaḥ ham iti aṃśasya tattvam eva durupagamam
translated: And if it has the nature of luminosity, then the nature of the part I which is luminous is difficult to accept, as it would be the same as consciousness, etc.

analyzed: grāhya vikalpa pratyuddhāre pi eṣaḥ eva prakāraḥ
translated: This is the same method even when the alternatives of the grasped and the grasper are removed.

analyzed: atas vāsanā abhidhāna samanantara pratyaya sāmarthyāt anādya vidyā vaśāt ca samāropita avāstava grāhya grāhaka vikalpa ullekhinī svayaṃprakāśā saṃvid eva paramārtha satī
translated: Therefore, due to the power of the impressions, the designation, and the immediately preceding conditions, and also due to beginningless ignorance, the self-luminous consciousness itself, which is ultimately real, manifests the superimposed unreal alternatives of the grasped and the grasper.

analyzed: sā eva ātmā iti saugatāḥ prakaṭāḥ pracchannāḥ ca
translated: That itself is the Self, say the Buddhists, both openly and secretly.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ prakaṭāḥ buddhi ātmā viparyāsita darśanaiḥ
translated: As the open ones say: Even the undivided Self of consciousness, by those whose vision is perverted,

analyzed: grāhya grāhaka saṃvitti bhedavān iva lakṣyate iti
translated: is seen as if it had the distinction of the consciousness of the grasped and the grasper.

original: yathā vā pracchannāḥ śuddhaṃ tattvaṃ prapañcasya na heturanivṛttitaḥ /
analyzed: yathā vā pracchannāḥ śuddham tattvam prapañcasya na hetuḥ anivṛttitaḥ
translated: Or as the secret ones say: Pure reality is not the cause of the world, because it does not cease.

analyzed: jñātṛ jñeya vibhāgasya māyā eva jananī tatas iti
translated: Maya alone is the mother of the distinction between the knower and the known.

analyzed: iti saṃvid ātma tva pūrvapakṣa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the prima facie view of consciousness being the Self.

analyzed: atra aha kṣaṇa bhaṅginī prati viṣayam anyā anyā ca saṃvid cakāsti
translated: Here it is said: The consciousness, which is momentary and different for each object, appears.

analyzed: sā eva ced ātmā
translated: And if that itself were the self,

original: pūrvedyurdṛṣṭamaparedyurahamidamadarśamiti kathamiva pratyabhijānīyāt / /🔽na ca nīrālambanapratibhābhedamātratayeha samādheyam nirālambanatvapratijñāyāḥ pratyakṣādisaka
analyzed: pūrvedyus dṛṣṭam aparedyus aham idam adarśam iti katham iva pratyabhijānīyāt  na ca nīra ālambana pratibhā bheda mātra tayā iha samādheyam nirālambana tva pratijñāyāḥ pratyakṣa ādi sakala
translated: how could it recognize, Yesterday I saw this, today I see it again, since it is different?

And here it cannot be accepted merely on the basis of the difference in the appearance of consciousness without an object, because the proposition of being without an object is contradicted by all the means of valid knowledge, such as perception,

analyzed: sādhanasya ca sālambana tve tad aviśeṣāt aśeṣa śemuṣīṇām tathātva āpatteḥ
translated: and because if the means of valid knowledge have an object, then all the other means of valid knowledge would have to be the same, due to their non-difference.

analyzed: nirālambana tve ca sādhana abhāvāt eva sādhya asiddheḥ
translated: And if they are without an object, then the conclusion is not established, because there is no means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: prapañcitaḥ ca pūrva uttara mīmāṃsā bhāgayoḥ nirālambana tva pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: The refutation of being without an object has been extensively discussed in the earlier and later parts of the Mīmāṃsā.

original: yathārtharavyātisamarthanena ca śāstra iti na vyāvarṇyate /
analyzed: ca śāstre iti na vyāvarṇyate
translated: And it is not described in the treatise by the establishment of the truth of the scriptures.

original: ata eva na santānāśrayaṇenāpi pratyabhijñopapādanaṃ sādhīyaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva na santāna āśrayaṇena api pratyabhijñā upapādanam sādhīyaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the explanation of recognition by resorting to a series is not appropriate.

analyzed: vijñāna kṣaṇa vyatiriktasya sthāyinaḥ nusandhāyinaḥ santānasya abhyupagame sva siddhānta tyāgaḥ
translated: If a permanent continuum that is different from momentary consciousness and that connects [them] is accepted, then one's own doctrine is abandoned,

analyzed: para siddhānta abhyupagamaḥ ca
translated: and the doctrine of others is accepted.

analyzed: an abhyupagame pratyabhijñā anupapattiḥ
translated: If [the existence of the soul] is not accepted, recognition is not possible.

analyzed: na hi anyena anubhūte nyasya pratisandhāna saṃbhavaḥ
translated: For it is not possible for one to remember what was experienced by another.

original: na ca susadṛśatayā bhedāgrahaṇena pradīpādāviva pramātari pratyabhijñābhrāntiḥ /
analyzed: na ca su sadṛśa tayā bheda agrahaṇena pradīpa ādau iva pramātari pratyabhijñā bhrāntiḥ
translated: And it is not proper to suppose that the recognition of the cognizer is a mistake, as in the case of a lamp, due to the non-apprehension of difference by similarity.

original: yujyate hi tatraikasyaiva pūrvāparavyaktidarśinaḥ tulyasaṃsthānatayā vyaktīnāṃ bhedamaviduṣaḥ tathā bhramaḥ /
analyzed: yujyate hi tatra ekasya eva pūrva apara vyakti darśinaḥ tulya saṃsthāna tayā vyaktīnām bhedam aviduṣaḥ tathā bhramaḥ
translated: For there, it is proper for one who sees the previous and subsequent moments to be mistaken in that way, not knowing the difference between the moments due to their having the same form.

original: iha tu saṃvidvyaktayaḥ parasparavārtānabhijñā niranvayavināśinyaśca sugatamata iti na tāsvekatvabhramasyā'śrayatā viṣayatā vā saṃbhavinī /
analyzed: iha tu saṃvid vyaktayaḥ paraspara vārttā anabhijñāḥ niranvaya vināśinyaḥ ca sugata mate iti na tāsu eka tva bhramasya āśraya tā viṣaya tā vā saṃbhavinī
translated: But in this case, according to the doctrine of the Sugata (Buddha), the moments of consciousness are mutually ignorant of each other and perish without remainder. Thus, it is not possible for them to be the basis or object of the illusion of oneness.

original: na ca susadṛśatve 'pi anyena kṛtamātmakṛtatayānyo 'nusandhātumalamityāgamāpāyisaṃvitsantānāśrayaḥ pratyabhijñānakṣaṇasthāyī cetano 'bhyupagantavyaḥ
analyzed: na ca su sadṛśa tve pi anyena kṛtam ātma kṛta tayā anyaḥ nusandhātum alam iti āgama apāyi saṃvid santāna āśrayaḥ pratyabhijñāna kṣaṇa sthāyī cetanaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: And even if they are very similar, it is not possible for one to remember what was done by another as if done by oneself. Therefore, a conscious being must be accepted as the basis of the stream of consciousness, which arises and perishes, and as the substratum of recognition, which lasts for a moment.

analyzed: iti kṣaṇika vijñāna ātma vāda nirāsa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the refutation of the doctrine of momentary consciousness as the self.

analyzed: kaścid āhana saṃvid anityā
translated: Someone says: Consciousness is not eternal.

analyzed: prāgabhāva ādi asiddheḥ
translated: Because prior non-existence, etc. are not established.

analyzed: tad asiddhiḥ ca tasyāḥ svatas siddha tvāt
translated: And the non-establishment of that is because it is established by itself.

analyzed: nahi svatas siddhasya prāgabhāva ādayaḥ svatas nyatas vā  siddhyanti
translated: For the prior non-existence, etc. of what is self-established are not established either by itself or by another.

original: svayaṃ hi svābhāvamavagamayat sadvā asadvā sādhayet /
analyzed: svayam hi svābhāvam avagamayat sat vā asat vā sādhayet
translated: For itself, indeed, while making known its own nature, would establish what is existent or non-existent.

analyzed: sattve bhāvaḥ eva na asti iti katham sādhayet
translated: If it is existent, then non-existence itself does not exist, so how could it establish it?

original: asattvādeva sādhakasya pakṣāntare natarāṃ sādhakatvamiti na svataḥ tāvattatsiddhiḥ /
analyzed: asattvāt eva sādhakasya pakṣa antare natarām sādhaka tvam iti na svatas tāvat tad siddhiḥ
translated: Due to non-existence itself, the establisher is not at all an establisher in another case. Thus its establishment is not from itself.

analyzed: na api anyatas
translated: Nor from another.

analyzed: an anya gocara tvāt anu bhūteḥ
translated: Because of not having another as its object, like cognition.

analyzed: anubhāvya tve ca ghaṭa ādi vat ananubhūti tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And if it were to be cognized, then it would follow that it is not cognized, like a pot, etc.

analyzed: atas sā na jāyate
translated: Therefore, it is not produced.

analyzed: janma abhāvāt eva itare pi bhāva vikārāḥ nirākāryāḥ
translated: Due to the absence of production itself, the other modifications of existence are to be rejected.

analyzed: tad pratibaddha tvāt teṣām
translated: Because they are dependent on that.

analyzed: atas eva nānātvam api saṃvidi pratyuktam
translated: For this very reason, diversity in consciousness is also refuted.
Because the cessation of diversity, which is pervaded by having production, is established by the cessation of what pervades it.

analyzed: na hi a cam vibhāgī asti
translated: For what is unborn cannot be divided.

analyzed: cetya tvāt ca bheda itaretarābhāva ādayaḥ na tad dharmāḥ rūpa ādi vat
translated: And because of being cognizable, the other properties of difference, such as mutual absence, are not its properties, like color, etc.

analyzed: atas syāḥ na meyaḥ kaścid api
translated: Therefore, this has no property at all that is to be measured.

analyzed: atas nirdhūta nikhila bheda vikalpa nirdharma prakāśa mātra ekarasā kūṭastha nityā saṃvid eva ātmā paramātmā ca
translated: Therefore, consciousness alone, which is the essence of the self and the supreme self, is the abode of the meaning of the Vedanta texts.

analyzed: yathā āha iti
translated: As it is said: That experience which is unborn, immeasurable, and of the nature of the infinite self.

analyzed: sā eva ca vedānta vākya tātparya bhūmiḥ iti
translated: And that alone is the abode of the meaning of the Vedanta texts.

analyzed: teṣām bhāṣā
translated: This is their doctrine.

original: yathā'ha tadvārtikakāraḥ parāgarthaprameyeṣu yā phalatvena saṃmatā /
analyzed: yathā āha tad vārtikakāraḥ parāk artha prameyeṣu yā phala tvena saṃmatā
translated: As the author of the Varttika says: That consciousness which is accepted as the fruit in the objects to be known,

analyzed: saṃvid sā eva eha meya ūrthaḥ vedānta ukti pramāṇataḥ
translated: That alone is the object to be known here, according to the authority of the statements of the Vedanta.

analyzed: aprāmāṇya prasaktiḥ ca syāt itas nyārtha kalpane
translated: And there would be the consequence of invalidity if another meaning were imagined from this,

analyzed: vedāntānām atas tasmāt na anyam artham prakalpayet iti
translated: Therefore, one should not imagine any other meaning of the Vedanta texts.

analyzed: iti nirviśeṣa nitya vijñāna ātma tva mata upapādana prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the establishment of the doctrine of the self being the non-distinct, eternal consciousness.

analyzed: tat idam alaukikam avaidikam ca darśanam iti ātma vidaḥ
translated: The knowers of the self say that this is a non-worldly and non-Vedic view.

original: tathāhisaṃviditi svāśrayaṃ prati sattayaiva kasyacitprakāśanaśīlo jñānāvagatyanubhūtyādipadaparyāyanāmā sakarmakaḥ saṃvediturātmano dharmaḥ 🔽prasiddhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi saṃvid iti sva āśrayam prati sattayā eva kasyacid prakāśana śīlaḥ jñāna avagati anubhūti ādi pada paryāya nāmā sa karmakaḥ saṃvedituḥ ātmanaḥ dharmaḥ  /🔽prasiddhaḥ
translated: For thus, consciousness, which is the attribute of the self, the experiencer, is well-known as having an object, being the nature of the self, and having the nature of illuminating something by its own existence. It is synonymous with knowledge, understanding, experience, and so on.

analyzed: tathā eva hi sarva prāṇabhṛt pratyātma siddhaḥ yam anubhavaḥ aham idam saṃvedmi iti
translated: For, in the same way, this experience is established in the self of every living being: 'I am conscious of this.'

analyzed: tasya asya utpatti sthiti nirodhāḥ ca sukha duḥkha ādeḥ iva pratyakṣāḥ prakāśante
translated: And its origination, continuance, and cessation are manifest, like those of pleasure, pain, etc., through perception.

analyzed: svāpa mada mūrcchā daśāsu ca yogya anupalambha nirākṛtaḥ tad sadbhāvaḥ na abhyupagamam arhati
translated: And the existence of that [consciousness] cannot be accepted as negated by the non-apprehension of what is possible in the states of sleep, intoxication, and fainting.

analyzed: yadi hi tāsu api daśāsu saṃvedanam avartiṣyata
translated: For if consciousness were to continue to exist in those states,

analyzed: tatas prabodha samaye
translated: then it would be remembered upon awakening.

analyzed: na ca anusandhīyate
translated: But it is not remembered.

original: ata eva hi 'iyantaṃ kālaṃ na kiñcidahamajñāsiṣa'miti prabuddhaḥ pratyavamṛśati /🔽yāvadanubhūtapadārthasmaraṇaniyamābhāve 'pi saṃskāravicchedanimittaprāyaṇādiprabalahetuvirahe 'pi nityavadasmaraṇamanubhavābhāvameva sādhayati
analyzed: atas eva hi iyantam kālam na kiñcid aham ajñāsiṣam iti prabuddhaḥ pratyavamṛśati  yāvat anubhūta padārtha smaraṇa niyama abhāve pi saṃskāra viccheda nimitta prāyaṇa ādi prabala hetu virahe pi nitya vat asmaraṇam anubhava abhāvam eva sādhayati
translated: For this very reason, one who has awakened reflects: 'For so long I knew nothing at all.'🔽Even in the absence of the restriction of memory of experienced objects, the absence of memory as if it were eternal, even in the absence of powerful causes such as death that are the cause of the interruption of impressions, proves the absence of experience itself.

analyzed: na ca sati api saṃvid prakāśe viṣaya avaccheda virahāt ahaṅkāra gocara apāyāt vā tad smṛti anudayaḥ
translated: And even if the manifestation of consciousness exists, the non-arising of its memory is not due to the absence of the determination of the object or to the disappearance of the sphere of egoism.

analyzed: artha antara abhāvasya tad agrahaṇasya ca artha antara prakāśa prayukta kārya pratibandhaka tva ayogāt
translated: Because the absence of another object and the non-apprehension of that cannot be the cause of the obstruction of the effect produced by the manifestation of another object.

analyzed: tritaya avabhāse pi yathāsvam avabhāsānām sva gocara smaraṇa hetu tvāt
translated: Even in the manifestation of the three, the manifestations are the cause of the recollection of their own objects, according to their nature.

original: naca pratyabhijñābalalabdhasthemāhamarthaḥ svāpādidaśāsu nidhanamupagata iti śakyo 'bhidhātum /
analyzed: na ca pratyabhijñā bala labdha sthemā ahamarthaḥ svāpa ādi daśāsu nidhanam upagataḥ iti śakyaḥ abhidhātum
translated: And it cannot be said that the meaning of 'I', which has been established by the power of recognition, has perished in the states of sleep etc.

original: ata eva hi 'iyantaṃ kālamahasvāpsa'miti prabodhe parāmarśaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva hi iyantam kālam ahasva apsam iti prabodhe parāmarśaḥ
translated: For this very reason, there is the reflection 'I slept for this long' upon awakening.

original: naca nirviṣayā nirāśrayā vā saṃvinnāma kācit saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na ca nirviṣayā nirāśrayā vā saṃvid nāma kācid saṃbhavati
translated: And there is no such thing as consciousness without an object or without a basis.

analyzed: atyanta anupalabdheḥ
translated: Because it is not apprehended at all.

analyzed: saṃbandhi śabdāḥ ca saṃvid anubhūti jñāna prakāśa ādi śabdāḥ iti śabda artha vidaḥ
translated: And the words 'relation' and 'related' are used in the sense of 'consciousness', 'experience', 'knowledge', 'light', etc., according to the grammarians.

original: na hyakarmakasya jānātyāderakartṛkasya vā prayogo loke vede vā /
analyzed: na hi akarmakasya jānāti ādeḥ akartṛkasya vā prayogaḥ loke vede vā
translated: For in the world or in the Veda, there is no usage of 'knows' etc. without an object or of 'I' etc. without a subject.

original: yattu svataḥsiddhasya sattve tadvirodhādeva prāgabhāvādeḥ tadānīmavasthānāsaṃbhavānna tataḥ siddhiriti /
analyzed: yat tu svatas siddhasya sattve tad virodhāt eva prāgabhāva ādeḥ tadānīm avasthāna asaṃbhavān na tatas siddhiḥ iti
translated: As for the argument that if existence is self-established, then the non-existence prior to that and the abiding at that time cannot be established because of the contradiction with that,

analyzed: tat atisthavīyaḥ
translated: that is very weak.

analyzed: nahi eva arthāḥ siddhyanti iti asti niyamaḥ
translated: For there is no rule that objects exist only at the time of consciousness.

analyzed: atīta anāgatayoḥ asaṃvedya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the past and future are not cognizable.

analyzed: atha saṃvid prāgabhāva ādeḥ siddhyataḥ tad sama kāla tayā bhavitavyam iti
translated: If it is argued that the past and future are established by consciousness, they must exist simultaneously with it.

analyzed: kim evam kvacid dṛṣṭam hanta evam
translated: Is such a thing seen anywhere? If so,

analyzed: sati tad siddheḥ na prāgabhāva ādi asiddhiḥ
translated: then the non-establishment of the past and future is not due to their establishment.

analyzed: tad prāgabhāvaḥ tad sama kālaḥ iti unmatta vacaḥ
translated: The past of that is simultaneous with that - this is the talk of a madman.

analyzed: aindriyika pratyakṣa svabhāvaḥ hi ayam sva sama kāla padārtha prakāśaka tvam nāma
translated: For this [consciousness] has the nature of sensory perception, which illuminates objects simultaneous with itself,

analyzed: na jñāna mātrasya
translated: not [illuminates] mere knowledge,

original: pramāṇamātrasya vā /🔽etena tadapi parākṛtam mānaṃ svayaṃprakāśatvātsvataḥsaccetsadāstyataḥ /
analyzed: pramāṇa mātrasya vā  etena tat api parākṛtam mānam svayam prakāśa tvāt svatas sat ced sadā asti atas
translated: or mere valid cognition.🔽By this, that [view] is also refuted: If valid cognition is self-luminous and real by itself, then it exists.

original: tanmeyaṃ ca sadāstyeva mānaṃ meyayugeva hi //
analyzed: tat meyam ca sadā asti eva mānam meya yugā iva hi
translated: And its object also exists, for valid cognition exists only when there is an object.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: nahi mānasya sva sattā kāla īrtha avinābhāvaḥ meya yogaḥ
translated: For at the time of the existence of valid cognition, the connection with the object through non-separation is not the connection with the object.

analyzed: kintu yad deśa kāla ādimat tayā meyam avabhāsate tādṛśa tad rūpa mithyātva virodhi tvam
translated: But rather, the quality of being the opposite of the falsity of that form in which the object appears as having a particular place, time, etc.

analyzed: atas eva smṛtiḥ na bāhya viṣayā
translated: For this very reason, memory does not have an external object as its object.

original: naṣṭe 'pyarthe smṛtidarśanā'dityapi pralāpaḥ /🔽atha saṃvitprāgabhāvāderavartamānatayā na pratyakṣatvam /
analyzed: naṣṭe pi arthe smṛti darśanāt iti api pralāpaḥ  atha saṃvid prāgabhāva ādeḥ avartamāna tayā na pratyakṣa tvam
translated: The statement that even when the object is destroyed, it is seen in memory, is also mere prattle.🔽If consciousness is not perception because of the non-existence of what is past, etc.,

original: liṅgādyabhāvācca na pramāṇāntarataḥ siddhiriti /🔽yadyevam / akāraṇaṃ tarhi svataḥsiddhatvaṃ prāga
analyzed: liṅga ādi abhāvāt ca na pramāṇa antarataḥ siddhiḥ iti  yadi evam akāraṇam tarhi svatas siddha tvam prāga
translated: and it is not established by any other means of knowledge due to the absence of inference, etc.,

analyzed: bhāva ādi asiddheḥ  pramāṇa abhāvaḥ eva hi idānīm vācyaḥ
translated: if that is so, then the self-established existence of consciousness is not caused, because what is past, etc. is not established.🔽For now, only the absence of means of knowledge should be stated.

analyzed: na ca tad abhāvaḥ śakyaḥ abhidhātum iti uktam eva
translated: And that absence cannot be expressed - this has already been said.

analyzed: yogya anupalabdhyā eva abhāvasya samarthita tvāt
translated: Because absence is established by the non-apprehension of what is possible.

original: apica pratyakṣasaṃvit svasattākāle svaviṣayasya sadbhāvaṃ sādhayantī yattasya na sarvadā sattāṃ sādhayati /
analyzed: apica pratyakṣa saṃvid sva sattā kāle sva viṣayasya sadbhāvam sādhayantī yat tasya na sarvadā sattām sādhayati
translated: Moreover, when the consciousness of perception establishes the existence of its object at the time of its own existence, it does not establish its existence at all times.

original: tadavasīyate ahamidānīmevāsmi nānyadeti kālaviśeṣāvacchinnaiva sā cakāstīti /
analyzed: tat avasīyate aham idānīm eva asmi na anyadā iti kāla viśeṣa avacchinnā eva sā cakāsti iti
translated: It is understood that I exist now only, not at another time, and that consciousness appears as limited by a particular time.

analyzed: itarathā ghaṭa ādeḥ api nitya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, it would follow that even a pot, etc. would be eternal.

analyzed: evam anumāna ādi saṃvidaḥ pi
translated: The same applies to the consciousness of inference, etc.

original: naca pratyakṣānumānādibhedaśūnyā nirviṣayā nirāśrayā dhīḥ saṃbhavatītyuktameva /
analyzed: na ca pratyakṣa anumāna ādi bheda śūnyā nirviṣayā nirāśrayā dhīḥ saṃbhavati iti uktam eva
translated: And it has been said that a cognition devoid of the distinction of perception, inference, etc., which is objectless and baseless, is not possible.

analyzed: na ca anya aviṣaya tvāt saṃvidaḥ nyatas tad prāgabhāva ādi asiddhiḥ
translated: And the non-existence, etc. of that (consciousness) is not unestablished because of the consciousness not having another object.

analyzed: ajñāsiṣam iti prāktana saṃvidaḥ dyatana dhiyā viṣayīkriyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because the consciousness of the past is made the object of the present consciousness by the expression I knew.

analyzed: pratikūla anuviṣaya niyata hāna upādāna ādi liṅga avagamya tvāt ca para saṃvidaḥ
translated: And because the consciousness of another is inferred from the signs of rejection, acceptance, etc. which are restricted to the object that is contrary (to one's own).

analyzed: tad anabhyupagame ca śabda artha grahaṇa asaṃbhavena vaidika laukika samasta vyavahāra abhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if that (consciousness of another) is not accepted, then there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of all worldly and Vedic usage due to the impossibility of grasping the meaning of words.

analyzed: guru upasarpaṇa ādi anupapattiḥ ca
translated: And the impossibility of approaching a teacher, etc. would follow.

analyzed: jñānavat tvena tasya apratīteḥ
translated: Because that (consciousness of another) is not cognized as possessing knowledge.

analyzed: na ca anya viṣaya tve na anubhūti tvam
translated: And it is not that it is not an experience because it has another object.🔽The self-subsistence of the self is manifested by its own existence.

analyzed: sva viṣaya sādhana tvam vā hi anubhūti tvam
translated: Or the state of being an experience is the state of being the means of knowing the self as its object.

original: te ca saṃvidantara viṣayabhāve 'pi svānubhavasiddhe na bhraśyata iti kathamananubhūtitva prasaṅgaḥ / /
analyzed: te ca saṃvid antara viṣaya bhāve sva anubhava siddhe na bhraśyate iti katham ananubhūti tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And those (self-subsistence and self-existence) are not lost even when they are the objects of another consciousness, which is established by one's own experience. So how can there be the undesirable consequence of their not being experiences?

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ tu tathā svābhāvya abhāvāt eva ananubhūti tvam
translated: But the pot, etc. are not experiences because they simply do not have that nature.

analyzed: na anubhāvya tvāt
translated: Not because they are not to be experienced.

analyzed: api ca ananubhāvya tve pi samānaḥ tad prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Moreover, the same undesirable consequence would follow even if they were not to be experienced.

analyzed: gagana kusuma vat
translated: Like a sky-flower.

analyzed: na ca ātmanaḥ nubhūti tvam
translated: And the self is not the experience.

analyzed: anubhavitṛ tvāt
translated: Because it is the experiencer.

analyzed: na api asau ananubhāvyaḥ  anubhavasya iva svatas siddhyataḥ pi asya sva para saṃvedya tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Nor is it not to be experienced.🔽Because, like experience, it is accepted as being known to itself and to others, even though it is established by itself.

analyzed: vedya tve na ātma tva āpādanam avedya tve pi samānam pūrvavat
translated: If it is to be known, the consequence of being non-self is the same even if it is not to be known, as before.

analyzed: yadi tu gagana kusumasya asattvam eva anātma tva ananubhūti tva prayojakam āsthīyeta
translated: But if the non-existence of a sky-flower alone is accepted as the reason for being non-self and not being experienced,

analyzed: āsthīyatām tarhi ghaṭa ādeḥ api asaṃvid āśraya tva ajñāna avirodhi tvayoḥ eva tad prayojaka tvam
translated: then let the non-existence of a pot, etc. be accepted as the reason for being neither the substrate of consciousness nor being incompatible with knowledge.

original: atha te api viṣayatve syātāmiti cet /🔽aviṣayatve 'pi tathaivetyalamapratiṣṭhitakṛtarkāpahasanena /
analyzed: atha te api viṣaya tve syātām iti ced  aviṣaya tve pi tathā evā iti alam apratiṣṭhita kṛ tarka apahasanena
translated: If it is argued that these would be objects even if they are not objects,🔽then it is enough to stop laughing at the unestablished arguments.

analyzed: yat api janana virahāt anubhūteḥ vikāra antara nirasanam
translated: As for the refutation of other modifications of experience due to the absence of production,

analyzed: vyabhicarati tat api prāgabhāve
translated: that also deviates in the case of prior non-existence.

analyzed: janma abhāve pi tasya vināśa darśanāt  bhāva viśeṣaṇa upādāne pi bhavat abhimata avidyayā anaikāntyam
translated: Because its destruction is seen even in the absence of birth.🔽Even if the qualification of existence is accepted, there is no single instance in what is accepted by you, ignorance.

original: sā hyanādirapi vividhavikāravatī vināśavatī ca tattvajñānodayāt /
analyzed: sā hi anādiḥ api vividha vikāravatī vināśavatī ca tattva jñāna udayāt
translated: For that, though beginningless, has various modifications and is subject to destruction, due to the arising of true knowledge.

analyzed: aparama arthāḥ tad vikārāḥ santi iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the unreal modifications exist,

analyzed: parama arthāḥ ca te kim vikārāḥ santi
translated: and are they the modifications of the real?

analyzed: janmavantaḥ vā parama arthāḥ
translated: Or are the real things born?

original: yena pāramārthyena viśeṣaṇaṃ sādhyasya sādhanasya vār'thavattāmaśnuvīta /
analyzed: yena pāramārthyena viśeṣaṇam sādhyasya sādhanasya vā arthavat tām aśnuvīta
translated: By what reality the qualification of the probandum or the probans would be meaningful.

analyzed: tathā ca sati sādhu samarthitam tarka kuśalena iti amanena
translated: And if that is so, it is well argued by this one skilled in reasoning.

analyzed: yat api na hi ajam vibhāgī asti iti
translated: As for what was said, There is no division of the unborn,

analyzed: tat api na
translated: that too is not so.

analyzed: ajasya eva ātmanaḥ deha indriya ādibhyaḥ vibhāgasya samarthita tvāt
translated: Because the division of the unborn Self itself from the body, senses, etc. has been established.

analyzed: anādi tvena abhyupagatasya ajñānasya ātmanaḥ vyatirikta tayā avaśya āśrayaṇīya tvāt
