translated: Because the ignorance, which is accepted as beginningless, must be necessarily accepted as separate from the Self.

analyzed: aparama arthaḥ sa vibhāgaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that that division is unreal,

analyzed: paramārtha bhedaḥ kim janma pratibaddhaḥ kvacid dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: is any difference in reality ever seen to be dependent on birth anywhere?

original: nirbādhapratītisiddhaśca dṛgdṛśyabhedaḥ paramārtha evetyanantaramevopapādayiṣyāmaḥ /🔽yadapi nāsyā meyo dharmo 'pyasti /
analyzed: nirbādha pratīti siddhaḥ ca dṛś dṛśya bhedaḥ paramārthaḥ eva iti anantaram eva upapādayiṣyāmaḥ  yat api na asyāḥ meyaḥ dharmaḥ u pi asti
translated: And the difference between the seer and the seen, which is established by unobstructed cognition, is indeed real. We will explain this immediately after.🔽As for what was said, This has no object, nor is it a property of the cognizer,

analyzed: cetyānām na cit dharma tvam iti ca
translated: and The cognized are not properties of consciousness,

analyzed: tat api śāstra anumāna ādi pramāṇa siddhaiḥ svayaṃprakāśa tva nitya tva ādi dharmaiḥ svayam abhyupagataiḥ anaikāntikam
translated: That also is inconclusive by the properties of self-luminosity, eternality, etc., which are established by such means of valid knowledge as scriptures and inference, and which are accepted by themselves.

original: na ca te citimātramiti vācyam /🔽tatsiddhāvapi teṣu
analyzed: na ca te citi mātram iti vācyam  tad siddhau api teṣu
translated: And it cannot be said that those are mere consciousness.

analyzed: vimati darśanāt
translated: Even if that is established, because doubt is seen in them.

original: abhyupagamyaiva hi saṃvidaṃ tadanumeyatvakṣaṇikatvādi pratijānate vādinaḥ /
analyzed: abhyupagamya eva hi saṃvidam tad anumeya tva kṣaṇika tva ādi pratijānate vādinaḥ
translated: For the proponents declare the knowability by that and momentariness, etc., only by accepting consciousness.

analyzed: svarūpa bhedāt ca
translated: And because of the difference in nature.

original: svāśrayaṃ prati sattayaiva kasyacit prakāśanaṃ hi saṃvedanam /
analyzed: sva āśrayam prati sattayā eva kasyacid prakāśanam hi saṃvedanam
translated: For consciousness is the manifestation of something to its own substratum by mere existence.

original: svayaṃprakāśatā tu sattayaivā'tmane prakāśamānatā /🔽prakāśaśca cidacidaśeṣapadārthasādhāraṇo dharma iti saṃvitsiddhāveva sādhitam /
analyzed: svayaṃprakāśa tā tu sattayā eva ātmane prakāśamāna tā  prakāśaḥ ca cit acit aśeṣa padārtha sādhāraṇaḥ dharmaḥ iti saṃvid siddhau eva sādhitam
translated: But self-luminosity is the manifestation of itself by mere existence.🔽And light is a property common to all conscious and unconscious things, so it has been proved even in the establishment of consciousness.

analyzed: tad anabhyupagame tu vyavahāra ānuguṇya vacanaḥ prakāśa śabdaḥ
translated: But if that is not accepted, the word light is used in accordance with usage.

analyzed: nitya tā tu sarva kāla vartamāna tā
translated: Eternality, on the other hand, is being present at all times.

analyzed: eka saṅkhyā avacchedaḥ eka tvam iti
translated: The delimitation by the number one is oneness.

original: naca jaḍatvakāladeśanānātvādyavaccheda śūnyatārūpatvātteṣāṃ na yathoktadoṣa iti yuktam /
analyzed: na ca jaḍa tva kāla deśa nānātva ādi avaccheda śūnyatā rūpa tvāt teṣām na yathā ukta doṣaḥ iti yuktam
translated: And it is not right to say that those are not subject to the faults stated because they are of the nature of being devoid of the delimitations of inertness, time, space, plurality, etc.

analyzed: tathābhūtaiḥ api taiḥ citi dharma bhūtaiḥ anaikāntyasya aparihārya tvāt  saṃvidi ca niṣedhya tva abhimata ja
translated: Even by those who are such, because of the inevitability of inconclusiveness due to being properties of consciousness.

analyzed: eva
translated: And in consciousness, the statement of negation is mere statement, in the absence of various contradictory properties such as knowability, impermanence, multiplicity, etc., which are intended to be negated.

analyzed: cetyam ca ajñānam ātmani dṛṣṭam iṣṭam ca bhavatām
translated: And the object of consciousness is seen and desired by you as ignorance in the self.

original: api cāsyā iti ṣaṣṭhyānubhūteḥ saṃbandhamabhidhāya nirdharmatvaṃ pratijñāyamānaṃ vandhyātvamiva jananyā viruddhārthamāpadyeta /
analyzed: api ca asyāḥ iti ṣaṣṭhyā anubhūteḥ saṃbandham abhidhāya nirdharma tvam pratijñāyamānam vandhyā tvam iva jananyā viruddha artham āpadyeta
translated: Moreover, the promise of the absence of properties, after stating the relation of the sixth case of this to the experienced, would result in a contradictory meaning, like the barrenness of a mother.

analyzed: prāṇa ātma vāde deha ātma vāda dūṣaṇa jātam atidiśan āha nirastaḥ iti
translated: Referring to the class of refutations of the doctrine of the self being the vital breath, he says refuted.

original: anirasto 'dūṣito hi pratipakṣitayāvasthitaḥ prāṇātmavādaḥ nirāsakayuktayantarāpādana prayojakībhāvamāpadyeta /
analyzed: a nirastaḥ dūṣitaḥ hi pratipakṣi tayā avasthitaḥ prāṇa ātma vādaḥ prayojakībhāvam āpadyeta
translated: For the doctrine of the self being the vital breath, which is not refuted, i.e., not criticized, but remains opposed, would result in the absence of the need for the statement of further reasons for refutation.

original: na tu dehātmavādadūṣaṇaireva dūṣito 'satprāya iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: na tu deha ātma vāda dūṣaṇaiḥ eva sat prāyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the doctrine of the self being the body, which is criticized by the very refutations of the self being the body, becomes mostly false. This is the idea.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ gati anupapattim pariharati avibhu tvena i ti
translated: He answers the objection that the self cannot move by saying because of non-omnipresence.

analyzed: vibhu tve gatiḥ na upapadyeta iti yuktam
translated: It is proper to say that movement is not possible if it is omnipresent.

original: aṇutve tu manasa iva niḥsparśasyāpi gatirātmana upapadyata eva /
analyzed: aṇu tve tu manasaḥ iva niḥsparśasya api gatiḥ ātmanaḥ upapadyate eva
translated: But if the soul is atomic, like the mind, motion is possible even for the intangible soul.

original: na ca sparśasya gatau hetutvaṃ prayatnādṛṣṭādipreraṇamantareti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na ca sparśasya gatau hetu tvam prayatna adṛṣṭa ādi preraṇam antarā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the idea is that touch does not have the nature of a cause in motion, in the absence of impulsion by effort, unseen [forces], etc.

analyzed: parimāṇe ti
translated: In size.

original: etadātmano gatimattvamātmanaḥ parimāṇanirūpaṇaprakaraṇe 'pi nirūpitaṃ bhaviṣyatīti adhunaitāvatā gatimattvavarṇanenālamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: etat ātmanaḥ gatimat tvam ātmanaḥ parimāṇa nirūpaṇa prakaraṇe nirūpitam bhaviṣyati iti adhunā etāvatā gatimat tva varṇanena alam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this motion of the soul will be determined in the section on determining the size of the soul, so it is enough with just this much description of motion now.

analyzed: alam amunā iti pāṭha antaram
translated: The alternative reading is enough with this.

original: atra saṃvidātmavādī samuttiṣṭhate bhavatu tarhī ti /
analyzed: atra saṃvid ātma vādī samuttiṣṭhate bhavatu tarhi iti
translated: Here, the proponent of the consciousness-soul rises up, saying Let it be so, then.

analyzed: saṃvid ātmā
translated: The consciousness-soul.

analyzed: a jaḍa tvāt iti prayogaḥ
translated: The argument is because of non-dullness.

analyzed: vyatireka vyāptim āha jaḍa tve ti
translated: He states the pervasion by contraposition: If it were dull, etc.

analyzed: pratibaddham vyāpyam  anātmyam anātma tvam
translated: The pervaded is restricted.🔽Non-soulness is non-selfhood.

original: ātmano bhāva ātmyaṃ tasyābhāva iti vyutpatteḥ /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ bhāvaḥ ātmyam tasya abhāvaḥ iti vyutpatteḥ
translated: The derivation is that soulness is the existence of the soul, and the absence of that is non-soulness.

analyzed: vyatireka upanaya nigamane āha jaḍa tvam ca iti
translated: He states the conclusion by way of contraposition and pervasion: If it were dull, etc.

analyzed: tat api anātmyam api
translated: That also means non-soulness.

original: vyāpakanivṛttervyāpyanivṛttyākṣepakatvāt vyāpaka jaḍatvanivṛttyā vyāpyānātmyanivṛttiḥ siddhyatīti bhāvaḥ /
translated: Because the cessation of the pervader implies the cessation of the pervaded, the cessation of non-soulness is established by the cessation of the pervader dullness. This is the idea.

analyzed: ajaḍa tva hetoḥ asiddhim pariharati ajaḍa tvam ca iti
translated: To avoid the fallacy of the reason being unestablished due to not being non-dull, he says non-dullness and so on.

analyzed: sva sattā mātrataḥ prakāśamāna tvāt para āyatta prakāśa tva lakṣaṇa jaḍa tva abhāvaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is non-dullness, which is characterized by not being dependent on another for manifestation, because it manifests by its own mere existence.

analyzed: nahi ti
translated: For it is not and so on.

analyzed: jaḍā iti yāvat
translated: Dependent on another for establishment means dependent on another for manifestation.🔽That is, non-dull, is what is meant.

original: atra saṃvidanumeyatvavādināṃ bhāṭṭānāṃ matamanuvadati syānmatam iti /
analyzed: atra saṃvid anumeya tva vādinām bhāṭṭānām matam anuvadati syāt matam iti
translated: Here, he presents the view of the Bhattas, who maintain that consciousness is to be inferred, with It may be argued and so on.

analyzed: viṣaya mātram iti
translated: Mere object means:

original: na hi nīlo 'yaṃ ghaṭa iti jñāne jñānasya viṣayatvaṃ saṃbhavati paṭāderiveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na hi nīlaḥ yam ghaṭaḥ iti jñāne jñānasya viṣaya tvam saṃbhavati paṭa ādeḥ iva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: For in the cognition this is a blue pot, the objectness of cognition is not possible, as it is for a cloth and so on. This is the meaning.

original: nanu ghaṭamahaṃ jānāmīti jñānaprakāśastarhi katham / tatrāha
analyzed: nanu ghaṭam aham jānāmi iti jñāna prakāśaḥ tarhi katham tatra āha
translated: But then, how is the manifestation of cognition in I know the pot? To that he says

analyzed: tatas ca iti tatas paścāt ca iti anvayaḥ
translated: and then and so on. And then is to be construed.

analyzed: castu arthe
translated: Cha has the meaning of tu.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ jñānādviṣaye jñātatā nāma dharmo jāyate /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ jñānāt viṣaye jñātatā nāma dharmaḥ jāyate
translated: The meaning is this: from cognition, a property called knownness arises in the object.

analyzed: saḥ eva prakāśaḥ iti ucyate
translated: That itself is called manifestation.

analyzed: saḥ eva jñāna kṛtaḥ ṛthasya atiśayaḥ nāma
translated: That itself is the superimposition of the object created by cognition.

analyzed: sa ca pratyakṣaḥ jñātuḥ
translated: And that is directly perceived by the knower.

analyzed: tena ca artha prakāśa rūpa liṅgena ātmani tad hetum jñānam anuminoti
translated: And by that inferential mark in the form of the manifestation of the object, he infers the cognition, which is its cause, in the self.

analyzed: ānumānika jñāna ālambanaḥ ca ghaṭam aham jānāmi iti nirukta pratyayaḥ
translated: And the cognition expressed in the form I know the pot has inference as its object.

original: anumānaprakāraśca iyaṃ ghaṭatvaprakārakajñātatā ghaṭatvaprakārakajñānajanyā tathā vidhajñātatātvāditi /🔽taddharmaprakārakajñānajñātatayoḥ
analyzed: anumāna prakāraḥ ca iyam ghaṭa tva prakāraka jñāta tā ghaṭa tva prakāraka jñāna janyā tathāvidha jñāta tā tvāt iti  tad dharma prakāraka jñāna jñāta tayoḥ
translated: And the mode of inference is: this knownness having the form of potness is produced by the cognition having the form of potness, because it is such knownness.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt ca vyāpti siddhiḥ
translated: And the relation of invariable concomitance is established by the relation of cause and effect between the knownness consisting in the cognition of the property of that [potness] and the cognition.

analyzed: etat bhāṭṭa matam pratikṣipati tat na iti
translated: He rejects this view of the Bhatta school with That is not so.

analyzed: jñāne ti
translated: In cognition means:

analyzed: jñāna viṣaya tā hi jñāta tā
translated: For knownness is the object of cognition.

analyzed: tad viṣaya tayā artha saṃbaddha jñāna vyatirikta tayā viṣaya dharmasya atiśaya viśeṣasya asiddhiḥ
translated: And because of the absence of any other object connected with the object, the property of the object, a special excess, is not established.

analyzed: mama ghaṭa jñānam jātam
translated: My cognition of the pot has arisen.

analyzed: jñātaḥ mayā ghaṭaḥ iti pratītyoḥ dharmi dharma bhāva vyatyāsam antarā artha bhedasya an ānubhāvika tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The pot is known by me. The difference in meaning, which is merely the reversal of the relation of property and possessor of the property between these two cognitions, is not experienced. This is the idea.

analyzed: pratyakṣa asiddhim uktvā jñāta tā rūpa atirikta prakāśe kalpanā siddhim āha ubhaye ti
translated: Having stated the non-establishment of perception, he states the non-establishment of the postulation of a manifestation other than knownness in the form of Both [means] both the cognition and the object.

analyzed: jñāna viṣaya tayā eva arthe jñāta vyavahāra upapatteḥ tad anupapatti lakṣaṇam jñāta tāyām atiriktāyām kalpakam asiddham iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the definition of the existence of knowledge, which is the non-apprehension of the object, is not established if knowledge is imagined to be something different from the object being known by the cognition.

original: arthajñāneṣu jñānasya jñāturahamarthasyātmanaśca niyataṃ bhānamiti prābhākaraprakriyayā samarthayati vittī ti /
analyzed: artha jñāneṣu jñānasya jñātuḥ ahamarthasya ātmanaḥ ca niyatam bhānam iti prābhākara prakriyayā samarthayati vittī ti
translated: By the Prabhākara procedure, the cognition is definitely manifested in the cognitions of the object, in the cognition, and in the self which is the object of the notion of 'I'. He establishes this with the word 'vitti'.

original: jñānajñātranavagāhinyāṃ jñeyapratītāvupagatāyāṃ jāte 'pi ghaṭajñāne 'haṃ tajjñānavān na veti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: jñāna jñātṛ anavagāhinyām jñeya pratītau upagatāyām jāte ghaṭa jñāne ham tad jñānavān na vā iti saṃśayaḥ
translated: When there is apprehension of the object which does not go into the cognition and the cognizer, even though there is cognition of the pot, there may be doubt as to whether I am possessed of that cognition or not.

analyzed: tad jñāna abhāvavān aham ityādi viparīta niścayaḥ ca kadācid bhavet
translated: And there may be a contrary ascertainment at some time that I am not possessed of that cognition, and so on.

analyzed: svasya jñānavat tvena apratibhāsāt
translated: Because one's own self does not appear as possessed of cognition.

analyzed: tat tritaya viṣayaka tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the cognition should be taken as having the triad as its object.

original: tathāca svaprakāśatvasiddherjñānasya tata eva viṣayavyavahāravat jñātatāvyavahāro 'pi ghaṭata iti nārthāntarajñātatākalpanāvasara iti hārdam
analyzed: tathā ca sva prakāśa tva siddheḥ jñānasya tatas eva viṣaya vyavahāra vat jñāta tā vyavahāraḥ pi ghaṭate iti na artha antara jñāta tā kalpanā avasaraḥ iti hārdam
translated: And thus, since the self-luminousness of cognition is established, the notion of the existence of knowledge is also possible just from that, like the notion of the object. So there is no occasion to imagine the existence of knowledge as something different from the object. This is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: atha atīta anāgateṣu artheṣu jñāta tāyāḥ utpatti asaṃbhavāt tatra jñānena eva jñāta tā pratītiḥ upapādyā
translated: Now, since the production of the state of being known with regard to past and future objects is impossible, the cognition of the state of being known must be established by the cognition itself.

original: samaiva ceyaṃ rītiḥ pratyakṣe 'pītyāśayenā'ha atīte ti /
analyzed: samā eva ca iyam rītiḥ pratyakṣe pi iti āśayena āha atīte ti
translated: And this method is the same even in the case of perception. With this idea in mind, he says with regard to past and future objects.

analyzed: atra grahaṇam anumāna ādi lakṣaṇam
translated: Here, apprehension refers to the definition of inference, etc.

analyzed: vyāhāraḥ śabdaḥ vyavahāraḥ
translated: Usage refers to words, and conduct refers to verbal communication.

analyzed: vyavahāraḥ kāyikaḥ hāna upādāna ādiḥ
translated: Conduct refers to bodily actions such as giving up and taking up.

analyzed: ubhau vidita tva pratīti mūlau atra grāhyau
translated: Both of these should be understood here as having the state of being known as their root.

original: viditapratītimūlayostayoḥ sadbhāve 'sadbhāve vā viditatvavyavahārātpūrvameva viditatvapratītestanmūlabhūtāyā udaya iti na tatra vyāhāraliṅgena 🔽viditatvamanumāya tato vedanānumā
analyzed: vidita pratīti mūlayoḥ tayoḥ sadbhāve sadbhāve vā vidita tva vyavahārāt pūrvam eva vidita tva pratīteḥ tad mūla bhūtāyāḥ udaye iti na tatra vyāhāra liṅgena  vidita tvam anumāya tatas vedanā anumā
translated: When those two have the state of being known as their root, or when they do not, the state of being known is known even before the conduct of the state of being known. Therefore, the state of being known, which is the root of that, arises. Thus, the state of being known is not inferred by the mark of conduct there,

original: nam / kintu svayaṃprakāśavedanabalādeva viditatvapratītiḥ atha ca tanmūlavyavahāra iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kintu svayam prakāśa vedana balāt eva vidita tva pratītiḥ atha ca tad mūla vyavahāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: and then feeling is inferred from that. Rather, the state of being known is known by the power of self-luminous feeling itself, and then conduct has that as its root. This is the idea.

analyzed: ānumānikī tatra
translated: The establishment of the object there is

analyzed: viṣaya siddhiḥ iti kvacid pāṭhe yam arthaḥ viṣayasya siddhiḥ prakāśa rūpa anumāna pramāṇa pratipannā iti
translated: by inference. In some readings, this is the meaning: the establishment of the object is by inference in the form of manifestation.

original: viṣayaprakāśasiddhi riti pāṭhe tu anumānapramāṇajanitā viṣayaprakāśānumitirityarthaḥ /
analyzed: viṣaya prakāśa siddhiḥ iti pāṭhe tu anumāna pramāṇa janitā viṣaya prakāśa anumitiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: If the reading is proof of the manifestation of the object, then the meaning is that the manifestation of the object is inferred from the inferential means of knowledge.

original: vyavahārātpūrvameva jñātatvapratītiṃ smṛtisthale udāharati kenaci diti /
analyzed: vyavahārāt pūrvam eva jñāta tva pratītim smṛti sthale udāharati kenacid iti
translated: He cites the cognition of being known even before the usage in the case of memory, saying by someone.

original: smaraṇenaivārthasya smṛtatvamavabuddhya vyāharati smṛtamadya maye ti /
analyzed: smaraṇena eva arthasya smṛta tvam avabuddhya vyāharati smṛtam adya maye ti
translated: He speaks of the object being remembered only through memory, saying I remembered it today.

analyzed: yadi laiṅgikī smṛta tva pratītiḥ
translated: If the cognition of being remembered is inferential.

original: tarhyanenaiva vyāhāreṇa liṅgena svasyārthe smṛtatvapratītirānumānikīti vācyam /
analyzed: tarhi anena eva vyāhāreṇa liṅgena svasya arthe smṛta tva pratītiḥ ānumānikī iti vācyam
translated: Then it must be said that the cognition of being remembered in one's own object is inferential from this very statement, which is the inferential mark.

analyzed: tatra ca anyonya āśrayaṇam prasajyate
translated: And in that case, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: smṛta tva pratītyā tad vyavahāraḥ
translated: The usage is due to the cognition of being remembered.

analyzed: tena eva ca sā svasya iti
translated: And that itself is in one's own self.

analyzed: tathā ca jñāna sva prakāśa tva nibandhanā eva jñāta tva pratītiḥ eṣṭavyā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the idea is that the cognition of being known should be accepted to be based on the self-luminosity of knowledge.

analyzed: sva vyāhāreṇa eva iti
translated: By one's own statement means

analyzed: nirapatrapaḥ iva kaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: Who is shameless like this? is the continuation.

analyzed: nirapatrapaḥ nirlajjaḥ  sva vyāhāreṇa aham  jānāmi iti sva niṣṭha jñāna vyavahāreṇa
translated: Shameless means without shame.🔽By one's own statement means by the statement of one's own knowledge, I know.

analyzed: sva jñāna anumānam sva niṣṭha jñāna pratītim laiṅgikīm
translated: The inference of one's own knowledge is the inferential cognition of one's own knowledge.

original: vyavahāre vyavahartavyajñānasya hetutvāt svakīyajñānavyavahāreṇaiva svasya svakīyajñānānumānamiti pratijñānupapannātyantamiti yāvat /
analyzed: vyavahāre vyavahartavya jñānasya hetu tvāt svakīya jñāna vyavahāreṇa eva svasya svakīya jñāna anumānam iti pratijñā anupapanna atyantam iti yāvat
translated: Because it is the cause of the knowledge that should be engaged in in conventional usage, the inference of one's own knowledge is only by one's own conventional usage of knowledge. Thus, the proposition is not established at all.

original: parakīyena parātmano jñānavyavahāreṇa tadanyasya parātmaniṣṭhajñānānumānasaṃbhavāt svavyāhāreṇa svajñānānumānam iti nirdiṣṭam /
analyzed: parakīyena para ātmanaḥ jñāna vyavahāreṇa tad anyasya para ātma niṣṭha jñāna anumāna saṃbhavāt sva vyāhāreṇa sva jñāna anumānam iti nirdiṣṭam
translated: Since the inference of the knowledge belonging to another person by the conventional usage of knowledge belonging to another person is possible for someone else, it is stated that the inference of one's own knowledge is by one's own conventional usage.

original: evaṃ jñātatāyā asiddhiḥ /🔽jñāta iti pratītivyavahārayoḥ svaprakāśajñānata evopapatteḥ /
analyzed: evam jñāta tāyāḥ asiddhiḥ  jñātaḥ iti pratīti vyavahārayoḥ sva prakāśa jñānataḥ eva upapatteḥ
translated: Thus, the non-establishment of knownness.🔽Because the cognition and usage of is known are logically possible only from self-luminous knowledge.

original: jñānasya svaprakāśatvaṃ cajāte jñāne svātmani jñānasaṃśayajñānābhāvaniścayānudayabalāt niśceyamiti varṇitam /
analyzed: jñānasya sva prakāśa tvam ca jāte jñāne sva ātmani jñāna saṃśaya jñāna abhāva niścaya anudaya balāt niśceyam iti varṇitam
translated: And the self-luminosity of knowledge is to be ascertained by the force of the non-arising of the ascertainment of the absence of doubt about knowledge in one's own self when knowledge arises, it is said.

original: idānīmabhyupagamyāpi viṣayaniṣṭhaṃ dharmāntaraṃ prakāśaṃ tadavaṣṭambhenaiva jñānasya svayaṃprakāśatvaṃ samarthayati prakāśānumeyajñānavādanirāsārtham
analyzed: idānīm abhyupagamya api viṣaya niṣṭham dharma antaram prakāśam tad avaṣṭambhena eva jñānasya svayaṃprakāśa tvam samarthayati prakāśa anumeya jñāna vāda nirāsa artham
translated: Now, even accepting the manifestation which is another property belonging to the object, he proves the self-luminosity of knowledge only by its support, in order to refute the doctrine that knowledge is to be inferred from manifestation.

analyzed: anyaḥ ca ityādinā
translated: With and if it is different... and so on.

original: atra prayogadvayamanubhūtirananyādhīnataddharmā svasaṃbandhādarthāntare taddharmahetutvāt yathā rūpam /🔽taddhi svasaṃbandhāddhāṭādau cākṣuṣatve hetuḥ svasmin rūpāntarānapekṣataddharmavat /
analyzed: atra prayoga dvayam anubhūtiḥ ananya adhīna tad dharmā sva saṃbandhāt artha antare tad dharma hetu tvāt yathā rūpam  tat hi sva saṃbandhāt hāṭa ādau cākṣuṣa tve hetuḥ svasmin rūpa antara anapekṣa tad dharma vat
translated: Here are the two arguments: Experience is not dependent on another for its property, because it is the cause of that property in another thing through its connection with itself, just as color is.🔽For that is the cause of visual perception in a pot, etc., through its connection with itself, like color, which does not depend on another color in itself.

analyzed: anubhūtiḥ ananya adhīna sva vyavahārā sva saṃbandhāt artha antare vyavahāra hetu tvāt
translated: Experience is not dependent on another for its own expression, because it is the cause of expression in another thing through its connection with itself.

original: yathā sattā /🔽sā hi svasaṃbandhāddhaṭādau saditi vyavahārahetuḥ svīyasadvyavahāre sattāntarā
analyzed: yathā sattā  sā hi sva saṃbandhāt dhaṭa ādau sat iti vyavahāra hetuḥ svīya sat vyavahāre sattā antarā
translated: Just as existence.

analyzed: napekṣāḥ iti
translated: For that is the cause of the expression existent in a pot, etc., through its connection with itself, not depending on another existence in its own expression of existence.

analyzed: ādyaḥ jñātatā rūpam dharma antaram abhyupetya
translated: The first argument here is based on the acceptance of a different property in the form of cognition.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu tad anupagamena
translated: The second is without that acceptance.
The extraction of the reason and the conclusion should be understood from the Śrutaprakāśikā, etc.

analyzed: anena jñāna niṣṭha prakāśasya jñāna antara anapekṣa tva siddhyā jñānasya svayaṃprakāśa tva upapattiḥ
translated: By establishing the independence of the light which is based on cognition from another cognition through this, the self-luminosity of cognition is justified.

analyzed: tathā ca tasya eva ātma tvam iti āha svayam prakāśa tvāt iti
translated: And thus, that itself is the self, he says, because of self-luminosity.

original: atredamākūtamātmanaḥ svayaṃprakāśatvaṃ tāvat atrāyaṃ puruṣaḥ svayañjyotirbhavatī tyādiśrutisiddham /
analyzed: atrā idam ākūtam ātmanaḥ svayam prakāśa tvam tāvat atra ayam puruṣaḥ svayan jyotiḥ bhavati ityādi śruti siddham
translated: Here this is the idea: First, the self's own-illumination is established by scriptures such as Here this person becomes his own light.

analyzed: jñānasya svayam prakāśa tvam ca nirukta anumānataḥ
translated: And the self-illumination of knowledge is established by the previously stated inference.

original: atastasyaivātmatvaṃ nyāyyamiti /🔽saṃvida ātmatve lāghavamapyāha kiṃ ce ti /
analyzed: atas tasya eva ātmatvam nyāyyam iti  saṃvidaḥ ātma tve lāghavam api āha kim ca iti
translated: Therefore, it is proper that it alone is the self.🔽He also says that there is simplicity in consciousness being the self, with Moreover...

analyzed: veditrī jñātṛ rūpāḥ ātmā iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is: the self is in the form of the experiencer and knower.

analyzed: bhavatu iti kāmacāra abhyanujñāyām
translated: Let it be so is in the optative mood, meaning permission to act as one wishes.

original: itipadamanuṣañjanīyam /🔽saṃvida eva prakāmamātmatvamityabhyanujñānaṃ śreṣṭhamityarthaḥ /🔽saṃvida ātmatve bādhakamāśaṅkate nanvaham iti /
analyzed: iti padam anuṣañjanīyam  saṃvidaḥ eva prakāmam ātma tvam iti abhyanujñānam śreṣṭham iti arthaḥ  saṃvidaḥ ātma tve bādhakam āśaṅkate nanu aham iti
translated: The word iti is to be supplied.🔽The meaning is: the permission that consciousness alone is the self is best.🔽He raises a doubt that consciousness being the self is contradicted, with But...

analyzed: prādhānyāt ahamarthasya eva ātma tvam pratīyate
translated: The meaning is: because of its predominance, the meaning of I is understood to be the self,

original: natu dharmatayā bhāsamānāyāḥ saṃvida iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na tu dharma tayā bhāsamānāyāḥ saṃvidaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: but not consciousness, which appears as a property.

analyzed: ardha aṅgīkāreṇa pariharati satyam iti
translated: He replies by partially accepting, with True...

analyzed: jñātṛ tva pratītau upagamaḥ
translated: He accepts the appearance of the knower,

analyzed: tad prāmāṇye n upagamaḥ
translated: but does not accept its validity.

analyzed: tad aprāmāṇye hetum āha sa tu iti
translated: He gives a reason for its invalidity, with But...

analyzed: jñātā tu bheda rūpa tayā na sākṣāt pratyakṣa pramāṇa siddhaḥ
translated: The knower, however, is not directly established by perception as having the form of difference.

analyzed: kintu bhrānti siddhaḥ  sva lakṣaṇa vastu mātra avagāhi nirvikalpakam eva hi pramāṇam
translated: But it is established by error.🔽For only indeterminate cognition, which penetrates only the particular thing, is a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: dharma dharmi bhāva ādi kalpita bheda avagāhi sa vikalpakam tu  bhrama lakṣaṇam ati hārdam
translated: But determinate cognition, which penetrates the difference imagined as the relation of attribute and substratum, etc.,🔽is indeed a mistake, as is well known.

analyzed: jñātṛ bheda pratīteḥ yauktika bādham api āha bheda jñāne ti  siddhavatkāreṇa iti asya agre pi iti yojyam
translated: He says that there is also logical contradiction in the cognition of difference in the words in the cognition of difference.🔽As if it were established should be connected with even later.

analyzed: apṛthak vastutaye ti pāṭhaḥ saṃbhāvyate
translated: The reading for the sake of non-distinct entities is possible.

analyzed: vā aprakāśa ātmanaḥ iti padacchedaḥ  tathā ca ayam arthaḥ bheda jñāna siddhavatkāreṇa api kvacid bheda jñānasya prāmāṇya upagamena api
translated: Or the word of non-manifest nature is to be divided.🔽And the meaning is this: Even by accepting the validity of the cognition of difference in some cases as if it were established,

analyzed: saṃvedanānām bhedasya saugataiḥ tattvataḥ iṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: because the difference of cognitions is accepted as real by the Buddhists.

analyzed: apṛthak vastu tayā abhinna vastu tvena sādhyena  gṛhīta avyabhicāreṇa gṛhīta vyāptikena
translated: By the probandum of being non-distinct entities, i.e., having an undifferentiated entity.🔽By the invariable concomitance grasped, i.e., by the invariable concomitance grasped.

analyzed: saha upalambha niyamena jñāna jñātroḥ mahā upambha niyama rūpa hetunā
translated: By the rule of the simultaneous apprehension of cognition and cognizer, i.e., by the reason in the form of the rule of simultaneous apprehension.

analyzed: jñātuḥ aprakāśa svabhāva tve prakāśa ayogaḥ svabhāva virodhāt eva
translated: If the cognizer has a nature of non-manifestation, there is an impossibility of manifestation due to contradiction with its nature itself.

original: prakāśasvabhāvatve ca saṃvedanatvamevetyādinā vā saṃvidabhedasādhakena saṃvidbhedavādhakena
analyzed: prakāśa svabhāva tve ca saṃvedana tvam eva ityādinā vā saṃvid abheda sādhakena saṃvid bheda vādhakena
translated: And in the case of being of the nature of light, by the reason proving the non-difference of consciousness, which refutes the difference of consciousness,

original: hetunā aprakāśātmanaḥ saṃvidbhinnasya jñāturahamarthasyātmanaḥ tattvaṃsvarūpaṃ durupagamamupagantumaśakyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: hetunā aprakāśa ātmanaḥ saṃvid bhinnasya jñātuḥ ahamarthasya ātmanaḥ tattvam svarūpam durupagamam upagantum aśakyam iti arthaḥ
translated: it is said that the true nature of the self, the object of the notion of I, which is of the nature of non-light and different from consciousness, is difficult to accept, meaning it is impossible to accept.

analyzed: tṛtīya anta dvayam durupagamam iti anena anvitam
translated: The two words ending in the third case are connected with difficult to accept.

original: jñātā saṃvidabhinnaḥ saṃvidā sahaivopalabhyamānatvāt prakāśasvabhāvatvādvā iti prayogo 'tra bodhyaḥ /
analyzed: jñātā saṃvid abhinnaḥ saṃvidā saha eva upalabhyamāna tvāt prakāśa svabhāva tvāt vā iti prayogaḥ tra bodhyaḥ
translated: Here it should be understood that the argument is: the knower is non-different from consciousness, because it is perceived along with consciousness, or because it is of the nature of light.

analyzed: yat vā pṛthak vastuta yena tvāt syāt pāṭhaḥ
translated: Or, the reading could be because of being a separate entity.

analyzed: avyabhicāra nirūpakasya abheda rūpa sādhyasya upasthitiḥ tu arthāt
translated: The presence of the invariable indicator, which is the probandum in the form of non-difference, is understood by implication.

analyzed: prakāśa ātmanaḥ iti eva ca astu padacchedaḥ
translated: And the word-division should be of the nature of light itself.

original: sahopalambhaniyamena /🔽prakāśasvābhāvye ca saṃvedanatvamityādinā vā hetunā prakāśātmanaḥ saṃvidabhinnasya siddhyata ātmanaḥ /
analyzed: saha upalambha niyamena  prakāśa svābhāvye ca saṃvedana tvam ityādinā vā hetunā prakāśa ātmanaḥ saṃvid abhinnasya siddhyataḥ ātmanaḥ
translated: By the rule of being necessarily perceived together.🔽And in the case of being of the nature of light, by the reason being of the nature of consciousness, etc., the self, which is of the nature of light and non-different from consciousness, is established.
By accepting it as if the validity of the cognition of difference were established, as if the validity of the cognition of difference were established.
The existence of the object as distinct from consciousness is not tenable.

analyzed: durupagamam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is difficult to accept.

analyzed: niruk prakāram grāhaka bheda nirāsa hetum grāhya bheda nirāse pi atidiśati grāhye ti
translated: He extends the reason for the denial of the difference of the apprehender to the denial of the difference of the apprehended, saying in the case of the apprehended.

original: sahopalambhaniyamāt prakāśasvabhāvye ca saṃvedanatvamityādito vā saṃvidabhinnatvaṃ nīlāderviṣayasyeti jñānabhinnatvena nīlādyarthabhedasyāpyasattvamityarthaḥ
analyzed: saha upalambha niyamāt prakāśa svabhāvye ca saṃvedana tvam iti āditaḥ vā saṃvid abhinna tvam nīla ādeḥ viṣayasya iti jñāna bhinna tvena nīla ādi artha bhedasya api asattvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The object such as blue is not different from consciousness because of the rule of simultaneous perception, and because of the nature of manifestation, and because of the nature of being experienced, and so on. The meaning is that the difference of the object such as blue as different from consciousness is also non-existent.

original: nanu grāhyagrāhakayoḥ saṃvidabhede jñātṛjñeyabhedānāṃ jñānatobhedenāvabhāsaḥ kathamityatrāha ata iti /
analyzed: nanu grāhya grāhakayoḥ saṃvid abhede jñātṛ jñeya bhedānām jñānataḥ bhedena avabhāsaḥ katham iti atra āha atas iti
translated: But if the apprehended and the apprehender are not different from consciousness, how is the appearance of the difference of the knower and the known as different from knowledge? To this he says for this reason.

analyzed: mithyā
translated: The appearance of the difference of the apprehended and the apprehender, which is based on a fault, is false.

analyzed: saṃvid ābhāsa mātram satyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the appearance of consciousness alone is true.

original: tatra vāsanā doṣa iti prakaṭānāṃ saugatānāṃ yogācārāṇāṃ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: tatra vāsanā doṣaḥ iti prakaṭānām saugatānām yoga ācārāṇām pakṣaḥ
translated: Among them, the view of the manifest Sautrāntikas, Yogācārins, is that the fault is the latent impressions.

analyzed: anādya vidyā doṣaḥ iti pracchannānām māyā vādinām
translated: The view of the concealed Mādhyamikas, proponents of illusion, is that the fault is beginningless ignorance.

The conceptualization of the apprehended and the apprehender, the difference of the known and the knower, characterized by the nature of being the object of knowledge and the substratum of knowledge, is the fault.

original: uktārthe prakaṭānāṃ saugatānāṃ saṃmatiṃ pradarśayati avibhogo 'pī ti /
analyzed: ukta arthe prakaṭānām saugatānām saṃmatim pradarśayati avibhogaḥ ti
translated: He shows the agreement of the manifest Buddhists on the meaning stated with Even the indivisible...

analyzed: buddhiḥ eva ātmā
translated: The intellect itself is the self.

original: sā ca nirbhedāpi bhrāntijñānaiḥ nīlabhedādigrāhyabhedacaitramaitrādigrāhaka bheda pratyakṣatvānumānatvādilakṣaṇajñānabhedavatīva pratīyata
analyzed: sā ca nirbhedā api bhrānti jñānaiḥ nīla bheda ādi grāhya bheda caitra maitra ādi grāhaka bheda pratyakṣa tva anumāna tva ādi lakṣaṇa jñāna bhedavatī iva pratīyata
translated: And that, although indivisible, is cognized as having the difference of the knowledge of error, such as the difference of blue, etc., the difference of the apprehender of Caitra, Maitra, etc., and the difference of the knowledge characterized by perception, inference, etc.

analyzed: iti kārikā arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the verse.

analyzed: māyinām saṃmatim upadarśayati śuddham iti
translated: He shows the agreement of the Mādhyamikas with Pure...

analyzed: bheda prapañcasya śuddham tattvam na upādānam
translated: The pure reality of the manifold world is not its material cause.

analyzed: tathā sati paramārtha tva āpattyā anivṛtti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were so, it would follow that it would not cease, since it would become ultimate.

analyzed: tatas tasya prapañcasya māyā eva vividha vicitra mithyā artha pratibhāsa hetuḥ mithyā bhū
translated: Therefore, the māyā itself of that world, the cause of the appearance of various diverse false objects, is the false

analyzed: tān ādya vidyā eva jananī upādānam iti kārikā arthaḥ
translated: mother, the beginningless ignorance itself, the material cause. This is the meaning of the verse.

analyzed: nirviśeṣa sanmātram cit rūpam paramārthaḥ
translated: The ultimate is the consciousness-form, which is pure existence alone, without distinctions.

analyzed: tatra adhiṣṭhāne aparamārtha nānā bheda pratibhāsaḥ māyayā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the appearance of various distinctions, which are not ultimate, is due to māyā in that substratum.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ svayam prakāśa tvam śrautam
translated: The self's self-luminousness is taught in the scriptures.

analyzed: saṃvidaḥ tathātvam ca yukti siddham
translated: And the consciousness's suchness is established by reasoning.

analyzed: tat tasyāḥ eva ātma tvam
translated: That is the very nature of consciousness itself.

original: tadbhinnasya tu sarvasya doṣamūlatvādābhāsamātratvamiti saṃvidātmatvaṃ pūrvapakṣitam /
analyzed: tad bhinnasya tu sarvasya doṣa mūla tvāt ābhāsa mātra tvam iti saṃvid ātma tvam pūrvapakṣitam
translated: But everything different from that is mere appearance, because it is rooted in error. Thus, the view that consciousness is the self has been presented.

analyzed: tatra ca asti mata dvayam
translated: And there are two opinions on this:

analyzed: kṣaṇika vijñānam ātmā
translated: The momentary consciousness is the self.

analyzed: nitya vijñānam ātmā iti ca
translated: And the eternal consciousness is the self.

original: tatra kṣaṇikavijñānātmatvamataṃ prakaṭasaugatānāṃ tāvannirasyati atrā'he tyādinā /
analyzed: tatra kṣaṇika vijñāna ātma tva matam prakaṭa saugatānām tāvat nirasyati atra āhe tyādinā
translated: Among them, the view that the momentary consciousness is the self is first refuted by the clear Buddhists, with the words Here it is said... and so on.

analyzed: nitya ātma vāda īkṣaṇika vijñāna ātma vāde dūṣaṇam āha iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the proponent of the eternal self states the fault in the view that the momentary consciousness is the self.

analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅginī ti
translated: Momentary means

analyzed: kṣaṇa rūpa avināśa svabhāvā viṣaya bhedena nānā ca saṃvid upalabhyate
translated: Consciousness, which has the nature of being momentary and imperishable, is perceived to be different due to the difference in objects.

analyzed: tasyāḥ ced ātma tvam pratyabhijñā ādikam na upapadyate
translated: And if that is the self, recognition and so on are not possible.

analyzed: anusandhātuḥ ātmanaḥ sthira tve eva tad upapatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that that is possible only if the self, which is the connector, is permanent.

original: atha pratibhāyā iva nirviṣayatvaṃ pratyabhijñāyāḥ śaṅkate na ca nirālambane ti /
analyzed: atha pratibhāyāḥ iva nirviṣaya tvam pratyabhijñāyāḥ śaṅkate na ca nirālambane ti
translated: Now, he doubts that recognition, like an illusion, is without an object, with And recognition is not without an object...

analyzed: pratyabhijñā nirviṣayā pratibhā tvāt mānasa kalpanā vilāsa vat iti prayogaḥ
translated: The argument is: Recognition is without an object, because it is an illusion, like the play of mental imagination.

analyzed: atra bādhita tvam āha nirālambana tve ti
translated: Here, he states the contradiction with If it is without an object...

original: jñānasāmānyasya saviṣayakatvaniyamānnirviṣayakatve jñānatvāyogāt jñānaviśeṣe nirviṣayakatvasādhanaṃ bādhitaviṣayamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: jñāna sāmānyasya sa viṣayaka tva niyamāt nirviṣayaka tve jñāna tva ayogāt jñāna viśeṣe nirviṣayaka tva sādhanam bādhita viṣayam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the proof of the absence of an object in a particular kind of knowledge is contradicted, because knowledge in general must have an object, and if it were without an object, it could not be knowledge.

analyzed: pratibhāyām api na atyantāya nirviṣaya tvam
translated: Even in intuition, there is not absolute absence of an object.

analyzed: anyatra sataḥ eva anyatra bhānāt
translated: Because what exists elsewhere appears elsewhere.

analyzed: kvacid yāthārthyasya api dṛṣṭeḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that somewhere, even the correspondence with reality is seen.

original: jñānasāmānyasya nirviṣayakatvamiti pakṣe svapravṛttivyāghātamapyāha sādhanasya ce ti /
analyzed: jñāna sāmānyasya nirviṣayaka tvam iti pakṣe sva pravṛtti vyāghātam api āha sādhanasya ca iti
translated: In the case of the proposition that knowledge in general is without an object, he also states the contradiction with one's own engagement, saying And of the proof, etc.

analyzed: nirviṣayaka tva sādhaka anumānasya sa viṣayaka tve tad aviśeṣeṇa aśeṣa jñānānām sa viṣayaka tvam syāt
translated: If the inference proving the absence of an object has an object, then all knowledge without distinction would have an object.

original: tasya nirviṣayakatve ca na nirviṣayakatvarūpasādhyasiddhiriti sādhanārthapravṛttivaighaṭyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasya nirviṣayaka tve ca na nirviṣayaka tva rūpa sādhya siddhiḥ iti sādhana artha pravṛtti vaighaṭyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And if it were without an object, there would be no establishment of the probandum in the form of being without an object. The idea is that there would be an obstacle to engaging in the proof.

analyzed: prapañcitaḥ ca iti
translated: And it has been elaborated.

original: pūrvamīmāṃsāprathamādhyāyaprathamapāde uttaramīmāṃsādvitīyādhyāyacaraṇe ca jñānanirālambanatvamatanirākaraṇaṃ sūtratadvyākhyākartṛbhiḥ kṛtam
analyzed: pūrva mīmāṃsā prathama adhyāya prathama pāde uttara mīmāṃsā dvitīya adhyāya caraṇe ca jñāna nirālambana tva mata nirākaraṇam sūtra tad vyākhyā kartṛbhiḥ kṛtam
translated: The refutation of the doctrine of the absence of an objective support of knowledge has been done by the authors of the aphorisms and their commentaries in the first quarter of the first chapter of the Pūrva Mīmāṃsā, and in the second quarter of the second chapter of the Uttara Mīmāṃsā.

analyzed: śāstre ca nyāya tattau akhye sarva vijñāna yāthārthya samarthanena kṛtam iti arthaḥ
translated: And in the treatise, it is said that the purpose is accomplished by establishing the truth of all knowledge through the establishment of logic.

original: atra pūrvottaramīmāṃsābhāgayorityanena mīmāṃsāyā viṃśatilakṣaṇyā aikaśāstrayaṃ tatpūrvottarabhāgarūpatvaṃ ca karmabrahmavicārayorabhimatam
analyzed: atra pūrva uttara mīmāṃsā bhāgayoḥ iti anena mīmāṃsāyāḥ viṃśati lakṣaṇyāḥ aikaśāstrayam tad pūrva uttara bhāga rūpatvam ca karma brahma vicārayoḥ abhimatam
translated: Here, by the two parts of the earlier and later Mīmāṃsā, it is intended that Mīmāṃsā, which has twenty characteristics, is one treatise, and that it has the form of earlier and later parts, in the consideration of ritual and Brahman.

analyzed: nanu vijñānam dvividham pravṛtti vijñānam ālayavijñānam ca iti
translated: Now, knowledge is of two kinds: knowledge of engagement and knowledge of the storehouse.

analyzed: tatra ādyam nīla pīta ādi jñānam
translated: The first is the knowledge of blue, yellow, etc.

analyzed: antyam ca aham ākāram ātma rūpam
translated: The latter is the form of the self in the form of I.

original: kṣaṇikatve 'pyubhayavidhavijñānasyā'layavijñānadhārānuvṛttyā pratyabhijñopapadyata ityatrāha ata eve ti /🔽vijñānakṣaṇe ti /
analyzed: kṣaṇika tve pi ubhayavidha vijñānasya ālayavijñāna dhārā anuvṛttyā pratyabhijñā upapadyate iti atra āha atas eva iti  vijñāna kṣaṇe ti
translated: Even in momentariness, recognition is possible by the continuation of the stream of the knowledge of the storehouse of both kinds of knowledge. Here it is said for this very reason.🔽In the moment of knowledge means:

analyzed: vijñānam eva kṣaṇaḥ vijñāna kṣaṇaḥ
translated: The moment is the knowledge itself.

analyzed: anusandhāyinaḥ pūrva anubhūta artha pratisandhāna kartṛḥ kṣaṇika vijñāna vyatiriktasya sthirasya upagame sarvam kṣaṇikam iti siddhānta tyāgaḥ
translated: If one accepts a stable [knower] other than the momentary knowledge, which is the agent of the recollection of the previously experienced object, then one abandons the established doctrine that everything is momentary.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa jñāna vyatirikta jñātṛ abhyupaga 🔽ma prasaṅgaḥ ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And there would be the undesirable consequence of accepting a knower separate from knowledge in another way. This is the idea.

analyzed: anabhyupagamaḥ iti  kṣaṇika kramika vijñāna samudāya lakṣaṇam santānam samudāyi anatiriktam ced pratyabhijñā anupapattiḥ eva
translated: ‘Non-acceptance’ of the view that the ‘Chain’ is something different from the aggregate of momentary Cognitions.

analyzed: santāna antargatasya pūrvasya anubhavituḥ vinaṣṭa tvāt
translated: If the ‘Chain’ is held to be the aggregate of momentary Cognitions, appearing in succession, and not different from the aggregate, then Recognition becomes impossible; because the previous Cognition, which would be the ‘Chain’, would have disappeared, and the subsequent Cognition would not be the same as the previous one, and hence could not apprehend what has been apprehended by this latter.

original: uttarasya cānanubhavitṛtvena pratisandhānāyogāditi bhāvaḥ /🔽atredamanusandheyamkṣaṇikānāṃ samudāyabhāvo 'pi na ghaṭate /🔽sthiraikadeśakālādyupādhikroḍīkārāsaṃbhavāt saugate naye /🔽ekabuddhikroḍīkārastvatiprasaktaḥ /🔽bhinnasantānivijñānānāmapi tathātvena santānaniyamānupapattyāpatteḥ /
analyzed: uttarasya ca ananubhavitṛ tvena pratisandhāna ayogāt iti bhāvaḥ  atrā idam anusandheyam kṣaṇikānām samudāya bhāvaḥ na ghaṭate  sthira eka deśa kāla ādi upādhi kroḍīkāra asaṃbhavāt saugate naye  eka buddhi kroḍīkāraḥ tu ati prasaktaḥ  bhinna santāni vijñānānām api tathātvena santāna niyama anupapatti āpatteḥ
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: pūrva pūrva vijñāna upādānaka uttara uttara vijñāna paramparā santānam iti ced na 🔽vinaṣṭasya kārya kāle sataḥ upādāna tva ayogāt 🔽pūrva tva mātrasya ati prasakta tvāt ca 🔽tad santāna niyama anupapattiḥ eva iti
translated: In this connection, the following points may be considered: (1) The aggregate of momentary Cognitions cannot be right; because in the Buddhist philosophy, the ‘aggregate’ cannot be the receptacle of the ‘permanent factor’ in the shape of Space, Time, etc.; (2) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘uncognised’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘cognised’ Cognition; (3) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unrelated’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘related’ Cognition; (4) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unmanifested’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘manifested’ Cognition; (5) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unmodified’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘modified’ Cognition; (6) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unmoving’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘moving’ Cognition; (7) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unperceived’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘perceived’ Cognition; (8) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unremembered’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘remembered’ Cognition; (9) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘uncognised’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘cognised’ Cognition; (10) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unrelated’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘related’ Cognition; (11) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unmanifested’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘manifested’ Cognition; (12) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unmodified’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘modified’ Cognition; (13) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unmoving’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘moving’ Cognition; (14) the ‘aggregate’ being something ‘unperceived’, it cannot be the receptacle of the ‘perceived’ Cognition; (15) the ‘aggregate

original: nanvālayavijñānasya sausādṛśyena aikyabhrāntyā pratisandhānaṃ bhramātmakaṃ ghaṭata iti śaṅkate na ci ti /
analyzed: nanu ālayavijñānasya sausādṛśyena aikya bhrāntyā pratisandhānam bhrama ātmakam ghaṭate iti śaṅkate na ti
translated: Now, he doubts that the recognition in the form of an error is possible, thinking that the recollection of the store-consciousness is possible by the error of identity due to similarity, saying not the recognition.

original: bhrāntirūpā ca pratyabhijñā na ghaṭata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: bhrānti rūpā ca pratyabhijñā na ghaṭate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the recognition in the form of an error is not possible.

analyzed: ghaṭate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that it is possible.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta vaiṣamyam upapādayati yujyate iti
translated: He explains the inequality of the example, saying is proper.

original: dṛṣṭānte bhinnakālikadīpakalikayoḥ susadṛśayoḥ sākṣātkartā sthiraścetanaḥ prasiddho bhrāntibhāktvayogyaḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭānte bhinna kālika dīpa kalikayoḥ su sadṛśayoḥ sākṣātkartā sthiraḥ cetanaḥ prasiddhaḥ bhrānti bhāktva yogyaḥ
translated: In the example, the perceiver of the two lamp-flames, which are very similar and are at different times, is known to be stable and intelligent, and is fit to be the subject of error.

analyzed: tat tatra bhrānti rūpā pratyabhijñā ghaṭate
translated: Therefore, the recognition in the form of an error is proper there.

original: na ca tathā prakṛte saṃvidāṃ draṣṭātiriktaḥ sthiro 'bhyupeyate /
analyzed: na ca tathā prakṛte saṃvidām draṣṭā atiriktaḥ sthiraḥ bhyupeyate
translated: And in the same way, a stable [perceiver] other than consciousness is not accepted in the case of [consciousness].

analyzed: atas saṃvid eva ātmā anyena ātmanā abhedam svātmani bhāvayet iti vācyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said that consciousness itself, by another form of itself, produces the non-difference in its own self.

analyzed: paraspara vārtām abhijña tvāt na anyasmāt bhedam abhedam vā sva ātmani gṛhītum alam
translated: Because they are mutually aware of each other, it is not possible for them to grasp either difference or non-difference from another in their own self.

original: niranvayavināśācca pūrvadharmānuvṛttibalādapi pūrvānubhūtapratisandhānādi na ghaṭate iti samuditāśayaḥ /
analyzed: niranvaya vināśāt ca pūrva dharma anuvṛtti balāt api pūrva anubhūta pratisandhāna ādi na ghaṭate iti samudita āśayaḥ
translated: And because of the destruction without remainder, the continuation of the previous qualities is not possible, and therefore the recollection of what was previously experienced and so on is not possible either. This is the combined intention [of the author].
Not knowing each other's news means not being grasped by another cognition of that object.

analyzed: niranvaya vināśi tvam samūla vināśi tvam svarūpataḥ dharmataḥ ca
translated: Being destroyed without remainder means being destroyed along with the root, both in terms of its own nature and as a property.

analyzed: uttara uttara kṣaṇeṣu pūrva pūrva vijñāna kṣaṇataḥ vāsanā udayāt pratisandhāna upapattiḥ iti api na
translated: The arising of impressions from the preceding moments of consciousness in the subsequent moments explains the possibility of recollection. This is also not so.

analyzed: ananta vāsanā utpatti vināśa ādi kalpanāyām ati gauravāt iti diś
translated: Because the postulation of the arising and destruction of infinite impressions is too complicated. This is the direction.

analyzed: śiṣṭam spaṣṭam
translated: The rest is clear.

original: atra nityātmavādinā kenaciduktaṃ saṃvida āgamāpāyitvādikamamṛṣyamāṇo 'dvaitī pratyavatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: atra nitya ātma vādinā kenacid uktam saṃvidaḥ āgama apāyi tva ādikam amṛṣyamāṇaḥ dvaitī pratyavatiṣṭhate
translated: Here, someone who believes in the eternal self, unable to tolerate the coming and going of consciousness, etc., a non-dualist responds.

analyzed: tat ucyate kaścid āhe ti
translated: That is said: Someone says...

original: svasyāsattve grāhakābhāvāt svasya svattve grāhyābhāvāśca na svataḥ saṃvidaḥ prāgabhāvagrahaḥ /
analyzed: svasya asattve grāhaka abhāvāt svasya grāhya abhāvāḥ ca na svatas saṃvidaḥ prāgabhāva grahaḥ
translated: Because there is no apprehender if one's own [consciousness] does not exist, and because there is no apprehended if one's own [consciousness] does exist, the prior absence of consciousness is not grasped from itself.

analyzed: saṃvidaḥ jñāna antara agocara tvena anya jñānataḥ tad jñāna prāgabhāva grahaḥ pi na saṃbhavati
translated: If consciousness is not the object of another cognition, the prior absence of that [consciousness] cannot be grasped from another cognition either.

analyzed: jñāna viṣayīkāram antarā tad uparakta prāgabhāva grahaṇa ayogāt
translated: Because without being the object of cognition, it is not possible to grasp the prior absence that is tinged with it.

analyzed: jñāna antara gocara tve ca ghaṭa ādi vat jaḍa tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And if it is the object of another cognition, it would follow that it is inert like a pot, etc.

analyzed: tad pramāṇa abhāvāt prāgabhāvaḥ saṃvidaḥ na asti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no prior non-existence of consciousness due to the absence of its measure.

analyzed: atas iti  prāgabhāva abhāvāt utpattiḥ nā asti saṃvidaḥ
translated: For this reason.🔽Because there is no prior non-existence, there is no origination of consciousness.

analyzed: prāgabhāvasya api utpādaka antargata tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that prior non-existence is included within the producer.

analyzed: janma abhāvāt iti  itare bhāva vikārāḥ astitva vṛddhi pariṇāma apakṣaya vināśāḥ
translated: Because of the absence of origination.🔽The other modifications of existence are existence, increase, transformation, decrease, and destruction.

analyzed: astitvam atra sva upā dāna avacchinna sthiti lakṣaṇam
translated: Existence here is characterized by the presence delimited by its own conditions.

analyzed: utpatti pratibaddha tvāt tu
translated: Because it is bound to origination.

analyzed: tpatti vyāpya tvāt
translated: Because it is pervaded by origination.

analyzed: vyāpaka nivṛttyā vyāpya nivṛttiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the cessation of what is pervaded is due to the cessation of what pervades.

analyzed: atas eva iti
translated: For this very reason.

analyzed: utpatti abhāvāt eva sajātīya saṃvid bheda lakṣaṇam nānātvam api nirastam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that diversity, which is characterized by the difference of consciousness of the same kind, is also excluded due to the absence of origination alone.

analyzed: utpattimat tva vyāpake ti
translated: That which is pervaded by having origination.

analyzed: karmadhārayaḥ yam
translated: This is a karmadhāraya compound.

analyzed: vibhāgi nānā bhinnam
translated: It is different from what is divided, i.e., different.

analyzed: atra saṃvid na nānā
translated: Here, consciousness is not different.

analyzed: na api vikāravatī
translated: Nor does it have modifications.

original: ajatvādyannaivaṃ tannevaṃ yathā ghaṭa iti vyatirekiprayogaḥ /
analyzed: aja tvāt yat na evam tat na evam yathā ghaṭaḥ iti vyatireki prayogaḥ
translated: The negative vyatireka formulation is: What does not have this is not like this, like a pot.

original: saṃvidi bhedādiniṣedhe dharmapakṣakamanvayi ca pradarśayati cetyatvācce ti /
analyzed: saṃvidi bheda ādi niṣedhe dharma pakṣakam anvayi ca pradarśayati cetya tvāt ca iti
translated: In the negation of difference etc. in consciousness, he shows the anvaya formulation with respect to dharma, with because of being conscious etc.

analyzed: bheda ādayaḥ na saṃvidi anubhāvya tvāt rūpa ādi vat
translated: Difference, etc. are not experienced in consciousness, because they are like color, etc.

analyzed: atra bheda padam vikāra ātmaka utpatti ādi avasthā bheda param prakaraṇāt
translated: Here, the word difference refers to the differences in states such as change, origination, etc., as is clear from the context.

analyzed: itaretara abhāvaḥ sajātīya bhedaḥ  vijātīya svāgata bhedau ādi pada grāhyau
translated: Mutual absence is difference from things of the same class.🔽Difference from things of different classes and internal differences are to be understood from the word etc.

analyzed: yat vā bhedaḥ vijātīya bhedaḥ
translated: Or, difference is difference from things of different classes.

analyzed: itaretarābhāvaḥ yathā ukta rūpaḥ
translated: Mutual absence is of the nature described above.

analyzed: ādi pada grāhyāḥ utpatti ādi avasthāḥ svagata bhedāḥ ca
translated: Origination, etc., and internal differences are to be understood from the word etc.

analyzed: etat matam kroḍīkaroti atas iti
translated: He includes this view with therefore.

analyzed: nirasta nikhila bheda asattva prakāśa tva ādi dharma rahitā prakāśa eka svarūpā saṃvid eva avikāra nityā paramātmā jīvātmā ca
translated: Consciousness alone, which is of the nature of light devoid of all differences and non-existences such as light, etc., is the unchanging, eternal Supreme Self and individual Self.

analyzed: jīva bhedaḥ pi kalpitaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The difference among individual selves is also imagined, this is the idea.

analyzed: ukta arthe saṃvādam udāharati yā anubhūtiḥ riti
translated: He cites an agreement on the stated meaning with That experience.

analyzed: aja tvam anutpattimat tvam
translated: Immortality is non-origination.

analyzed: ameya tvam jñāna agocara tvam
translated: Incalculability is being beyond the scope of knowledge.

analyzed: ananta tvam vināśa rāhityam
translated: Boundlessness is absence of destruction.

analyzed: ātma tvam jīvātma paramātma rūpa tvam
translated: Selfhood is being of the nature of the individual Self and Supreme Self.

original: niruktarūpaikā saṃvideva sarvavyāpikā paramātmarūpopādhibhedena nānājīvātmarūpā ceti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nirukta rūpā ekā saṃvid eva sarva vyāpikā paramātma rūpa upādhi bhedena nānā jīvātma rūpā ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is one consciousness alone, of the nature of the supreme self, which is all-pervading, and which, due to the difference in limiting adjuncts in the form of the supreme self, is of the nature of many individual selves.

analyzed: sā eva ca iti
translated: And that alone is the meaning.

analyzed: na vācya śaktayā iyam vedānteṣu pratipādyate
translated: This is not taught in the Vedanta texts for the sake of expressing the inexpressible.

original: avācyaiva satī tātparyavṛttyā teṣu gamyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: avācyā eva satī tātparya vṛttyā teṣu gamyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is understood in them through the operation of the primary meaning, even though it is inexpressible.

analyzed: bhāṣā paribhāṣā
translated: Definition of language.

analyzed: saṅkete iti yāvat
translated: It means convention.

analyzed: saṅketa balāt eva śraddheya tvam etad matasya iti hārdam
translated: The heart's desire is that this doctrine should be accepted by the power of convention itself.

original: vedāntānāmevaṃbhūtāyāṃ saṃvidyeva tātparyamadvaitavārtikakāravacanena saṃvādayati parāgarthe ti /🔽ghaṭapaṭādiṣu parāgartheṣu yā pramāṇajanyām iti ḥ phalarūpeṣyate tāntrikaiḥ saiva mitirvedānteṣu prameyabhūtā /
analyzed: vedāntānām evaṃbhūtāyām saṃvidyā iva tātparyam advaita vārtikakāra vacanena saṃvādayati parāc arthe ti  ghaṭa paṭa ādiṣu parāc artheṣu yā pramāṇa janyām iti phala rūpā iṣyate tāntrikaiḥ sā eva mitiḥ vedānteṣu prameya bhūtā
translated: The author of the Advaita-makaranda agrees with the statement that the Vedanta has its purport only in such consciousness, with the words in the external object.🔽The same cognition that is accepted by the Tantrikas as having the form of the result produced by the means of knowledge in regard to external objects like pot, cloth etc., that alone is the object of knowledge in the Vedanta.

original: ito 'nyasmin parāgarthe tātparyakalpane ca vedāntānāmaprāmāṇyameva syāt /
analyzed: itas parāc arthe tātparya kalpane ca vedāntānām aprāmāṇyam eva syāt
translated: If the purport were imagined in some other external object, the Vedanta would be invalid,

analyzed: parāk arthasya asatya tvāt iti śloka dvaya arthaḥ
translated: because the external object is unreal. This is the meaning of the two verses.

analyzed: nirviśeṣa nitya caitanya mātrasya eva tad tad pramāṇa adhīna antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti pratibimbita tayā tad tad vṛtti avacchinna tayā vā tad tad artha prakāśaka tvāt pramāṇa phalatva upacāra
translated: The result of valid knowledge is figuratively applied to the mere eternal consciousness without distinction, because it illuminates that and that object by being reflected in the internal organ dependent on this and that valid knowledge, or by being limited by those and those operations.

analyzed: iti bodhyam
translated: This is what should be understood.

original: prakrāntaṃ māyāvādimataṃ tāvadvistareṇa pratikṣeptumupakramate tadidam ityādinā /
analyzed: prakrāntam māyāvādi matam tāvat vistareṇa pratikṣeptum upakramate tat idam ityādinā
translated: In order to refute in detail the doctrine of the Mādhyamikas, which has been introduced, he begins with the words This and so on.

analyzed: alaukika mlaukika pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇa viruddham
translated: It is illogical, contrary to ordinary perception and other means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: a vaidikam veda ādi sat śāstra viruddham
translated: It is non-Vedic, contrary to the true scriptures such as the Vedas.

original: lokavedānanuguṇaṃ cedaṃ māyāvādināṃ darśanamityātmatattvasākṣātkartāro vadantīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: loka veda ananuguṇam ca idam māyā vādinām darśanam iti ātma tattva sākṣātkartāraḥ vadanti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The doctrine of the Mādhyamikas is contrary to the world and the Vedas, say those who have realized the truth of the self. This is the idea.

analyzed: saṃvid advaite para abhimate dhyakṣa virodham ādau nirūpayati tathā hi ityādinā
translated: He first examines the contradiction with perception in the accepted non-duality of consciousness with the words Thus, indeed and so on.

analyzed: parāc artha pramiteḥ hi ātma tvam uktam vārtika kṛtā
translated: For the author of the Vārttika has said that the nature of the knowledge of an external object is the self.

analyzed: tasyāḥ sphuṭam eva anātma tvam iti āha saṃvi diti
translated: He says that its non-self nature is clearly evident with the words consciousness and so on.

analyzed: jñāna ādi padam praryāya nāma ekārtha vācakam yasyai
translated: The word knowledge and so on is a synonym expressing the same meaning as consciousness.

analyzed: vaṃbhūtaḥ ātma dharmaḥ kaścid viṣaya prakāśakaḥ saṃvid śabditaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that some self and dharma are the illuminator of the object, which is called consciousness.

analyzed: tasya āsye ti
translated: Of this.

original: anyadharmatvenānityatvena ca pratyakṣasiddhasyāsya pramāṇaphalasya viṣayavedanasya na nityātmasvarūpatvaṃ saṃbhavatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: anya dharma tvena anitya tvena ca pratyakṣa siddhasya asya pramāṇa phalasya viṣaya vedanasya na nitya ātma svarūpa tvam saṃbhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not possible for this pramāṇa-phala, which is established by perception as being a dharma of something else and as being non-eternal, to be of the nature of the eternal self.

original: pramāṇaphalasya sakarmakasyānubhavasyānityatvaṃ prakārāntareṇa sādhayati svāpe ti /
analyzed: pramāṇa phalasya sa karmakasya anubhavasya anitya tvam prakāra antareṇa sādhayati svāpe ti
translated: He proves in another way the non-eternality of the pramāṇa-phala, which is an experience with an object, by saying 'in sleep' etc.

analyzed: svāpa ādau sattve yogya tvāt vedanasya upalabdhiḥ syāt
translated: In sleep etc., there would be the perception of consciousness due to its existence and suitability.

original: anupalabdheśca na tadā tasya sattvamiti bhāvaḥ /🔽suṣuptikālikaṃ vedanābhāvaṃ suptotthitasya parāmarśenāpi draḍhayati ata eva hī ti /🔽nanu saṃvidaḥ svaprakāśatvātsvāpe 'pyastyevopalambhaḥ /
analyzed: anupalabdheḥ ca na tadā tasya sattvam iti bhāvaḥ  suṣupti kālikam vedanā bhāvam supta utthitasya parāmarśena api draḍhayati atas eva hi iti  nanu saṃvidaḥ sva prakāśa tvāt svāpe pi asti eva upalambhaḥ
translated: And because it is not perceived, it does not exist at that time - this is the meaning.🔽He also strengthens the absence of consciousness during the time of deep sleep by the reflection of one who has just awakened, by saying 'for this very reason' etc.🔽But since consciousness is self-luminous, it is perceived even in sleep.

original: anubhūtamavaśyaṃ smartavyamiti niyamābhāvācca tadananusandhānaṃ ghaṭate prabodhe /
analyzed: anubhūtam avaśyam smartavyam iti niyama abhāvāt ca tad ananusandhānam ghaṭate prabodhe
translated: And because there is no rule that what is experienced must necessarily be remembered, the non-recollection of it is possible upon awakening.

original: iyantaṃ kālaṃ na kiñcidahamavediṣam iti parāmarśastu viṣayaprakāśakatvaviśiṣṭajñānābhāvagocaraḥ /
analyzed: iyantam kālam na kiñcid aham avediṣam iti parāmarśaḥ tu viṣaya prakāśaka tva viśiṣṭa jñāna abhāva gocaraḥ
translated: The reflection For so long a time I did not know anything pertains to the absence of knowledge characterized by the illumination of objects.

original: svāpe sato 'pi hi vijñānasya na viṣayaprakāśakatvamiti codyamanūdya pariharati yāva diti /
analyzed: svāpe sataḥ api hi vijñānasya na viṣaya prakāśaka tvam iti codyam anūdya pariharati yāvat iti
translated: Even in sleep, although consciousness exists, it does not illuminate objects. This objection is raised and answered with the words As long as...

analyzed: niyama abhāve pi ityantena codya anuvādaḥ
translated: Up to even in the absence of a rule is the statement of the objection.

analyzed: agre parihāraḥ
translated: The answer comes later.

analyzed: prāyaṇa ādeḥ saṃskāra viccheda kara tvam saṃvid sidvau abhihitam prāyaṇāt naraka kleśāt prasūti vyasanāt api
translated: The severance of impressions by death and so on has been stated in the proof of consciousness: From death, from the suffering of hell, and from the calamity of birth,

analyzed: cira ativṛttāḥ prāc janma bhogāḥ na smṛti gocarāḥ iti
translated: The experiences of past lives, long past, are not within the range of memory.

analyzed: prāyaṇam maraṇam
translated: Death means dying.

analyzed: nitya vat sārvadikam  yat vā niyamavat
translated: Always means constantly.🔽Or with a rule means.

analyzed: niyatam iti yāvat
translated: With a rule means.

analyzed: nikhila saṃskāra pramoṣa hetu prabala duḥkha hetu virahe niyamena asmaraṇam saṃvidaḥ svāpe prakāśam eva sādhayet
translated: Even in the absence of the cause of the complete loss of all impressions, the powerful cause of suffering, the constant non-remembrance would establish the non-illumination of consciousness in sleep.

original: svayaṃprakāśasvabhāvāyāśca tasyā aprakāśastadā tadabhāvaparyavasanna iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svayam prakāśa svabhāvāyāḥ ca tasyāḥ aprakāśaḥ tadā tad abhāva paryavasannaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the non-illumination of that consciousness, which has self-illumination as its nature, is tantamount to its non-existence at that time - this is the idea.

original: siddhānte tu viṣayaprakāśanavelāyāmeva dharmabhūtajñānasya svayaṃprakāśatvopagamāt svāpesato 'pi tasyāprakāśo na kṣatikara iti bodhyam /
analyzed: siddhānte tu viṣaya prakāśana velāyām eva dharma bhūta jñānasya svayaṃprakāśa tva upagamāt tasya aprakāśaḥ na kṣati karaḥ iti bodhyam
translated: But in the Siddhānta, it should be understood that even in sleep, the non-illumination of the self-luminous knowledge which is the attribute, at the very time of the illumination of the object, does not cause any harm.

analyzed: atra śaṅkate na ca
translated: Here he raises an objection: Not so,

analyzed: sati api ti  ahaṅkāra gocara abhāvāt aham buddhi bodhyasya jñātuḥ aham arthasya vilayāt
translated: even though it exists, due to the absence of the determination of the object, due to the absence of the relation with the object,🔽due to the absence of the object of ego, due to the dissolution of the known self, the meaning of 'I', which is to be understood by the cognition of 'I',

analyzed: ahamartha upaśliṣṭāyāḥ viṣaya anvayavatyāḥ eva saṃvidaḥ saṃskāra ādhāyaka tvam
translated: the consciousness which is connected with the meaning of 'I', which is related to the object, alone produces the impression.

original: svāpetadubhayavaidhuryātsvaprakāśasyāpi caitanyamātrasya na saṃskārādhāyakatvamiti na tasya prabodhe 'nusandhānaprasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svāpa etad ubhaya vaidhuryāt sva prakāśasya api caitanya mātrasya na saṃskāra ādhāyaka tvam iti na tasya prabodhe iti bhāvaḥ
translated: In sleep, due to the absence of both, even the self-luminous mere consciousness does not produce the impression. Therefore, there is no possibility of remembrance of it at the time of waking. This is the idea.

analyzed: atra uttaram āha artha antare ti
translated: Here he replies: In another object, etc.

analyzed: tad agrahaṇasya artha antara agrahaṇasya
translated: The non-apprehension of that, i.e., the non-apprehension of another object.

analyzed: tritaye ti
translated: In the three,

analyzed: jñāna jñeya jñātṛ tritaya avabhāse pi yathāyatham tad tad anubhavasya eva tad tad saṃskāram
translated: even in the appearance of the triad of knowledge, object of knowledge, and knower, the impression of each is produced by the experience of each, as it is.

original: prati hetutvādekāgratayā saṃvidanubhave sati svāpe tataḥ tatsaṃskārotpāde 'hamarthavilayaghaṭapaṭādyarthāntarānanubhavayorapratibandhakatvātsaṃvinmātrapratyavamarśaprasaṅgo
analyzed: prati hetu tvāt ekāgra tayā saṃvid anubhave sati svāpe tatas tad saṃskāra utpāde ham artha vilaya ghaṭa paṭa ādi artha antara ananubhavayoḥ apratibandhaka tvāt saṃvid mātra pratyavamarśa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: When there is experience of consciousness with one-pointedness due to the cause of sleep, then, due to the production of its impressions, and due to the non-obstruction of the dissolution of the meaning of 'I' and the non-experience of other objects like pot, there is the undesirable consequence of the reflection of mere consciousness.

analyzed: durvāraḥ bhavat mate prabodha samayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that according to your view, it is unavoidable at the time of waking.

original: nanu jñāturvinaṣṭatvātsvāpekaḥ smaredityatrāha na ca pratyabhijñe ti /
analyzed: nanu jñātuḥ vinaṣṭa tvāt sva apekaḥ smaret iti atra āha na ca pratyabhijñā iti
translated: Now, since the knower is destroyed, who would remember in sleep? To this he says: And there is recognition.

original: pūrvadine kṛtasyāparadine pratisandhānātpūrvāparadinasthāyitvena sidhyato jñāturahamarthasya madhyakāle svāpe vilayo na ghaṭata iti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: pūrva dine kṛtasya apara dine pratisandhānāt pūrva apara dina sthāyi tvena sidhyataḥ jñātuḥ ahamarthasya madhya kāle svāpe vilayaḥ na ghaṭate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the dissolution of the known 'I' meaning, which is established as abiding in the previous and subsequent days due to the connection of what was done on the previous day on the subsequent day, does not occur in sleep in the middle period.

analyzed: evam svāpe pi aham arthasya
translated: Thus, even in sleep, the existence of the 'I' meaning

original: sadbhāvamupapādya tadā tadbhānamapi vartata ityupapādayati ata eva hī ti /
analyzed: sadbhāvam upapādya tadā tad bhānam api vartate iti upapādayati atas eva hi iti
translated: is established. To establish that its manifestation also occurs at that time, he says: For this very reason, then.

analyzed: svāpa kālika ahamartha pratisandhānam idam tātkālika tad pratibhāsa samarthakam
translated: This remembrance of the 'I' meaning belonging to the time of sleep supports the manifestation of that at that time.

analyzed: na ca anumita svāpa tat sukha tva ātma svarūpa sattā gocaram idam astu
translated: And let this not be the sphere of the inferred existence of the nature of the 'I' consisting of the bliss of sleep at that time.

original: tathā cedaṃ na svāpe 'hamarthaprakāśasyopapādakamiti vācyam /🔽svāpāṃśe 'numitilakṣaṇatve 'pi ahamarthe pratisandhānarūpatvasya prātastatrāhaṃ na
analyzed: tathā ca idam na svāpe ham artha prakāśasya upapādakam iti vācyam  svāpa aṃśe numiti lakṣaṇa tve pi ahamarthe pratisandhāna rūpa tvasya prātar tatra aham na
translated: And so it cannot be said that this [pratibhā] is not the cause of the manifestation of the meaning of 'I' in sleep.

analyzed: āsa m ityādau iva svarasa siddhasya anapodya tvāt
translated: Even if the part of sleep is characterized by inference, the form of recollection in the meaning of 'I' is established by its own nature in the morning, as in 'I did not sleep last night', and cannot be refuted.
Just as the form of recollection in the form of the self experienced in the morning is established by the reflection on the form of the self experienced in the morning.

analyzed: evam svāpe nubhūta ātma sva rūpa parāmarśi tvāt ātma aṃśe pratisandhāna rūpa tva upapattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: In the same way, the form of recollection in the part of the self in sleep is established by the reflection on the form of the self experienced in sleep. This is the idea.

original: na ca nityātmaprakāśasya saṃskārajanakatve mānābhāvātkathamahamartha ātmani pratisandhānarūpatvamasyeti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca nitya ātma prakāśasya saṃskāra janaka tve māna abhāvāt katham ahamarthaḥ ātmani pratisandhāna rūpatvam asya iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that since there is no proof for the eternal manifestation of the self being the cause of the production of impressions, how can the form of recollection in the self in the meaning of 'I' be established.

analyzed: sva janya saṃskāravat tvena anubhavasya pratisandhāne eka hetu tva nirvāhāya nitya anubhavasya api saṃskāra hetu tva upagamāt
translated: Because even the eternal experience is accepted as the cause of impressions in order to establish a single cause for the experience in recollection by virtue of being endowed with the impressions produced by itself.

analyzed: spaṣṭam ca idam siddhāntasiddhāñcane
translated: And this is clearly established in the Siddhānta Siddhānta.

analyzed: svāpe nubhūta ātma aṃśa prakāśana rūpa tvāt vā pratisandhāna vācaḥ yuktiḥ
translated: Or the statement of recollection is reasonable by virtue of the form of manifestation of the part of the self experienced in sleep.

analyzed: adhikam anyatra
translated: And more so in other places.

original: nanu saviṣayajñānasya nityatvaṃ māstu śuddhasaṃvido nityatvādyupapannamevetyatrāha na ca nirviṣaye ti /
analyzed: nanu sa viṣaya jñānasya nitya tvam mā astu śuddha saṃvidaḥ nitya tva ādi upapannam eva iti atra āha na ca nirviṣaye ti
translated: But let the eternality of knowledge with an object be not accepted; the eternality etc. of pure consciousness is quite possible. To this he says: And there is no (eternality etc.) in objectless (consciousness).

original: svayaṃprakāśasaṃvidanubhavo hi viṣayāśrayopaśliṣṭasaṃvidviṣaya eva lokaviditaḥ idamahaṃ jānāmī ti /
analyzed: svayam prakāśa saṃvid anubhavaḥ hi viṣaya āśraya upaśliṣṭa saṃvid viṣayaḥ eva loka viditaḥ idam aham jānāmi iti
translated: For, the experience of self-luminous consciousness, which is consciousness associated with the object-dependent substratum, is known to the world as 'I know this'.

original: kevalasaṃvidanubhavastu na kasyāpi svato 'nyato vā prasiddha iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kevala saṃvid anubhavaḥ tu na kasya api svatas nyatas vā prasiddhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the experience of mere consciousness is not known to anyone, either from itself or from anything else. This is the idea.

original: nanu siddhānte jñānasvarūpasyātmano nirviṣayatvaṃ nirāśrayatvaṃ cābhyupagataṃ kathaṃ saṅgacchate / /
analyzed: nanu siddhānte jñāna svarūpasya ātmanaḥ nirviṣaya tvam nirāśraya tvam ca abhyupagatam katham saṅgacchate
translated: But how is it consistent in the Siddhānta (Advaita Vedānta) to accept that the nature of knowledge, which is the Self, is objectless and without a substratum?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: saṃvid ādi śabdānām sa viṣayaka jñāne eva rūḍha tvāt tad arthasya nirviṣaya tva ādi niṣedha uktiḥ upapannā eva
translated: Since words like 'consciousness' are well-established only in relation to knowledge with an object, the statement of the negation of its objectlessness etc. is quite appropriate.

original: dharmabhūtasya jñānasya ca viṣayaprakāśakasya na nirāśrayatvaṃ nityātmasvarūpāśritatvāt /
analyzed: dharma bhūtasya jñānasya ca viṣaya prakāśakasya na nirāśraya tvam nitya ātma svarūpa āśrita tvāt
translated: And the knowledge which is a quality, and which illuminates the object, is not without a substratum, because it is based on the eternal Self.

original: ātmasvarūpajñānasyāpi pratyaktvānukūlatvaikatvaprakārataḥ svarūpaprakāśakatvānna nirviṣayatvaṃ nirdharmakatvaṃ vā /
analyzed: ātma svarūpa jñānasya api pratyaktva anukūla tva ekatva prakārataḥ svarūpa prakāśaka tvāt na nirviṣaya tvam nirdharmaka tvam vā
translated: Even the knowledge of the nature of the self is not objectless or devoid of properties, because it illuminates its own nature in the form of being favorable to direct experience.

analyzed: ātmani ekatva anekatva ahantva anahantva ādi saṃśayasya kadāpi anudayāt ca pratyaktavādinā bhānam eṣṭavyam
translated: And because doubt regarding oneness, manyness, I-ness, not-I-ness, etc. in the self never arises, direct experience must be accepted by the proponent of direct experience.

analyzed: nirupādhika prema āspada tvāt ca sukha tvena iti siddhānte bhimataḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: And because it is the object of love without any limiting adjunct, it is established as bliss. This is the special feature accepted in the conclusion.

original: saṃvidaḥ saviśeṣatvaṃ saṃvidādiśabdānāṃ saṃbandhiśabdatvaprasiddhyāpyupapādayati saṃbandhī ti /
analyzed: saṃvidaḥ sa viśeṣa tvam saṃvid ādi śabdānām saṃbandhi śabda tva prasiddhyā api upapādayati saṃbandhī ti
translated: He explains the qualified nature of consciousness also by the well-known fact that words like consciousness are relational terms, with the words 'relational' etc.

analyzed: niyata saṃbandhi ākāṅkṣā śāli tvam
translated: Being inclined to have a definite relation is being a relational term.

original: jñānaṃ / saṃvedanamityukte hi kasya kiṃviṣayakamiti viṣayāśrayākāṅkṣā niyatā /
analyzed: jñānam saṃvedanam iti ukte hi kasya kiṃviṣayakam iti viṣaya āśraya ākāṅkṣā niyatā
