translated: For when it is said 'knowledge', 'experience', there is a definite inclination to ask about the object and the substratum, 'whose' and 'with regard to what'.

original: etadeva vyatireka niṣedhena draḍhayati na hī
analyzed: etat eva vyatireka niṣedhena draḍhayati na hī
translated: He strengthens this very [fact] by a negative vyatireka, with the words 'for' etc.

analyzed: ti jānāti ādeḥ jñā dhātu prabhṛteḥ
translated: 'For' means for the root jña and others.

original: nanu jñānasvarūpa mityādiṣu kevalasyaiva prayogo dṛśyata iti cenna /
analyzed: nanu jñāna sva rūpa mityādiṣu kevalasya eva prayogaḥ dṛśyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in 'the nature of knowledge' etc. only the bare [word] is seen to be used, it is not so.

analyzed: āśaya anabhijñaḥ hi bhavān
translated: For you do not understand the intention.

analyzed: atratyasya dharmi vācinaḥ jñāna śabdasya svayaṃprakāśa tva pravṛtti nimittakasya saṃbandhi śabdāt dharma bhūta jñāna vācinaḥ
translated: Here, the word jñāna (knowledge), which denotes the substratum, has the connotation of self-luminousness. It is different from the words denoting the knowledge that is an attribute,

analyzed: śabdāt śabda antara tvāt catuṣpād vācinaḥ iva go śabdāt kiraṇa ādi vācinaḥ tasya
translated: which are relational words, like the word go (cow) denoting four-footed animals from the words denoting rays etc.

analyzed: asmākam saṃbandhi śabda tva prasiddhiḥ
translated: For us, the well-known relational character

analyzed: dharma bhūta jñāna vācini sa avakāśā
translated: is applicable to the words denoting the knowledge that is an attribute.

original: bhavatāṃ tu dharmiṇaḥ svarūpajñānasya dharmabhūtasya ca viṣayajñānasya bhedābhāvāt
analyzed: bhavatām tu dharmiṇaḥ svarūpa jñānasya dharma bhūtasya ca viṣaya jñānasya bheda abhāvāt
translated: But for you, since there is no difference between the knowledge of the nature of the substratum and the knowledge of the object that is an attribute,

analyzed: ekasya eva caitanyasya ātma rūpasya nirviśeṣa tva siddhāntāt saṃbandhi śabda tva prathāna upapannā
translated: and since the established doctrine is that the same consciousness, which is of the nature of the self, is without distinctions, the application of relational words

analyzed: saṃvid ādi śabdasya iti
translated: is not possible for the words saṃvid (consciousness) etc.

analyzed: nirviśeṣa jñapti mātrasya dharmi vāci jñāna śabda vācya tvam api na saṃbhavati iti api anusandheyam
translated: It should also be understood that even the denotation of the word jñāna (knowledge), which denotes the substratum, is not possible by the mere fact that the cause of denotation is not applicable to mere knowledge without distinctions.

analyzed: evam paraiḥ ātma tayā abhimatasya pramāṇa phalasya āgantuka tvāt ātma dharma tvāt ca na ātma tvam iti aktam
translated: Thus, it has been said that the means of knowledge and its result, which are accepted by others as the self, are not the self because they are adventitious and because they are attributes of the self.

original: atha tasya prāgabhāvāsiddhiṃ paroktāmanuvadati yattu svata iti /
analyzed: atha tasya prāgabhāva asiddhim para uktām anuvadati yat tu svatas iti
translated: Now, he repeats the previously stated non-establishment of its prior non-existence, saying But that which is from itself...

analyzed: anyatas siddhi abhāva sphorakam svatas siddhasya iti  anubhavasya iti viśeṣya padam adhyāhāryam
translated: From itself indicates the absence of establishment from another.🔽The qualifying word of experience should be supplied.

analyzed: tad virodhāt eva pratiyoginā yaugapadya avasthāna asaṃbhava lakṣaṇāt virodhāt eva
translated: Due to contradiction itself means due to the contradiction characterized by the impossibility of the co-existence of the counter-correlate.

analyzed: prāgabhāva ādeḥ saṃvid prāgabhāva ādeḥ
translated: Of the prior non-existence of consciousness means of the prior non-existence of consciousness.

analyzed: śiṣṭam spaṣṭam
translated: The rest is clear.

analyzed: dūṣayati ta dityādinā
translated: He refutes it with That... and so on.

analyzed: jñāna sāmānyasya sva samāna kālika artha grāhi tva niyame doṣam āha atīte ti
translated: In the rule that the general cognition must grasp an object existing at the same time as itself, he states the fault with If it were so...

analyzed: śaṅkā anuvādaḥ atha i ti
translated: The statement of the doubt is If it be said...

analyzed: iti iti anantaram matam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: After thus, the remainder is it is thought.
The meaning of the statement of the doubt is that the rule is that the prior non-existence of consciousness is only to be grasped by what exists at the same time as itself.

analyzed: niyamam upagamya āha kim evam iti
translated: Accepting the rule, he says If so, then...

analyzed: tad siddheḥ saṃvid prāgabhāva graha siddheḥ
translated: From the establishment of that means from the establishment of the grasping of the prior non-existence of consciousness.

analyzed: na prāgabhāva ādi asiddhiḥ na saṃvid prāgabhāva ādi asiddhiḥ
translated: There is no non-establishment of prior non-existence, etc. means there is no non-establishment of the prior non-existence of consciousness, etc.

original: ayaṃ ca niyamo yadyapi siddhānte yuktaḥ /
analyzed: ayam ca niyamaḥ yadi api siddhānte yuktaḥ
translated: Although this rule is proper in the established conclusion,

analyzed: vidyamāna yat kiñcat jñāna prāgabhāvasya vidyamānena eva jñāna antareṇa anumāna ādinā grahaṇāt
translated: Because the prior non-existence of the present cognition of something existent is grasped by another cognition itself which is existent, by inference etc.

analyzed: aham idānīm cākṣuṣa abhāvavān unmīlita cakṣuṣka tvāt ityādi anumāna saṃbhavāt
translated: Because inference like I now possess the absence of visual cognition, because I have opened my eyes is possible.

analyzed: atha api para mate yam niyamaḥ nupapannaḥ iti āha
translated: Now, even in the opponent's view, this rule is not logically possible, he says

analyzed: tad prāgabhāvaḥ iti
translated: The prior non-existence of that etc.

analyzed: bhavatā hi jñānam jñāna antara a grāhyam iṣyate
translated: For you, cognition is accepted as not apprehended by another cognition.

analyzed: evam sati tad jñāna prāgabhāvaḥ tena eva syāt bhavat ukta niyama anusārāt
translated: If that is so, the prior non-existence of that cognition would have to be apprehended by that very cognition occurring at the same time, because it follows the rule stated by you.

analyzed: tat ca anupapannam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And that is logically impossible, is the idea.

original: nanvata evāsmābhiḥ saṃvitprāgabhāvāsiddhirucyata iti cettatrāha aindriyike ti /
analyzed: nanu atas eva asmābhiḥ saṃvid prāgabhāva asiddhiḥ ucyate iti ced tatra āha aindriyike ti
translated: If it is said that we are just stating the non-establishment of the prior non-existence of consciousness, then he says In the case of the sensory etc.

analyzed: laukika pratyakṣe eva samāna kālika padārtha grāhi tvam iti niyamaḥ
translated: The rule is that in worldly perception itself there is the apprehension of objects occurring at the same time.

analyzed: na tu jñāna sāmānyasya
translated: But not of cognition in general.

analyzed: pramiti sāmānyasya vā
translated: Or of the general form of valid cognition.

original: tathā ca prākkālikasya svaprāgabhāvasya tenaiva vartamānena jñānena grahaṇe nānupapattiriti hārdam /
analyzed: tathā ca prākkālikasya sva prāgabhāvasya tena eva vartamānena jñānena grahaṇe nā anupapattiḥ iti hārdam
translated: And in that case, there is no logical impossibility in the apprehension of the prior non-existence of oneself occurring at an earlier time by that very cognition occurring in the present. This is the idea.

analyzed: agre ca etat vyaktībhaviṣyati
translated: This will become clear later on.

original: pramāṇasya prameyāvinābhūtatvātpramāṇajñānasya svayaṃprakāśatvena nityatvāttatprameyamapi nityamiti mataṃ nirākaroti etene ti /
analyzed: pramāṇasya prameya avinābhūta tvāt pramāṇa jñānasya svayam prakāśa tvena nitya tvāt tat prameyam api nityam iti matam nirākaroti etena i ti
translated: He refutes the view that the object of knowledge is eternal because the means of knowledge is inseparable from the object of knowledge and the knowledge of the means of knowledge is eternal by its own manifestation.

analyzed: etena pramāṇa jñāna mātrasya samāna kāla padārtha grāhi tva niyama abhāvena
translated: By this, the restriction that the mere knowledge of the means of knowledge grasps objects of the same time is absent.
The statement to be refuted is means of knowledge.

analyzed: svayam prakāśa tvāt
translated: Because of self-manifestation.

analyzed: mānaṃpramitiḥ
translated: Means of knowledge is cognition.

analyzed: svatas satana nyāpekṣa sattākam sadā asti eva
translated: It exists by itself, not depending on anything else.

original: evaṃ cet / ato vakṣyamāṇāddhetoḥ tanmeyaṃ ca vastu sadāstyeva /
analyzed: evam ced atas vakṣyamāṇāt hetoḥ tat meyam ca vastu sadā asti eva
translated: If so, then for this reason to be stated, that object also exists.

analyzed: mānam pramāṇa jñānam
translated: For, the means of knowledge is the knowledge of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: meya yugā iva prameya avinābhāvī iva iti arthaḥ  svayam prakāśasya api pramāṇa jñānasya pramāṇa janya tvāt eva anitya
translated: It is only in conjunction with the object of knowledge, i.e., it is inseparable from the object of knowledge.

original: tvam / tatprāgabhāvagraho 'pi svataḥ parato vā saṃbhavedeva /🔽ato mitinityatvamupajīvya meyanityatvavyavasthāpanamayuktam /
analyzed: svatas paratas vā saṃbhavet eva  atas miti nitya tvam upajīvya meya nitya tva vyavasthāpanam ayuktam
translated: Even the self-manifest knowledge of the means of knowledge is impermanent because it is produced by the means of knowledge itself. The apprehension of its prior non-existence can occur either by itself or through something else.🔽Therefore, it is not proper to establish the permanence of the object of knowledge depending on the permanence of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: pramāṇa jñānasya samāna kāla artha grāhaka tva niyama abhāvāt ca iti parākaraṇa prakāraḥ bodhyaḥ
translated: And because there is no restriction that the knowledge of the means of knowledge grasps objects of the same time, the method of refutation should be understood.

analyzed: nanu asat artha grāhi tve miteḥ katham prameya avinābhāvaḥ ghaṭate
translated: If cognition grasps a non-existent object, how can the invariable concomitance with the cognized object be established?

analyzed: tatra āha na hi iti
translated: In response to that, he says: No, etc.

original: yadā prabhitistadā prameyamiti na prameyāvinābhāvaḥ pramiteḥ /
analyzed: yadā prabhitiḥ tadā prameyam iti na prameya avinābhāvaḥ pramiteḥ
translated: When there is cognition, the cognized object exists. Thus, there is no invariable concomitance of cognition with the cognized object.

original: kintu yaddeśakālasaṃbandhitvena yādṛśākāravattvena ca yadbhāsate pramitau /
analyzed: kintu yad deśa kāla saṃbandhi tvena yādṛśa ākāravat tvena ca yat bhāsate pramitau
translated: But rather, what appears in cognition as connected with a particular place and time, and as having a certain form,

analyzed: tasya tad prakāra abhāva abhāva paryavasitam prameya yogi tvam
translated: its being connected with the cognized object is concluded to be the absence of the absence of that kind.

analyzed: a tad rūpa anavagāhi tvam meye
translated: The cognized object is the non-apprehension of a form that is not that.

analyzed: tadvati tad prakāraka tvam eva ca tat iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that having that [cognized object] and being of that form is just that [cognized object].

original: smṛteraprāmāṇyamatamapi pratikṣipati prasaṅgataḥ ata eve ti /
analyzed: smṛteḥ aprāmāṇya matam api pratikṣipati prasaṅgataḥ atas eva iti
translated: He also rejects the view that memory is not a valid means of knowledge, in the context of the discussion, with For this very reason, etc.

analyzed: pralāpaḥ pralāpa mātram
translated: Pralapa is mere prattle.

analyzed: nirarthakam vacanam iti yāvat
translated: It means meaningless speech.

analyzed: atītam api bāhyam artham tathātvena eva avagāhinyāḥ smṛteḥ na nirviṣaya tā
translated: Memory, which grasps the past external object as it is, does not have an unreal object.

analyzed: meya vyabhicāraḥ vā
translated: Nor is there a deviation from the cognized object.

analyzed: prameya yogi tvasya tadvati tad prakāra avagāhi tva rūpa tvāt eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that the being connected with the cognized object is of the form of apprehending it as having that [cognized object].

analyzed: atha i tyādiḥ śaṅkā anuvādaḥ  u ti ete ti vā
translated: If, etc. is a statement of the doubt.🔽These, etc.

analyzed: matam iti vā śeṣaḥ pūraṇīyaḥ
translated: The remainder, view, should be supplied.

analyzed: parihāraḥ yadi eva mityādiḥ
translated: The answer beginning with “If it is so, etc.”

original: svataḥsiddhatvāt saṃvidaḥ prāgabhāvādyasiddhiriti vadatā pramāṇābhāvasyedānīṃ taddhetutvenābhidhāne hetvantaram /
analyzed: svatas siddha tvāt saṃvidaḥ prāgabhāva ādi asiddhiḥ iti vadatā pramāṇa abhāvasya idānīm tad hetu tvena abhidhāne hetu antaram
translated: By saying that consciousness is self-established, and therefore prior non-existence, etc. are not established, and now stating the absence of means of knowledge as the cause of that, another reason is given.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvaḥ pi asiddhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the absence of means of knowledge is also not established.

analyzed: samarthita tvāt iti
translated: Because it has been established.

original: abhihitaṃ hi pūrvameva svāpamadamūrcchādaśāsu ca yogyānupalambhanirākṛtaḥ tatsadbhāvo nābhyupagamamarhatī ti /
analyzed: abhihitam hi pūrvam eva svāpa mada mūrcchā daśāsu ca yogya anupalambha nirākṛtaḥ tad sadbhāvaḥ na abhyupagamam arhati iti
translated: For it has been stated earlier itself that in the states of sleep, intoxication, and fainting, the existence of that [consciousness] cannot be accepted, as it is refuted by the non-apprehension of the fit object.

original: atredaṃ bodhyam aprakāśe 'pi saṃvidaḥ svāpe 'haṃ na jānāmīti tadabhāvapratyakṣamātmani tadā na ghaṭate yadyapi /
analyzed: atrā idam bodhyam aprakāśe saṃvidaḥ svāpe ham na jānāmi iti tad abhāva pratyakṣam ātmani tadā na ghaṭate yadi api
translated: Here this should be understood: Even in sleep, when consciousness is not manifest, the perception of its absence in the self, I do not know, does not occur then, if it does not.

analyzed: svāpasya vyāghātāt
translated: Because of the contradiction of sleep.
For it is the absence of the general cognition of an object.

analyzed: atha api svayam prakāśa svabhāvāyāḥ saṃvidaḥ prakāśāt svāpe bhāvaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Even so, the absence of consciousness, which has the nature of self-luminous, in sleep due to its non-manifestation, is established.

analyzed: tad pratītiḥ sva ānumānikī prabodhaḥ eva asmaraṇa niyama anumitena svāpa kālika saṃvid ananubhava liṅgena yogya anupalabdhi lakṣaṇena
translated: The cognition of that [absence] is inferential in nature. It is only in the awakened state, by the logical mark of the non-experience of consciousness at the time of sleep, inferred through the rule of non-remembrance, which has the characteristic of non-apprehension of the fit object.

original: idameva cānumānaṃ jñānatvasāmānyena svāpe svasyāpyabhāvaṃ viṣayīkarotīti siddhaṃ svaprāgabhāvagrahaḥ svenaiveti /
analyzed: idam eva ca anumānam jñāna tva sāmānyena svāpe svasya api abhāvam viṣayīkaroti iti siddham sva prāgabhāva grahaḥ svena eva iti
translated: And this very inference, by the commonality of being knowledge, makes its own non-existence in sleep an object. Thus it is established that the apprehension of its own prior non-existence is by itself alone.

original: prakārāntareṇāpyanityatvaṃ saṃvidāṃ sādhayati api ce ti /
analyzed: prakāra antareṇa api anitya tvam saṃvidām sādhayati api ca iti
translated: In another way also, he proves the impermanence of cognitions, with Moreover...

analyzed: na sādhayati na prakāśayati
translated: It does not prove, it does not illuminate.

analyzed: tat tasmāt
translated: That, for that reason.
It is only occasional, delimited by a particular time.

analyzed: kādācitka tayā pratyakṣa prakāśasya abhinayaḥ aham idānīm eva asmi na anyadā iti
translated: By its occasionality, the manifestation of the light of perception is indicated as I exist now only, not at another time.

analyzed: cetana samādhi āropeṇa evam vyapadeśaḥ
translated: This is designated by superimposing the state of consciousness of the knower.

original: yadvā pramāṇaphalasyaivātmatvasvaprakāśatvayoḥ parairupagamāttanmata evameva prakāśaḥ pramiteḥ syādityākūtam /
analyzed: yat vā pramāṇa phalasya eva ātma tva sva prakāśa tvayoḥ paraiḥ upagamāt tad mataḥ evam eva prakāśaḥ pramiteḥ syāt iti ākūtam
translated: Or, since the result of the means of knowledge is accepted by others as being the self and self-luminous, the intention is that the manifestation of knowledge would be like that according to their view.

analyzed: itarathā ti
translated: Otherwise,

original: pratyakṣasya samānakālīnārthaprakāśakatvasvābhāvyena tasya nityatve tadviṣayasya ghaṭāderapi nityatvaprasaṅga iti yāvat /
analyzed: pratyakṣasya samāna kālīna artha prakāśaka tva svābhāvyena tasya nitya tve tad viṣayasya ghaṭa ādeḥ api nitya tva prasaṅgaḥ iti yāvat
translated: if perception were by nature to illuminate its object at the same time, and were therefore eternal, it would follow that the pot and other objects of perception would also be eternal. That is as far as it goes.

analyzed: yāvat sva sattam ghaṭa ādiḥ na adhyakṣyate
translated: As long as the pot and other things exist, they are not perceived by perception.

analyzed: kintu san api kadācid eva
translated: But even though they exist, they are perceived only occasionally.

analyzed: tathā ca ghaṭa ādi adhyakṣasya kādācitkatvam na viṣaya asattva prayuktam
translated: And so the occasional nature of the perception of pot etc. is not due to the non-existence of the object.

analyzed: kintu svasya kādācitkatva prayuktam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But it is due to its own occasional nature alone, is the idea.

analyzed: atra prayogaḥ pratyakṣa saṃvid sva viṣaya kāla avyāpinī
translated: Here the argument is: The cognition of perception does not extend over its own object and time.

analyzed: samāna kālīna artha bhāsaka tve sati yāvat artha sattam tad aprakāśaka tvāt iti
translated: Because it does not illuminate the object as long as it exists, while illuminating the object at the same time.

analyzed: pratyakṣa vat anumāna ādi saṃvidām api anitya tvam sādhayati evam iti
translated: In the same way, he proves the impermanence of inferential and other cognitions also, saying Thus.

analyzed: kādācitkatayā eva cakāsatī ti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: It appears only occasionally.

original: liṅgaparāmarśādisāpekṣāṇāṃ tāsāṃ na hi nityatvaṃ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: liṅga parāmarśa ādi sāpekṣāṇām tāsām na hi nitya tvam saṃbhavati
translated: For those which depend on the apprehension of the mark etc., permanence is not possible.

analyzed: anvaminavam
translated: It is to be inferred.

analyzed: aśāt bayam ityādi pratītayaḥ ca kādācitkatām gamayanti
translated: And the notions such as the two moons etc. convey occasional nature.

analyzed: samāna kāla artha grāhi tva niyama rahitānām api etāsām pratītam kādācitkatvam na viṣaya asattva aupādhikam
translated: Even though these notions are devoid of the restriction of grasping objects at the same time, their occasional nature is not due to the superimposition of the non-existence of the object.

analyzed: kintu svarūpa prayuktam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But it is due to its own form alone, is the idea.

original: nanu saviṣayakajñānānāmanityatve 'pi nirviṣayaṃ jñānamātraṃ nityamiti cettatrāha nace ti /
analyzed: nanu sa viṣayaka jñānānām anitya tve pi nirviṣayam jñāna mātram nityam iti ced tatra āha na ca iti
translated: If it is argued that even though cognitions with objects are impermanent, mere cognition without an object is permanent, he says And not so etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣa anumāna pade bhāva pradhāne
translated: The words 'perception' and 'inference' are predominant in meaning.

analyzed: dhī saṃvid ādi padānām sa viṣayaka jñāne eva svārasikaḥ prayogaḥ
translated: The words 'understanding', 'consciousness', etc. are naturally used only in the sense of knowledge with an object.

analyzed: tad arthasya ca sāśraya tva niyamaḥ eva
translated: And the meaning of that is only restricted to having a basis.

analyzed: upalambha balāt śāstra balāt ca svarūpa jñānasya api na nirviśeṣa tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even the knowledge of one's own nature is not without distinction, by the force of perception and the force of scripture.

analyzed: etena caitanya mātram nitya nirviśeṣa sva prakāśa rūpam sat
translated: By this, mere consciousness, which is eternal, without distinction, and of the nature of self-luminous, exists.

analyzed: tasya eva antar karaṇa vṛtti avacchinnasya viṣaya prakāśaka tvam
translated: The manifestation of objects belongs to that very [consciousness] which is limited by the activity of the internal organ.🔽The cognition of that [consciousness] which is distinguished by the occasional nature of the limiting adjuncts is cognized as non-eternal.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa avacchinnam tat eva jñātṛ iti api parāstam
translated: The view that the same [consciousness] limited by the internal organ is the knower is also refuted.

original: antaḥkaraṇasya vṛttiḥ kiṃ vyāpāralakṣaṇā uta pariṇāmalakṣaṇā /
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇasya vṛttiḥ kim vyāpāra lakṣaṇā uta pariṇāma lakṣaṇā
translated: Is the activity of the internal organ characterized by operation or by transformation?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ tāvat mātreṇa jñāna vyāpāram antarā viṣaya prakāśa abhāvāt
translated: Not the first, because without the operation of knowledge alone, there is no manifestation of objects.

analyzed: indriyāṇām hi caratām yat manaḥ nuvidhīyate
translated: For, when the moving senses are directed by the mind,

original: tadasya harati prajñām tenāsyakṣarati prajñā ityādiṣu manaindriyadvārakajñānaprasaraṇata
analyzed: tat asya harati prajñām tena asya kṣarati prajñā ityādiṣu
translated: it carries away his wisdom. By that his wisdom leaks away. In such passages, the spreading of knowledge through the door of the mind and senses is said to be the activity of the internal organ.

analyzed: eva artha prakāśa vyavasthāpanāt
translated: Because it establishes the manifestation of just that object.

analyzed: kvacid prajñā manasoḥ abheda upadeśaḥ tu jñāna vyāpāra anuguṇa vyāpāravat tvāt manasaḥ bhāktaḥ jñeyaḥ
translated: But in some places, the teaching of the non-difference of prajñā and manas should be understood figuratively, because the manas has activity that is in accordance with the activity of knowledge.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: manasaḥ viṣaya ākāra parimāṇe dṛḍhatara pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no very firm evidence for the form and size of the object of the manas.

analyzed: caitanyasya nirviśeṣa tve ca na pramāṇam
translated: And there is no evidence for the non-specificity of consciousness.

analyzed: yena tasya eva aupadhika bheda rūpa tva kalpanam jñātṛ ādeḥ sādhīyaḥ bhavet
translated: By which the postulation of the form of difference due to the addition of that itself could be more reasonable for the knower, etc.

analyzed: nirūpa adhika jñātṛ jñeya jñāna bheda pratipādaka abādhita pratyakṣa śāstra ādi pramāṇa bādhitam ca idam iti alam adhunā
translated: And it is contradicted by the uncontradicted perception, scripture, etc., which teach the difference of the knower, the knowable, and knowledge, which are without additions. Thus, enough for now.

original: evaṃ svenaiva svaprāgabhāvasiddhimuktvānyato 'pi tāmāha na cānye ti /🔽atītasya svakīyajñānasya smṛtyādigrāhyatvamuktvā parakīyajñānasyāpi jñānāntaragrāhyatvamāha pratikūle ti /
analyzed: evam svena eva sva prāgabhāva siddhim uktvā anyatas tām āha na ca anye ti  atītasya svakīya jñānasya smṛti ādi grāhya tvam uktvā parakīya jñānasya api jñāna antara grāhya tvam āha pratikūle ti
translated: Having thus stated the establishment of one's own prior non-existence by oneself, he states it from another also, saying and not from another.🔽Having stated that one's own past knowledge is to be grasped by memory, etc., he says that the knowledge of others is also to be grasped by another knowledge, saying in what is adverse.

analyzed: parakīyasya viṣaya viśeṣe nukūla tva jñānasya pratikūla tva jñānasya vā tadīya hāna upādāna ādi pravṛtti rūpa darśana anumeya tvāt iti yāvat
translated: This means that the knowledge of the favorability of the particular object of others, or the knowledge of its unfavorability, is to be inferred from the appearance in the form of engagement in relinquishment, acceptance, etc. of that.

original: jñānasya jñānāntaragrāhyatvānupagame bādhakamāha tadanupagame ce ti /🔽parajñānānupagame vyavahārācchaktigrahasya parajñānānumānasāpekṣatvācchaktigrahasyaivāsaṃbhavena tanmūlasya vyavahārasya vilopaprasaṅga ityarthaḥ
analyzed: jñānasya jñāna antara grāhya tva anupagame bādhakam āha tad anupagame ca iti  para jñāna anupagame vyavahārāt śaktigrahasya para jñāna anumāna sāpekṣa tvāt śaktigrahasya eva asaṃbhavena tad mūlasya vyavahārasya vilopa prasaṅgaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: He states the contradiction in not accepting that knowledge is apprehended by another knowledge: And in not accepting that, there is the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all verbal usage.🔽The meaning is that if the knowledge of the relation between word and meaning is not accepted, then the knowledge of the relation between word and meaning, which is based on the inference of another's knowledge, would be impossible, and so the verbal usage which has that as its basis would be destroyed.

original: yadvā śabdārthasaṃbandhasya bodhyabodhakabhāvasya bodhaghaṭitasya jñānasya jñānāntaragrāhyatvānupagame vyākaraṇādinā🔽pratipādanāsaṃbhavātsamastaśābdavyavahāravilopaprasaṅga ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā śabda artha saṃbandhasya bodhya bodhaka bhāvasya bodha ghaṭitasya jñānasya jñāna antara grāhya tva anupagame vyākaraṇa ādinā  pratipādana asaṃbhavāt samasta śābda vyavahāra vilopa prasaṅgaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning is that if the relation between word and meaning, which is the relation between the taught and the teacher, which is a form of knowledge, is not accepted as apprehended by another knowledge, then it would be impossible to teach it by grammar etc.,🔽and so there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all verbal usage.

analyzed: śabda artha grahaṇa asaṃbhavena śabda artha saṃbandha grahaṇa asaṃbhavena
translated: Due to the impossibility of grasping the relation between word and meaning.

analyzed: parakīya jñāna anumāna anupagame guru upasarpaṇa ādeḥ api anupapattiḥ iti āha guru upasarpaṇe ti
translated: He says that if the inference of another's knowledge is not accepted, then even approaching a teacher would be impossible: In approaching a teacher, etc.

analyzed: tasya guroḥ
translated: Of him, the teacher.

analyzed: atha anubhāvya tvasya anubhūti tva viruddha tvam pratikṣipati na ca anya viṣaya tve iti
translated: Now he rejects the contradiction of being an object of experience being contrary to being an experience: And not being the object of another, etc.

analyzed: sva āśrayasya iti ubhayatra saṃbadhyate
translated: Of its own substratum is connected with both.

original: svāśrayāya svayameva prakāśamānatvam /🔽svāśrayāya svaviṣayaprakāśakatvaṃ vā svasattākāle saṃvido vidyata eva /
analyzed: sva āśrayāya svayam eva prakāśamāna tvam  sva āśrayāya sva viṣaya prakāśaka tvam vā sva sattā kāle saṃvidaḥ vidyate eva
translated: Being manifest to itself, i.e., to its own substratum.🔽Or, being the illuminator of its own object, i.e., of its own substratum, is present in consciousness at the time of its own existence.

original: ubhayavidhaṃ cedamanubhūtitvaṃ svasattākāle svāśrayāyāprakāśamānatve svaviṣayāprakāśakatve vā na ghaṭeta /
analyzed: ubhayavidham ca idam anubhūti tvam sva sattā kāle sva āśrayāya aprakāśamāna tve sva viṣaya aprakāśaka tve vā na ghaṭeta
translated: And this twofold nature of being an experience would not be possible if it were not manifest to its own substratum at the time of its own existence, or if it were not the illuminator of its own object.

analyzed: na tat asti
translated: That is not so.

original: atītatvadaśāyāṃ svāśrayāya vartamānadaśāyāṃ vā puruṣāntarāya jñānāntareṇa bhāsamānatve 'pi tasyā na niruktānubhūtitvabhaṅgaprasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: atīta tva daśāyām sva āśrayāya vartamāna daśāyām vā puruṣa antarāya jñāna antareṇa bhāsamāna tve pi tasyāḥ na nirukta anubhūti tva bhaṅga prasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even though it is manifest to its own substratum in the past state or to another person in the present state by another cognition, there is no implication of the destruction of its being a well-defined experience. This is the idea.

analyzed: anubhāvya tvasya ananubhūti tve prayojaka tvam ca āha ghaṭa ādeḥ iti
translated: He says that being an object of experience is not a reason for not being an experience, with a pot, etc.

analyzed: tathā svābhāvya abhāvāt eva nirukta ubhayavidha anubhūti tva virahāt eva
translated: Because of the absence of such a nature, i.e., because of the absence of the well-defined twofold nature of being an experience.

analyzed: an anūbhūti tvam anubhūti bhinna tvam
translated: Not being an experience means being different from an experience.

analyzed: anubhūti pada avācya tvam vā
translated: Or, not being denoted by the word experience.

analyzed: sāhacarya mātreṇa anubhāvya tvasya ananubhūti tva prayojaka tve pratibandi upakṣepaḥ api ca iti
translated: In the case of being an object of experience being a reason for not being an experience merely by co-occurrence, he raises a counter-argument with Moreover...

analyzed: tad prasaṅgaḥ ananubhūti tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: That implication means the implication of not being an experience.
The statement as an example of the non-existent is according to the theory of others.

analyzed: evam saṃvidaḥ nubhāvya tvam samarthya ātmanaḥ pi tat
translated: Thus, the experience of consciousness is established, and the self also has that.

original: saṃvidbhinnatvaṃ ca samarthayate na cātmana iti /🔽anubhūtitvaṃviṣayadhīrūpatvam /
analyzed: saṃvid bhinna tvam ca samarthayate na ca ātmanaḥ iti
translated: And it establishes the difference from consciousness, but not for the self.🔽The state of being an experience is the nature of the cognition of an object.

analyzed: anubhavitṛ tvāt viṣaya dhyadhikaraṇa tvāt
translated: The state of being an experiencer is due to being the substratum of the cognition of an object.

analyzed: na api asau iti
translated: Nor is it not so.

analyzed: jñāna antara nirapekṣa prakāśasya api nija ātma svarūpasya śravaṇa ādi jñāna grāhya tvāt
translated: Because even the natural self-form, which is manifested independently of another cognition, is to be grasped by the cognition of hearing etc.

analyzed: parātmanaḥ api tad śarīra gata ceṣṭā ādinā anumeya tvāt ātmanaḥ nanubhāvya tvam śruti yukti viruddham anupapannam iti arthaḥ
translated: And because even the supreme self is to be inferred by the activity etc. in its body, the non-experience of the self is contradictory to the scriptures and reasonings, and is not logically possible - this is the meaning.

analyzed: āsthīyatām iti
translated: Let it be accepted -

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ jñāna anāśraya tvam eva anātma tve jñāna avirodhi tvam eva ananubhūti tve prayojakam iṣyatām na anubhāvya tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: Let it be accepted that the non-selfness of the pot etc. is the mere non-substantiality of cognition, and the non-experience is the mere non-contradiction with ignorance, and not the non-experienceability - this is the meaning.

analyzed: śaṅkā atra atha i ti
translated: The doubt here is then.

analyzed: te jñāna anāśraya tva ajñāna avirodhi tve
translated: Those non-substantiality of cognition and non-contradiction with ignorance.

analyzed: viṣaya tve anubhāvya tve
translated: In the case of being an object, in the case of being an experience.

analyzed: parihāraḥ aviṣaya tve ti
translated: The answer is even in the case of non-objectivity.

analyzed: tathā eva te syātām gagana kusuma vat iti yāvat
translated: Those two would be just like sky-flowers. That is as far as it goes.

original: asattvameva tayoḥ prayojakaṃnānanubhāvyatvamiti cet ananubhāvyatve 'sattvamapi prāptaṃ tadvadeva /
analyzed: asattvam eva tayoḥ prayojakam na ananubhāvya tvam iti ced ananubhāvya tve sattvam api prāptam tadvat eva
translated: If it is argued that non-existence alone is the reason, not non-apprehension, then non-existence is also obtained in non-apprehension, just like that.

analyzed: aprayojaka tmavam iti ced tulyam anubhāvya tve pi iti hārdam
translated: If it is argued that it is not a reason, then the heart says that it is the same even in apprehension.

analyzed: iti alam iti
translated: Thus, enough.

analyzed: vyāpti ābhāsa mūla tvāt kutarka tvam
translated: It is a bad reasoning because it is based on a false pervasion.

original: ata evāpratiṣṭhitatvaṃ siṣādhayiṣitārthasiddhiparyavasānaviraha iti bodhyam /🔽eva manubhāvyatvasamarthanena parato 'pi saṃvidaḥ prāgabhāvasiddhirabhimatā /
analyzed: atas eva apratiṣṭhita tvam siṣādhayiṣita artha siddhi paryavasāna virahaḥ iti bodhyam  eva manubhāvya tva samarthanena paratas saṃvidaḥ prāgabhāva siddhiḥ abhimatā
translated: It should be understood that for this very reason, it is not well-established, meaning it does not lead to the establishment of the intended meaning.🔽Thus, by establishing the non-apprehension of consciousness, the non-existence of consciousness prior to [its object] is accepted.

analyzed: siddhānte dharma bhūta jñānasya nitya tve pi viṣaya prakāśa upayogi avasthā viśeṣa viśiṣṭasya anitya tvāt īṣṭam eva iti dhyeyam
translated: Even though consciousness as a property of God is accepted as eternal in the established doctrine, it should be understood that its particular state useful for illuminating the object is accepted as non-eternal.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tvāt saṃvidaḥ na prāgabhāva siddhiḥ
translated: Consciousness is self-luminous, so its non-existence prior to [its object] is not established.

analyzed: prāgabhāva abhāvāt ca anutpanna tvam tatas eva
translated: And because there is no prior non-existence, it is not produced. For this very reason,

analyzed: bhāva vikāra rahita tvam ca uktam anyaiḥ
translated: others have stated that it is free from the modifications of existence.

analyzed: tatra saṃvid prāgabhāva siddhi samarthanena anutpanna tva hetoḥ svarūpa asiddham siddhavatkṛtya vikāra antara nirāsaka anumāne na aikāntyam āha vyabhicaratī  / ti
translated: There, by establishing the prior non-existence of consciousness, he makes the reason of non-production as if it were established, and says that the inference which refutes other modifications is inconclusive, saying it deviates.

analyzed: saptamyāḥ avacchedaka tvam arthaḥ
translated: The seventh case has the meaning of delimitation.

analyzed: tasya vyabhicāra padārthe nvayaḥ
translated: It is related to the meaning of deviation.

analyzed: anutpanna tvam prāgabhāva avacchedena avināśi tva rūpa sādhya vyabhicāri iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that non-production deviates from the probandum, which is the nature of non-destruction delimited by prior non-existence.

original: tadadhikaraṇasyaiva tanniṣṭhadharmāvacchedakatvātprāgabhāvasya hetuniṣṭhavyabhicārāvacchedakasya hetumattvaṃ sādhyābhāvavattvaṃ ca siddhyati
analyzed: tad adhikaraṇasya eva tad niṣṭha dharma avacchedaka tvāt prāgabhāvasya hetu niṣṭha vyabhicāra avacchedakasya hetumat tvam sādhya abhāvavat tvam ca siddhi ati
translated: Because only that which is the substratum of that is the delimitor of the property residing in it, the prior non-existence which is the delimitor of the deviation residing in the reason becomes the reason, and the absence of the probandum becomes established.

analyzed: bhāve ti
translated: In existence.

analyzed: bhāva vṛtti tvasya anutpanna tva hetu viśeṣaṇa tve pi para abhimatāyām anādisānta avidyāyām vyabhicāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even though the qualification of the reason of non-production is the nature of existing, there is deviation in the beginningless and endless ignorance accepted by others.

analyzed: vyabhicāre vacchedakasya jñānasya tad hetu tva vivakṣātaḥ vidyayā iti tṛtīyā
translated: In deviation, the third case is used as by ignorance because of the intention to state that the knowledge which is the delimitor is the cause of that.

analyzed: anaikāntyam parihartum śaṅkate aparama arthāḥ iti
translated: In order to avoid inconclusiveness, he raises the doubt that they are not ultimate.
The probandum is the absence of modification in the ultimate sense.

original: tadabhāvaśca paramārthavikāro nāvidyāyāmiti na vyabhicāra iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ ca paramārtha vikāraḥ na avidyāyām iti na vyabhicāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the absence of that is a real modification, not in ignorance. Thus there is no fallacy.

analyzed: prativakti parama arthāḥ ca iti
translated: He replies: If it is a real modification, etc.

analyzed: tetava
translated: That is, in your view.

analyzed: mate iti pūraṇīyam  sādhyasya sādhya ghaṭaka vikāra ādeḥ
translated: This should be supplied.🔽Of the probandum, which is a modification that is a component of the probandum,

analyzed: sādhanasya vā a sādhana ghaṭaka utpatteḥ vā
translated: or of the proof, which is the origin that is a component of the proof.

analyzed: arthavat tām aśruvīta anvita arthakam bhavet
translated: It would have meaning, i.e., it would have a connected meaning.

original: vyabhicārasyāsiddheśca vārakatayā saprayojanaṃ vā /🔽saṃvido 'pi kalpitotpattimattvasaṃbhavena svarūpāsiddhivāraṇāya sādhanasya vetyuktam /
analyzed: vyabhicārasya asiddheḥ ca vāraka tayā sa prayojanam vā  saṃvidaḥ api kalpita utpattimat tva saṃbhavena svarūpa asiddhi vāraṇāya sādhanasya vā iti uktam
translated: Or it would have a purpose, in the sense of precluding fallacy and unestablished [reasons].🔽In order to preclude the unestablished [reason] of consciousness also being possibly imagined to have origination, of the proof is stated.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ paramārthavikārādeḥ paramārthotpattervānupagamādbhavatāṃ sādhyahetvoḥ pāramārthyaviśeṣaṇaṃ na ghaṭate /🔽sādhyasādhanavyatirekavyāptīnāmaprasiddhiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ paramārtha vikāra ādeḥ paramārtha utpatteḥ vā anupagamāt bhavatām sādhya hetvoḥ pāramārthya viśeṣaṇam na ghaṭate  sādhya sādhana vyatireka vyāptīnām aprasiddhi prasaṅgāt
translated: The idea is this: Since real modification and real origination are not accepted, the qualification of reality for your probandum and probans is not appropriate.🔽Because the vyāpti of the vyatireka of the probandum and probans would be unestablished.

original: aviśeṣaṇe ca vyabhicārasya svarūpāsiddhervā na parihārasaṃbhava iti /
analyzed: aviśeṣaṇe ca vyabhicārasya svarūpa asiddheḥ vā na parihāra saṃbhavaḥ iti
translated: And if it is not qualified, fallacy and unestablished [reasons] cannot be avoided.

analyzed: tathā ca sati ti
translated: And if that is so, etc.

analyzed: upahāsa garbham upālambha vacanam idam
translated: This is a statement of reproach with a hint of ridicule.

analyzed: tathā ca sati viśeṣaṇa dāne sati ca
translated: And in that case, when a qualification is given,

original: vyabhicāravārakaṃ viśeṣaṇaṃ vivakṣatāsiddhau dṛṣṭirna vidhīyata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vyabhicāra vārakam viśeṣaṇam vivakṣatā asiddhau dṛṣṭiḥ na vidhīyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the meaning is that one who wishes to state a qualification that excludes contradiction does not prescribe seeing in the case of non-establishment.

original: anutpannatvānnirbhedatvaṃ saṃvida iti cānūdya pratikṣipati yadapī ti /
analyzed: anutpanna tvāt nirbheda tvam saṃvidaḥ iti ca anūdya pratikṣipati yat api iti
translated: And having stated that consciousness is without distinction due to its non-origination, he rejects it with That also is not so.

analyzed: tat api na iti
translated: That also is not so.

analyzed: sajātīya vijātīya svagata bhedānām abādhita adhyakṣa ādi siddha tvāt bādhita viṣayam tat niṣedha anumānam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the inference that denies that is contradicted in its object, because distinctions of the same and different kinds and of its own nature are established by unobstructed perception and other means of knowledge.

analyzed: vibhāgi bheda yogi
translated: Divisible means having distinctions.

analyzed: vijātīya bheda niṣedhe na utpanna tvena siṣādhayiṣite na aikāntyam āha ajasya eva iti
translated: When the denial of distinctions of different kinds is to be proved by non-origination, he states the fallacy of inconclusive reason with Of the unborn itself.

analyzed: para abhimate jñāne tat āha anādi tvena i ti
translated: Even in the ignorance accepted by others, he says that with If it is beginningless.

analyzed: ātma anātma bhedasya aparama artha tvāt paramārtha bhedasya niṣedhe na anaikāntyam iti abhimānena śaṅkate aparama arthaḥ iti
translated: Because the distinction between the self and the non-self is not ultimate, there is no fallacy of inconclusive reason in the denial of the ultimate distinction. With this in mind, he doubts with If it is not ultimate.

analyzed: abhimānam nirākaroti paramārtha bhedaḥ iti
translated: He rejects the doubt with The ultimate distinction.
Bound by birth means pervaded by having origination.

analyzed: yat paramārtha bhedavat tat utpannam iti hi vyatireka vyāptiḥ vācyā
translated: For the pervasion by the negative concomitance must be stated thus: Whatever has the ultimate distinction is originated.

original: sā ca na / paramārthabhedasyaiva bhavannaye 'prasiddheḥ /🔽tathā ca viśeṣaṇadāne 'siddhiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: sā ca na parama artha bhedasya eva bhavat naye prasiddheḥ  tathā ca viśeṣaṇa dāne siddhi prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And that is not so, because the difference in the ultimate sense is not accepted in your system.🔽And in that case, if a qualifier is added, there is the undesirable consequence of non-establishment.

original: viśeṣaṇādāne cānaikāntyaṃ duṣpariharamiti bhāvaḥ /🔽naca paramārthatvarūpavyadhikaraṇadharmāvacchinnabhedaniṣṭhapratiyogitākābhāvaḥ sādhyate / tathā ca na
analyzed: viśeṣaṇa ādāne ca anaikāntyam duṣpariharam iti bhāvaḥ  naca paramārtha tva rūpa vyadhikaraṇa dharma avacchinna bheda niṣṭha pratiyogitāka abhāvaḥ sādhyate tathā ca na
translated: And if a qualifier is not added, the fallacy of inconclusive reason is difficult to avoid. This is the idea.

analyzed: doṣaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it is not to be said that the absence having as its counter-correlate the difference qualified by the property of being ultimate is to be established, and so there is no fault.

analyzed: evam api bhavat mate hetu sādhyayoḥ  sāhacarya graha upayogi pakṣa atirikta sthala antara abhāvāt vyāpya tva asiddhiḥ eva
translated: Even so, in your view, there is non-establishment of the pervasion,🔽because there is no other place apart from the subject which is useful for grasping the concomitance between the reason and the probandum.
Because the absence having as its counter-correlate the property which is the qualifier is only positive, and the pervasion by the negative concomitance is also difficult to state.

original: naca śāstrata eva saṃvinmātrasya nityatvaṃ nirbhedatvaṃ ca sidhyatīti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca śāstrataḥ eva saṃvid mātrasya nitya tvam nirbheda tvam ca sidhyati iti vācyam
translated: And it is not to be said that the eternality and partlessness of consciousness alone is established just from the scriptures.

analyzed: śāstrasya api bhavat mata vipratīpa tvāt
translated: Because the scriptures are also contrary to your view.

original: nityānāṃ cidacidīśvarādīnāṃ paramārthato bhedo hi śāstreṣu varṇyata ityanyatra vistaraḥ /
analyzed: nityānām cit acit īśvara ādīnām paramārthataḥ bhedaḥ hi śāstreṣu varṇyate iti anyatra vistaraḥ
translated: For, in the scriptures, the ultimate difference of the eternal, non-eternal, God and so on is described. The details are given elsewhere.

analyzed: agre ca vyaktībhaviṣyati
translated: And it will become clear later on.

original: saṃvidi sajātīyabhedaniṣedhe sādhyamāne pratyakṣabādhamāha nirbādhe ti /
analyzed: saṃvidi sajātīya bheda niṣedhe sādhyamāne pratyakṣa bādham āha nirbādhe ti
translated: When the exclusion of homogeneous difference is being proved in consciousness, he states the contradiction with perception in 'nirvāhya'.

analyzed: dṛś dṛśya bhedaḥ dṛśām
translated: The difference between the seer and the seen is of the seers.

analyzed: dṛśyānām
translated: Of the objects of perception.

analyzed: dṛś dṛśyānām ca mithas bhedaḥ
translated: And the difference between the seer and the seen.

analyzed: saṃvidaḥ svagata bheda niṣedha anumāne dūṣaṇam āha tat api iti
translated: Even in the inference of the exclusion of self-contained difference in consciousness, he states the fault in 'tat api'.

original: saṃviddharmāṇāṃ pramāṇasiddhatvakathanena saṃvidi dharmaniṣedhasādhanasya kālātyayāpadiṣṭatvaṃ phalitam /
analyzed: saṃvid dharmāṇām pramāṇa siddha tva kathanena saṃvidi dharma niṣedha sādhanasya kāla atyaya apadiṣṭa tvam phalitam
translated: By stating the establishment of the attributes of consciousness by means of valid cognition, the fact that the proof of the exclusion of attributes in consciousness is contradicted by time is implied.

original: ata eva saṃvitpakṣake vyatirekiṇi dharmapakṣake cānvayini saṃviddharmaniṣedhānumāne pakṣa eva vyabhicārodbhāvanaṃ ghaṭate /
analyzed: atas eva saṃvid pakṣake vyatirekiṇi dharma pakṣake ca anvayini saṃvid dharma niṣedha anumāne pakṣe eva vyabhicāra udbhāvanam ghaṭate
translated: For this very reason, the pointing out of the fallacy in the subject itself is possible in the case of the negative inference of attributes of consciousness in the case of the party who holds the view of consciousness, and in the case of the positive inference of attributes in the case of the party who holds the view of attributes.

original: nanu saṃviddharmāṇāṃ saṃvidabhinnatayā bhinnadharmaniṣedhānumāne na kṣatirityatrāha tatsiddhāvapī ti /
analyzed: nanu saṃvid dharmāṇām saṃvid abhinna tayā bhinna dharma niṣedha anumāne na kṣatiḥ iti atra āha tad siddhau api iti
translated: But if the attributes of consciousness are non-different from consciousness, there is no harm in the inference of the exclusion of different attributes. In this regard, he says 'tat siddhau api'.

original: vivādaviṣayāṇāṃ dharmāṇāṃ saṃpratipannasaṃvitsvarūpatā na ghaṭata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vivāda viṣayāṇām dharmāṇām saṃpratipanna saṃvid svarūpa tā na ghaṭate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the nature of the attributes which are the subject of dispute cannot be established as identical with the nature of consciousness which is accepted.

analyzed: ghaṭa paṭayoḥ iva ākāra bhedāt ca saṃvid tad dharmayoḥ na aikyam iti āha svarūpa bhedāt ca iti
translated: And because of the difference in form, like between a pot and a cloth, the consciousness and its attributes are not one. He says 'svabhāva bhedāt ca'.

analyzed: svarūpa bhedam eva upapādayati sva āśraya mityādinā
translated: He explains the difference in their nature by beginning with “The manifestation of an object to a cognizer.”

analyzed: kasyacid kiñcid arthasya            saṃvedanam iti bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: Of some object for someone.🔽Manifestation is the production of manifestation.🔽The explanation in terms of the abstract noun is predominant.

analyzed: saṃvedana tvam iti yāvat
translated: It means the nature of being a manifestation.

analyzed: yat vā prakāśanam prakāśakam
translated: Or, manifestation is that which manifests.

analyzed: ātmane svasmai
translated: To itself, to itself.

analyzed: sva āśrayāya vā  sva āśrayāya sva viṣaya prakāśaka tvam saṃvedanasya saṃvedana tvam
translated: Or to its own basis.🔽The nature of being a manifestation is the property of being a manifestation of consciousness, which is the property of consciousness of manifesting its own object.

original: svayaṃbhāsamānatvaṃ ca saṃvedanasya svayaṃprakāśatvamityenayordharmayoḥ svarūpabhedo bodhyaḥ /
analyzed: svayam bhāsamāna tvam ca saṃvedanasya svayam prakāśa tvam iti enayoḥ dharmayoḥ svarūpa bhedaḥ bodhyaḥ
translated: And the property of self-luminousness is the property of consciousness of being self-luminous. The difference in nature between these two properties should be understood.

analyzed: saṃvedana tva svayaṃprakāśa tva śarīra anupraviṣṭam prakāśa padārtham āha prakāśaḥ ca iti
translated: He explains the meaning of the word manifestation, which is included in the body of the nature of being a manifestation and self-luminousness, by saying manifestation is...

analyzed: prakāśaḥ yam dharma viśeṣaḥ
translated: This manifestation, which is synonymous with being known, is a particular property.

analyzed: ayam ca na jaḍa mātrasya
translated: And this is not just of the inert,

analyzed: kintu cit padārthasya api
translated: but also of the object of consciousness.

analyzed: tat ucyate cit acit aśeṣa padārtha sādhāraṇaḥ iti
translated: Therefore it is said to be common to all objects, both conscious and unconscious.

analyzed: saṃvid siddhau eva iti
translated: Only in the proof of consciousness...
The meaning is: in the proof of the self-luminousness of consciousness.

analyzed: yat vā saṃvitsiddhi nāmake prakaraṇe eva iti arthaḥ
translated: Or the meaning is that it is in the chapter itself named the Establishment of Consciousness.

analyzed: etena ātma siddheḥ pūrvam eva saṃvid siddheḥ kṛta tvam jñāyate
translated: By this it is known that the establishment of consciousness has already been done even before the establishment of the self.

analyzed: yadi api upalabhyamāne saṃvitsiddhi grantha bhāge prakāśa padārtha nirūpaṇam na upalabhyate
translated: Although in the part of the text on the establishment of consciousness that is available, the examination of the meaning of light is not found,

original: athāpi saṃvitsiddhaubhūyāṃso bhāgā ādāvante madhye ca viluptāḥ /
analyzed: atha api saṃvid siddhau bhūyāṃsaḥ bhāgāḥ ādau ante madhye ca viluptāḥ
translated: nevertheless, in the establishment of consciousness, many parts have been lost at the beginning, end, and middle.

analyzed: tatra etat saṃbhavati iti dhyeyam
translated: It should be contemplated that this is possible there.

analyzed: dharma antara prakāśa anabhyupagame pi āha tad anabhyupagame iti
translated: Even when the manifestation of other properties is not accepted, he says if that is not accepted.

analyzed: vyavahāra ānuguṇyam eva jñāna adhīnam prakāśa śabditam
translated: The conformity with usage, which is dependent on knowledge, is called manifestation.

analyzed: avyavahliyamāṇasya api jñānataḥ vyavahāra yogya tā kṣuṇṇā eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even for one who is not engaged in usage, the capacity for usage is not destroyed by knowledge.
The determination by the number one is the possession of the number one.

analyzed: śaṅkate na ca jaḍa tve ti  jaḍa tva abhāvaḥ
translated: He doubts, And if it is insentient...

analyzed: kāśa tvam deśa kāla aparicchinna tve vibhu tva nitya tve
translated: The absence of insentience is self-manifestation. Being without limitation of space and time is omnipresence and eternity.

analyzed: bahu tva abhāvaḥ eka tvam
translated: The absence of plurality is oneness.

analyzed: na tu etāni bhāva rūpāṇi
translated: But these are not properties of existence.

original: abhāvasya cādhikaraṇātmakatvānna saṃvidaḥ sadharmatvaṃ prasajatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: abhāvasya ca adhikaraṇa ātmaka tvāt na saṃvidaḥ sadharma tvam prasajati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And since non-existence has the nature of a substratum, it does not follow that consciousness has the same property. This is the idea.

analyzed: pariharati tathābhūtaiḥ api iti
translated: He answers: Even by such [properties].

analyzed: abhāvānām atirikta tvam adhikaraṇa vṛtti dharma antara rūpa tvam vā
translated: Either non-existences are separate, or they have the nature of another property that occurs in the substratum.

analyzed: ādhāra ādheya bhāva pratīti svārasyāt iti abhāva rūpaiḥ api sadharma tvam avarjanīyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Even by properties that have the form of non-existence, the fact of having the same property cannot be avoided, because of the naturalness of the cognition of the relation of container and contained. This is the meaning.

original: yasmin pratīte niṣedhyabuddhirnodeti tasyaivābhāvarūpatvam /🔽pratīyamānāyāmapi saṃvidi anityatvādisaṃśayodayācca na tadabhāvarūpatvaṃ tasyāḥ /
analyzed: yasmin pratīte niṣedhya buddhiḥ nā udeti tasya eva abhāva rūpa tvam  pratīyamānāyām api saṃvidi anitya tva ādi saṃśaya udayāt ca na tad abhāva rūpa tvam tasyāḥ
translated: That of which the cognition of the negatee does not arise when it is cognized, that alone has the form of non-existence.🔽And because doubt about impermanence, etc. arises even when consciousness is being cognized, it does not have the form of non-existence.

analyzed: kintu sarva kāla saṃbandhi tva ādi virodhi dharma antara lakṣaṇam eva nitya tva ādi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But permanence, etc. is characterized by another property that is incompatible with being related to all times, etc. This is the idea.

analyzed: saṃvidi ti
translated: Of consciousness.

analyzed: virodhi dharmavat tā bodhanam antarā jaḍa tva ādi niṣedhaka tva anupapattiḥ pratijñāyāḥ
translated: Without the cognition of having a property that is incompatible, the proposition cannot be established as negating insentience, etc.

analyzed: tad bodhane ca sadharma tva siddhiḥ avarjanīyā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And when that is cognized, the fact of having the same property is established and cannot be avoided. This is the idea.

original: naca jaḍatvādivirodhisvarūpatvameva pratijñayā bodhyate saṃvido na virodhidharmavattvamiti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca jaḍa tva ādi virodhi svarūpa tvam eva pratijñayā bodhyate saṃvidaḥ na virodhi dharmavat tvam iti vācyam
translated: Nor can it be said that the thesis only teaches the nature of consciousness as not being opposed by the nature of inertness etc., not the possession of contradictory properties.

analyzed: sarva adhyāsa adhiṣṭhāna bhūtāyāḥ tasyāḥ sarva virodhi tva asiddheḥ
translated: For it is not established that it, which is the substratum of all superimpositions, is opposed to everything.

analyzed: na ca śuddhā sā tathā iti vācyam
translated: Nor can it be said that it is pure in that way.

analyzed: tasyāḥ sarva viśeṣa pratyanīka tva upagame jaḍa tva ādi pratyanīka tā iva ajaḍa tva ādi pratyanīka tā api iti jaḍa ajaḍa vilakṣaṇa tva ādi prasaṅgāt
translated: For if it is accepted that it is opposed to all distinctions, then it is also opposed to inertness etc., so the consequence is that it is different from the inert and the non-inert etc.

original: ajaḍatvādyabhāve 'pi ajaḍādisvarūpaiva seti ceddharmatvābhāve 'pi dharmasvarūpaiva sā kiṃ na syāditi dik /
analyzed: ajaḍa tva ādi abhāve pi ajaḍa ādi svarūpā eva sā iti ced dharma tva abhāve pi dharma svarūpā eva sā kim na syāt iti diś
translated: If it is argued that even in the absence of non-inertness etc., it is just the nature of non-inert etc., then it may be asked why it cannot be just the nature of properties even in the absence of being a property.

analyzed: bheda ādi dharma pakṣaka cit saṃbandhi tva abhāva sādhane na aikāntyam api āha cetyam iti
translated: He also says that there is inconclusiveness in proving the absence of the relation of consciousness with the property of difference etc., with the word cetas.

analyzed: cetyam anubhāvyam
translated: Cetas means what is to be experienced.

analyzed: ātmani cit mātre ātmani
translated: Ātmani means in the self, in mere consciousness.

analyzed: kiñca cit dharma tva abhāva sādhanam anupapannam
translated: Moreover, the proof of the absence of being a property of consciousness is not proper.

analyzed: pratiyogi aprasiddheḥ
translated: Because the counter-correlate is not well-known.

original: dharmā na cita ityapi na sādhīyaḥ /
analyzed: dharmāḥ na citaḥ iti api na sādhīyaḥ
translated: The properties are not consciousness is also not a good argument.

original: ṣaṣṭhyarthasya saṃbandhasya citpadārthenānanvayādbhavatāsityāha api ce ti /
analyzed: ṣaṣṭhī arthasya saṃbandhasya cit padārthena ananvayāt bhavatā as iti āha api ca iti
translated: Because the relation denoted by the genitive case does not apply to the word cit (consciousness), he says Moreover.

original: pratyayānāṃ prakṛtyarthānvitasvārthabodhakatvavyutpatteḥ cito vibhaktyarthasaṃbandhitvaṃ siddhamiti tatra viśeṣasāmānyaniṣedhapratijñā vyāhatārtheti
analyzed: pratyayānām prakṛti artha anvita sva artha bodhaka tva vyutpatteḥ citaḥ vibhakti artha saṃbandhi tvam siddham iti tatra viśeṣa sāmānya niṣedha pratijñā vyāhata arthā iti
translated: Since it is well-known that affixes denote their own meaning in relation to the meaning of the verbal root, it is established that consciousness is related to the meaning of the case endings. Therefore, the proposition to negate the particular and the general in that (consciousness) is contradictory.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the idea.

analyzed: siddhiḥ ced abhyupeyeta saṃvidaḥ syāt sadharma tā
translated: If establishment is accepted, consciousness would have properties.

analyzed: na ced tuccha tvam eva uktam bhavet śaśaviṣāṇa vat
translated: If not, it would be said to be empty, like the horn of a rabbit.

analyzed: nanu siddhiḥ eva sā
translated: But is it not established?

analyzed: kasya bhoḥ yadi na kasyacid
translated: Whose? If not anyone's,

analyzed: na tarhi siddhiḥ eva
translated: then it is not established.

analyzed: sā hi putra tvam iva kasyacid kiñcid prati
translated: For that (establishment) is like sonship for someone in relation to something.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said to be of the self,

analyzed: kaḥ ṣaṣṭhī arthaḥ
translated: what is the meaning of the genitive case?

original: tadevaṃ vyomāravindasadṛśavapuṣi yathoditadṛśi vedāntatātparyavarṇanaṃ vedāntāyaiva syāt /
analyzed: tat evam vyoma aravinda sadṛśa vapuṣi yathā udita dṛśi vedānta tātparya varṇanam vedāntāya eva syāt
translated: Thus, the description of the purport of the Vedanta in the consciousness that is like the body of a sky-lotus and has the vision as stated would be for the Vedanta itself.

analyzed: api ca nitya tve pi anubhuteḥ pratyabhijñā anupapattiḥ tad avasthā eva
translated: Moreover, even if experience is eternal, the non-apprehension of recognition remains as it is.

analyzed: sā hi anubhavitāram pūrva apara kāla avasthāyinam upasthāpayati aham idam anvabhūvam iti
translated: For it presents the experiencer as existing in the earlier and later times, as in the thought I experienced this.

analyzed: anubhūtiḥ tu anubhūtiḥ eva bhavatām
translated: But for you, experience is just experience.

original: na tāṃ prati sā kartrīṃ karma vā /
analyzed: na tām prati sā kartrīm karma vā
translated: It is neither the agent nor the object with respect to that.

analyzed: iti māyā vādi abhimata nitya vijñāna ātma tva nirāsa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the refutation of the doctrine of the eternal consciousness-self as accepted by the Mādhyamikas.

original: yadyucyeta paramārthataḥ tathābhūtāpi bhrāntyānubhavitṛtayā parisphurati rajatatayeva śuktiḥ /
analyzed: yadi ucyeta paramārthataḥ tathābhūtā api bhrāntyā anubhavitṛ tayā parisphurati rajata tayā iva śuktiḥ
translated: If it is said that although it is really so, it appears as the experiencer due to delusion, just as a shell appears as silver,

analyzed: na hi tathyam an avalambya mithyā avabhāsasya utthānam iti tat na
translated: for the false appearance does not arise without relying on the real, that is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati anubhava samāna adhikaraṇa tayā anubhavitā ahamarthaḥ prakāśeta anubhūtiḥ aham iti  puras sthita bhāsvara dravya śaṅkha mukha candra ādeḥ ākāra tayā iva rajata pīta mukura stha tā dvi tva ādi
translated: For if that were so, the experiencer, which is of the same domain as experience, would appear as the meaning of I, as in I experience.🔽Just as the form of a bright substance like a conch shell or the moon in the mouth appears as silver, yellow, or duality in a mirror, etc.

original: pṛthagavabhāsamāna eva tu ayamanubhavo daṇḍa iva devadattamarthāntaramahamarthaṃviśiṃṣan ālakṣyate anubhavāmyahamiti /
analyzed: pṛthak avabhāsamānaḥ eva tu ayam anubhavaḥ daṇḍaḥ iva devadattam artha antaram aham artham viśiṃṣan ālakṣyate anubhavāmi aham iti
translated: But this experience is seen as distinct, distinguishing the meaning of I as a different object like a stick, as in I experience.

analyzed: tat evam anubhava viśiṣṭam asmat artham avabhāsayan ayam ahaṃpratyayaḥ katham iva viśeṣaṇa bhūta anubhūti mātra avalambanaḥ pratijñāyeta
translated: Thus, this notion of 'I', manifesting the object 'I' along with the experience, how can it be said to be based merely on the qualifying experience alone?

original: daṇḍamātra iva daṇḍī devadatta iti pratyayaḥ /
analyzed: daṇḍa mātraḥ iva daṇḍī devadattaḥ iti pratyayaḥ
translated: Just as the notion 'Devadatta with a stick' is based on the stick alone.

original: kutaścaiṣa niścayaḥadhyastaṃ jñātṛtvamiti / /🔽sthūlo 'hamitivat dehātmābhimānavataḥ pratibhāsanāditi cet /
analyzed: kutas ca eṣa niścayaḥ adhyastam jñātṛ tvam iti  sthūlaḥ ham iti vat deha ātma abhimānavataḥ pratibhāsanāt iti ced
translated: And how is this ascertained that the experience is superimposed on the knower?🔽If it is argued that it appears to one who has the notion of the body as the self, as 'I am gross',

original: nanvātmatayābhimatānubhūtirapi tadūta evāvabhātīti sāpi tathā syāt /
analyzed: nanu ātma tayā abhimata anubhūtiḥ api tad ūtaḥ evā avabhāti iti sā api tathā syāt
translated: then the experience that is considered as the self also appears as that alone. Therefore, that too would be so.

original: tattvajñānodayāt parato 'pi tadanuvṛtterna tathā seti cet / kiṃ bhoḥ/🔽tattvajñānātparamaboddhaivāyamātmā /
analyzed: tattva jñāna udayāt tad anuvṛtteḥ na tathā sā iti ced kim bhoḥ  tattva jñānāt parama boddhā eva ayam ātmā
translated: If it is argued that even after the rise of the knowledge of reality, its continuation is not so, then what is this?

analyzed: hanta evam tattva vedi tvam
translated: The self is indeed to be known only after the rise of the knowledge of reality.🔽Alas, it is better to be one who does not know the truth in this way.

original: bhrāntyāpi hi tatra bahu bhadraṃ paśyatīti /
analyzed: bhrāntyā api hi tatra bahu bhadram paśyati iti
translated: For one who has the notion of the self, even through error, sees much good in it.

analyzed: nanu jñātṛ tvam jñāna kriyā kartṛ tvam vikriyā ātmakam jaḍam ahaṅkāra granthi stham
translated: Is it not that the state of being a knower, which is the state of being an agent of the action of knowing, is subject to change, is inert, and resides in the knot of egoism?

analyzed: tad phala bhuj akartā avikriyaḥ sākṣī prakāśa mātraḥ ātmā
translated: The experiencer of its fruits is the agent, is changeless, is the witness, is light alone, is the self.

analyzed: kartṛ tva ādiḥ hi dṛśya tvāt rūpa ādi vat na ātma dharmaḥ
translated: For the state of being an agent, etc., is not a property of the self, like color, etc., because it is perceptible.

analyzed: kartṛ tve hi ātmanaḥ haṃpratyaya gocara tve pi dehasya iva an atma tva parārtha tva jaḍa tva ādi prasaṅgaḥ durnivāraḥ
translated: For if the self were an agent, then even though it is the object of the notion of I, the undesirable consequence of its being non-self, serving the purpose of another, being inert, etc., like the body, would be unavoidable.

original: dṛṣṭaṃ ca laukikavaidikakarmasu kartṛtayā prasiddhāddehāttatkriyāphalabhujaḥ pramātuḥ ahaṃpratyayinaḥ pṛthaktvam /
analyzed: dṛṣṭam ca laukika vaidika karmasu kartṛ tayā prasiddhāt dehāt tad kriyā phala bhujaḥ pramātuḥ ahaṃpratyayinaḥ pṛthaktvam
translated: And in worldly and Vedic rites, the difference of the cognizer, who experiences the fruits of those actions, from the body, which is well-known as the agent, is seen.

analyzed: tathā iha api pramātuḥ ahamarthāt vilakṣaṇaḥ sākṣī pratyagātmā iti yuktam
translated: Similarly, here also, it is proper to say that the witness, the inner self, is different from the object of I of the cognizer.

original: naivaṃ yuktam /🔽ahaṃ jānāmīti jñātṛtayā sidhyataḥ pratyagātmano vyatirekeṇa sikṣiṇo nāma prakāśamātrasyā'tmano 'nupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: na evam yuktam  aham jānāmi iti jñātṛ tayā sidhyataḥ pratyagātmanaḥ vyatirekeṇa sikṣiṇaḥ nāma prakāśa mātrasya ātmanaḥ n upalabdheḥ
translated: This is not proper.🔽Because, except for the inner self, which is established as the knower by the cognition I know, there is no perception of the self, which is mere light and is different from it.

original: dehendriyamanaḥprāṇavijñānebhyo jñānāśrayatayā vivicyamāne pratīpamañcatīva nirbhāsamāno 'haṃbhāva eva hi pratyaktvaṃ nāma /🔽sākṣitvamapi tasya sākṣājjñātṛtvam /
analyzed: deha indriya manaḥ prāṇa vijñānebhyaḥ jñāna āśraya tayā vivicyamāne pratīpam añcati iva nirbhāsamānaḥ haṃbhāvaḥ eva hi pratyaktvam nāma  sākṣi tvam api tasya sākṣāt jñātṛ tvam
translated: The state of being the inner self is indeed the notion of I, which appears as if it were receding when the self is distinguished from the body, sense organs, mind, life force, and consciousness as the substratum of cognition.🔽Witnessing is also its direct knowing.

analyzed: na hi ajānan sikṣi iti apadiśyate
translated: For one who does not know is not called a witness.

original: sarvaṃ ca prakāśamānaṃ jñātre 'hamiti cakāsate prakāśata iti pratyātmasiddho 'yamanubhavaḥ ahaṃ jānāmi /
analyzed: sarvam ca prakāśamānam jñātre ham iti cakāsate prakāśate iti pratyātma siddhaḥ yam anubhavaḥ aham jānāmi
translated: And everything that is manifest shines forth as 'I' in the knower. This experience is established in every person's self: 'I know',

analyzed: mahyam prakāśate iti
translated: 'It is manifest to me'.

analyzed: iti jñātuḥ ahamarthasya pratyagātma tva nirūpaṇam
translated: Thus the definition of the knower, the meaning of 'I', as being the inner self.

analyzed: na ca avyākṛta pariṇāma bhedasya ahaṅkāra nāmnaḥ buddhi nāmadheyasya vā jñātṛ tvam
translated: And the consciousness called 'I', which is a modification of the unmanifest, or the intellect called 'I', cannot be the knower.

analyzed: dehasya iva acetana tva pariṇāmi tva jaḍa tva parārtha tva ādi hetubhiḥ tad anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not logically possible for them to be the knower on the grounds that they are insentient, are modifications, are inert, are for the sake of another, and so on, like the body.

analyzed: na ca citi chāyā āpattyā tayoḥ tad saṃbhavaḥ
translated: And it is not possible for them to be the knower by the attainment of the reflection of consciousness.

analyzed: acākṣuṣasya chāyā darśanāt
translated: Because the reflection of what is not seen by the eyes is not seen.

original: na ca jñātṛtvaṃ citāvapi te vāstavamasti /
analyzed: na ca jñātṛ tvam citau api te vāstavam asti
translated: And the knowership does not really exist in consciousness either.

original: yenāgnisaṃparkādayaḥ piṇḍa ivauṣṇyaṃ tatsaṃparkādarthāntare jñātṛtvaṃ jāyeta jñāyeta vā /
analyzed: yena agni saṃparka ādayaḥ piṇḍe iva auṣṇyam tad saṃparkāt artha antare jñātṛ tvam jāyeta jñāyeta vā
translated: By which, like a lump of clay, the knowership would arise or be known in another thing by contact with it, like heat by contact with fire.

analyzed: iti ahaṅkārasya jñātṛ tva tad pratīti anupapatti nirūpaṇam
translated: Thus the definition of the impossibility of the knowership and the cognition of 'I' in egoism.

analyzed: yadi ucyeta jñāpti mātram eva ātmānam abhivyañjan acetanaḥ u pi ahaṅkāraḥ svāśrayatayā tam abhivyanakti
translated: If it is said that even the insentient ego, manifesting only the cognition of the self, manifests that self as its substratum, like a mirror,

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ hi ayam vyañjakānām yat ātma stha tayā abhivyaṅgyam abhivyañjanti
translated: For this is the nature of the manifestors, that they manifest what is to be manifested by being present in themselves.

analyzed: darpaṇa jala khaṇḍa muṇḍa ādayaḥ iva mukha mihira bimba go tva ādīn
translated: Like mirrors, water-pots, and heads manifest faces, sun-images, and cow-horns.

analyzed: tad kṛtaḥ ca ayam aham jānāmi iti bhramaḥ
translated: And this delusion I know is produced by that.

original: ata eva khalu ahamullekhavigame suṣuptimuktayoḥ svābhāvikaviśadānubhavamātrarūpeṇā'tmanaḥ prakāśaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva khalu aham ullekha vigame suṣupti muktayoḥ svābhāvika viśada anubhava mātra rūpeṇa ātmanaḥ prakāśaḥ
translated: For this very reason, indeed, in the absence of the reflection I in deep sleep and liberation, the manifestation of the self is only in the form of the natural pure experience.

analyzed: tatas eva ca anātma tvam ahamarthasya
translated: And for this very reason, the object of I is not the self.

analyzed: tathā ca saura īśam vacaḥ
translated: And in this way, the statement of Suresha (Shankaracharya):

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ced aham dharmaḥ yāyāt mukti suṣuptayoḥ
translated: If the self were the attribute of 'I', it would go to liberation and deep sleep,

analyzed: yatas na anveti tena ayam anyadīyaḥ bhavet aham iti
translated: Since it does not follow from that, this 'I' would belong to another.

analyzed: iti ahaṅkārasya saṃvid abhivyañjaka tva pūrvapakṣa upapādanam
translated: Thus, the explanation of the prima facie view that ego is the manifester of consciousness.

original: prakārāntareṇāpi saṃvidaḥ sadharmakatvaṃ sādhayati siddhiśce diti /
analyzed: prakāra antareṇa api saṃvidaḥ sadharmaka tvam sādhayati siddhiḥ ced iti
translated: He establishes the property of consciousness in another way also by saying and success.

analyzed: siddhiḥ prakāśaḥ
translated: Success is manifestation.

analyzed: tad upagame tena eva saṃvidaḥ sadharma tā syāt
translated: If that is accepted, then by that alone consciousness would have the property.

original: tadanupagame tu śaśaviṣāṇādivadaprakāśamānāyā asiddhyantyāstasyāstucchatvameva prasajyata iti kārikārthaḥ ////
analyzed: tad anupagame tu śaśaviṣāṇa ādi vat aprakāśamānāyāḥ asiddhi antyāḥ tasyāḥ tuccha tvam eva prasajyate iti kārikā arthaḥ
translated: But if it is not accepted, then like the horn of a hare, being unilluminated and unestablished, it would only result in its being empty. This is the meaning of the verse.

analyzed: atra śaṅkate nanu siddhiḥ eva iti
translated: Here he raises the doubt: But surely establishment itself...

analyzed: na prakāśa āśrayaḥ  kintu prakāśa svarūpā eva saṃvid
translated: is not the substratum of illumination,🔽but rather consciousness is the very form of illumination.

analyzed: tat na tuccha tvam sadharmaka tvam vā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that it is not empty or endowed with properties.

analyzed: ākṣipati kasya bho r iti
translated: He raises the objection: Whose, sir?

original: saviśeṣatvaprasaṅgādbhītaḥ para āha na kasyaci diti /🔽prativakti siddhāntī na tarhī ti /
analyzed: sa viśeṣa tva prasaṅgāt bhītaḥ paraḥ āha na kasyacid iti  prativakti siddhāntī na tarhi ti
translated: Fearing the consequence of having a distinction, the opponent says: Of no one.🔽The proponent of the established doctrine replies: Then not of consciousness.

original: prakāśo hi dharmo vinā dharmiṇā na ghaṭata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: prakāśaḥ hi dharmaḥ vinā dharmiṇā na ghaṭate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that illumination is not possible without a substratum.

original: siddheḥ sasaṃbandhikatvaṃ vyutpādayati sā hī ti /
analyzed: siddheḥ sa saṃbandhika tvam vyutpādayati sā hi iti
translated: He explains the relation of establishment: For establishment...

analyzed: pituḥ hi putraḥ
translated: The son of the father,

analyzed: putra tvam iva anuyogi pratiyogi sāpekṣā siddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: like the relation of son, establishment is dependent on the object of relation and the counter-correlate. This is the point.

analyzed: ananyagatikatayā āha ātmanaḥ iti
translated: Out of the necessity of having no other recourse, he says of the self.

analyzed: ātma anuyogikā ātma pratiyogikā eva siddhiḥ saṃvidaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the establishment of consciousness is only in relation to itself as the object and itself as the counter-correlate.

analyzed: ātma śabdaḥ tra svarūpa vācī
translated: The word self here denotes its own nature.

original: evaṃ cet sadharmatvamāyātyeva saṃvida ityāha ka iti /
analyzed: evam ced sadharma tvam āyāti eva saṃvidaḥ iti āha kaḥ iti
translated: If it is so, then consciousness does come to have properties. He says What?

original: pitaraṃ prati putrasya putratvamivātmapratiyogikaḥ prakāśo dharmaḥ saṃvidātmanaḥ sidhyatītyarthaḥ / evaṃ kāri
analyzed: pitaram prati putrasya putra tvam iva ātma pratiyogikaḥ prakāśaḥ dharmaḥ saṃvid ātmanaḥ sidhyati iti arthaḥ evam kāri
translated: The meaning is that just as sonship is the property of a son with respect to his father, so too the property of manifestation with respect to the self is established for the nature of consciousness.

analyzed: ākṣepa parihāra padakaiḥ katibhiḥ cit vivṛtaḥ
translated: Thus, the meaning of the word eva is explained by a few words of objection and reply.

original: evaṃ saṃvido nirviśeṣatvaṃ nirasya nirviśeṣasaṃvidi vedāntatātparyavarṇanaṃ vedāntānāmaprāmāṇyapraryavasāyītyāha tadevam iti /
analyzed: evam saṃvidaḥ nirviśeṣa tvam nirasya nirviśeṣa saṃvidi vedānta tātparya varṇanam vedāntānām aprāmāṇya praryavasāyi iti āha tat evam iti
translated: Having thus refuted the non-distinction of consciousness, he says That being so that the purport of the Vedanta in the non-distinguished consciousness leads to the conclusion of the unreality of the Vedanta.

analyzed: vedāntāya veda vināśāya
translated: For the destruction of the Vedas.

analyzed: veda prāmāṇya ucchittyai iti yāvat
translated: That is, for the removal of the validity of the Vedas.

original: kṣaṇikavijñānātmavāde smaraṇādyanupapattyā niraste hi nityavijñānātmavādina utthānam /
analyzed: kṣaṇika vijñāna ātma vāde smaraṇa ādi anupapattyā niraste hi nitya vijñāna ātma vādinaḥ utthānam
translated: When the doctrine of the momentary consciousness-self has been refuted by the impossibility of memory etc., the proponents of the eternal consciousness-self rise up.

original: etatpakṣe 'pi tāmāha api ce ti /🔽jñāturnityatva evāhamidamanvabhavamityāderupapattiḥ /
analyzed: etad pakṣe tām āha api ca iti  jñātuḥ nitya tve eva aham idam anvabhavam ityādeḥ upapattiḥ
translated: In this view also, he states that objection with And moreover.🔽The establishment of the self as eternal is the basis for the statement I experienced this.

analyzed: na tu jñāna nitya tva mātreṇa iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Not merely by the eternality of knowledge. This is the idea.

analyzed: etat eva vivṛṇoti anubhūtiḥ riti
translated: He explains this very thing with Experience.

analyzed: eva kāra artham āha na tām iti
translated: He states the meaning of the word eva with Not that.

analyzed: yadi api siddhānte na anubhavitṛ tvam anubhūteḥ
translated: Even in the established view, the experiencer is not the experience.

analyzed: atha api anubhāvya tvam iṣyate
translated: But even then, the object of experience is accepted.

analyzed: jñātuḥ ca ahamarthasya ātmanaḥ nitya tvam
translated: And of the knower, the object, the self, there is eternality.

analyzed: tathā ca pūrva anubhūta anubhūti ādi pratisandhānam ghaṭate
translated: And thus the recollection of what was previously experienced is possible.

analyzed: para mate tu ananubhāvya tvāt ananubhavitṛ tvāt ca saṃvid ātmanaḥ nirukta pratisandhāna anupapattiḥ eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But in the opponent's view, due to consciousness not being experienced and not being the experiencer, the stated recollection is impossible. This is the idea.

original: tadevaṃ pratisandhānabalājjñāturevātmatvaṃ na jñānamātrasyeti sthita hṛdi /
analyzed: tat evam pratisandhāna balāt jñātuḥ eva ātmatvam na jñāna mātrasya iti sthita hṛdi
translated: Thus, by the power of recollection, the knower alone is the self, not mere knowledge. This being established in the heart,

analyzed: etat eva samarthayiṣyati agrima grantha sandarbheṇa
translated: he will prove this very thing with the following series of texts.

analyzed: tatra ādau jñātṛ tva pratīteḥ bhrānti rūpa tām para abhimatām anuvadati yadi ucyete ti
translated: There, at the beginning, he repeats the idea of the falsity of the cognition of the knower, which is accepted by the opponent, with the words If it is said.
Consciousness alone is the ultimate reality.

analyzed: saḥ eva ātmā
translated: That alone is the self.

analyzed: asmin adhiṣṭhāne jñātuḥ aham arthasya bhrāntiḥ śuktau iva rajatasya
translated: On this basis, the knower, the object of the notion of I, is an illusion, like silver in a shell.

analyzed: bhrama upapatti artham adhiṣṭhāna saṃvid mātra pāramārthyam abhyupeyam iti pareṣām āśayaḥ  dūṣayati tat na iti
translated: The idea of the opponents is that in order for the illusion to be possible, the ultimate reality of consciousness alone, which is the basis, must be accepted.🔽He refutes this with the words That is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati ti
translated: If it were so,

original: ayamāśayaḥ dharmiṇi dharmyantarārope āropyādhiṣṭhānayoḥ samānādhikaraṇyena abhedena
analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ dharmiṇi dharmi antara ārope āropya adhiṣṭhānayoḥ samāna ādhikaraṇyena abhedena
translated: The idea is this: In the superimposition of one thing on another, the superimposition and the basis are on the same level, without distinction,

original: bhānaṃ bhavedidaṃ rajatamiti yathā /🔽anyatrānyadharmārope cāropyadharmavatā tathā bhānaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ śaṅkhaḥ pītavān /
analyzed: bhānam bhavet idam rajatam iti yathā  anyatra anya dharma ārope ca āropya dharmavatā tathā bhānam dṛṣṭam śaṅkhaḥ pītavān
translated: As in This is silver, where the form of silver is superimposed on something else.

analyzed: mukha darpaṇa stham
translated: And the shining of something else with the attribute of what is superimposed is seen, as in The yellow conch, The face in the mirror,

analyzed: candrau dvau iti
translated: The two moons.

original: na caivamatrānubhūtirahamiti vā ahaṃvatīti vā bhānamasti /
analyzed: na ca evam atra anubhūtiḥ aham iti vā ahaṃvatī iti vā bhānam asti
translated: And there is no such experience here, either as I or as having I.

analyzed: tat na saṃvidi ahamartha āropaḥ iti yuktam iti
translated: Therefore it is not reasonable that the attribute of the object I is superimposed on consciousness.

original: ahamarthe saṃvidāropopagamastu na ghaṭate pareṣāṃ satyālambanatvaniyamādāropasya /
analyzed: aham arthe saṃvid āropa upagamaḥ tu na ghaṭate pareṣām satya ālambana tva niyamāt āropasya
translated: But the acceptance of the superimposition of consciousness on the object I does not hold for others, because of the restriction of superimposition to what is real,
