translated: For, according to Kanabhaksha's view, liberation is characterized by the complete cessation of all the specific qualities of the self such as intellect, pleasure, pain, etc.

original: na cātyantaluptakāryaṃ vastu tatkāryajananaśaktamityatra kiñcitpramāṇaṃ kramate /
analyzed: na ca atyanta lupta kāryam vastu tad kārya janana śaktam iti atra kiñcid pramāṇam kramate
translated: And there is no valid means of knowledge that a thing which is completely destroyed cannot have the power to produce its effect.

analyzed: deha ādi viśiṣṭa saṃbandhi tayā dṛśyamāna sukha duḥkha jñāna ādi kāryam viśiṣṭa vartinīm eva ātma utpāda śaktim kalpayati
translated: The effect such as pleasure, pain, knowledge, etc. which is seen as related to the body etc. postulates only the power to produce the self which exists in the specific [effect].

analyzed: dhūmaḥ iva ārdra indhana saṃbandhini dhūmadhvaje sva utpādana sāmarthyam
translated: Just as the power to produce itself in the smoky banner related to wet fuel [is inferred from the smoke].

analyzed: vrīhi aṅkure iva ca sa tuṣa taṇḍule
translated: And just as the sprout of rice in the husked rice.

original: api ca bodhe satyevātmano 'nātmavyavacchede saṃbhavati kṛtaṃ tacchaktayāśrayaṇena /
analyzed: api ca bodhe sati eva ātmanaḥ na ātma vyavacchede saṃbhavati kṛtam tad śaktayā āśrayaṇena
translated: Moreover, when the self is seen to be distinguished from the non-self only when there is consciousness, it is enough to postulate that power.

original: na caivaṃ sati bodha eva paramātmeti yuktam /
analyzed: na ca evam sati bodhaḥ eva paramātmā iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that thus the supreme self is consciousness itself.

original: tasyā'śrayapratiyogisāpekṣasvarūpatvādātmanaśca tadviparītasvabhāvatvāt /🔽sākṣācca cetayiturahamarthasya sphuraṇāt /🔽anubhavatarkāgamabalena citimata ātmabhāvasyānantarameva prapañcitatvācca /
analyzed: tasya āśraya pratiyogi sāpekṣa svarūpa tvāt ātmanaḥ ca tad viparīta svabhāva tvāt  sākṣāt ca cetayituḥ ahamarthasya sphuraṇāt  anubhava tarka āgama balena citimataḥ ātma bhāvasya anantaram eva prapañcita tvāt ca
translated: Because the nature of consciousness depends on a substratum and an object, and the nature of the self is the opposite of that.🔽And because the object of the notion of I, which is the experiencer, is directly manifested.🔽And because the nature of the self as the substratum of consciousness has been fully discussed immediately after.

original: naca citimātrātmavāde 'pi tasyāgantukaviṣayasaṃbandhe bodhatvamadhyāropya boddhṛtvasamarthanaṃ sādhīyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca citi mātra ātma vāde pi tasya āgantuka viṣaya saṃbandhe bodha tvam adhyāropya boddhṛ tva samarthanam sādhīyaḥ
translated: And even in the doctrine of the self as mere consciousness, it is not proper to establish the self as the experiencer by superimposing the nature of consciousness on the adventitious relation with an object.

analyzed: saṃbandhasya ubhaya niṣṭha tayā arthasya api boddhṛ tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because, the relation being common to both, the object also would be the experiencer.

analyzed: na ca kārya kāraṇa bhāvavat vyavasthi tvam
translated: And it is not like the relation of cause and effect, which is restricted.

analyzed: tatra janimataḥ janayituḥ ca paraspara apekṣā niyama lakṣaṇa saṃbandhaḥ
translated: There, the relation in the form of mutual dependence is restricted to the produced and the producer.

analyzed: iha api saḥ eva iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the same is the case here also, it is not so.

analyzed: apekṣā hetu abhāvāt  kimartham arthaḥ caitanyam apekṣate
translated: Because there is no cause for dependence.🔽For what purpose does the object depend on consciousness?

analyzed: caitanyam vā artham
translated: Or does consciousness depend on the object?

analyzed: siddhi artham iti ced
translated: If it is said it is for the purpose of manifestation,

analyzed: kaḥ siddhi arthaḥ
translated: what is the purpose of manifestation?

analyzed: na tāvat utpattiḥ
translated: First, it is not production.

analyzed: tasyāḥ nirjñāta nimitta antara tvāt
translated: Because its cause is already known.

original: ghaṭādayo hi prasiddhamṛddaṇḍacakrabhramaṇādiparyāptanimittāntara śālino na citimapi nijajanane 'pekṣante /
analyzed: ghaṭa ādayaḥ hi prasiddha mṛd daṇḍa cakra bhramaṇa ādi paryāpta nimitta antara śālinaḥ na citim api nija janane pekṣante
translated: For pots and such things, which have sufficient other causes such as well-known clay, stick, wheel-rotation, etc., do not even depend on consciousness for their own production.

analyzed: nirastaḥ ca vijñāna mātra vādaḥ
translated: And the doctrine of consciousness-only has been refuted.

analyzed: nityasya ātmanaḥ utpatti artham artha apekṣā iti su vyāhṛtam
translated: It is well-said that the eternal self depends on an object for production.

analyzed: siddhiḥ prakāśaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the establishment is illumination,

analyzed: kim bhoḥ ātmā svayam jyotiḥ api artha adhīna prakāśaḥ
translated: then is the self, though self-luminous, dependent on an object for illumination?

analyzed: yat asau tad artham artham apekṣate
translated: That it depends on an object for that purpose.

analyzed: mahanīyam idam ātma vedi tvam  prakāśaḥ ca na saṃvid atirekī kaścid artha dharmaḥ saṃbhavati iti āveditam
translated: This self-knowledge is to be praised.🔽And it has been explained that illumination is not a property of an object that is separate from consciousness.

analyzed: saṃbhavan api asau na citi sva rūpa mātra nimittaḥ
translated: Even if it were possible, that [illumination] is not the sole cause of the nature of consciousness.

analyzed: sarvadā sarva artha prakāśa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because then everything would always be illuminated.

original: na hi sadā saṃnihitasamagrakāraṇaṃ kāryaṃ kadācidbhavati /🔽āgantukātiśayāśrayaṇe vā nāmānta
analyzed: na hi sadā saṃnihita samagra kāraṇam kāryam kadācid bhavati  āgantuka atiśaya āśrayaṇe vā nāma anta
translated: For an effect never occurs sometimes, when its complete set of always-present causes is present.🔽Or if it is argued that it depends on some adventitious excellence, then knowledge itself has been accepted under a different name.

analyzed: reṇa jñānam eva aṅgīkṛtam iti tadvān eva ātmā āyātaḥ
translated: Thus the self has become just that [knowledge].

analyzed: iti dharma bhūta jñānasya nitya tva sādhanam
translated: Thus the proof of the eternality of knowledge which is a quality [of the self]

analyzed: nanu evam artha siddhi vyavasthāpaka tayā abhyupagatam jñānam āgantukam kriyā rūpam iti katham tad ātma svabhāvaḥ
translated: But if knowledge, which is accepted as the determiner of the establishment of the object, is adventitious and of the nature of action, how can it be of the nature of the self?

original: tathāhiarthāntaragatatve sati janakadravyāntara prati kāryatvādikena rūpeṇāsādhāraṇo🔽gantavyadeśaprāptyādiryaṃ pratyasādhāraṇaḥ tatsamavetāgantukāsādhāraṇagamanādikriyājanyo dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi artha antara gata tve sati janaka dravya antara prati kāryatva ādikena rūpeṇa asādhāraṇaḥ  gantavya deśa prāpti ādiḥ yam prati asādhāraṇaḥ tad samaveta āgantuka asādhāraṇa gamana ādi kriyā janyaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Thus, when it is present in another object, it is to be inferred as being produced by a different generative substance, by its form such as being the effect, etc.🔽That which is not common to one who has reached the destination, etc., is seen to be produced by the uncommon action of going, etc., which inheres in that [person].

original: tādṛśī cārthasiddhiryaṃ puruṣaṃ pratyasādhāraṇī tatsamavetatādṛśakriyājanyeti śakyamanumātum /
analyzed: tādṛśī ca artha siddhiḥ yam puruṣam prati asādhāraṇī tad samaveta tādṛśa kriyā janyā iti śakyam anumātum
translated: And it is possible to infer that the establishment of the object, which is not common to a certain person, is produced by the similar action which inheres in that [person].

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: akriyā janyena abhāva prāpta kṣetra ādi svatvena kṣetriṇam prati asādhāraṇena kṣetra ja vrīhi ādi svatvena ca anaikāntyāt
translated: Because of the non-uniqueness of the ownership of the field, etc., which is obtained by the absence of what is produced by non-action, in relation to the owner of the field, and because of the ownership of the barley produced in the field, etc.

analyzed: naca nirvyāpāra tayā kṣetriṇaḥ tatra ajanaka tvam
translated: And it is not that the owner is not the producer there because of inactivity.

analyzed: vyāpāra kāla ādinā vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of the error in relation to the time of activity, etc.

analyzed: tad bhāva bhāvi tvasya ca aviśeṣāt
translated: And because of the non-distinction of the relation of invariable concomitance.

analyzed: tad jīvanam eva tatra janaka vyāpāraḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the life of that [person] itself is the productive activity there,

analyzed: nanu tat sasya pālana ādi sādhāraṇam iti katham asādhāraṇa kriyā janya tvam
translated: But that is common to the protection of crops and other [actions]. How can it be produced by an uncommon action?

analyzed: api ca evam sati tat eva artha prakāśe stu
translated: Moreover, if it is so, let that itself be the productive operation even in the manifestation of the object.

analyzed: kim akṛpta kalpanayā
translated: What is the use of an unestablished assumption?

original: satyapi tasminnartho na prakāśata iti cet /🔽svatvaṃ vā kiṃ yathoditaṃ sati jīvane jāyata eva / /
analyzed: sati api tasmin arthaḥ na prakāśate iti ced  svatvam vā kim yathā uditam sati jīvane jāyate eva
translated: If it is argued that even when that exists, the object is not manifested,🔽then why does ownership not arise just as stated when there is life?

analyzed: vrīhi ādi sattā api apekṣyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that even when that exists, the existence of rice etc. is required,

analyzed: iha api indriya ādi pratyāsaktiḥ iti samānaḥ carcaḥ
translated: then the same discussion applies here also that the proximity of the sense organs etc. is required.

original: ato yaṃ pratyasādhāraṇo yathoditadharmaḥ tadīyāsādhāraṇadharmanimitta ityetāvat /
analyzed: atas yam prati asādhāraṇaḥ yathā udita dharmaḥ tadīya asādhāraṇa dharma nimittaḥ iti etāvat
translated: Therefore, it is only this much that the uncommon property as stated is due to the uncommon property of that [object] for whom it is uncommon.

analyzed: sa ca iṣyate eva ātmanaḥ caitanyam raveḥ iva tejasvi tvam
translated: And that is accepted, just as the sentience of the self is like the luminosity of the sun.

analyzed: na ca hetu bheda anuvidhāyi tayā
translated: And it is not due to the variation of causes.

analyzed: jāna abhyajñāsiṣam ityādi kāla avaccheda pratīteḥ gamana ādeḥ iva jñānasya āgantuka tvam anumeyam
translated: The transitoriness of knowledge is inferred from the cognition of the distinction of time such as 'I knew', 'I was knowing', 'I will know', like that of motion.

analyzed: āditya prakāśena an aikāntyāt
translated: Because of the non-exclusiveness of the light of the sun.

original: asti hi tatrāpīmaṃ deśamādityaḥ prakāśayati prācīkaśat prakāśayiṣyatīti pratītiḥ /
analyzed: asti hi tatra api imam deśam ādityaḥ prakāśayati prācīkaśat prakāśayiṣyati iti pratītiḥ
translated: For there is also the cognition 'The sun illuminates this place', 'It illuminated', 'It will illuminate'.

analyzed: svārasika tve pi āditya prakāśasya prakāśya deśa saṃbandha kādācitkatayā avaccheda pratītiḥ upapadyate iti ced
translated: If it be said that, even though the light of the sun is natural, the cognition of limitation is possible because of the accidental connection of the light with the place that is illumined,

analyzed: iha api tarhi indriya ādi pratyāsatti samāsādita yogya bhāvaḥ nu bhāvya bhedaḥ svābhāvikam ātmanaḥ caitanya guṇam avacchinatti iti
translated: then, in the same way, here also, the difference of the object of cognition, which has attained fitness by the proximity of the sense-organ etc., limits the natural quality of consciousness of the self.

analyzed: tad apekṣayā eva indriya ādi anuvidhānam atīta anāgata pratyutpanna tva pratyaya prayogau ca upapadyante
translated: And on that very account, the dependence on the sense-organ etc., and the use of the notions of past, future and present are possible.

analyzed: katham punar atra nirṇayaḥ
translated: But how is the decision here?

analyzed: maṇi dyumaṇi prakāśa ādeḥ iva aupādhikaḥ yam bhedaḥ
translated: This difference is adventitious, like the light of a gem or a lamp,

analyzed: na tu gamana pacana ādeḥ iva svābhāvikaḥ iti
translated: but not natural, like going, cooking etc.

analyzed: tādrūpyeṇa eva pratyakṣa tvāt
translated: Because it is perceived as having that form.

analyzed: na hi jātucit adrūpaḥ yam ātmā loṣṭa ādi vat daṣṭa caraḥ
translated: For the self is never seen as having a form different from that, like a clod etc.

analyzed: yaḥ ca yad guṇa tayā eva sākṣāt bhavati
translated: And he who is directly perceived as having a certain quality,

analyzed: sa tad svabhāvaḥ
translated: he has that nature.

analyzed: marut iva sparśa guṇa tayā eva adhyakṣyamāṇaḥ
translated: Like the wind, which is perceived as having the quality of touch.

analyzed: yaḥ yad svabhāvaḥ na bhavati
translated: He who does not have a certain nature,

analyzed: na tad viraheṇa api svarūpataḥ upalabhyate
translated: is not perceived as having a form even in the absence of that,

analyzed: gamana ādi rahita tayā iva devadatta ādiḥ
translated: like Devadatta etc., who are devoid of going etc.

analyzed: śarīra vat iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is like the body, no (says the siddhāntin);

analyzed: asiddha tvāt
translated: because that is not established.

original: syādetatyathaiva khlvasvabhāvabhūtenāpi śarīreṇa sadhrīcīna evāyaṃ cetanaścakāsti /
analyzed: syāt etat yathā eva khlu asvabhāva bhūtena api śarīreṇa sadhrīcīnaḥ eva ayam cetanaḥ cakāsti
translated: This may be said: Even though the body is not of the nature of consciousness, it shines forth as united with consciousness.

analyzed: tathā caitanyena api iti
translated: And so does consciousness.

analyzed: tat na evam asiddha tvāt
translated: That is not so, because it is not established.

analyzed: na hi tanu viśiṣṭa tayā eva ayam cetanaḥ parisphurati
translated: For this [self] does not shine forth only as distinguished by the body.

original: yogināṃ praṇihitamanasāmuparatabahirindriyāṇāṃ ca dehānusandhānaviraheṇāpi ahamiti sphuṭamanubhavāt /
analyzed: yoginām praṇihita manasām uparata bahis indriyāṇām ca deha anusandhāna viraheṇa api aham iti sphuṭam anubhavāt
translated: Because even without the connection with the body, yogis whose minds are concentrated and whose external senses are withdrawn clearly experience the thought I am.

original: jānāmīti pratyayaḥ śarīravarṇasanniveśanirbhāsaśūnyatayā tattvāntaragocara iti ca prāgevāvocam /
analyzed: jānāmi iti pratyayaḥ śarīra varṇa sanniveśa nirbhāsa śūnya tayā tattva antara gocaraḥ iti ca prāk eva avocam
translated: And I have already said that the idea I know is devoid of the appearance of the arrangement of the body's color and form, and is the experience of something else.

original: karmānuguṇyena suramanujādijātīyatayā bhidyamānāsvāgamāpāyinīṣu tanuṣu manasa ivaikasya varṣmaṇaḥ svabhāvānubandhitvenāśrayitumaśakyatvāt /
analyzed: karma ānuguṇyena sura manuja ādi jātīya tayā bhidyamānāsu āgama apāyinīṣu tanuṣu manasaḥ iva ekasya varṣmaṇaḥ svabhāva anubandhi tvena āśrayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because it is impossible for a single body to be connected with the nature of the mind in the same way that the mind is, in the bodies that come and go, which are divided into the species of gods, humans, etc. according to the conformity with karma.

analyzed: liṅgasya punar anuvṛttau api apratyakṣa tvāt na vyabhicāri tvam
translated: And even if the mark [of consciousness] continues, it is not contradicted, because it is not perceptible.

analyzed: iti jñānasya ātma svabhāva tva pratiṣṭhāpanam
translated: Thus the establishment of consciousness as the nature of the self.

original: bodhasvābhāvye puṃsaḥ svāpamūrcchayoḥ prakāśaprasaṅga iti cenna /
analyzed: bodha svābhāvye puṃsaḥ svāpa mūrcchayoḥ prakāśa prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that, if the soul is of the nature of consciousness, there would be manifestation in the states of sleep and swoon, we say no.

analyzed: vikalpa asaha tvāt
translated: Because that is not logically possible.

original: tathāhiprakāśa iti padārthamātrasādhāraṇaṃ bodhajanyaṃ prakaṭatādipadaparyāyaṃ dharmamabhipretya vāyaṃ prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi prakāśaḥ iti padārtha mātra sādhāraṇam bodha janyam prakaṭa tā ādi pada paryāyam dharmam abhipretya vā ayam prasaṅgaḥ
translated: For this objection is based on the assumption that the term manifestation is a property common to all things, synonymous with manifestation, etc., and produced by consciousness.

analyzed: atha bodham eva
translated: Or, if it is consciousness itself,

analyzed: tad aviprakarṣam vā
translated: or that which is not far removed from it.

analyzed: ādye tad abhāvāt eva na prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the first case, there is no objection, because there is no manifestation.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ ca prakaṭitaḥ eva saṃvid svatas siddhi samarthana samaye
translated: And the absence of manifestation has already been made clear in the proof of the self-validity of consciousness.

analyzed: bhāve pi tamaḥ pratibandhāt api anudayaḥ saṃbhavī
translated: Even if there is manifestation, non-appearance is possible due to obstruction by darkness.

original: itarayorabhimatamevāpāditamityadoṣodbhāvanam /🔽bodhasvābhāvye hi puruṣasya svāpādidaśāsu ca tathābhāvo 'bhimata eveti na hi tadāpādanaṃ doṣāya /
analyzed: itarayoḥ abhimatam eva āpāditam iti adoṣa udbhāvanam  bodha svābhāvye hi puruṣasya svāpa ādi daśāsu ca tathābhāvaḥ bhimataḥ evā iti na hi tad āpādanam doṣāya
translated: The other two cases lead to the desired conclusion, so there is no fault in stating them.🔽For if the soul is of the nature of consciousness, its existence in the states of sleep, etc. is also accepted, so asserting it as an objection is not a fault.

original: atha matamsvāpādāvapi svānubhavasadbhāve jāgara iva vyavahāraprasaṅga iti / maivam /
analyzed: atha matam svāpa ādau api sva anubhava sadbhāve jāgare iva vyavahāra prasaṅgaḥ iti mā evam
translated: If it is argued that even in sleep, etc., there would be the same usage as in the waking state due to the existence of self-experience, we say no.

analyzed: vyavahāra agocara tvāt
translated: Because it is not the object of usage.

analyzed: kaḥ khalu ātmani vyavahāraḥ
translated: For what is usage regarding the self?

analyzed: na hi asau ādātum hātum upekṣitum vā śakyaḥ
translated: For it cannot be accepted, rejected, or ignored.

analyzed: vyāhāraḥ prasajyate iti ced kim aṅga
translated: If it be said that there would be the contingence of expression, we say—what is the harm?

analyzed: nirvikalpaka bāla mūka ādi vedana viṣayaḥ vyavahniyate eva
translated: The object of the indeterminate cognition of a child, a dumb person, etc. is indeed expressed.

analyzed: karaṇa pāṭava vyavajihīrṣā ādi sahakāri virahāt tatra vyāhāra anudayaḥ iti ced
translated: If it be said that there is no expression there because of the absence of the co-operating factors such as the skill in the instrument, the desire to speak, etc.,

analyzed: samānaḥ yam vidhiḥ itaratra api iti niranuyojyānuyogaḥ
translated: we say that the same rule applies in the other case also. So it is an irrelevant rejoinder.

analyzed: smṛti prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there would be the contingence of memory, we say no.

analyzed: avṛtti tvāt
translated: Because there is no operation.

original: yadyucyetamūrcchādāvātmānubhavābhyupagamer'thāntarānubhava ivaivamahamanvabhūvamiti parastāt smṛtiḥ prasajyata iti / tanna /
analyzed: yadi ucyeta mūrcchā ādau ātma anubhava abhyupagama īrtha antara anubhave iva evam aham anvabhūvam iti parastāt smṛtiḥ prasajyate iti tat na
translated: If it be said that when the experience of the self is admitted in a swoon, etc., there would be the contingence of memory in the form ‘I experienced thus’ afterwards, as in the case of the experience of another object, that is not so.

analyzed: avṛti t tvāt
translated: Because there is no operation.

original: na hi mūrcchā prasvāpo vā buddhivṛttiviśeṣo darśanasparśanādivat / yena
analyzed: na hi mūrcchā prasvāpaḥ vā buddhi vṛtti viśeṣaḥ darśana sparśana ādi vat yena
translated: For a swoon or sleep is not a particular operation of the intellect, like seeing, touching, etc., by which

analyzed: smṛti bījam saṃskāram ādadhīyātām
translated: it would lay down the impression, the seed of memory.

analyzed: kintu udbhūtena tamasā uparata vyāpāreṣu karaṇeṣu nirvṛttika sāṃsiddhika bodha svarūpeṇa avasthāna mātram ātmanaḥ
translated: But the self remains merely in the form of self-luminous cognition, whose operation has ceased on account of the manifest tamas, and whose function is suspended.

analyzed: na ca bodha svabhāva tvāt eva asya saṃskāra ādhāyaka tvam
translated: And it is not that it lays down the impression because of its being of the nature of cognition.

analyzed: anavarata upacīyamāna saṃskāra tayā anirmokṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because there would be the contingence of no liberation on account of the impression being accumulated without interruption.

analyzed: anubhave ca sva anurūpa saṃskāra ādhāna niruddhe sadṛśa saṃbandhi darśana ādi samudbodhita nija bīja anusāreṇa smaraṇam upajāyate
translated: And when the experience has ceased, having produced a suitable impression, the memory arises in accordance with its own seed awakened by the perception of a similar related object, etc.

analyzed: na ca iha ātma svarūpa bodhasya jātucit nirodhaḥ janma vā
translated: And here there is never any cessation or origination of the knowledge of the nature of the self.

analyzed: nitya ātma sattā prayukta tvāt
translated: Because it is employed in the existence of the eternal self.

analyzed: nimitta antara abhāvaḥ ca anantaram eva vyākariṣyate
translated: And the absence of another cause will be explained immediately after this.

analyzed: tat evam anuvartamāne eva anubhave katham smṛtiḥ udayam āsādayet
translated: So how can memory arise when the experience continues in this way?

original: ya evāhaṃ pūrvedyurāsaṃ sa evāhamadyāpīti smṛtisaṃbhinnapratyayo 'pi kālāvacchinnasvarūpagocaraḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ eva aham pūrvedyus āsam saḥ eva aham adya api iti smṛti saṃbhinna pratyayaḥ kāla avacchinna sva rūpa gocaraḥ
translated: The cognition that is mixed with memory, I was yesterday, I am today, also has as its object the form limited by time.

analyzed: na svarūpa mātre
translated: Not just the form alone.

analyzed: aviśadaḥ ca svāpa ādau sva anubhavaḥ nirvikalpakaḥ ca
translated: And self-experience in sleep, etc., is indistinct and non-conceptual.

original: paṭīyasā savikalpakenāvagamena smṛtibījamādhīyata iti ca kutastatprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: paṭīyasā sa vikalpakena avagamena smṛti bījam ādhīyate iti ca kutas tad prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And how can there be the possibility of that [memory] when the seed of memory is laid down by a vivid conceptual cognition?

analyzed: sāmyāt ca ananubhava abhimānaḥ śarīra tad dhāraṇa prayatna ananusaṃdhāna vat
translated: And the conception of non-experience is due to similarity, like the non-remembrance of the body and the effort to support it.

analyzed: na ca avikṛta svābhāvika bodha mātreṇa avasthāne svāpa mokṣayoḥ aviśeṣa āpattiḥ
translated: And it is not the case that there is no difference between sleep and liberation in the case of remaining with just the unmodified natural knowledge.

analyzed: kleśa vāsanānām guṇa abhibhavasya ca ekatra bhāvāt
translated: Because the impressions of afflictions and the sublation of the qualities exist in one [state],

analyzed: itaratra tad atyanta nivṛtteḥ
translated: but in the other [state] they are completely absent.

original: asaṃprajñātasamādhāvapi paramavairāgyaśālinā paṭutaranirodhasaṃskāreṇa caritādhikāriṇā apavargiṇā viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: asaṃprajñāta samādhau api parama vairāgya śālinā paṭutara nirodha saṃskāreṇa carita adhikāriṇā apavargiṇā viśeṣaḥ
translated: Even in the non-conceptual concentration, there is a difference for one who possesses supreme detachment and who has performed his duty with the very sharp impressions of cessation, and for one who is liberated.

analyzed: iti jñāna nitya tve prasakta ākṣepāṇām pariharaṇam
translated: Thus, the objections raised against the eternality of knowledge are refuted.

original: kathaṃ punarnidrāyā avṛttitve prabuddhasya pratyavamarśāḥ sukhamahamasvāpsamityādyāḥ /
analyzed: katham punar nidrāyāḥ avṛtti tve prabuddhasya pratyavamarśāḥ sukham aham asvāpsam ityādyāḥ
translated: How, then, when sleep does not function, are there recollections in one who is awake, such as I slept happily?

analyzed: na hi ananubhūta gocarāḥ smṛtayaḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: For memories cannot occur about objects that have not been experienced.

analyzed: sattva saciva samullasita tamaḥ guṇa anubhava bhāvita bhāvanā yoniḥ khalu sukham aham asvāpsam
translated: Indeed, the recollection I slept happily is born from the impressions cultivated by the experience of the tamas quality that arises along with the sattva [quality].

analyzed: prasannam me manaḥ
translated: My mind is clear.

analyzed: laghūni me gātrāṇi iti pratyavamarśaḥ
translated: My limbs are light.

analyzed: rajaḥ tamaḥ samudreke tu duḥkham aham asvāpsam
translated: But when rajas and tamas predominate, the recollection is I slept unhappily.

analyzed: bhramati anavasthitam me cittam iti
translated: My mind is agitated and unsteady.

original: sattvarajasī tvabhibhūya nitāntamudbhūte tamasi gāḍhamūḍhaṃ supto 'smi /
analyzed: sattva rajasī tu abhibhūya nitāntam udbhūte tamasi gāḍham ūḍham suptaḥ smi
translated: But when tamas is extremely predominant, overpowering sattva and rajas, I slept deeply,

analyzed: gurūṇi me gātrāṇi
translated: my limbs are heavy,

analyzed: muṣitam iva manaḥ
translated: and my mind is as if lost.

analyzed: mīlitam iva iti
translated: As if it were closed.

analyzed: satyam evam
translated: This is true.

analyzed: datta uttaram hi etat
translated: For this has already been answered.

analyzed: na eva amī vāsanā yonayaḥ pratyayāḥ
translated: These are not the causes of the impressions.

analyzed: api tu tātkālika śarīra indriya āmanaḥ vasthā viśeṣa paryālocana nimittā
translated: But they are caused by the consideration of the particular states of the body, senses, and mind at that time.

analyzed: ānumānikāḥ iti
translated: They are inferred.

analyzed: evaṃrūpā hi imā iyatas prasannam me manaḥ
translated: For it is like this: my mind was clear from that.

analyzed: samyak āhāra pariṇāma vaśāt laghūni ca aṅgāni
translated: My limbs were light due to the proper digestion of food.

analyzed: atas sukham aham asvāpsam iti
translated: Therefore, I slept happily.

analyzed: svāpa avasthāyām vā
translated: Or in the state of sleep,

analyzed: indriya uparama tāratamya vaśāt aviśada tātkālika tad tad anukūla pratikūla viṣaya anusandhāna nibandhana tayā api smaraṇam upapadyate iti na vṛtti antara tvam  nidrāyāḥ
translated: memory also arises due to the indistinct recollection of the particular favorable and unfavorable objects due to the degree of cessation of the senses. Thus sleep is not a separate transformation.

original: kathaṃ tarhi pāramarṣaṃ sūtram abhāvapratyayālambanā vṛttirnidrā iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi pāramarṣam sūtram abhāva pratyaya ālambanā vṛttiḥ nidrā iti
translated: How then is the aphorism of the great sage: Sleep is a transformation that has non-existence for its object?

analyzed: nirodha para tvāt prakaraṇasya na vṛtti svarūpe tātparyam viparyaya vat
translated: Because the context is about cessation, it does not mean the nature of the transformation, like error.

analyzed: na hi a tad rūpa pratiṣṭham mithyājñānam kiñcid asti
translated: For there is no false knowledge that is not based on that form.

analyzed: sarva saṃvidām artha avyabhicārāt
translated: Because all cognitions are non-deviating with regard to their object.

analyzed: sa ca adhikaraṇa siddhaḥ
translated: And that is established by the topic.

analyzed: sādhayiṣyate ca upariṣṭāt
translated: And it will be accomplished later on.

analyzed: kaivalya bhāgi yat cit tad pratyanīka tayā nidrā ādeḥ nirodhya tvena upadeśaḥ
translated: The teaching that the Self is to be known as the opposite of sleep etc., which is a part of Kaivalya (liberation), is by way of its being obstructed by sleep etc.

analyzed: iti nidrāyāḥ vṛtti rūpa tva niṣedhanam
translated: Thus, the denial of sleep being a modification.

analyzed: astu vā pūrva ukta pramāṇa ādi vṛtti abhāva kāraṇa bhūta pracitatama tamaḥ guṇa avalambanā vṛttiḥ eva nidrā
translated: Or let sleep itself be a modification, the cause of the absence of the previously mentioned means of knowledge etc., based on the quality of tamas that is extremely accumulated.

analyzed: santu ca prabuddha pratyavamarśāḥ ca smaraṇāni
translated: And let there be the recollections of the awakened person's self-awareness.

analyzed: tathā sati apya
translated: Even so,

analyzed: nava rata anuvṛtta bodha tayā sthitam eva puṃsaḥ bodha svabhāva tvam
translated: the nature of the Self as consciousness remains, due to the continuity of the unchanging consciousness.

original: āhabodhakāraṇānuvṛttyāpi bodhānuvṛttirupapadyata iti kathaṃ tathāsvābhāvyaniścayaḥ / ittham
analyzed: āha bodha kāraṇa anuvṛttyā api bodha anuvṛttiḥ upapadyate iti katham tathāsvābhāvya niścayaḥ ittham
translated: It is said: Even by the continuity of the cause of consciousness, the continuity of consciousness is possible. How then is the certainty of its natural state? Thus

analyzed: evam viṣaya prakāśa kādācitkatvena ātmanaḥ dharma bhūtam jñānam āgantukam eva
translated: In this way, the knowledge that is a property of the Self, which is the illumination of objects, is adventitious only.

analyzed: ātma svarūpa prakāśaḥ na sarvadā
translated: The illumination of the nature of the Self itself is not always present.

analyzed: kintu viṣaya jñāna kāle eva jñānataḥ
translated: But only at the time of the knowledge of objects, from the knowledge,

original: na svataḥ iti pratyavasthānaprasaṅge jñānasya nityatvaṃ tāvadvyavasthāpayati atrāhu riti /
analyzed: na svatas iti pratyavasthāna prasaṅge jñānasya nitya tvam tāvat vyavasthāpayati atra āhuḥ iti
translated: not from itself. When this is objected to, he establishes the eternality of knowledge, saying they say etc.

analyzed: ātma svarūpa prayuktam jñānam
translated: Knowledge is employed in the nature of the Self.

analyzed: tat ca ātmanaḥ nitya tvāt nityam eva
translated: And that is eternal because the self is eternal.

original: ātmasvarūpanirūpakadharmatvācca jñānasya na jñānarahitamātmanaḥ svarūpaṃ vyavatiṣṭeta prakāśarahitamiva tejaḥ /
analyzed: ātma svarūpa nirūpaka dharma tvāt ca jñānasya na jñāna rahitam ātmanaḥ svarūpam vyavatiṣṭeta prakāśa rahitam iva tejaḥ
translated: And because knowledge is a quality that defines the nature of the self, the nature of the self cannot be established as devoid of knowledge, just as light cannot be established as devoid of illumination.

analyzed: atas muktau api jñānavat tvam upeyam
translated: Therefore, even in liberation, the possession of knowledge must be accepted.

analyzed: jñāna śūnyasya anātma tvāt iti śloka dvaya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the two verses is that if there were no knowledge, the self would not be the self.

original: nanu jñānābhāve 'pi jñānaśaktimadātmasvarūpaṃ muktikāla ityatrāha citiśaktaye ti /
analyzed: nanu jñāna abhāve pi jñāna śaktimat ātma svarūpam mukti kāle iti atra āha citi śaktaye ti
translated: But if it is argued that at the time of liberation, the nature of the self possesses the power of knowledge even in the absence of knowledge, he says the power of consciousness.

analyzed: luptam uttara ardham asya
translated: The second half of this verse is missing.

analyzed: tad sthāne smadīyam pūraṇam
translated: In its place, our own completion

analyzed: etat cihna antar niveśitam
translated: is inserted within this mark.

analyzed: nityasya svarūpa yogya tve phala avaśyaṃbhāva niyamāt jñāna śaktimat tve muktasya kadācid jñānam udiyāt
translated: And this is because if the eternal is fit by its own nature, the result must necessarily occur. If it possesses the power of knowledge, knowledge might arise at some time for the liberated one.

original: muktau kadāpi jñānasyānudayāttacchaktirapi tadā naṣṭaiveti ātmanāśa eva pratijñāto bhavet /
analyzed: muktau kadāpi jñānasya anudayāt tad śaktiḥ api tadā naṣṭā eva iti ātma nāśaḥ eva pratijñātaḥ bhavet
translated: But because knowledge never arises at the time of liberation, that power also perishes at that time. Thus, the destruction of the self would be what is asserted.

analyzed: svarūpa nirūpaka dharma nivṛttau svarūpa nivṛtteḥ avaśyambhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if a quality that defines the nature [of the self] ceases to exist, the nature [of the self] must necessarily cease to exist.

analyzed: nanu jñānasya jñānaśakteḥ vā na ātma svarūpa nirūpaka tvam
translated: But knowledge or the power of knowledge does not define the nature of the self.

original: kintu āgantukamapi tadātmana eveṣyate dharmabhūtaṃ na ghaṭāderityātmanātmavyavasthopapadyata iti cet /
analyzed: kintu āgantukam api tat ātmanaḥ evā iṣyate dharma bhūtam na ghaṭa ādeḥ iti ātmanā ātma vyavasthā upapadyate iti ced
translated: But if it be said that though adventitious, it is held to belong to the Self itself, and not to the jar etc., and so the distinction of the Self from the non-Self is established?

analyzed: mā evam jñānasya ātma svarūpa nirūpaka dharma tāyāḥ sthāpayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: No, because the nature of knowledge as the defining attribute of the Self's own nature is going to be established.

analyzed: jaḍa ātma vādasya trayī anta viruddha tvena sadbhiḥ anādaraṇīya tvāt ca iti hārdam
translated: And because the doctrine of the inert Self is contradicted by the three Vedas and is not to be accepted by the good. This is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: citi śaktye tyādi vivṛṇoti buddhī tyādinā
translated: He explains in the power of consciousness etc. with in the cognition etc.

original: pāṣāṇakalpasya muktātmano 'cidvyāvartakacicchaktayāśrayaṇaṃ vyarthamityāha api ce ti /
analyzed: pāṣāṇa kalpasya mukta ātmanaḥ cit vyāvartaka cicchaktayā āśrayaṇam vyartham iti āha api ca iti
translated: He says that it is useless for the liberated Self, which is like a stone, to rely on the power of consciousness that turns away from inert matter.

analyzed: lupta ardha vivaraṇam syāt idam
translated: This would be an explanation of a verse with a missing half.

original: nanu nityatve jñānasyā'tmatvamapīṣyatāṃ tasyaiveti śaṅkāmanūdya pariharati na caivaṃ satī ti /🔽paramvaram /
analyzed: nanu nitya tve jñānasya ātmatvam api iṣyatām tasya eva iti śaṅkām anūdya pariharati na ca evam sati iti  paramvaram
translated: Now, if it is argued that the eternality of knowledge should be accepted, let that be the Self, he raises the doubt and answers it thus. And in this case, it is not so.🔽Rather,

analyzed: tasya ti
translated: of that.

analyzed: viṣaya āśraya sāpekṣasya jñānasya tad anapekṣa svatantra ātma svarūpa tvam ayuktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not proper for knowledge, which depends on the support of objects, to be the nature of the independent Self, which does not depend on that.

analyzed: kiñca kalpanāyām eva lāghava gaurava carcā avasaraḥ
translated: Moreover, there is an occasion for discussing lightness and heaviness only in the case of assumption.

analyzed: na tu sphuṭa pratipanne boddhṛ ātmani iti āha sākṣāt ca iti
translated: But not in the clearly cognized knower-self. Therefore he says 'directly' etc.

original: ahaṃ jānāmīti jñātrātmapratyakṣasya bhramatvamiti cettatrāha anubhave ti /
analyzed: aham jānāmi iti jñātṛ ātma pratyakṣasya bhrama tvam iti ced tatra āha anubhave ti
translated: If it is argued that the direct perception of the knower-self as 'I know' is an error, he says 'in experience' etc.

analyzed: anantaram eva avyavahita pūrvam eva
translated: Immediately - without any obstruction.

analyzed: jñātuḥ ātma tva samarthane iti yāvat
translated: Up to the establishment of the knower as the self.

analyzed: sat pramāṇa tarka anugrahāt jñātṛ ātma pratyakṣasya abhrānti tvam eva saṃmantavyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The implication is that the direct perception of the knower-self should be accepted as non-erroneous due to the support of valid means of knowledge and reasoning.

analyzed: nanu caitanyam eva ātmā
translated: But consciousness itself is the self.

analyzed: viṣaya saṃbandhaḥ eva tasya bodhaḥ nāma
translated: The connection with the object is called its knowledge.

original: ato boddhṛtvapratipattirātmana upapadyata iti śaṅkate na ca citimātre ti /
analyzed: atas boddhṛ tva pratipattiḥ ātmanaḥ upapadyate iti śaṅkate na ca citi mātre ti
translated: Therefore, the establishment of the knower-self is reasonable. This is suspected in 'not in mere consciousness' etc.

original: viṣayacaitanyasaṃbandhasya bodhatvābhimatasya saṃyogarūpatve tasya dviṣṭhatvādviṣayasyāpi boddhṛtvaprasaṅga ityāha sambandhasye ti /
analyzed: viṣaya caitanya saṃbandhasya bodha tva abhimatasya saṃyoga rūpa tve tasya dviṣṭha tvāt viṣayasya api boddhṛ tva prasaṅgaḥ iti āha sambandhasya iti
translated: If the connection of consciousness with the object, which is supposed to be knowledge, is of the nature of conjunction, then since it is dependent on two, the object also would be a knower. This is stated in 'of the connection' etc.

analyzed: śaṅkate na ca kārye ti
translated: He suspects in 'not in the effect' etc.

original: yathā kāryakāraṇabhāvasya hetuhetumadubhayanirūpyatve 'pi hetuhetumatorvyavasthā idamasya kāraṇam /
analyzed: yathā kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya hetu hetumat ubhaya nirūpya tve pi hetu hetumatoḥ vyavasthā idam asya kāraṇam
translated: Even though the relation of cause and effect is to be determined by both the cause and the effect, there is a distinction between the cause and the effect - this is the cause of that,

analyzed: idam tu asya kāryam iti
translated: but this is the effect of that.

original: evaṃ cidviṣayasaṃbandhasya viṣayaviṣayinirūpyatve 'pi boddhṛbodhyavyavasthā ghaṭata iti śaṅkiturāśayaḥ /
analyzed: evam cit viṣaya saṃbandhasya viṣaya viṣayi nirūpya tve pi boddhṛ bodhya vyavasthā ghaṭate iti śaṅkituḥ āśayaḥ
translated: Thus, the intention of the objector is that even when the relation of consciousness to its object is dependent on the determination of the object and subject, the distinction between the knower and the known is possible.

analyzed: pariharati tatra ti
translated: He replies: There (in the case of the relation of inherence, etc.).

original: yadyapi kāryasya kāraṇasya ca saṃbandhaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ kathyate /🔽paraṃ tu kāryatvaṃ kāraṇanirūpitaṃ kāryaniṣṭhaṃ svapūrvavartikāraṇāpekṣatvalakṣaṇaṃ svaprākkālāvacchedena kāryavyāpakakāraṇakatvaparyasāyi /
analyzed: yadi api kāryasya kāraṇasya ca saṃbandhaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ kathyate  param tu kārya tvam kāraṇa nirūpitam kārya niṣṭham sva pūrva varti kāraṇa apekṣa tva lakṣaṇam sva prāk kāla avacchedena kārya vyāpaka kāraṇaka tva paryasāyi
translated: Although the relation between an effect and its cause is said to be the relation of cause and effect,🔽however, the quality of being an effect is characterized by the property of requiring its own cause that existed before it, and it is included in the property of being an effect that pervades its own cause, which is determined by the cause.

original: kāraṇatvaṃ ca kāryanirūpitaṃ kāraṇaniṣṭhaṃ svottarabhāvikāryāpekṣatvalakṣaṇaṃ kāryaniyataprākkālavartitvaparyavasāyi bhinnabhinnameva tatra
analyzed: kāraṇa tvam ca kārya nirūpitam kāraṇa niṣṭham sva uttara bhāvi kārya apekṣa tva lakṣaṇam kārya niyata prāk kāla varti tva paryavasāyi bhinna bhinnam eva tatra
translated: And the quality of being a cause is characterized by the property of requiring its own effect that will exist after it, and it is included in the property of existing before its effect with a fixed time, and it is different in each case.

original: praviṣṭam /🔽atra tu eka evobhayasamavetaḥ saṃyoga iti vyavasthādurghaṭetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: praviṣṭam  atra tu ekaḥ eva ubhaya samavetaḥ saṃyogaḥ iti vyavasthā durghaṭa iti arthaḥ
translated: It has entered there (in the relation of cause and effect).🔽The meaning is that here (in the case of the relation of conjunction), there is only one conjunction that inheres in both, and it is difficult to establish such a rule.

original: yadyapi saṃyogasyobhayaniṣṭhatve 'pi anuyogitāsaṃbandhena tasya cinniṣṭhatvāccita eva boddhṛtvam /
analyzed: yadi api saṃyogasya ubhaya niṣṭha tve pi anuyogitā saṃbandhena tasya cit niṣṭha tvāt citaḥ eva boddhṛ tvam
translated: Although conjunction exists in both, because it exists in consciousness by the relation of inherence, consciousness alone is the knower.

analyzed: tad pratiyoginaḥ tu viṣayasya bodhya tvam iti vyavasthā ghaṭeta
translated: The determination would be that the object, which is the counter-correlate of that [consciousness], is to be known.

original: athāpi na cinmātratvamātmanaḥ /🔽kintu cityāśrayatvamapi śrautatvādupeyameveti dhyeyam /
analyzed: atha api na cit mātra tvam ātmanaḥ  kintu citi āśraya tvam api śrauta tvāt upeyam eva iti dhyeyam
translated: Even so, the self is not mere consciousness.🔽But it should be understood that the fact that it is the substratum of consciousness should also be accepted on the basis of scriptural authority.

original: ciccetyayorapi parasparāpekṣāniyamalakṣaṇā eva saṃbandho 'stviti śaṅkate ihāpī ti /
analyzed: cit cetyayoḥ api paraspara apekṣā niyama lakṣaṇāḥ eva saṃbandhaḥ u stu iti śaṅkate iha api iti
translated: He doubts that even consciousness and the object of consciousness have a relation characterized by mutual dependence, saying in this case also.

analyzed: pariharati na apekṣe ti
translated: He replies there is no dependence [on the object of consciousness].

analyzed: apekṣāyāḥ hetuḥ prayojana rūpaḥ arthaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no purpose in the form of an aim for dependence.

analyzed: tasya eva vivaraṇam kimartham ityādi
translated: This is explained by for what purpose and so on.

original: nanvarthānāṃ vāsanādoṣāccaitanya eva kalpitatvādadhiṣṭhānatayā cito 'pekṣā syādevetyatrā'ha nirastaśce🔽ti / evamarthasyotpattau cidapekṣāṃ pratikṣipya cita
analyzed: nanu arthānām vāsanā doṣāt caitanye eva kalpita tvāt adhiṣṭhāna tayā citā upekṣā syāt eva iti atra āha nirastaḥ ca  evam arthasya utpattau cit apekṣām pratikṣipya
translated: If it is argued that since the object of consciousness is imagined to exist in consciousness due to the fault of latent impressions, there must be dependence of consciousness as the substratum, he says and that is refuted.

analyzed: utpattau artha apekṣām pratikṣipati nityasya iti
translated: Having thus refuted the dependence of consciousness in the production of the object, he refutes the dependence of the object in the production of consciousness, saying of the eternal [consciousness].

analyzed: nitya caitanyasya artha apekṣā utpatti vacanam vyāhatataram iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The statement that the production of eternal consciousness depends on the object is even more contradictory, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tad prakāśasya artha apekṣām nirasyati
translated: He refutes the dependence of the manifestation of that [consciousness] on the object,

analyzed: kim iti mahanīya mityādi sa upālambham
translated: saying what and so on, with reproach.

analyzed: anātma vettṛ tvam eva evam vaktuḥ phalati
translated: The result of the speaker's statement is that he does not know the Self.

analyzed: arthānām bhāsakasya ātma jyotiṣaḥ svayam prākāśa tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the Self, which is the illuminator of objects, is self-luminous, because it is light.

analyzed: nanu astu cit apekṣā
translated: Now, let there be dependence on consciousness for the illumination of objects.

analyzed: tatra āha prakāśaḥ ca iti
translated: There, he says If there is dependence on consciousness for illumination,

analyzed: saṃvid eva prakāśaḥ
translated: consciousness itself is illumination.

analyzed: tad artham saṃvid apekṣā ced ātma āśrayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if there is dependence on consciousness for that, it is a case of self-dependence.

analyzed: saṃvid atiḥ ukta prakāśa pakṣe pi āha saṃbhavan iti  nitya tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Even in the view that illumination is stated by consciousness, he says If it were possible,🔽the meaning is that if the illumination of objects depends only on consciousness, it would follow that it is eternal.

analyzed: āgantuka dharmavat cit apekṣa tve ca tasya jñātṛ ātma siddhiḥ apratyahā iti āha āgantuka iti
translated: And if it depends on consciousness, which has adventitious properties, the Self is established as the knower, without contradiction. He says If it were adventitious,

analyzed: āgantuka atiśayaḥ ca svadharma bhūta jñāna vikāsa rūpaḥ eva
translated: and the adventitious excess is of the nature of the development of knowledge, which is its own property.

analyzed: tad viśiṣṭam jñānam bodhaḥ
translated: Knowledge distinguished by that is awareness.

original: tadāśraya ātmeti na bodhamātramātmeti sāmpratamiti bhāvaḥ /🔽nanvevamātmano bodhasvarūpatvavadbodhasvabhāvatvamapi na saṃbhavati anityasya bodhasya nityātmasvabhāvatvāyogāt /
analyzed: tad āśrayaḥ ātmā iti na bodha mātram ātmā iti sāmpratam iti bhāvaḥ 🔽nanu evam ātmanaḥ bodha svarūpa tva vat bodha svabhāva tvam api na saṃbhavati anityasya bodhasya nitya ātma svabhāva tva ayogāt
translated: The Self is the basis of that. The idea is that it is not right to say that the Self is just awareness.

original: arthiprakāśakādācitkatvāya bodhakādācitkatāyā eva mantavyatvāditi śaṅkate nanvevam iti /
analyzed: arthi prakāśa kādācitkatvāya bodha kādācitkatāyāḥ eva mantavya tvāt iti śaṅkate nanu evam iti
translated: He raises the doubt that since the occasional nature of the illuminator is to be understood as the occasional nature of the illuminator, the occasional nature of the knowledge is to be understood as the occasional nature of the illuminator.

original: jñānasya kriyātvamāgantukatvaṃ ca sādhayituṃ sāmānyavyāptiṃ śikṣayati arthāntare ti /
analyzed: jñānasya kriyā tvam āgantuka tvam ca sādhayitum sāmānya vyāptim śikṣayati artha antare ti
translated: In order to establish the action-ness and adventitiousness of knowledge, he teaches the general pervasion with in another object and so on.

analyzed: artha antaram grāma ādi
translated: Another object is a village etc.

analyzed: janaka dravya antaraṃgantā
translated: Another generative substance is a man.

analyzed: gantavya deśa prāptiḥ grāma puruṣa saṃyogaḥ
translated: The attainment of the place to be reached is the conjunction of the village and the man.

original: ubhayaniṣṭho 'pyayaṃ puruṣapravṛttimūlatvena puruṣāsādhāraṇaḥ puruṣaniṣṭhāgantukagamanakriyājanyo dṛṣṭa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ubhaya niṣṭhā u pi ayam puruṣa pravṛtti mūla tvena puruṣa asādhāraṇaḥ puruṣa niṣṭha āgantuka gamana kriyā janyaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: This, though residing in both, is seen to be produced by the adventitious action of going residing in the man, which is based on the activity of the man.

analyzed: tādadhīnya ādinā tad asādhāraṇa artha antara niṣṭha dharmatva vyāpakam tad niṣṭha āgantuka kriyā janya tvam iti phalitam
translated: The conclusion is that the being produced by the adventitious action residing in that, which is the pervasion of the property residing in that which is uncommon to that, is dependent on that.

analyzed: udāharaṇam uktvā upanaya nigamane pradarśayati tādṛśī ti
translated: Having stated the example, he displays the application and conclusion with such and so on.

analyzed: pratijñā hetū artha siddhau
translated: The proposition and reason are established by the meaning.

analyzed: avayava traya prayogaḥ vā yatheccham
translated: Or the use of the three parts is as desired.

analyzed: jñeya niṣṭhaḥ ca prakāśaḥ tad tad puruṣa asādhāraṇaḥ tad tad puruṣīya āgantuka jñāna kriyā janyaḥ
translated: And the illumination residing in the object to be known, which is uncommon to each person, is produced by the adventitious action of knowledge belonging to each person, which is to be proved here.

analyzed: vyāptim eva dūṣayati mā eva m ityādinā
translated: He refutes the pervasion with Not so etc.

analyzed: akriye ti
translated: Not an action means

original: kulaparamparayā prāpte kṣetrādau janmata eva svatvaṃ yasya bhāgino 'nyasyābhāvāt /
analyzed: kula paramparayā prāpte kṣetra ādau janmataḥ eva svatvam yasya bhāginaḥ nyasya abhāvāt
translated: that which has ownership over a field etc. obtained by family tradition from birth itself, because there is no other sharer.

analyzed: bhāve vā dāyataḥ
translated: Or if there is, it is by inheritance.

original: tatra tadasādhāraṇer'thāntarakṣetrādisvatve tanniṣṭhakriyājanyatvaṃ nāstīti vyabhicāra ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra tad asādhāraṇa īrtha antara kṣetra ādi svatve tad niṣṭha kriyā janya tvam na asti iti vyabhicāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in that uncommon ownership of a different field etc., there is no being produced by an action based on that, so there is a fallacy.

original: abhāvaprāptetyatra bhāvaprāpteti svabhāvaprāpteti vānyathā vā pāṭhaḥ saṃbhāvyate /
analyzed: abhāva prāptā iti atra bhāva prāptā iti svabhāva prāptā iti vā anyathā vā pāṭhaḥ saṃbhāvyate
translated: In obtained by non-existence, obtained by existence, obtained by nature, or some other reading may be possible.

original: anyakriyayā daivena vā svakṣetre patitānāṃ bījānāṃ prarūḍhānāṃ svatve svāsādhāraṇe svīyāgantukakriyājanyatvaṃ nāstīti vyabhicāramapi pradarśayati
analyzed: anya kriyayā daivena vā sva kṣetre patitānām bījānām prarūḍhānām sva tve sva asādhāraṇe svīya āgantuka kriyā janya tvam na asti iti vyabhicāram api pradarśayati
translated: He also shows the fallacy that in the ownership of seeds that have fallen in one's own field by another's action or by fate and have grown, there is no being produced by one's own adventitious action in one's own uncommon ownership.

analyzed: kṣetriṇam iti
translated: The owner of the field etc.

analyzed: tad bhāve ti
translated: In its existence means

analyzed: yathā nirvyāpārasya api vyāpāra ādeḥ anvaya vyatirekābhyām kāraṇa tvam
translated: just as even an inactive thing is a cause by positive and negative concomitance of activity etc.,

original: tathā kṣetriṇaḥ sattva eva tannirūpitaṃ kṣetrādisvatvaṃ sidhyatīti tatra tata eva nirvyāpārasyāpi kṣetriṇo janakatvaṃ setsyatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā kṣetriṇaḥ sattve eva tat nirūpitam kṣetra ādi svatvam sidhyati iti tatra tatas eva nirvyāpārasya api kṣetriṇaḥ janaka tvam setsyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Similarly, the ownership of the field and so on, as determined by the owner of the field, is established only in relation to the being. Therefore, even for the owner of the field, who is without activity, the status of being a producer will be established just from that.

analyzed: nanu kṣetriṇaḥ na nirvyāpāra tvam
translated: But the owner is not without activity.

original: kintu jīvanameva vyāpāra iti śaṅkate tajjīvanameve ti /
analyzed: kintu jīvanam eva vyāpāraḥ iti śaṅkate tat jīvanam eva iti
translated: Rather, life itself is the activity. This is suspected in That life itself.

analyzed: pariharati nanu te
translated: He replies But that (verse 11).

original: kṣetriṇo jīvanaṃ hi sasyarakṣaṇādisādhāraṇakāraṇam /🔽na tu kṣetrādisvatve 'sādhāraṇakāraṇam / tathā
analyzed: kṣetriṇaḥ jīvanam hi sasya rakṣaṇa ādi sādhāraṇa kāraṇam  na tu kṣetra ādi sva tve sādhāraṇa kāraṇam tathā
translated: For the life of the owner is the common cause of protecting the crop and so on,🔽but it is not the uncommon cause of ownership of the field and so on.

analyzed: ca asādhāraṇāḥ āgantuka kriyā janya tva anumāne na aikāntyam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And so, in the inference of being produced by an uncommon instrumental action, there is only over-pervasion. This is the idea.

analyzed: nanu tad vyāpāra janya tvam eva sādhyate
translated: But the production by that activity is itself what is to be proved.

analyzed: na tu asādhāraṇa kriyā janya tvam
translated: It is not the production by an uncommon activity.

original: nāto vyabhicāra iti cettarhyarthāntaramityāha api caivam iti /
analyzed: na atas vyabhicāraḥ iti ced tarhi artha antaram iti āha api ca evam iti
translated: So there is no fallacy. If this is said, then it is irrelevant. Thus he says Moreover, in this way (verse 12).

analyzed: tat eva boddhuḥ jīvanam eva
translated: That very life of the knower.

analyzed: kim iti
translated: What?

analyzed: āgantuka jñāna kalpanā apārthā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is pointless to imagine an adventitious cognition.

analyzed: iha api iti
translated: Here also (verse 13).

analyzed: indriya artha sannikarṣa ādi sahakāri sampattau boddhuḥ jīvanam eva artha prakāśe janakam astu iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in the presence of the conjunction of the sense-object etc., the mere life of the knower itself is the producer of the manifestation of the object.

original: jīvanasyāpyuttarottarakālasattālakṣaṇasya na kriyārūpatvamiti na tadvyāpārajanyatvamapi sādhyam /
analyzed: jīvanasya api uttara uttara kāla sattā lakṣaṇasya na kriyā rūpatvam iti na tad vyāpāra janya tvam api sādhyam
translated: The life also, which is characterized by existence at later and later times, does not have the nature of an action. Therefore, the fact of being produced by its operation is not to be proved either.

analyzed: kintu tad asādhāraṇa dharma janya tvam eva iti upasaṃharati atas iti
translated: But it is concluded that it is produced only by its uncommon property. Thus he says 'therefore'.

analyzed: astu evam
translated: Let it be so.

analyzed: tāvatā bhavataḥ lābhaḥ kaḥ
translated: What is your gain by that much?

analyzed: tatra āha sa ca iṣyate eva iti
translated: There he says 'and that is certainly accepted'.

original: asmadaniṣṭaṃ sādhayituṃ pravṛttasya bhavator'thāntareṇa nigrahaṇamevāsmākaṃ lābha iti bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: asmad aniṣṭam sādhayitum pravṛttasya bhavataḥ ṛtha antareṇa nigrahaṇam eva asmākam lābhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that for you who have undertaken to prove what is undesirable for us, the mere refutation on another point is our gain.

original: svabhāvaprāptakṣetrādisvatve vyabhicārādevāgantukadharmajanyatvamapi na sādhayituṃ śakyata iti cānusandheyam /
analyzed: svabhāva prāpta kṣetra ādi sva tve vyabhicārāt eva āgantuka dharma janya tvam api na sādhayitum śakyate iti ca anusandheyam
translated: And it should be understood that the fact of being produced by an adventitious property cannot be proved even because of the fallacy of the natural possession of ownership of the field etc.

analyzed: evam artha prakāśa kādācitkatvena jñāna āgantuka tva sādhanam dūṣitam
translated: Thus the proof of the adventitiousness of knowledge by the occasional manifestation of the object has been refuted.

original: prakārāntareṇa ca tatsādhanaṃ dūṣayitumanuvadati na ca hetubhede ti /
analyzed: prakāra antareṇa ca tat sādhanam dūṣayitum anuvadati na ca hetu bhede ti
translated: In order to refute the proof of that in another way, he repeats 'and there is no difference in the cause'.

analyzed: jñānam āgantukam kāla avacchinna tayā pratīteḥ
translated: Knowledge is adventitious because it is cognized as limited by time.

analyzed: gamana ādi vat
translated: Like going, etc.

analyzed: jñānam indriya artha sannikarṣa ādi janyam tad bhāva abhāva anuvidhāyi bhāva abhāva tvāt indhana ādi janya pāka ādi vat iti prayoga dvayam atra garbhitam
translated: Knowledge is produced by the contact of sense and object, because its existence and non-existence follow the existence and non-existence of that, like cooking, etc. produced by fuel, etc. These two arguments are implied here.

analyzed: vyabhicāreṇa eva dūṣayati āditye ti
translated: He refutes it with counterexample, saying in the case of the sun, etc.

analyzed: svābhāvikasya api āditya prakāśasya tad tad prakāśya deśa saṃbandhasya kāla traya paricchinna tayā
translated: Even the natural light of the sun, which is connected with each illuminated place, is limited to the three times,

analyzed: tad viśiṣṭa viṣayiṇī kāla paricchinna tva pratītiḥ na prakāśa svarūpasya kādācitkatva sādhikā iti
translated: so the cognition of being limited by time, which is qualified by that, does not prove the occasional nature of the form of light.

analyzed: śaṅkate svārasika tve ti
translated: He raises an objection, saying even if it is natural, etc.

analyzed: svārasika tvam svābhāvika tvam
translated: Naturalness means naturalness.

original: viśiṣṭe vidhiniṣedhau viśeṣaṇamupasaṅkāmataḥ sati viśeṣye bādhe iti nyāyena viśiṣṭe kālāvacchedapratītirviśeṣaṇe paryavasyati /
analyzed: viśiṣṭe vidhi niṣedhau viśeṣaṇam upasaṅkāmataḥ sati viśeṣye bādhe iti nyāyena viśiṣṭe kāla avaccheda pratītiḥ viśeṣaṇe paryavasyati
translated: By the rule that affirmation and negation of the qualified refer to the qualifier, when the qualified is contradicted when the qualified is present, the cognition of being limited by time in the qualified refers to the qualifier.

analyzed: anitya tva anumānam ca viśiṣṭa viṣayam
translated: And the inference of non-eternality has a qualified object.

analyzed: na tu svarūpa mātra viṣayam
translated: But it is not about the mere form.

original: tathā ca yadrūpāvacchinnasya kālāvacchedapratītiḥ tasyānityatvameva svarūpamātrasya ca na kālāvacchedapratītiriti na vyabhicāra iti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: tathā ca yad rūpa avacchinnasya kāla avaccheda pratītiḥ tasya anitya tvam eva sva rūpa mātrasya ca na kāla avaccheda pratītiḥ iti na vyabhicāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, where there is cognition of a particular time in relation to a form, that is impermanent. But there is no cognition of a particular time in relation to mere form, so there is no fallacy of over-extension.

original: svarūpamātrasya kālāvacchedapratītiḥ pakṣe 'pyasiddheti pariharati ihāpī ti /
analyzed: svarūpa mātrasya kāla avaccheda pratītiḥ pakṣe pi asiddhā iti pariharati iha api iti
translated: He answers that the non-establishment of mere form as having a particular time is also the case in the thesis, with Here also.

analyzed: yogya bhāvaḥ prakāśa yogyatā
translated: Fitness means suitability for manifestation.

original: avacchinattikālāvacchinnatvaṃ yathā bhavettathā svasaṃbandhena viśinaṣṭi caitanyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: avacchinatti kāla avacchinna tvam yathā bhavet tathā sva saṃbandhena viśinaṣṭi caitanyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that consciousness distinguishes itself by its own relation in such a way as to have the property of having a particular time.

analyzed: hetu viśeṣa anuvidhānasya api anyathāsiddhim āha tad apekṣayā eva iti
translated: He says that the dependence on a particular cause is also otherwise established with Only in relation to that.

analyzed: artha saṃbandha apekṣayā eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it depends only on the relation to the object.

analyzed: tathā ca prathama anumānasya aprayojaka tvam iti hārdam
translated: And thus, the first inference is not a proper reason, this is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: kāla avaccheda ādeḥ aupādhika tvam svābhāvika tvam tatra tatra dṛṣṭam
translated: The adventitiousness or naturalness of having a particular time, etc. is seen here and there.

original: jñāne tasyaupādhikatvaniścaya ekāntataḥ kuta iti punaḥ śaṅkate kathaṃ puna riti /
analyzed: jñāne tasya aupādhika tva niścayaḥ ekāntataḥ kutas iti punar śaṅkate katham punar iti
translated: How can there be a definite ascertainment of its adventitiousness in cognition? He again doubts with How, again?.

analyzed: aupādhikaḥ yam
translated: This is adventitious.

analyzed: bhedaḥ bhūta bhaviṣyat tva ādi bhedaḥ jñānasya viṣaya saṃbandha aupādhikaḥ
translated: The difference in knowledge, such as past and future, is due to the adventitious connection with the object.

analyzed: tādrūpyeṇa eva iti
translated: Only in that form.

analyzed: jñānasya nitya ātma svabhāva tvāt nitya tvam iti tad kāla avaccheda pratīteḥ aupādhika tvam su niśceyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that since knowledge has the nature of the eternal self, its eternality is certain, so the cognition of its being limited to that time is surely due to an adventitious cause.

analyzed: jñānavat tvena eva sākṣātkriyamāṇa tvāt ātmā jñāna svābhāvaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the self is of the nature of knowledge because it is directly perceived only as possessing knowledge.
Direct perception is a particular mental function.

original: sa cātmano jñānavattvenaiveti yāvat /🔽tenātmanaḥ svarūpata eva prakāśamānasya svāpe jñānavattvenāprakāśe 'pi na kṣatiḥ /
analyzed: sa ca ātmanaḥ jñānavat tvena eva iti yāvat  tena ātmanaḥ svarūpataḥ eva prakāśamānasya svāpe jñānavat tvena aprakāśe pi na kṣatiḥ
translated: And that is only as far as the self is possessed of knowledge.🔽Therefore, when the self, which is manifest in its own form, is not manifest as possessing knowledge in sleep, there is no harm.

analyzed: na ca evam api aham sukhī
translated: And even so, it cannot be said that the reason is not established because the self is not manifest as possessing knowledge in the direct perception I am happy,

analyzed: aham duḥkhī
translated: I am unhappy,🔽I desire,

original: ahamicchāmi /🔽ahaṃ dviṣyāmītyātmanaḥ sākṣātkāre jñānavattvenāprakāśādasiddhatvaṃ hetoriti vācyam /
analyzed: aham icchāmi  aham dviṣyāmi iti ātmanaḥ sākṣātkāre jñānavat tvena aprakāśāt asiddha tvam hetoḥ iti vācyam
translated: I hate,

analyzed: tatra api aham iti anukūla pratikūla viṣayaka jñānavat tvasya ullekhāt
translated: because in that case also, the possession of knowledge regarding favorable and unfavorable objects is mentioned in the form I.

analyzed: sukha ādeḥ api jñāna avasthā viśeṣa tvāt ca
translated: And because happiness etc. are also particular states of knowledge.

original: icchādipratyakṣakāle jñānasya svayaṃprakāśatvādicchādyanubhavavattvenāpyātmano bhānācca jñānavattvenaivātmana upalambhaḥ setsyatīti cānusandheyam
analyzed: icchā ādi pratyakṣa kāle jñānasya svayam prakāśa tvāt icchā ādi anubhavavat tvena api ātmanaḥ bhānāt ca jñānavat tvena eva ātmanaḥ upalambhaḥ setsyati iti ca anusandheyam
translated: And it should be understood that the self is perceived as having knowledge itself, because at the time of the direct perception of desire etc., knowledge is self-luminous, and the self appears as having the experience of desire etc.

analyzed: yadi api jñānasya ātma svabhāva tva ādau śrutiḥ eva jāgarti
translated: Although there is indeed a Vedic text about the self being of the nature of knowledge etc.,

analyzed: athā api yukti pradhāna tvāt prakaraṇasya asya yuktiḥ evā atra nidarśitā
translated: nevertheless, since this section is primarily concerned with reasoning, only reasoning is shown here.

analyzed: śāstram ca agre pradarśayiṣyate  na hi iti
translated: And the scripture will be shown later.🔽For it is said: The self is not of the nature of knowledge, because it is perceived as having a body etc.
Not of the nature of consciousness, not the substratum of consciousness.

analyzed: śiṣṭam spaṣṭam
translated: The rest is clear.

original: atra śaṅkate śarīravaditī ti /🔽tadvattayaivopalabhyamānatvaṃ na tatsvabhāvakatvavyāpyam /
analyzed: atra śaṅkate śarīra vat iti iti  tadvat tayā eva upalabhyamāna tvam na tad svabhāvaka tva vyāpyam
translated: Here he raises the objection: as having a body etc.🔽Being perceived as having that [body] is not pervaded by being of its nature.

analyzed: śarīravat tayā eva upalabhyamānasya api ātmanaḥ śarīra svabhāvaka tva abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even though the self is perceived as having a body, it is not of the nature of the body.

analyzed: pariharati asiddha tvāt iti
translated: He replies: Because it is not established etc.

analyzed: śaṅkā granthasya vivaraṇam syāt etat ityādi
translated: The explanation of the statement of the objection begins with This may be said etc.

analyzed: sadhrīcīnaḥ eva sahitaḥ eva
translated: Together with, along with.

analyzed: parihāra granthasya vivaraṇam tat na eva m ityādi
translated: The explanation of the statement of the reply begins with That is not so etc.

analyzed: śarīravat tayā eva upalambhaḥ ātmanaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: The perception of the self as having a body is not established.

analyzed: yoga daśāyām avadhāna daśāyām mānasa anubhava daśāyām api śarīram vinā eva ātmanaḥ bhānāt
translated: Because the self shines even without the body in the state of yoga, in the state of attention, and in the state of mental experience.

analyzed: tathāca na vyabhicāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus there is no fallacy, this is the idea.

original: yogipratyakṣe ātmacintane ca dehaṃ vinā'tmabhānamuktvā laukikapratyakṣe 'pi tadāha jānāmī ti /
analyzed: yogi pratyakṣe ātma cintane ca deham vinā ātma bhānam uktvā laukika pratyakṣe tat āha jānāmi iti
translated: Having stated that in yogic perception and in the contemplation of the self, the self shines without the body, he says in ordinary perception also, I know etc.

analyzed: śarīrasya ātma svabhāva tva abhāvam draḍhayati karma iti
translated: He strengthens the absence of the body being of the nature of the self with action etc.

analyzed: tat tat manuṣya ādi śarīra viśeṣavat tayā eva upalambhaḥ ca ātmanaḥ siddhaḥ iti ca hārdam
translated: And the perception of the self as having the particular human body etc. is also unestablished, this is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: manasaḥ iva iti vaidharmya dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: As in the case of the mind is an example of dissimilarity.

original: mano yathānuvartate na tathā śarīramekamiti yāvat /
analyzed: manaḥ yathā anuvartate na tathā śarīram ekam iti yāvat
translated: As the mind continues, so does not the body, one, up to this extent.

analyzed: mukta avasthāyām api manaḥ nu vṛtti āśayena idam
translated: This is with the intention that the mind continues even in the liberated state.

analyzed: nanu sthūlaśarīrasya nivṛttau api sūkṣmaśarīrasya sarvadā anuvṛttiḥ vartate
translated: But even when the gross body ceases, the subtle body continues to exist at all times.

original: tasya ca nātmasvabhāvatvamiti tatra vyabhicāra iti mandāśaṅkāmapanudati liṅgasye ti /
analyzed: tasya ca na ātma svabhāva tvam iti tatra vyabhicāraḥ iti manda āśaṅkām apanudati liṅgasya iti
translated: And that is not of the nature of the self, so there is fallacy there, this is the weak doubt. He removes it with of the mark etc.

original: apinānuvṛttireva nāsti pralaye mokṣe ceti vyajyate /
analyzed: apinā anuvṛttiḥ eva nā asti pralaye mokṣe ca iti vyajyate
translated: By also it is indicated that there is no continuation at all in dissolution and in liberation.

analyzed: liṅga śarīrasya atīndriya tvāt hetu abhāvāt na vyabhicāraḥ iti ca bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no contradiction due to the absence of a reason, because the subtle body is beyond the senses.

analyzed: atrā idam bodhyam ātma dharma bhūta jñāna svarūpam tāvat nityam eva
translated: Here, this is to be understood: The nature of knowledge, which is a property of the self, is indeed eternal.

analyzed: kintu saṅkhoca vikāsa śālinaḥ tasya indriya ādi dvāraka prasaraṇāt artha prakāśaka tvam iti  punar artha prakāśaka tva viśiṣṭasya anitya tvam iṣyate
translated: But it has contraction and expansion, and it illuminates objects by spreading through the doors of the senses and so on.🔽Therefore, the state of illuminating objects is accepted as non-eternal, while the qualified form is eternal.

original: ato viśiṣṭaviśeṣeṇānityatvaṃ svarūpato nityatvaṃ ca vyavasthāpitaṃ tasyātreti /
analyzed: atas viśiṣṭa viśeṣeṇa anitya tvam svarūpataḥ nitya tvam ca vyavasthāpitam tasya atra iti
translated: Thus, non-eternality is established by the qualified particular, and eternality by the nature. This is to be understood here.

original: atha nityatve jñānasya caturdhā'kṣepamupakṣipya pratikṣipati bodhasvābhāvya ityādinā /
analyzed: atha nitya tve jñānasya caturdhā ākṣepam upakṣipya pratikṣipati bodha svābhāvye ityādinā
translated: Now, raising the objection of knowledge being eternal in four ways, he rejects it with In the nature of consciousness... and so on.

original: jñānasvabhāvatve puṃsaḥ svāpamūrcchayoḥ svarūpaprakāśaḥ syāditi prathamākṣepaḥ /
analyzed: jñāna svabhāva tve puṃsaḥ svāpa mūrcchayoḥ sva rūpa prakāśaḥ syāt iti prathama ākṣepaḥ
translated: If knowledge is the nature of the self, there would be self-illumination in sleep and fainting, this is the first objection.

analyzed: prakāśa padārtha vikalpena enam pariharati vikalpe tyādinā
translated: He rejects this by the option of the meaning of illumination with In option... and so on.

original: jñānātiriktasya jñānajanyasya prakāśasya sattve 'pi ātmani bodhena tasyājananaṃ svāpe tamoguṇapratibandhādgāḍhāndhakārapratibandhādiva cākṣuṣasyājananamiti
analyzed: jñāna atiriktasya jñāna janyasya prakāśasya sattve pi ātmani bodhena tasya ajananam svāpe tamaḥ guṇa pratibandhāt gāḍha andhakāra pratibandhāt iva cākṣuṣasya ajananam iti
translated: Even though there is light produced by knowledge, apart from knowledge, the non-production of that by the self through awareness, in sleep, is due to the obstruction of the quality of tamas, like the non-production of the visual [light] due to the obstruction of thick darkness.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the idea.

analyzed: tathābhāvaḥ iti
translated: The state of being thus.

analyzed: bodhavat tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: having awareness.

original: bodhasya sattve svāpa ātmano vyavahāraprasaṅga iti dvitīyākṣepaḥ /
analyzed: bodhasya sattve svāpe ātmanaḥ vyavahāra prasaṅgaḥ iti dvitīya ākṣepaḥ
translated: The second objection is: if awareness exists, then the self would be engaged in worldly activity in sleep.

analyzed: tam anubhāṣate atha matam iti
translated: He repeats the opponent's view with But it is held.

analyzed: pariharati mā evam iti
translated: He replies Not so with No.

analyzed: vyavahāraḥ kāyikaḥ vicikaḥ vā āpādyate
translated: Is worldly activity, whether bodily or verbal, being objected to?

original: ādyo na sambhavatītyāha kaḥ khalvi ti /
analyzed: ādyaḥ na sambhavati iti āha kaḥ khalu iti
translated: The first is not possible, he says What, indeed, is worldly activity?

analyzed: kim śabdaḥ kṣepe
translated: The word what is for censure.

analyzed: na hi asau iti
translated: For that is not so.

analyzed: nitya prāpta tvāt ātma svarūpasya iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the nature of the self is always attained.

analyzed: dvitīyam anuvadati vyāhāraḥ iti
translated: He repeats the second with Vyakharana.

analyzed: pariharati kim aṅge ti
translated: He replies What is the harm? with No.

analyzed: nirvikalpakam vācaka śabda ādi viśeṣaṇa an ullekhi yat jñānam bāla mūka ādeḥ
translated: Non-conceptual knowledge is the knowledge that does not mention the specific words and so on that denote.

original: tatsattve 'pi na tadviṣayasya vyāharaṇaṃ dṛśyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tad sattve pi na tad viṣayasya vyāharaṇam dṛśyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Even though that exists, the expression of its object is not seen, this is the meaning.

original: tathāca svaviṣayavyāhāravyāptirjñānasya nāstītyasthāne prasaṅga iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathāca sva viṣaya vyāhāra vyāptiḥ jñānasya na asti iti asthāne prasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the idea is that in that case, knowledge is not pervaded by its own expression regarding its object, so the reductio is out of place.

original: anubhave sati svāpa ātmano jāgaraṇe smṛtiprasaṅga iti tṛtīyākṣepaḥ /
analyzed: anubhave sati svāpe ātmanaḥ jāgaraṇe smṛti prasaṅgaḥ iti tṛtīya ākṣepaḥ
translated: The third objection is that if there is experience, then memory would follow for the self when it is awake, during sleep.

analyzed: tam anuvadati smṛtī ti
translated: He repeats the objection with memory.

analyzed: pariharati avṛtti tvāt iti
translated: He answers with because of non-occurrence.

analyzed: śaṅkā vivaraṇam tyādi  parihara vivaraṇam tad na ityādi
translated: The explanation of the doubt is if it is said.🔽The explanation of the answer is that is not so.

analyzed: na hi iti
translated: For means:

analyzed: buddhi vṛtti viśeṣaḥ dharma bhūta jñāna avasthā viśeṣaḥ
translated: The idea is that only the modification of consciousness generates the impression that is the seed of memory.🔽But means:

analyzed: svāpa ādi kālika ātma anubhavaḥ svabhāva lakṣaṇaḥ eva
translated: The self remains only by having natural, inherent knowledge during sleep, etc.🔽The idea is that there are no modifications of knowledge.

analyzed: na tu dharma bhūta jñāna avasthā viśeṣa lakṣaṇaḥ iti yāvat
translated: And consciousness means:🔽The meaning is that it is of the nature of eternal self-cognition.🔽The inherent knowledge is eternal and has the self as its object.

analyzed: yena ti
translated: By which means:

analyzed: jñāna vṛtteḥ eva smṛti bīja saṃskāra janaka tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that only the modification of knowledge generates the impression that is the seed of memory.

analyzed: kintu iti
translated: But means:

analyzed: svāpa ādau svābhāvika dharma bhūta jñānavat tvena avasthānam eva ātmanaḥ
translated: The self remains only by having natural, inherent knowledge during sleep, etc.

original: na tu jñānasya vṛttaya iti bhāvaḥ/
analyzed: na tu jñānasya vṛttayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there are no modifications of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca bodhe ti  nitya sva viṣayaka bodha svabhāvaka tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And consciousness means:🔽The meaning is that it is of the nature of eternal self-cognition.

analyzed: dharma bhūta jñānam tāvat nityam ātma viṣayakam
translated: The inherent knowledge is eternal and has the self as its object.

analyzed: indriya artha sannikarṣa ādi sahakāri saṃpattyā
translated: By the attainment of the cooperation of sense-object contact, etc.,

analyzed: punar viṣaya grāhi iti ekadeśi matena idam
translated: it again grasps the object, according to the opinion of a certain school.

original: yadvā bodha eva svo bhāvaḥ svarūpam /
analyzed: yat vā bodhaḥ eva svaḥ bhāvaḥ svarūpam
translated: Or, the essence of itself is its own nature, which is consciousness.

original: tattvāccidrūpatvādevāsyaātmanaḥ svaviṣayakasaṃskārajanakatvaṃ kiṃ na syāditi śaṅkā /
analyzed: tattvāt cit rūpa tvāt eva asya ātmanaḥ sva viṣayaka saṃskāra janakatvam kim na syāt iti śaṅkā
translated: And how could this Self, because of being of the nature of consciousness, not produce impressions with regard to its own object? This is the doubt.

analyzed: param prakaraṇa vaśāt pūrva ukta rītyā eva su saṅgataḥ
translated: However, due to the context, the meaning here is very relevant in the same way as stated earlier.

analyzed: asya nitya bodhasya
translated: Of this impermanent consciousness.

analyzed: nitya bodhasya saṃskāra janaka tva śaṅkām pariharati anavarate ti
translated: He rejects the doubt that the permanent consciousness produces impressions with An-avarata-sambandhāt.

original: tathāsati sāmagrībalātpratikṣaṇaṃ saskārodayasaṃbhavena saṃskāradhārāviśramābhāvaprasaṅga / tathā🔽ca kleśakarmavipākāśayānāmātyantikanivṛttilakṣaṇamokṣasyāsiddhiprasaṅgaḥ ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā asati sāmagrī balāt pratikṣaṇam saskāra udaya saṃbhavena saṃskāra dhārā viśrama abhāva prasaṅga tathā  ca kleśa karma vipāka āśayānām ātyantika nivṛtti lakṣaṇa mokṣasya asiddhi prasaṅgaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: If it were so, then there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of rest of the stream of impressions due to the possibility of the arising of impressions every moment by the power of the assemblage of causes. Thus,🔽there would be the undesirable consequence of the non-establishment of liberation, which is characterized by the complete cessation of afflictions, actions, results, and tendencies. This is the meaning.

original: nityabodhasvarūpasya saṃskārajanakatvedoṣamuktvā niṣprayojanatvamapyāha anubhave ce ti /
analyzed: nitya bodha svarūpasya saṃskāra janaka tve doṣam uktvā niṣprayojana tvam api āha anubhave ca iti
translated: Having stated the fault of the permanent consciousness producing impressions, he also says that it is purposeless with Anubhave ca.

analyzed: saṃskāra kalpanam hi anubhūta carasya an anubhūyamānasya pratipatti artham
translated: For the postulation of impressions is for the purpose of cognizing what has been experienced but is not being experienced.

original: nityānubhava eva jāgrati kaḥ saṃskārakalpanāyā artha iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nitya anubhavaḥ eva jāgrati kaḥ saṃskāra kalpanāyāḥ arthaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is: when there is always experience, what is the use of postulating impressions?
Similarity to itself means having the same object as the experience.

analyzed: nija bījam smṛti bījam saṃskāraḥ
translated: One's own seed is the seed of memory, which is an impression.

analyzed: nanu ātma viṣayiṇī api smṛtiḥ dṛṣṭā iti atra āha yaḥ eva aham iti
translated: But since memory is also seen to have the self as its object, he says that which is I.

analyzed: smṛti saṃbhinna pratyayaḥ pūrva kāla avaccheda aṃśe smṛti rūpaḥ vartamāna kāla avaccheda aṃśe nubhava rūpaḥ ca ātma svarūpa gocaraḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: The cognition mixed with memory is in the part delimited by past time in the form of memory, and in the part delimited by present time in the form of experience, and has the nature of the self as its object.

analyzed: kāla avacchinne ti
translated: Delimited by time means:

original: ātmasvarūpamātrasya sadā prakāśe 'pi tattatkālādyavacchinnasya vṛttigrāhyatayā vṛtteśca saṃskārajanakatayā nirukta pratyaya upapadyata ityarthaḥ
analyzed: ātma sva rūpa mātrasya sadā prakāśe tad tad kāla ādi avacchinnasya vṛtti grāhya tayā vṛtteḥ ca saṃskāra janaka tayā nirukta pratyayaḥ upapadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Although the nature of the self alone is always manifest, the cognition described is possible because the self delimited by that particular time, etc., is to be grasped by the modifications, and the modifications produce impressions.

original: na svarūpamātrena svarūpamātraviṣayakaḥ /🔽nityātmabodhasya saṃskārajanakatve bādhakaṃ prayojanābhāvaṃ cābhidhāya tasya svāpādikālikasya saṃskārajanakatvāsaṃbhavamapyabhidhatte aviśadaśce
analyzed: na svarūpa mātrena svarūpa mātra viṣayakaḥ  nitya ātma bodhasya saṃskāra janaka tve bādhakam prayojana abhāvam ca abhidhāya tasya svāpa ādi kālikasya saṃskāra janaka tva asaṃbhavam api abhidhatte aviśadaḥ ca
translated: It is not that which has the nature of the self alone as its object by its mere nature.

analyzed: ti
translated: Having stated the contradiction and the absence of purpose in the production of impressions by the eternal cognition of the self, he also states the impossibility of the production of impressions by that which is of the time of sleep, etc., with and indistinct.

analyzed: tamaḥ guṇa abhibhavāt aviśadaḥ
translated: It is indistinct due to being overwhelmed by the quality of darkness.
