analyzed: bāhya antara viśeṣaṇa an avagāhanāt nirvikalpaḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is non-conceptual because it does not penetrate the distinctions between external and internal.

analyzed: paṭīyasā a abhibhūtena
translated: By a stronger, i.e., not overpowered.

analyzed: smṛti bījam saṃskāraḥ
translated: The seed of memory is impression.

analyzed: ādhīyate utpādyate
translated: It is impressed, i.e., produced.

original: atredaṃ bodhyam yadyapi suptotthitasya sukhamahamasvāpsa mityādipratisandhānabalātsvāpakālikātmasvarūpānubhavasyāpi saṃskārajanakatvameṣṭavyam
analyzed: atrā idam bodhyam yadi api supta utthitasya sukham aham asvāpsam ityādi pratisandhāna balāt svāpa kālika ātma svarūpa anubhavasya api saṃskāra janaka tvam eṣṭavyam
translated: Here this should be understood: Although the experience of the nature of the self at the time of sleep must be accepted as producing impressions, because of the recollection of one who has arisen from sleep, such as I slept happily,

analyzed: atha api eka deśi mata āśrita vādaḥ yam
translated: nevertheless, this is a statement based on the opinion of a sectarian.

original: ata evāgre astu vā ityādinā pakṣāntaraṃ vakṣyati /
analyzed: atas eva agre astu vā ityādinā pakṣa antaram vakṣyati
translated: For this very reason, he will state an alternative view later on with Let it be so, etc.

original: anubhave vartamāne tāvanmātraviṣayakasmṛterudayāyoge 'pi pratyavamarśasyādhikaviṣayasya saṃskārabalādudaye na kṣatiriti /
analyzed: anubhave vartamāne tāvat mātra viṣayaka smṛteḥ udaya ayoge pi pratyavamarśasya adhika viṣayasya saṃskāra balāt udaye na kṣatiḥ iti
translated: Even though the arising of memory having only that much as its object is impossible while the experience is going on, there is no harm in the arising of the reflection having a greater object by the power of impression.

analyzed: adhikam agre
translated: More will be said later on.

analyzed: nanu sarvadā ātma svarūpa anubhavaḥ iti anupapannam
translated: But it is not possible that there is always experience of the nature of the self.

analyzed: viṣaya anubhava kāle eva sukha ādinā ahamartha prakāśasya anubhava siddha tvāt iti atra āha sāmyāt ca iti
translated: For the manifestation of the object of I by happiness, etc. is established by experience only at the time of the experience of the object. Here he says And because of equality, etc.

analyzed: eka ākāreṇa anubhūta māne viśeṣa ākāra asphūrteḥ ananubhava bhramaḥ
translated: When experienced with one form, the illusion of non-experience is due to the non-manifestation of the particular form.

analyzed: atra nidarśanam śarīra ādi
translated: The example here is the body, etc.

original: yathā jāgare sadānubhūyamānasyāpi karacaraṇādilakṣaṇasya śarīrasyāgantukaviśeṣasphuraṇavelāyāmeva viśeṣataḥ pratipattyānyadānanubhūyamānateva /
analyzed: yathā jāgare sadā anubhūyamānasya api kara caraṇa ādi lakṣaṇasya śarīrasya āgantuka viśeṣa sphuraṇa velāyām eva viśeṣataḥ pratipattyā anyadā ananubhūyamāna tā iva
translated: Just as, even though the body characterized by hands, feet, etc. is always experienced in the waking state, it is as if not experienced at other times except when there is a manifestation of some adventitious peculiarity.

original: yathā vā'ntarasya jāgaraṇe śarīradhāraṇaprayatnasya sadānuvartamānasyāpi buddhipūrvahastādyutkṣepaṇakāla eva sphuṭāvabhāsenānyadānanubhūyamānateva /
analyzed: yathā vā antarasya jāgaraṇe śarīra dhāraṇa prayatnasya sadā anuvartamānasya api buddhi pūrva hasta ādi utkṣepaṇa kāle eva sphuṭa avabhāsena anyadā ananubhūyamāna tā iva
translated: Or just as, even though the effort to sustain the body during internal wakefulness always continues, it is as if not experienced at other times except at the time of intentionally raising the hand, etc., due to the clear manifestation.

analyzed: tathā prakṛte pi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the same is the case here.

analyzed: yadi api śarīra dhāraṇa prayatnasya
translated: Even though the effort to sustain the body,

original: jīvanayoniśabditasyātīndriyatvamiṣyate tārkikaiḥ /🔽athāpi adṛṣṭata eva jīvanasyopapatteratīndriyayatnakalpanaṃ gurubhūtam /
analyzed: jīvanayoni śabditasya atīndriya tvam iṣyate tārkikaiḥ  atha api adṛṣṭataḥ eva jīvanasya upapatteḥ atīndriya yatna kalpanam guru bhūtam
translated: called the source of life, is considered to be imperceptible by the logicians,🔽nevertheless, the postulation of an imperceptible effort is heavy, since life is possible even from unseen [forces].

analyzed: jāgare tu śarīra tad avayava dhānaṇam iṣyate
translated: But in the waking state, the restraint of the body and its parts is considered to be due to effort.

analyzed: sa ca prayatnaḥ pratyakṣa yogyaḥ eva
translated: And that effort is indeed perceptible.

analyzed: nidrāyām tu adṛṣṭataḥ eva śarīra dhāraṇam iti hārdam ācārya taraṇānām
translated: The heart of the teacher's disciples is that in sleep, the sustenance of the body is due to unseen [forces] alone.

analyzed: tat dṛṣṭāntasya asya nā anupapattiḥ iti dhyeyam
translated: It should be understood that this example is not unestablished.

original: svāpe 'pi bodhānuvṛttau samādhimuktayoḥ svāpāviśeṣaprasaṅga ityākṣepāntaramanūdya pariharati na cāvikṛte ti /
analyzed: svāpe bodha anuvṛttau samādhi muktayoḥ svāpa aviśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ iti ākṣepa antaram anūdya pariharati na ca avikṛte ti
translated: In sleep also, if consciousness continues, there would be the undesirable consequence of no difference between sleep and the states of concentration and liberation. Anticipating another objection, he replies: And in the unmodified...

analyzed: avidyā ādi kleśaḥ
translated: Afflictions like ignorance.

analyzed: tamaḥ guṇa abhibhavāt atyanta saṅkucita jñāna tvam ca svāpe
translated: In sleep, there is extreme contraction of knowledge due to the predominance of the quality of darkness.

analyzed: na hi tadā jñānena sva ātma prakāśaḥ pi
translated: For at that time, even the self-illumination of knowledge is not there.
But in liberation, there is complete cessation of afflictions.

analyzed: āvaraṇa nivṛttyā nitya asaṅkucita sarva viṣaya jñāna tā ca iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: And by the removal of obscurations, there is the state of eternal, unrestricted knowledge of all objects. This is the difference.

analyzed: asaṃprajñāte ti
translated: In the state of concentration without discursive thought...

analyzed: saṃprajñātā iti kvacid pāṭhaḥ
translated: In some places, the reading is in the state of concentration with discursive thought.

original: samādhau ca puṃsaḥ paramavairāgyanirodhasaṃskārapāṭavātmaikapravaṇamanaskatvaprayuktamokṣopāyasiddhikṛtaḥ svāpato mahān viśeṣo 'stīti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: samādhau ca puṃsaḥ parama vairāgya nirodha saṃskāra pāṭava ātma eka pravaṇa manaska tva prayukta mokṣa upāya siddhi kṛtaḥ svāpataḥ mahān viśeṣaḥ sti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And in concentration, there is a great difference between the soul and sleep due to the accomplishment of the means of attaining liberation, which consists in the extreme dispassion, cessation, and the sharpness of impressions, and the mind being inclined solely towards the Self. This is the idea.

analyzed: carita adhikāreṇa i ti tu samīcīnaḥ pāṭhaḥ
translated: But the correct reading is by the authority of practice.

analyzed: kṛta adhikāreṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by the authority of what has been done.

analyzed: apavargiṇā apavarga upadhāyakena  kaivalya avasthā ātma sākṣātkaraṇa yogyena iti yāvat
translated: By the one who is destined for final liberation, who is engaged in final liberation.🔽This means who is fit for the realization of the Self in the state of isolation.

analyzed: manasā iti viśeṣyam adhyāhāryam
translated: The qualifying word mind should be supplied.

analyzed: carita adhikāriṇā iti pāṭhe tu kṛtātmanā iti arthaḥ
translated: If the reading is 'to one who has fulfilled his duty', then the meaning is 'to one who has accomplished his Self'.

analyzed: kṛtakṛtyena iti vā
translated: Or 'to one who has done what was to be done'.

original: evaṃ citsvarūpatvaṃ citsvabhāvatvaṃ copapāditaṃ prasaktākṣepapariharaṇena /🔽atha svāpe 'pi anutyayā vṛttyaivātmanaḥ prakāśaḥ setsyati /
analyzed: evam cit svarūpa tvam cit svabhāva tvam ca upapāditam prasakta ākṣepa pariharaṇena  atha svāpe pi anutyayā vṛttyā eva ātmanaḥ prakāśaḥ setsyati
translated: Thus, the nature of being the Self of consciousness and the nature of being of the nature of consciousness have been established by refuting the objections that were raised.🔽Now, if it is argued that in sleep also, the Self's manifestation is accomplished by the mere functioning of consciousness,

original: kṛtaṃ svaprakāśatvenetyantarnidhāya svāpe 'pi buddhivṛttireṣṭavyeti śaṅkate kathaṃ puna riti /
analyzed: kṛtam sva prakāśa tvena iti antar nidhāya svāpe buddhi vṛttiḥ eṣṭavyā iti śaṅkate katham punar iti
translated: then it is as good as saying that its self-luminosity is established. Thus, the functioning of consciousness should be accepted even in sleep. This is the doubt expressed in the words 'How, again...'.

analyzed: atrā ayam samudita āśayaḥ svāpaḥ nāma tamaḥ guṇa anubhavaḥ
translated: Here is the summarized meaning: Sleep is the experience of the quality of tamas.

analyzed: riṣat udbuddha sattva sahakṛtatamaḥ ālambana tve tasya sukha tvam
translated: When tamas is slightly awakened and associated with sattva, it becomes the object of perception and is experienced as pleasure.

analyzed: sattva kāryam ca laghu tva ādiḥ
translated: And the effects of sattva are lightness etc.

analyzed: iṣat udbuddha rajaḥ sahitatamaḥ ālambana tve duḥkha tvam calatva ādi ca
translated: When tamas is associated with slightly awakened rajas, it becomes the object of perception and is experienced as pain, and there is also motion etc.
When tamas is awakened to the point of completely overpowering sattva and rajas, it becomes the object of perception and there is deep delusion etc.

original: svāpe tama anubhave satyeva tajjasaṃskārataḥ prabodhe sukhamasvāpsamityādipratisandhānasyopapattiḥ nānyatheti /
analyzed: svāpe tamaḥ anubhave sati eva tad ja saṃskārataḥ prabodhe sukham asvāpsam ityādi pratisandhānasya upapattiḥ na anyathā iti
translated: When there is the experience of tamas in sleep, only then is the recollection possible at the time of waking, from the impressions produced by that, that 'I slept happily' etc., and not otherwise.

analyzed: ardha aṅgīkāreṇa pariharati satyam evam iti
translated: He replies by accepting half of the objection, saying This is true.

analyzed: nirukta pratītau abhyupagamaḥ
translated: The acceptance is in the case of the well-known cognition.
In the case of sleep being of the nature of a modification based on the quality of tamas,

analyzed: smṛti rūpa tve ca svāpa ādau nirukta pratīteḥ anabhyupagamaḥ
translated: and in the case of its being of the nature of memory, there is no acceptance of the well-known cognition in sleep.

analyzed: tat āha datta uttaram iti
translated: He says The answer has been given.

analyzed: ānumānikāḥ iti
translated: Inferred means:

analyzed: vṛtti sāmānya virahaḥ eva svāpaḥ
translated: Sleep is simply the absence of a general modification.

analyzed: yogyā smaraṇa liṅgāt ca prakāśa svabhāvāyāḥ vṛtteḥ abhāvasya tad kālīnasya anumānam
translated: And the absence of a modification whose nature is light is inferred from the time of sleep by the mark of the non-remembrance of the fit object.

analyzed: deha indriya lāghava ādi liṅgāt ca sukha tva ādeḥ tatra anumānam
translated: And the existence of pleasure etc. there is inferred from the mark of lightness of the body and senses etc.

analyzed: pūrva dina kṛtasya aparasmin dine
translated: Of what was done on the previous day, the remembrance on the next day

analyzed: pratyabhijñā balāt svāpa kālika ātma sattā aṃśe pi anumāna rūpā eva iyam pratītiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: is of the form of inference. The idea is that this cognition is of the form of inference even in the part of the existence of the self at the time of sleep, by the power of recognition.

analyzed: na vṛtti antara tvam iti
translated: It is not a different modification means:

analyzed: na tamaḥ guṇa viṣayaka buddhi vṛtti rūpa tvam nidrāyāḥ upagantavyam
translated: Sleep should not be accepted as being of the nature of the modification of the cognition that has tamas as its object.

analyzed: svāpa anumānāt eva nirukta pratīteḥ nirvāhāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the well-known cognition is accomplished by the inference of sleep itself.

original: nidrāyā vṛttirūpatvābhāve pātañjalasūtrasya kā gatiriti śaṅkate kathaṃ tarhī ti /
analyzed: nidrāyāḥ vṛtti rūpa tva abhāve pātañjala sūtrasya kā gatiḥ iti śaṅkate katham tarhi iti
translated: When sleep is not of the nature of a modification, he doubts what is the course of the Pātañjala aphorism, saying How then?.

analyzed: uttarayati nirodhe ti
translated: He replies: in the cessation of sleep.🔽The meaning is that sleep is the absence of the general occurrence of consciousness having an existent object.

analyzed: asyāḥ ca vṛtti vat niroddha tva sāmānyāt vṛtti tva upacāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ atra
translated: The idea is that, like an occurrence, it is figuratively called an occurrence because it has the commonality of being to be ceased. Here

original: nidarśanaṃ viparyayava diti /🔽anyathākhyāterabhāvena bhedāgrahasyaiva bhramasthalābhiṣiktasya viparyayaśabditasya niroddhavyatvatātparyeṇa vṛttitvavannidrāyā api vṛttitvaṃ
analyzed: nidarśanam viparyaya vat iti  anyathā khyāteḥ abhāvena bheda agrahasya eva bhrama sthala abhiṣiktasya viparyaya śabditasya niroddhavya tva tātparyeṇa vṛtti tva vat nidrāyāḥ api vṛtti tvam
translated: the example is: of error.

analyzed: kīrtyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that sleep is figuratively called an occurrence like an occurrence because of the intended meaning that only the place of delusion, which is the non-apprehension of difference due to the absence of false representation, which is called error, is to be ceased.

analyzed: sa ce ti
translated: And that.

analyzed: sarva saṃvidām artha avyabhicāraḥ yathārtha khyāti tva lakṣaṇaḥ nyāya tattva sa astrīya adhikaraṇa siddhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the non-deviation of all consciousnesses from their objects, which is characterized by true representation, is established by the treatise on the principles of logic.

original: niroddhavyatvaṃ caiṣāṃ kaivalyasādhanaparipanthitayetyāha kaivalye ti /🔽kaivalyabhāgi yaccitmokṣādhikṛtamātmasvarūpam /
analyzed: niroddhavya tvam ca eṣām kaivalya sādhana paripanthi tayā iti āha kaivalye ti  kaivalya bhāgi yat cit mokṣa adhikṛtam ātma svarūpam
translated: And the meaning of their being to be ceased is for the purpose of obstructing the means of attaining liberation, he says: in liberation.

analyzed: tad pratyanīka tayā a tad abhimata sādhana siddhi vighātaka tayā eteṣām niroddhavya tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the mind that is a partaker of liberation, which is the nature of the self that is qualified for liberation, is to be ceased because of being opposed to that, because of obstructing the attainment of the means that is desired by that.

original: sukhamahamasvāpsamiti pratīteḥ pratisandhānarūpatvamupagamyāpyāha astu ve ti /
analyzed: sukham aham asvāpsam iti pratīteḥ pratisandhāna rūpa tvam upagamya api āha astu vā iti
translated: Even granting that the cognition of the soul is of the nature of remembrance, he says: Let it be so.

analyzed: jñānavat tayā eva upalabhyamāna tvāt ātmanaḥ bodha svabhāva tvam uktam
translated: The soul is said to have the nature of consciousness because it is perceived only as possessing knowledge.

original: niruktarītyā svāpe 'pi bodhānuvṛttipratipādanācca tadeva pratiṣṭhāpitaṃ bhaviṣyatīti nāsmākaṃ kācit kṣatiḥ /
analyzed: nirukta rītyā svāpe pi bodha anuvṛtti pratipādanāt ca tat eva pratiṣṭhāpitam bhaviṣyati iti na asmākam kācid kṣatiḥ
translated: And because it will be established that consciousness continues even in sleep according to the method stated, we suffer no loss.

original: yatti hṛdayaṃ vṛttyaivātmanaḥ prakāśo na svarūpata iti /
analyzed: yatti hṛdayam vṛttyā eva ātmanaḥ prakāśaḥ na svarūpataḥ iti
translated: As for the view that the manifestation of the soul is only through modifications, not through its own nature,

original: tattvāśāmodakāyitamiti ca pūrvottarābhyāṃ sunirūpitaṃ bhaviṣyatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tattva āśā āmodakāyitam iti ca pūrva uttarābhyām su nirūpitam bhaviṣyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: that will be well refuted by the preceding and following arguments. This is the idea.

analyzed: smaraṇa ani pratisandhāna rūpāṇi
translated: Remembrances are of the nature of remembrance.

analyzed: yatas svatas sataḥ bodhāt ṛte puṃsaḥ yathā uditam
translated: Because for the self, which is inherently existent, apart from consciousness, as stated,

analyzed: tamaḥ svāpa ādi kālīnam na sidhyet hetu asiddhitaḥ
translated: the darkness of sleep and other times would not be established due to the non-establishment of the cause.

original: uparatāni hi prasvāpakāle sarvāṇyevendriyāṇi saha manasā /
analyzed: uparatāni hi prasvāpa kāle sarvāṇi eva indriyāṇi saha manasā
translated: For at the time of deep sleep, all the senses along with the mind cease to function.

analyzed: saṃskārasya ca na smṛteḥ anyatra sāmarthyam
translated: And a latent impression has no power except in memory.

analyzed: na ca sva prakāśam tamaḥ
translated: And darkness is not self-luminous.

analyzed: artha antara vartinaḥ u pi aniśam prakāśa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because then there would be constant manifestation even of things that are not present.

original: kḷptaśca sarvārthasādhanatayā bodha iti tenaiva karaṇavirahiṇā satā svabhāvabhūtenodbhūteno
analyzed: kḷptaḥ ca sarva artha sādhanatayā bodhaḥ iti tena eva karaṇa virahiṇā satā svabhāva bhūtena udbhūtena u
translated: And cognition is established as the means of accomplishing all purposes. Therefore, by that alone, which exists without instruments, which is of the nature of manifestation,

analyzed: dbhūta vṛtteḥ tamasaḥ nyasya vā ātma vartinaḥ guṇasya sphuraṇam iti balāt abhyupagamanīyam
translated: And since cognition is established as the means of accomplishing all purposes, it must be accepted by force that the manifestation of the self-existent, eternally manifest, non-existent, or other attribute residing in the self is due to that very cognition which is devoid of instruments and exists by its own nature.

analyzed: nitya prakāśaḥ ca ātmā pramātṛ tvāt
translated: And the self is eternally manifest, because it is the knower.

analyzed: a pramātṛ tva vyāpaka baddham hi anitya prakāśa tvam vyāpaka viruddha pramātṛ tva bhāgini ātmani na ātmānam labhate
translated: For the attribute of being eternally manifest, which is pervaded by non-knowing, does not find a locus in the self, which partakes of the contradictory of the pervader, i.e., knowing.

analyzed: svāpasya vṛtti tva upagame pi na jñāna nitya tva siddhiḥ
translated: Even if sleep is accepted as a state, it does not establish the eternality of knowledge,

original: vṛtteḥ karaṇajanyatvāditi parasya śaṅkāmanuvadati āhe ti /
analyzed: vṛtteḥ karaṇa janya tvāt iti parasya śaṅkām anuvadati āha ti
translated: because a state is produced by an instrument. Anticipating this objection of the opponent, he says the opponent says (in the commentary).

analyzed: pariharati ittham iti
translated: He answers thus (in the commentary).

analyzed: jñāna svabhāva tva niścayaḥ nantara nirdiśyamāna prakāreṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: The ascertainment of the nature of knowledge is in the manner to be described immediately after. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yatas iti
translated: For this reason (in the commentary).

original: svāpe kāraṇāyogātsvataḥsiddha eva tamaḥprakāśako bodha ityeṣṭavyamityarthaḥ ////
analyzed: svāpe kāraṇa ayogāt svatas siddhaḥ eva tamaḥ prakāśakaḥ bodhaḥ iti eṣṭavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in sleep, because there is no possibility of a cause, the manifestation of darkness must be accepted as self-established cognition.

analyzed: ślokam svayam eva vivṛṇoti uparatāni iti
translated: He himself explains the verse, beginning with when the instruments have ceased (in the commentary).

analyzed: anyasya vā asukha ādeḥ vā
translated: Or of something else, such as pleasure, etc.

original: uparatavyāpāratvātkaraṇānāṃ svāpe na jñānavṛtteravasaraḥ /🔽ataḥ svābhāvikena bodhenaiva tamoguṇaprakāśa
analyzed: uparata vyāpāra tvāt karaṇānām svāpe na jñāna vṛtteḥ avasaraḥ  atas svābhāvikena bodhena eva tamaḥ guṇa prakāśa
translated: In sleep, the organs having ceased to function, there is no opportunity for the functioning of knowledge.

original: iti balādeṣṭavyaṃ yadi tamo 'nubhavaḥ svāpa iṣyate /
analyzed: iti balāt eṣṭavyam yadi tamaḥ nubhavaḥ svāpaḥ iṣyate
translated: Therefore, if sleep is considered to be the experience of darkness, it must be accepted by force that the manifestation of the quality of darkness is by the natural consciousness itself.

analyzed: tat siddham bodha svabhāva tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that it is established that the nature of consciousness is to be conscious of itself.

analyzed: vastutas jñānasya na svāpe tamaḥ prakāśaka tvam ati saṅkucita vṛtti tvāt
translated: In reality, knowledge does not illuminate darkness in sleep, because its functioning is extremely limited.

original: svarūpānubhavabalātsukhatvena tadā bhāsamānasyātmanaḥ parāmarśaḥ paraṃ prabodha iti tu siddhāntaḥ /
analyzed: svarūpa anubhava balāt sukha tvena tadā bhāsamānasya ātmanaḥ parāmarśaḥ param prabodhaḥ iti tu siddhāntaḥ
translated: The conclusion is that the highest state of enlightenment is the reflection of the self, which appears as bliss by the power of the experience of its own nature.

original: asvāpsam iti svāpakālāṃśayostvanumitirūpaiva niruktapratītiḥ /🔽nityānubhavasya saṃskārājanakatve tu sākṣādeva svāpakālīnātmasvarūpānubhavasya niruktapratisandhānahetutvaṃ sukhatvenātmāgāhanāṃśa iti ca bodhyam
analyzed: asvāpsam iti svāpa kāla aṃśayoḥ tu anumiti rūpā eva nirukta pratītiḥ  nitya anubhavasya saṃskāra ajanaka tve tu sākṣāt eva svāpa kālīna ātma svarūpa anubhavasya nirukta pratisandhāna hetu tvam sukha tvena ātma āgāhana aṃśe iti ca bodhyam
translated: The expression I did not sleep is the remembrance of the self in the form of inference of the self and the time of sleep.🔽But if the eternal experience does not produce impressions, then it should be understood that the experience of the self during sleep itself is the cause of the remembrance described, in the aspect of the self being experienced as bliss.

original: bodhasvabhāvasyāpyātmano vṛttikāla evāstu prakāśo na sarvadetyatra tāvannityaprakāśatvaṃ sādhayati nityaprakāśaśce ti /
analyzed: bodha svabhāvasya api ātmanaḥ vṛtti kāle eva astu prakāśaḥ na sarvadā iti atra tāvat nitya prakāśa tvam sādhayati nitya prakāśaḥ ca iti
translated: As for the argument that the self, which is of the nature of consciousness, should be manifest only during the time of mental activity and not always, the author establishes its eternal manifestation with the words and its manifestation is eternal.

analyzed: a pramātṛ tve ti
translated: In the absence of being a knower.🔽The form of which is pervasion.

analyzed: tat vyāpyam iti arthaḥ  svatas siddha prakāśa tvam api asya jñātṛ bhāvataḥ
translated: The meaning is that which is pervaded by that.🔽The fact of being self-luminous is also established for it by its being a knower.

analyzed: ajñātṛ tvena hi vyāptā parāyatta prakāśa tā
translated: For, being a non-knower is pervaded by dependence on another for manifestation.

analyzed: iti ātmanaḥ jñāna svabhāvasya nitya sva prakāśa tva samarthanam
translated: Thus the establishment of the self as having the nature of knowledge and being eternally self-luminous.

analyzed: kaḥ punar ayam prakāśaḥ
translated: What, then, is this manifestation?

analyzed: yaḥ sya nityaḥ bhyupeyeta svābhāvikaḥ ca
translated: That which is accepted as eternal and natural for it.

analyzed: kaḥ ca asya ātmanā saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And what is its relation to the self?

analyzed: yadi jñānam eva
translated: If it is knowledge itself.

analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ ca āśraya āśrayi tvam
translated: And the relation is that of container and contained.

original: tato hetvabhāvena sādhyābhāvasya vyāptimupadarśayituṃ nidarśanatayā ghaṭādyupādātavyamyadanityaprakāśamanyādhīnaprakāśaṃ vā tadapramātṛ /
analyzed: tatas hetu abhāvena sādhya abhāvasya vyāptim upadarśayitum nidarśana tayā ghaṭa ādi upādātavyam yat anitya prakāśam anya adhīna prakāśam vā tat apramātṛ
translated: Then, in order to show the pervasion of the absence of the probandum by the absence of the probans, a pot and so on should be taken as an example, that which has non-eternal manifestation or manifestation dependent on another is not a knower.

analyzed: yathā ghaṭa ādi iti
translated: Like a pot and so on.

original: tatra ca viśeṣaniṣedhasya sāmānyābhyanujñākṣepakatvādāgantukaṃ jñānaṃ ghaṭādāvanumatamāpadyeta /
analyzed: tatra ca viśeṣa niṣedhasya sāmānya abhyanujñā kṣepaka tvāt āgantukam jñānam ghaṭa ādau anumatam āpadyeta
translated: And there, because the negation of a particular implies the affirmation of the general, it would follow that adventitious knowledge is accepted in a pot and so on.

original: atha tanmābhūditi viṣayaviṣayibhāva eva saṃbandhaḥ saṃgīyeta /
analyzed: atha tat mā abhūt iti viṣaya viṣayi bhāvaḥ eva saṃbandhaḥ saṃgīyeta
translated: Or, if that is not to be, the relation of object and subject should be accepted as the relation.

analyzed: tatas nitya vat jñāna viṣaya tvam ātmanaḥ prasatyeta
translated: Then, the self would always be the object of knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna viṣayīkāraḥ ca sādhana viśeṣa āyatta tvena niyataḥ iti na
translated: And being the object of knowledge is determined by dependence on a particular means, so

analyzed: svābhāvika tva sambhavaḥ
translated: it is not possible for it to be natural.

original: acetanagocara eva tathā niyama iti cenna /
analyzed: acetana gocaraḥ eva tathā niyamaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that such a restriction applies only to the sphere of the insentient, that is not so.

analyzed: cetanā antara viṣayīkāre pi tathā bhāva darśanāt
translated: Because even when it is the object of another consciousness, such a state is seen.

original: na cānātmagocara eva sādhanasāpekṣatvaniyama iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca anātma gocaraḥ eva sādhana sāpekṣatva niyamaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the restriction of dependence on a means applies only to the sphere of the non-self.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ pi ānumānika āgamika yoga jñāna viṣayīkāre tad sāpekṣa tva darśanāt
translated: Because even in the case of the self being the object of inferential or scriptural knowledge of yoga, dependence on a means is seen.

analyzed: viruddhe ca ekasya eka kriyāyām karma kartṛ tve
translated: And in the case of one thing, the contradiction of being both the object and the agent of an action,

analyzed: sūci agrasya iva ātma nivedhya vedhaka tve
translated: like the tip of a needle being both the pierced and the piercer.

analyzed: nitya tva niratiśaya sūkṣma tva vyāpi tva cit svābhāvya ādi rūpeṇa pratyak arthasya aupadeśika tvam ānumānika tvam vā
translated: The object of self-awareness, in the form of being eternal, having no superior, being subtle, being all-pervading, being consciousness, being natural, etc., is either taught or inferred.

analyzed: na svarūpataḥ
translated: Not in its own form.

analyzed: svarūpa apekṣayā eva svatas siddhiḥ abhyupeyate iti asamādheyaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: The self-established nature is accepted only in relation to its own form. This contradiction is irreconcilable.

analyzed: rūpa bhedena gamya gamaka tva aṅgīkāra pakṣe pakṣasya iva śabda ādeḥ na svatas siddha tvam
translated: Even in the view that accepts the relation of being inferred and inferring based on difference in form, like a non-subject, sound etc. are not self-established.

analyzed: iti jñāna āśraya tva viṣaya tvayoḥ prakāśamāna tva rūpa tve doṣa anukīrtanam
translated: Thus, the enumeration of faults regarding the nature of being the basis of knowledge and being the object of illumination.

analyzed: prakāśaḥ jñānam
translated: Now, it may be said that illumination is not knowledge.

analyzed: api tu tad nimittaḥ cetana itara sarva padārtha sādhāraṇaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: But rather, it is a property common to all things, conscious and non-conscious, that is the cause of that [illumination].

analyzed: yad vaśāt prakāśate iti sarva padārtheṣu aviśeṣeṇa
translated: By whose power, illumination and designation are applied to all things without distinction, saying it illuminates.

analyzed: āśraya āśrayi tva lakṣaṇaḥ ca saṃbandhaḥ tena saha sarva bhāvānām
translated: And the relation characterized by the relation of the basis and the based is with that [illumination] of all things.

original: sa ca yathoditasādhanabalādeva sāṃsiddhiko nityaścātmana iti /
analyzed: sa ca yathā udita sādhana balāt eva sāṃsiddhikaḥ nityaḥ ca ātmanaḥ iti
translated: And that [illumination] is naturally inherent and eternal in the self itself, by the power of the arguments stated above.

analyzed: parākṛtaḥ yam pakṣaḥ
translated: This position is refuted.

analyzed: na jñāna atirekī prakāśaḥ nāma
translated: There is no such thing as illumination apart from knowledge.

analyzed: yat vyavahāra upajanana anuguṇam jñānam
translated: That knowledge which is conducive to the production of the usage [of words like illuminates]

analyzed: tat prakāśate iti ucyate
translated: is said to illuminates.

original: jñeyasya jñātuḥ svātmanaśca vyavahārānuguṇaṃ jñānamudayata iti yuktaḥ triṣvapi ekarūpaḥ prakāśatevyavahāraḥ /
analyzed: jñeyasya jñātuḥ sva ātmanaḥ ca vyavahāra anuguṇam jñānam udayataḥ iti yuktaḥ triṣu api eka rūpaḥ prakāśatevyavahāraḥ
translated: It is proper that the usage of illuminates be of one form in all three [cases], since the knowledge arises in accordance with the usage of the object of knowledge, the knower, and one's own self.

original: tattvāntaraprakāśābhyupagametātsvābhāvye jhr na ṭa ca punaḥ kiṃ caitanyāśrayaṇena / /
analyzed: tattva antara prakāśa abhyupagama i t svābhāvye na ca punar kim caitanya āśrayaṇena
translated: If illumination is accepted as a separate entity, then what is the use of positing consciousness?

original: na ca prakāśa eva taditi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca prakāśaḥ eva tat iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that illumination itself is that [illumination].

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ api prakāśavat tayā cetana tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that even a pot and so on would be conscious because of having light.

analyzed: yadi ucyet sati cetanāvat tve puṃsaḥ prakāśamāna tvam iti
translated: If it is said that for a person, when there is consciousness, there is the state of being illuminated,

analyzed: saṃvidi idānīm kā vārtā
translated: what then is the situation with consciousness?

analyzed: cetanā eva hi sā
translated: For that is indeed conscious.

analyzed: na cetayate
translated: But it does not cognize.

original: atha saṃvidastatsaṃbandhādhīnaḥ sa dharma iti cet /
analyzed: atha saṃvidaḥ tad saṃbandha adhīnaḥ sa dharmaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said that that property of it depends on the relation with that [consciousness],

analyzed: kaḥ tayā saṃbandhaḥ
translated: what is the relation with that?

analyzed: yaḥ tat nibandhanam
translated: That which is the basis for that.

analyzed: na āśraya āśrayi tvam
translated: [It is not] the relation of the supported and the supporter.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ tad abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that a pot and so on would not have that [relation].

analyzed: na viṣaya viṣayi bhāvaḥ
translated: [It is not] the relation of object and subject.

analyzed: tasya eva a nirūpaṇāt
translated: Because that itself is not determined.

analyzed: anirūpaṇam ca bhrānti adhikaraṇa siddhānta ārambhe saṃvid siddhau ca anusandhātavyam
translated: And the non-determination should be understood in the beginning of the conclusion of the treatise on error and in the proof of consciousness.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ tasya ca aprakāśa prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: And there would be the consequence that the self and that [consciousness] would not be illuminated.

analyzed: jñāna adhīna prakāśa āśraya tā eva siddhiḥ
translated: The proof is just the state of being the support whose illumination depends on knowledge.

original: tayā cānumeyaṃ jñānamiti pakṣaḥ prāgeva pratikṣiptaḥ /
analyzed: tayā ca anumeyam jñānam iti pakṣaḥ prāk eva pratikṣiptaḥ
translated: And the position that knowledge is to be inferred by that [relation of the supported and the supporter] was already refuted earlier.

analyzed: sva prakāśa saṃvid vādinaḥ pi vyavahāra ānukūlye vairūpyam aśakya parihāram
translated: Even for one who maintains that consciousness is self-luminous, the impossibility of avoiding the difference [in the relation of the supported and the supporter] when [consciousness] is favorable to worldly convention is unavoidable.

original: ātmani samavetaṃ jñānamasaṃbandhinyarthe prakāśaṃ vyavahāraṃ vā kathaṃ prasuvītetyapi cintyam /
analyzed: ātmani samavetam jñānam asaṃbandhini arthe prakāśam vyavahāram vā katham prasuvīta iti api cintyam
translated: It should also be considered how knowledge, which inheres in the self, can produce cognition or activity in an unrelated object.

analyzed: indriya liṅga ādi sva kāraṇa pratyāsatti vasāt iti mā vocaḥ
translated: Do not say that it is due to the proximity of its own causes such as the sense organ and inference.

original: na khalu labdhātmakaṃ kāryaṃ svanimittakāraṇamanurudhya kāryamārabhate /
analyzed: na khalu labdha ātmakam kāryam sva nimitta kāraṇam anurudhya kāryam ārabhate
translated: For an effect that has attained its own nature does not commence its effect in conformity with its own instrumental cause.

analyzed: mā bhūt udaka āharaṇa ādi ghaṭa ādeḥ kulāla ādi samāna adhiṣṭānam
translated: Let it not be that the jar and so on, which bring water, have the same basis as the potter and so on.

analyzed: na ca nimitta kāraṇa nāśe kārya nāśaḥ
translated: And the destruction of the effect is not due to the destruction of the instrumental cause.

analyzed: naśyati ca indriya saṃprayoga ādi nāśe rūpa ādi jñānam
translated: And the knowledge of form and so on is destroyed when the contact with the sense organ is destroyed.

original: ata indriyeṇa saha caitanyamapi nissṛtya tena tenārthena sannikṛṣyate /
analyzed: atas indriyeṇa saha caitanyam api nissṛtya tena tena arthena sannikṛṣyate
translated: Therefore, consciousness also, along with the sense organ, departs and is brought into contact with each object,

analyzed: hasta ādinā iva tvac indriyam
translated: like the sense of touch with the hand and so on.

original: tathā sati hi tadupādhikatvāttajjñānasya yuktaṃ tadbhāvānuvidhāyitvam /
analyzed: tathā sati hi tad upādhika tvāt tad jñānasya yuktam tad bhāva anuvidhāyi tvam
translated: For in that case, it is proper that the knowledge, being conditioned by that, should conform to its existence, because it is due to that.

analyzed: anyathā utpannam jñānam indriya artha sannikarṣa nivṛttau kim iti nivartate
translated: Otherwise, how is it that the knowledge, which has arisen, ceases when the contact of the sense organ with the object ceases?

analyzed: jñāna janya artha dharma prakāśa vādinaḥ pi samānaḥ yam doṣaḥ
translated: This fault is the same for those who maintain that knowledge illuminates the property of the object that produces it.

analyzed: nimitta kāraṇam hi jñānam
translated: For knowledge is the instrumental cause.

analyzed: kutas tad nivṛttau artha prakāśaḥ nivartate
translated: How then can the manifestation of the object cease when that (self-luminosity) ceases?

analyzed: kutas vā yāvat tad bhāvam avatiṣṭhate
translated: Or how can it continue to exist as long as that (self-luminosity) exists?

original: nanu nityaprakāśatvaṃ svābhāvikabodhakṛtameva kiṃ na syādityatrāha svataḥsiddhe ti /
analyzed: nanu nitya prakāśa tvam svābhāvika bodha kṛtam eva kim na syāt iti atra āha svatas siddhā iti
translated: But why should not the self-luminosity be due to the inherent cognition itself? In this regard, he says if it were self-established.

analyzed: vyāptā a vyāpyā
translated: The pervaded and the pervader.

analyzed: vyāpaka abhāvāt vyāpya abhāvaḥ iti yāvat
translated: That is, the absence of the pervaded is due to the absence of the pervader.

original: jñātṛtvasvābhāvyādevānanyādhīnaprakāśatvasiddhiriti bhāvaḥ /🔽jñānasya prakāśo jñānāntarānapekṣo 'pyātmasambandhāpekṣa iti jñāne 'nanyādhīnaprakāśatvalakṣaṇaṃ sādhyaṃ nāsti /🔽tena sapakṣe jñāne sati pakṣamātravṛtti jñātṛtvaṃ bhavatyasādhāraṇamiti śaṅkānavakāśaḥ /
analyzed: jñātṛ tva svābhāvyāt eva ananya adhīna prakāśa tva siddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ  jñānasya prakāśaḥ jñāna antara anapekṣaḥ pyātma sambandha apekṣaḥ iti jñāne na anya adhīna prakāśa tva lakṣaṇam sādhyam na asti  tena sapakṣe jñāne sati pakṣa mātra vṛtti jñātṛ tvam bhavati asādhāraṇam iti śaṅkā anavakāśaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the establishment of self-luminosity, which is not dependent on anything else, is due to the inherent nature of being a knower itself.🔽The manifestation of knowledge, even though not dependent on another knowledge, is dependent on the connection with the self. Thus, the property to be proved, which is the characteristic of self-luminosity, does not exist in knowledge.🔽Therefore, when there is knowledge as the similar instance, the property of being a knower occurring only in the subject is not a common property. Thus, the doubt is not possible.

original: yadyapi kevalavyatirekiṇo na pramāṇatvaṃ siddhānte /🔽athāpi paraprakriyayā parān pratyetatsamarthanaṃ sambhavatyeva /
analyzed: yadi api kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ na pramāṇa tvam siddhānte  athā api para prakriyayā parān prati etat samarthanam sambhavati eva
translated: Although in the established doctrine, the negative-only inference is not accepted as a valid means of knowledge,🔽nevertheless, this establishment can be done for others by the method of others.

analyzed: siddhānte tu pūrvokta anvayinā eva sva prakāśa tva siddhiḥ ātmanaḥ
translated: But in the established doctrine, the self-luminosity of the self is established by the same positive-only inference stated earlier.

analyzed: nitya tva grāhaka pramāṇa balāt ca ātmanaḥ tad prakāśasya api nitya tvam artha siddham
translated: And by the power of the pramāṇa that grasps eternality, the eternality of the manifestation of the self is established as the meaning.

analyzed: śrutibhiḥ ca sakala artha pratiṣṭā iti parama ācāryāṇām āśayaḥ
translated: And by the śrutis, the supreme teachers' intention is that all meanings are established.

original: atha prasaṅgāt prakāśa padārthaṃ nirṇetuṃ vimarśamupakṣipati kaḥ puna riti /
analyzed: atha prasaṅgāt prakāśa padārtham nirṇetum vimarśam upakṣipati kaḥ punar iti
translated: Now, in order to determine the meaning of the word 'prakāśa' incidentally, he introduces the discussion with 'What is this?'

analyzed: nityasya api jñānasya prati karma vyavasthā upapādaka tvāt ca etad vimarśasya prakṛta upayogi tā
translated: And because this discussion is conducive to establishing the regularity of cognition even of the eternal self, it is useful for the present context.

original: yadī ti /🔽prakāśata ityatra dhātvarthaḥ prakāśo jñānam /
analyzed: yadi ti  prakāśate iti atra dhātvarthaḥ prakāśaḥ jñānam
translated: 'If' means:🔽If it is said that in 'prakāśate' the verbal root meaning is prakāśa (illumination), which is knowledge,

analyzed: ākhyāta arthaḥ ca āśraya tvam iti yadi kathyate iti arthaḥ
translated: and the meaning of the verb is substrateness, then that is the meaning.

analyzed: etat dūṣayati tatas iti
translated: He refutes this with 'Then...'

analyzed: tatra ca i ti
translated: 'There' means:

analyzed: vyatireki udāharaṇa vākye nitya prakāśa rūpa viśeṣa niṣedhasya prakāśa sāmānya abhyupagama paryavasāyi tvāt ca ghaṭa ādau āgantuka jñānavat tvam abhyupagatam
translated: And because the negation of the particular form of eternal illumination in the sentence giving an example of vyatireka (negative concomitance) necessarily implies the acceptance of the general notion of illumination, it would imply the acceptance of the presence of adventitious knowledge in a pot, etc.

analyzed: bhavet iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: na caivaṃ sati tatra hetvabhāvo 'jñātṛtvaṃ na syāditi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca evam sati tatra hetu abhāvaḥ jñātṛ tvam na syāt iti vācyam
translated: And in that case, it should not be said that there is no reason there, that it cannot be a knower.
Because the meaning of 'not being the knower' is intended here as 'not being the self'.

original: prakāśāśrayatvamātrasya tu sādhanāyogaḥ siddhatvāditi ca bodhyam /
analyzed: prakāśa āśraya tva mātrasya tu sādhana ayogaḥ siddha tvāt iti ca bodhyam
translated: But it should be understood that the mere fact of being the substratum of light cannot be established because it is already established.

original: uktadoṣaparihārāya prakārāntaraṃ śaṅkate atha tanmābhū diti /
analyzed: ukta doṣa parihārāya prakāra antaram śaṅkate atha tat mā abhūt iti
translated: In order to avoid the stated fault, he raises another possibility: If that be so, let it be so.

analyzed: yadi jñāna viṣaya tvam prakāśamāna tvam ucyate iti yāvat
translated: If it is said that being the object of knowledge means being manifest, that is all.

analyzed: etat api dūṣayati tatas iti
translated: He refutes this also with Then...

analyzed: nitya prakāśavat tva sādhanena ātmanaḥ sārvadikam jñāna viṣaya tvam prasajyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by establishing the self as having eternal light, its being always the object of knowledge is implied.

analyzed: iṣṭam evā idam iti ced tatra āha jñāne ti
translated: If it is said that this is indeed desired, he says In knowledge...

analyzed: jñānasya viṣaya prakāśana vyāpāraḥ hi indriya ādi dvārakaḥ  atas itara anapekṣaḥ
translated: For the function of knowledge in illuminating the object is through the sense organs etc.🔽Therefore, the fact that the self is the object of knowledge without depending on others

analyzed: nityaḥ ca jñāna viṣaya bhāvaḥ ātmanaḥ duḥsādhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: and is eternal is difficult to establish, is the meaning.

analyzed: tathā niyamaḥ iti
translated: And so is the rule.

analyzed: karaṇam apekṣya eva viṣayīkaraṇam iti niyamaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the rule is that the object is made an object only in dependence on the means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā bhāve ti
translated: And so in existence...

analyzed: karaṇa vyāpāra sāpekṣa tva darśanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because it is seen to depend on the operation of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca iti
translated: And not...

original: svātmabhinnaviṣaya eva viṣayīkārasya karaṇāpekṣatvamucyata iti na ca vācyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sva ātma bhinna viṣaye eva viṣayīkārasya karaṇa apekṣa tvam ucyate iti na ca vācyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it should not be said that the dependence on an instrument is only in regard to the object that is different from one's own self.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ pi iti
translated: Even of the self.

original: svātmaprakāśane 'pi śabdaliṅgādikaraṇasāpekṣatvadarśanāt niyamasaṅkoco na karaṇīya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sva ātma prakāśane pi śabda liṅga ādi karaṇa sāpekṣa tva darśanāt niyama saṅkocaḥ na karaṇīyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because even in the self's own manifestation, dependence on an instrument such as word, inference, etc. is seen, the restriction should not be narrowed down.
But it is to be proved that there is a permanent cognition which has as its object only one's own nature.

original: asya cātmaviṣayīkaraṇe na karaṇāpekṣetyatrāha viruddhe iti /
analyzed: asya ca ātma viṣayīkaraṇe na karaṇa apekṣā iti atra āha viruddhe iti
translated: And in this, when the self is made the object, there is no dependence on an instrument. To this he says 'contradictory'.

analyzed: svarūpa mātrasya eva kartṛ tva karma tvayoḥ upagamaḥ viruddhaḥ
translated: The acceptance of the self's own nature as both the agent and the object is contradictory.

original: svarūpamātrajñāne ākārabhedādavirodhasamarthanamapi na sambhavatītyāha nityatve tyādivākyadvayena /🔽nanu svarūpasyaiva gamyatvepi tasyaiva gamakatvaṃ sāmānyaviśeṣadharmabhedāddhaṭetetyatrāha
analyzed: svarūpa mātra jñāne ākāra bhedāt avirodha samarthanam api na sambhavati iti āha nitya tve tyādi vākya dvayena  nanu svarūpasya eva gamya tve pi tasya eva gamaka tvam sāmānya viśeṣa dharma bhedāt dhaṭeta iti atra āha
translated: Even in the cognition of one's own nature alone, the establishment of non-contradiction due to the difference in form is also not possible. This is stated in the two sentences beginning with 'in permanence'.

analyzed: rūpa bhedena iti
translated: But even when one's own nature is alone the object, its being the instrument is established due to the difference between the general and particular properties. To this he says 'by the difference in form'.

analyzed: yathā śabda śabdasya śabda śabda vācya tve pi vācya tā śrotra grāhya guṇa tva ākāreṇa
translated: Just as the word 'word' is denoted by the word 'word', the denotation is in the form of the quality apprehended by the ear.

analyzed: vācaka tā ca ānupūrvī viśeṣeṇa iti na svayaṃprakāśa tvam apakṣasya śabdasya
translated: And denotativeness is in a particular order, so the word, which is not self-luminous, does not have self-luminosity.

original: evaṃ grāhyagrāhakatāvacchedakadharmabhede pakṣīkṛtasyāpi ātmano na svaprakāśatvaṃ sidhyedityarthaḥ/
analyzed: evam grāhya grāhaka tā avacchedaka dharma bhede pakṣīkṛtasya api ātmanaḥ na svaprakāśa tvam sidhyet iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, even the self, which is the subject, does not succeed in being self-luminous, due to the difference in the limiting adjuncts that determine the object and the subject. This is the meaning.

analyzed: evam vimarśakena pakṣa dvayam dūṣitam
translated: Thus, the critic has refuted two positions.

analyzed: atha bhāṭṭa prakriyām anuvadati atha ucyete ti
translated: Now, following the Bhatta procedure, he says If it is said...

analyzed: prākaṭyam prakāśaḥ
translated: Manifestation is illumination.

analyzed: āśraya tvam ca saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And substrateness is the relation.

original: prakāśata iti pratītivyavahārau ca prākaṭyāśrayatvārthakāveva prācuryeṇa pravartete /
analyzed: prakāśate iti pratīti vyavahārau ca prākaṭya āśraya tva arthakau eva prācuryeṇa pravartete
translated: And the cognition and usage it is illuminated occur predominantly only in the sense of being the substratum of manifestation.

analyzed: jñāna janyaḥ prakāśaḥ ca cetana acetana sarva padārtha sādhāraṇaḥ
translated: And illumination, which is produced by knowledge, is common to all conscious and unconscious things.

original: sa eva nityaḥ svābhāvikaścātmanaḥ sādhyatāṃ jñātṛtvabalāditi śaṅkāgranthārthaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ eva nityaḥ svābhāvikaḥ ca ātmanaḥ sādhyatām jñātṛ tva balāt iti śaṅkā grantha arthaḥ
translated: And let that alone be eternal and natural of the self, by the force of being the knower. This is the meaning of the suspected text.

analyzed: prābhākara mukhena nirākaroti imam pakṣam parākṛtaḥ iti
translated: He refutes this position through the Prabhakara, saying This position is refuted.

original: jñātatāvyavahārasya svaprakāśajñānata evopapatterna jñānajanye jñātatākhye dharmāntare pramāṇaṃ kimapīti parākaraṇaprakāraḥ /
analyzed: jñātatā vyavahārasya sva prakāśa jñānataḥ eva upapatteḥ na jñāna janye jñātatā ākhye dharma antare pramāṇam kim api iti parākaraṇa prakāraḥ
translated: The method of refutation is that the usage of being known is possible only from self-luminous cognition itself, so there is no evidence for any other property called knownness produced by cognition.

analyzed: triṣu api eke ti
translated: One in all three.

analyzed: prakāśaḥ jñānam
translated: Light is cognition.

original: tadadhīnavyavahārānuguṇyaṃ sambandhaḥ prakāśata ityatrākhyātārtha iti pakṣa eva jñeyajñānajñātṛṣu ekārthakatā prakāśatevyavahārasya ghaṭata
analyzed: tad adhīna vyavahāra ānuguṇyam sambandhaḥ prakāśate iti atra ākhyātā arthaḥ iti pakṣe eva jñeya jñāna jñātṛṣu eka arthaka tā ghaṭata
translated: The relation that is conducive to usage dependent on that is manifested. The meaning of the verb to manifest is the same in the three: cognition, object of cognition, and cognizer. The usage of is manifested is possible.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.
The implication is that the nature of the cognition of a pot, etc. is the production of conformity with the usage of the triad.

original: jñānātiriktasya prakāśasya nityasyātmanyupagame tatra jñānaṃ vyarthamiti cāha tattvāntare ti /
analyzed: jñāna atiriktasya prakāśasya nityasya ātmani upagame tatra jñānam vyartham iti ca āha tattva antare ti
translated: If eternal light, which is distinct from cognition, is accepted to exist in the self, then cognition is useless there. He says this in in a different reality.

original: svaviṣayakajñāne satyevātmanaḥ prakāśamānateti kṣemasādhāraṇaprayojakatopagamānnātmani caitanyasya vaiyarthyamiti śaṅkate yadyucyete ti /🔽ākṣipati saṃvidī ti /
analyzed: sva viṣayaka jñāne sati eva ātmanaḥ prakāśamāna tā iti kṣema sādhāraṇa prayojaka tā upagamāt na ātmani caitanyasya vaiyarthyam iti śaṅkate yadi ucyete ti  ākṣipati saṃvidi ti
translated: The self is manifested only when there is cognition of itself as its object. Since the common cause is accepted to be the protector, there is no uselessness of consciousness in the self. This is suspected in if it is said.🔽He criticizes consciousness and so on.

analyzed: saṃvid jñānam eva
translated: Consciousness is cognition itself.

analyzed: na jñāna āśrayaḥ
translated: Not the substratum of cognition.

original: tathā ca caitanyasamavāyitvasya prakāśamānatāprayojakatve caitanye tadabhāvātprakāśamānatā na ghaṭeteti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca caitanya samavāyi tvasya prakāśamāna tā prayojaka tve caitanye tad abhāvāt prakāśamāna tā na ghaṭeta iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, if the inherence in consciousness were the cause of manifestation, then, since that is absent in consciousness, manifestation would not be possible in the pot. This is the idea.

original: nanu caitanyasambandha eva prakāśaheturupeyata iti cettatrāha kastaye ti /
analyzed: nanu caitanya sambandhaḥ eva prakāśa hetuḥ upeyate iti ced tatra āha kaḥ taye ti
translated: If it is argued that the relation with consciousness itself is accepted as the cause of manifestation, then he says What is the relation of that etc.

analyzed: tayā acetanayā
translated: By that means by the non-conscious.

analyzed: saṃbandha vikalpena dūṣaṇam atra kriyate
translated: The fault is stated here by the option of the relation.

analyzed: caitanya vat ātma samaveta tvasya caitanya saṃbandha tve ghaṭa ādeḥ aprakāśa āpattiḥ
translated: If the inherence in the self like consciousness were the relation with consciousness, then the pot etc. would not be manifested.

analyzed: tat āha ghaṭa ādeḥ iti
translated: He says of the pot etc.

analyzed: caitanya viṣaya tvasya tattve ca caitanyasya ātmanaḥ ca aprakāśa āpattiḥ
translated: If the object of consciousness were the truth, then the consciousness and the self would not be manifested.

analyzed: tat āha ātmanaḥ iti
translated: He says of the self etc.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ saṃvidaḥ
translated: Of the self, of consciousness.

analyzed: tasya puṃsaḥ
translated: Of that person.

analyzed: prakāśa prayojakasya caitanya viṣaya tvasya aṅguli agreṇa iva sva ātma sparśasya aśakya tvāt caitanye
translated: And because the object of consciousness, which is the cause of manifestation, is as incapable of being touched by one's own self as the tip of the finger is, in consciousness.

analyzed: karma kartṛ tva virodhāt ātmani ca asambhavaḥ iti hārdam
translated: And because it is impossible in the self due to the contradiction of being both the object and the agent, this is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: nanu karma kartṛ virodha upagame stu jñāna āśraya tayā eva ātmani
translated: If it is accepted that there is a contradiction in being both the object and the agent, then let there be the usage of the self being manifested only as the substratum of knowledge.

original: jñānasya tvatīndriyasya jñātatāliṅgakānumānātprākaṭyaṃ sambhavati prakāśatevyavahāranidānamityatrāha jñānādhīne ti /
analyzed: jñānasya tu atīndriyasya jñāta tā liṅgaka anumānāt prākaṭyam sambhavati prakāśa te vyavahāra nidānam iti atra āha jñāna adhīne ti
translated: But the manifestation of knowledge, which is supersensible, is possible through inference based on the mark of being known. The basis for the usage of the term 'manifests' is stated here as being dependent on knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna anumāna pratikṣepāt ca jñānasya jñāna rūpa tayā eva prakāśa tā vyavahāraḥ vācyaḥ
translated: And because the inference of knowledge is rejected, the usage of the term 'manifests' should be stated in terms of knowledge itself.

analyzed: tathā ca prākaṭyena jñāna ja dharmeṇa artheṣu
translated: And thus, in objects, there is the usage of 'manifests' through the property of knowledge, which is manifestation.

analyzed: jñāna rūpa tayā jñāne
translated: In knowledge, through the form of knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna āśraya tayā eva
translated: In the self, only through being the substratum of knowledge.

original: cātmani prakāśatevyavahāra iti triṣvapi tasyaikarūpyāsambhava etanmata iti sthitam /
analyzed: ca ātmani prakāśa tevyavahāraḥ iti triṣu api tasya aikarūpya asambhavaḥ etad mataḥ iti sthitam
translated: Thus, in all three, the impossibility of its being of one form is established according to this view.

analyzed: evam bhāṭṭa mate jñeya jñāna jñātṛṣu guru mukhena
translated: Thus, in the Bhatta view, the impossibility of the usage of 'manifests' being of one form in the knowable, knowledge, and knower is stated through the mouth of the teacher.

original: procya gurumate 'pi triṣu vyavahārānuguṇye aikarūpyāsambhavaṃ vimarśaka udbhāvayati svaprakāśe ti /
analyzed: procya guru mate triṣu vyavahāra ānuguṇye aikarūpya asambhavam vimarśakaḥ udbhāvayati sva prakāśe ti
translated: Having stated this, the commentator raises the question of the impossibility of consistency with usage in all three according to the teacher's view as well, saying 'In self-luminous knowledge'.

analyzed: jñāna viṣaya tayā arthe
translated: In the object, through being the content of knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna rūpa tayā jñāne
translated: In knowledge, through the form of knowledge.

original: jñānāśrayatayā cātmani vyavahārānuguṇyaṃ vaktavyamiti gurumate 'pi vairūpyamaśakyaparihāramityarthaḥ /
analyzed: jñāna āśraya tayā ca ātmani vyavahāra ānuguṇyam vaktavyam iti guru mate vairūpyam aśakya parihāram iti arthaḥ
translated: And in the self, through being the substratum of knowledge. The consistency with usage should be stated. Thus, even in the teacher's view, the diversity is unavoidable, is the meaning.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram api āha mata dvaye ātmani ti
translated: He states another fault in the two views, beginning with in the self.

original: atra śaṅkā indriye ti /🔽yadarthasaṃbaddhendriyaliṅgādinā yajjñānaṃ janitam /
analyzed: atra śaṅkā indriye ti  yad artha saṃbaddha indriya liṅga ādinā yat jñānam janitam
translated: Here, the doubt is expressed with in the sense organ.🔽The meaning of the doubt is: The knowledge that is produced by the sense organ, which is related to the object, and by the inferential mark, etc.,

original: tat tasminnarthe prakaṭatāṃ vyavahārānuguṇyaṃ vā niṣpādayatīti śaṅkārthaḥ /
analyzed: tat tasmin arthe prakaṭa tām vyavahāra ānuguṇyam vā niṣpādayati iti śaṅkā arthaḥ
translated: brings about either manifestation in that object or conformity with practical usage.

original: pratikṣipati na khalu labdhe ti /🔽kāryasya svotpattāveva nimittakāraṇāpekṣā /
analyzed: pratikṣipati na khalu labdhe ti  kāryasya sva utpattau eva nimitta kāraṇa apekṣā
translated: He rejects [the doubt] with Certainly, when the effect is produced, it does not need a cause again.🔽A cause is needed only for the production of its effect.

analyzed: na tu samutpannasya sva kārya janane
translated: But once produced, it does not need a cause even for producing its own effect.

analyzed: anyathā kulāla sannidhāne eva ghaṭena jalasya āharaṇam
translated: Otherwise, the pot would be able to draw water only when the potter is present,

analyzed: na anyatra ipi syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: and not elsewhere. This is the meaning.

original: jñānasyaiva svakāryaniṣpādane svanimittāpekṣetyāśrayaṇe cedamapi vaiṣamyaṃ prasajyata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: jñānasya eva sva kārya niṣpādane sva nimitta apekṣā iti āśrayaṇe ca idam api vaiṣamyam prasajyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if it is accepted that knowledge needs its own cause only for producing its own effect, then this inequality would also arise.

analyzed: kulāla ādi samāna adhiṣṭhānam kulāla ādi samāna adhikaraṇam  vaiṣamya antaram api āha na ca iti
translated: The potter, etc., are the same substratum as the potter, etc.🔽He states another inequality with And if it is accepted that knowledge is destroyed by the destruction of its cause.

original: anyatra nimittanāśe kāryanāśasyādarśanāt jñānasyaiva nimittanāśena nāśābhyupagamenāpi vaiṣamyaṃ prasaktaṃ pakṣadvaye 'pītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra nimitta nāśe kārya nāśasya adarśanāt jñānasya eva nimitta nāśena nāśa abhyupagamena api vaiṣamyam prasaktam pakṣa dvaye pi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even if it is accepted that knowledge is destroyed by the destruction of its cause, an inequality is entailed in both views, because the destruction of the effect is not seen elsewhere when the cause is destroyed.

original: kaṃ tarhi prakāśasya vyavahārasya vopapattiḥ / tatrāti /
analyzed: kam tarhi prakāśasya vyavahārasya vā upapattiḥ tatra ati
translated: Then what is the justification for the usage of light or manifestation? The answer is:

original: iti indriyādidvārā prasṛtasya tena sahārthasannikṛṣṭasya jñānasyārthaprakāśakasyārthapkāvyavahāra janakatvaṃ svīkāryamanāyatyeti hārdam /
analyzed: iti indriya ādi dvārā prasṛtasya tena saha artha sannikṛṣṭasya jñānasya artha prakāśakasya janaka tvam svīkāryam anāyatyā iti hārdam
translated: The heart of the matter is that the cognition which has spread through the sense organs etc. and is in contact with the object along with that must be accepted as the producer of the usage of manifesting the object, because it is reasonable.

analyzed: siddhāntinām pakṣaḥ yam
translated: This is the view of the proponents of the established conclusion.

analyzed: tathā asasati ti
translated: If it were not so.

original: indriyeṇa saha pravṛttyādimattve hi jñānasya tadarthasannikṛṣṭasya tatprakāśakasyendriyārthasannikarṣānvayavyatirekānuvidhāyyanvayavyat irekopapattirityarthaḥ
analyzed: indriyeṇa saha pravṛtti ādimattve hi jñānasya tad artha sannikṛṣṭasya tad prakāśakasya indriya artha sannikarṣa anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi anvaya vyat ireka upapattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: If the cognition had the property of operating along with the sense organ, then the cognition in contact with its object, which manifests it, would be in conformity with the positive and negative concomitance of the contact of the sense organ with the object. This is the meaning.

analyzed: anyathā ti
translated: Otherwise.

analyzed: indriya ādi dvāraka jñāna artha sannikarṣasya anupagame nimitta nāśasya kārya nāśe hetu tvāt indriya artha sannikarṣa ādi nivṛttau jñāna nivṛttiḥ na syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: If the contact of the cognition with the object through the sense organ etc. is not accepted, then the destruction of the cause would not be the cause of the destruction of the effect. Therefore, when the contact of the sense organ with the object etc. ceases, the cessation of cognition would not occur. This is the meaning.

analyzed: na ca saṅkhyā ādi nidarśanena atra pratyavasthānam yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to argue against this by citing number etc.

analyzed: asiddha tvena nāśasya saṅkhyāyāḥ buddhi nāśataḥ
translated: Because destruction is not established, number is not destroyed by the destruction of cognition.

analyzed: saṅkhyā tvāt anyāpyā adravya bhāvinī
translated: Like the number one, number arises from something other than substance, because it is number.

analyzed: sarvā hi eka āśrayā saṅkhyā nitya anitya artha vartinī
translated: For all numbers exist in one substratum, whether eternal or non-eternal.

analyzed: yāvat āśraya satyā iva saṃmatā sarva vādinām
translated: As long as the substratum exists, it is accepted by all logicians.

analyzed: dvi tva ādikā parārdha antā saṅkhyā yā aneka vartinī
translated: The number beginning with two and ending with the highest, which exists in many,

analyzed: sā api saṅkhyā tva sāmānye sati kasmāt na tādṛśī
translated: that also, being in the universal numberness, why is it not like that?

analyzed: nanu na eka tvam saṅkyā
translated: But oneness is not number.

analyzed: svarūpa anatirekāt
translated: Because it does not exceed its own nature.

analyzed: atas sādhana vikalam udāharaṇam
translated: Therefore the example is defective in the reason.

analyzed: mā evam saṅkhyā eva sā
translated: No, that is number itself.

analyzed: dravya antare pi anuvṛtteḥ
translated: Because it continues in another substance.

analyzed: yadi ghaṭa ādeḥ svarūpam eva ekatvam
translated: If oneness is the very nature of a pot, etc.,

analyzed: tatas ghaṭaḥ ekaḥ
translated: then a pot is one,

original: paṭa eka iti sarvadravyasādhāraṇyamekatvasya na syāt /
analyzed: paṭaḥ ekaḥ iti sarva dravya sādhāraṇyam eka tvasya na syāt
translated: a cloth is one - oneness would not be common to all substances.

original: nahi ghaṭasvarūpasya paṭasvarūpeṇa saṃbhavati sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ ghaṭaḥ paṭa iti /
analyzed: nahi ghaṭa sva rūpasya paṭa sva rūpeṇa saṃbhavati sāmānādhikaraṇyam ghaṭaḥ paṭaḥ iti
translated: For the identity of a pot's nature with a cloth's nature is not possible, as in a pot is a cloth.

analyzed: asti tu tad eka tvasya
translated: But that is possible for oneness.

analyzed: nanu nimitta nāśasya api kārya nāśe hetu tvam kvacid eṣṭavyam
translated: But somewhere the destruction of the cause must also be accepted as the cause of the destruction of the effect.

analyzed: anyathā apekṣā buddhi nāśāt di tva ādeḥ nāśasya anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, the destruction of the relative cognition would not be possible for the destruction of two, etc.

original: tathā prakṛte 'pi bhaviṣyatīti śaṅkate na ce ti /
analyzed: tathā prakṛte pi bhaviṣyati iti śaṅkate na ced ti
translated: In the same way, it will happen in the present case also. This is suspected by not etc.

analyzed: pariharati asiddha tvena i ti
translated: He answers: By the fact of its not being established.

original: apekṣābuddhināśena dvitvādināśasyāsiddhatvena na nimittanāśena kāryanāśe dvitvādernāśasya nidarśanatvaṃ saṃbhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: apekṣā buddhi nāśena dvi tva ādi nāśasya asiddha tvena na nimitta nāśena kārya nāśe dvi tva ādeḥ nāśasya nidarśana tvam saṃbhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the destruction of duality, etc. cannot be an example of the destruction of an effect by the destruction of its cause, because the destruction of duality, etc. is not established by the destruction of the cognition of dependence.

analyzed: eke ti
translated: One.

analyzed: yāvat āśraya bhāvi tvāt eka tvasya iva dvi tva ādeḥ saṅkhyā tvāt na apekṣā buddhi nāśāt nāśaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that duality, etc., like oneness, are not destroyed by the destruction of the cognition of dependence because they are number, existing as long as their substratum exists.

analyzed: asiddha tvam etena upapāditam bhavati
translated: By this, the fact of its not being established is explained.

analyzed: tra prayogaḥ dvi tva ādiḥ yāvat āśraya satī saṅkhyā tvāt eka tva vat iti
translated: The conclusion of the argument here is: Duality, etc., are numbers existing as long as their substratum exists because they are number, like oneness.

original: dṛṣṭānte hetvāsiddhiṃ śaṅkate nanu naikatvam iti /🔽pariharati maivam iti /
analyzed: dṛṣṭānte hetu āsiddhim śaṅkate nanu na ekatvam iti  pariharati mā evam iti
translated: He raises the doubt of the non-establishment of the reason in the example: But oneness is not.🔽He answers: Not so.

analyzed: yadi ti  tad tad vyakti svarūpasya eva eka pratīti vyavahāra niyāmaka tve ghaṭaḥ ekaḥ
translated: If so,🔽when the form of each individual is the regulator of a single cognition and usage, it is one pot.

analyzed: paṭaḥ ekaḥ ityādi anugata pratīti vyavahāra anupapattiḥ
translated: If the form of each individual alone were the determiner of the cognition and usage of oneness, then the cognition and usage of the continuity like the pot is one, the cloth is one etc. would not be possible.

analyzed: tad tad vyakti tvasya ananugata tvāt
translated: Because the nature of each individual is not continuous.

analyzed: eka tva saṅkhyāyāḥ tathātve tu eka tvena anugamāt anugata pratīti ādi upapattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But if the number oneness were like that, then the possibility of the continuous cognition etc. would be explained by the continuity through oneness. This is the idea.

analyzed: tārkika prakriyayā idam
translated: This is according to the method of the logicians.

analyzed: kiñca saṃṅkhyā ekatā viruddha tvāt dvi saṅkhyā iva anya saṅkhayā
translated: Moreover, the cognition of oneness and plurality is contradictory, like the cognition of duality and non-duality.

analyzed: ekam dvau iti na hi asti sāmānādhikaraṇya dhīḥ
translated: There is no cognition of co-reference like one and two.

analyzed: yat tu aneka dravya vṛtti tve sati guṇa tvāt saṃyogavat ayāvat dravya bhāvinī dvi tva ādi saṅkhyā iti
translated: As for the argument that number like two etc. inheres in substances as long as the substances last, because it is a quality inhering in many substances like conjunction,

analyzed: tat nanātve na aikāntikam
translated: that is inconclusive in the case of non-duality.

analyzed: na hi satoḥ api ghaṭa paṭayoḥ tat nānātvam naśyati
translated: For even when there are two, the pot and the cloth, their non-duality does not perish.

analyzed: na ca tat dvi tva saṅkhyā eva
translated: And that is not the number two itself.

analyzed: trayāṇām tad abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in the case of three, that would be impossible.

analyzed: na ca tad eka tva abhāva mātram
translated: And that is not merely the absence of unity.

analyzed: tucchasya api nānātva āpatteḥ
translated: Because even a void would be non-dual.

original: dṛṣṭānte hetvasiddhiṃ śaṅkate ' nanu naikatva 'm iti /🔽pariharati ' maiva 'miti /
analyzed: dṛṣṭānte hetu asiddhim śaṅkate nanu na ekatvam iti  pariharati mā eva miti
translated: He doubts the non-establishment of the reason in the example, saying But is not non-duality...🔽He replies, No,

analyzed: yadi ti  tad tad vyakti svarūpasya eva eka pratīti vyavahāra niyāmaka tve ghaṭaḥ ekaḥ
translated: 'If' (it is said that the universal is not the cause of the cognition of the individual, then the individual itself is the cause).🔽If the form of each individual alone were the cause of the cognition and usage, then there would be only one pot.

analyzed: paṭaḥ ekaḥ ityādi anugata pratīti vyavahāra anupapattiḥ
translated: If the form of each individual alone were the determiner of unitary cognition and usage, then the cognition and usage of one pot, one cloth etc. would be impossible,

analyzed: tad tad vyakti tvasya ananugata tvāt
translated: because the quality of being each individual is not universal.

analyzed: eka tva saṅkhyāyāḥ tathātve tu eka tvena anugamāt anugata pratīti ādi upapattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But if the number one were like that, then because it is followed by one, the cognition of the universal and so on would be explained.

analyzed: tārkika prakriyayā idam
translated: This is according to the method of the logicians.

original: svarūpatve bādhakamuktvaikatvasya saṅkhyātve sādhakamapyāha ' saṅkhyakate ' ti /
analyzed: sva rūpa tve bādhakam uktvā ekatvasya saṅkhyā tve sādhakam api āha saṅkhyakate ti
translated: Having stated the contradiction to the oneness being the nature [of the number one], he also states the proof for the oneness being a number, with it is a number.

analyzed: atra prayogaḥ eka tvam saṅkhyā saṅkhyā antara viruddha tvāt dvi tva ādi vat iti
translated: Here the argument is: Oneness is a number, because it is contradictory to other numbers, like two and so on.

analyzed: hetum pakṣe ghaṭayati iti
translated: He connects the reason to the subject with one.

analyzed: atra idam bodhyam uddeśya tā avacchedaka avacchinna paryāpteḥ dvi tva ādi saṃbandhatayā bhānāt ekatva avacchinna paryāpteḥ ca dvi tva ādi saṃbandha tva abhāvena na
translated: Here this should be understood: because the completeness characterized by the object of reference appears as the relation of two and so on, and because the completeness characterized by one does not have the nature of the relation of two and so on,

analyzed: ekam dvau iti prayogaḥ
translated: the usage one is two is not [correct].

analyzed: ekam dvi tva vat iti tu syāt nāma
translated: One is like two may be [correct].

analyzed: atra dvi tva samavāyasya eva svarūpa saṃbandhena bhānāt
translated: Here, because the inherence of two itself appears as the relation of identity,

analyzed: tasya ca ekasmin api abādhāt
translated: and because that is not contradicted even in one,🔽and because being contradictory to other numbers is defined as the absence of being the pervader of completeness characterized by the completeness characterized by other numbers,

analyzed: saṅkhyā antara viruddha tvam ca saṅkhyā antara paryāpti avacchedaka avacchinna paryāptika vṛttika tva abhāva lakṣaṇam iti
translated: [the argument is correct].

analyzed: dvi tva ādeḥ yāvat āśraya bhāvi tva anumāne dṛṣṭānte sādhana vaikalyam para hṛtam etāvatā  /
translated: In the inference of duality, etc., as long as they exist in dependence on the substrate, the deficiency of the reason in the example has been removed so far.

analyzed: āpekṣika tvāt dvi tva ādeḥ pratiyegya vavagrahāt  bubhutsā uparamāt ca api satyāḥ eva anavagrahaḥ
translated: Duality, etc. are relative, because they are grasped in dependence on the counter-correlate.🔽Even when they exist, there is no apprehension due to the cessation of desire to know.

analyzed: atas caitanyasya eva indriya dvārā artha sannikarṣaḥ eva tad bhāva anuvidhāna upapattiḥ
translated: And for this reason, the dependence of the existence of consciousness alone on the contact of the object through the sense organ is logically possible.

original: anyacca / arthasya prakāśakaṃ hi jñānaṃ bhavatām /
analyzed: anyat ca arthasya prakāśakam hi jñānam bhavatām
translated: Moreover, for you, knowledge is the illuminator of the object.

original: sarvaṃ ca prakāśakaṃ prakāśyavastusannikṛṣṭameva prakāśakaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ dīpaprabhādi /
analyzed: sarvam ca prakāśakam prakāśya vastu sannikṛṣṭam eva prakāśakam dṛṣṭam dīpa prabhā ādi
translated: And every illuminator is seen to be the illuminator only when in contact with the object to be illuminated, like the light of a lamp, etc.

analyzed: atas tat api tathā iti yuktam āśrayitum
translated: Therefore, it is proper to assume that this also is so.

analyzed: vyoma vat amūrtasya na kriyāvat tvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that an incorporeal thing like space does not possess action,

analyzed: kā iyam mūrtiḥ nāma
translated: what is this so-called corporeality?
That which is devoid of that is fit for action.

analyzed: yadi paribhāṣikī dravya tve sati kvācitkatā iti
translated: If it is defined as existing in some substances,

analyzed: iṣyate eva sā caitanye
translated: that is accepted even in consciousness.

analyzed: na hi tat sarva gatam dravyam
translated: For that is not an omnipresent substance.

analyzed: tathā asati yugapad sarva artha siddhi prasaṅgāt
translated: If it were so, then there would be the undesirable consequence of the simultaneous cognition of all objects.

original: kvācitkatve tu tadvi yadaikadaikendriyeṇa saṃprayuktaṃ tadarthābhimukham /
analyzed: kvācitkatve tu tat vi yadā ekadā eka indriyeṇa saṃprayuktam tad artha abhimukham
translated: But if it is occasional, then that which is associated with one sense organ at one time is directed towards its object.

analyzed: na tadā indriya antaram adhitiṣṭhati
translated: It does not control other sense organs.

analyzed: atas eva hi yugapad jñāna anutpattiḥ
translated: For this very reason, there is no simultaneous arising of cognitions.

analyzed: niratiśaya vegam ca tat
translated: And it has unsurpassed speed.

analyzed: yugapad iva ati śīghram aneka indriya adhiṣṭhāna darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen to control many sense organs simultaneously or very quickly.

analyzed: atas yathā uditam amūrta tvam asiddham
translated: Therefore, the immateriality as stated is not established.

analyzed: sparśavat tā mūrtiḥ
translated: Mūrti (materiality) is the state of having touch.

analyzed: tad vitara hān niṣkriya tvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the absence of action is due to the absence of that,

analyzed: śabdena an aikāntaḥ
translated: there is non-uniqueness with sound.

original: sa khalu śaṅkhamukhāderdavīyaso 'pi deśāt nodanaviśeṣeṇa loṣṭādiriva yāvadvegaṃ pratiṣṭhate sparśavihīno 'pi /
analyzed: sa khalu śaṅkha mukha ādeḥ davīyasaḥ pi deśāt nodana viśeṣeṇa loṣṭa ādiḥ iva yāvadvegam pratiṣṭhate sparśa vihīnaḥ u pi
translated: For that, even from a distant place like the mouth of a conch, moves as far as the speed by a special effort like a clod, even without touch.

analyzed: sparśa rahitasya api mana indriyasya kriyāvat tvam padārtha vākya artha vidām ubhayeṣām api saṃmatam eva
translated: The fact that the mental sense organ, which is devoid of touch, is active is accepted by both those who know the meaning of words and sentences.

analyzed: katham atīta anāgatayoḥ asatoḥ caitanyena saṃprayogaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how there can be association with consciousness of the past and future, which are non-existent,

analyzed: katham vā viṣaya bhāvaḥ
translated: how can there be the state of being an object?

analyzed: prakāśamāna tvam
translated: It is the state of being manifest.

analyzed: saṅkhyā ādi yogaḥ vā tayoḥ
translated: Or it is the possession of number and so on by them.

analyzed: yaḥ tatra nirvāhaḥ
translated: Whatever explanation there is for that,

analyzed: saḥ eva atra astu
translated: let that be the same here.

original: api cātītatayānāgatatayā ca tāvapyadyāpi vidyete iti tena rūpeṇa bodhasannikarṣe kānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: api ca atīta tayā anāgata tayā ca tau api adya api vidyete iti tena rūpeṇa bodha sannikarṣe kā anupapattiḥ
translated: Moreover, those two [universals] exist even now as past and future. So there is no inconsistency in the cognition being in contact with them in that form.

original: kiñca / yathā davīyasi deśe satā dhruvaśiṃśumārādinā dṛk tu sannikṛṣyate /
analyzed: kiñca yathā davīyasi deśe satā dhruva śiṃśumāra ādinā dṛś tu sannikṛṣyate
translated: Moreover, just as the distant Dhruva mountain and the sea-monster are seen by being brought closer,

original: tathā davīyasi kāle satā kalpādyantavartinā svayaṃbhuvādineti nālokaṃ kiñcit / kiñca
analyzed: tathā davīyasi kāle satā kalpa ādi anta vartinā svayaṃbhu ādinā iti kiñcid kiñca
translated: in the same way, the self-existent one existing at the distant past and future is seen. So there is nothing unseen. Moreover,

analyzed: sat pratipakṣam āśaṅkate yat tu aneke iti
translated: he suspects the counter-argument with 'But what is said by many'.

analyzed: pariharati tadi ti
translated: He replies with 'That is not so'.

analyzed: nānātvam bahutvam
translated: Plurality is multiplicity.

analyzed: tasya ca vyāsajya vṛtti tvāt dvi tva ādi vat guṇa tvam eva
translated: And that, being pervasive, is a quality like duality etc.

analyzed: na tu bheda rūpa tvam  bhedasya avyāsajya vṛtti tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But it is not of the nature of difference.🔽The idea is that difference is not pervasive.

original: nanu yāvadāśrayaṃ sattve āśrayopalambhakāle niyamata ekatvasyeva dvitvāderupalambhaḥ prasajyate iti cettatrāha ' āpekṣikatvā ' diti /
analyzed: nanu yāvadāśrayam sattve āśraya upalambha kāle niyamataḥ eka tvasya iva dvi tva ādeḥ upalambhaḥ prasajyate iti ced tatra āha āpekṣika tvāt iti
translated: If it is argued that when there is existence as long as the substratum, the apprehension of duality etc. would necessarily occur at the time of the apprehension of the substratum like the apprehension of oneness, then he says 'because it is relative'.

analyzed: saṃbandhi antara graha sāpekṣa grahasya dvi tva ādeḥ pratiyoginaḥ saṃbandhi antarasya agrahaṇāt
translated: Duality etc., which is apprehended in dependence on the apprehension of another related object, is not apprehended due to the non-apprehension of the counter-correlate, which is a different related object.

original: grahaṇe vā dvitvādibubhutsāyā apekṣābuddheśca tadvodhe sahakāriṇyā viraheṇa na sadā graha iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: grahaṇe vā dvi tva ādi bubhutsāyāḥ apekṣā buddheḥ ca tad vodhe sahakāriṇyāḥ viraheṇa na sadā grahaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in the case of apprehension, or in the desire to know duality etc., and in the cognition of that, due to the absence of the assisting cognition of the relation of inherence, there is no constant apprehension.

original: evaṃ ca nimittanāśanāśyatvasya na nidarśanībhavitumalaṃ dvitvādatyuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: evam ca nimitta nāśa nāśya tvasya na nidarśanībhavitum alam dvi tvāt atyuktam bhavati
translated: And thus it is said that duality etc. are not capable of being illustrated as being destroyed by the destruction of the cause.

original: vastuto 'pekṣābuddhiviśeṣātiriktaṃ dvitvādikamevāprāmāṇikamiti tannāśādhīnatannāśasya na tarāṃ prasaktiriti bodhyam // //
analyzed: vastutas upekṣā buddhi viśeṣa atiriktam dvi tva ādikam eva aprāmāṇikam iti tad nāśa adhīna tad nāśasya na tarām prasaktiḥ iti bodhyam  /
translated: In reality, duality etc. apart from the specific cognition of the relation of inherence are not authoritative. Therefore, the destruction dependent on their destruction is not at all possible. This should be understood.

analyzed: na atīta anāgate buddheḥ dūre bhavitum arhataḥ
translated: The past and future cannot be far from cognition,

analyzed: buddhyā prakāśamāna tvāt buddhi boddhṛ sva rūpa vat
translated: because they appear to cognition, like the nature of the cognizer and the cognized.

analyzed: evam ca caitanyasya
translated: And thus, consciousness

analyzed: niratiśaya vegi tayā antarāla deśa kāla agrahaṇa abhimānaḥ lāta cakra gata kramavat deśa bheda saṃyoga vibhāga agrahaṇa abhimāna vat
translated: due to its unsurpassed velocity, does not apprehend intermediate space and time, like the apparent lack of apprehension of the conjunction and disjunction of different places in a whirling firebrand.

analyzed: api ca indriya liṅga saṃskāra ādeḥ yat artha pratiniyatam rūpam
translated: Moreover, the form of the sense organ, inferential mark, impression etc. which is restricted to a particular object,

analyzed: tainā evā upaśliṣya nissarat caitanyam api tad gocareṇa eva sannikṛṣṭate
