translated: And as, etc. The bahuvrihi compound means having cognition as an adjunct.🔽The meaning is: the referent of the word self has the property of being the determiner of a nature that is not different from cognition.

analyzed: jñānavat tvena evā upalabhyamāna tva yuktayā bodha upādhi tvam ātmanaḥ samarthitam
translated: It has been argued that the self has cognition as an adjunct, being perceived as having cognition.

analyzed: viṣaya saṃbandha kādācitkatvāt viṣaya uparakta jñānasya kādācitkatva pratītau api jñāna svarūpam nityam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even though the relation to an object makes cognition occasional, and the perception is of the occasional nature of cognition that is related to an object, the form of cognition is eternal, this is the idea.

original: yadyapi jñānasyātmasvabhāvatve nityatve ca śāstramagre pramāṇīkariṣyate /
analyzed: yadi api jñānasya ātma svabhāva tve nitya tve ca śāstram agre pramāṇīkariṣyate
translated: Although the scriptures will be taken as authoritative later on regarding cognition being the intrinsic nature of the self and its eternality,

analyzed: athā api yukti pradhāna tvāt prakaraṇasya asya yuktiḥ eva puraskṛtā iti bodhyam
translated: still, since this section is primarily concerned with reasoning, reasoning should be given precedence, this is what should be understood.

analyzed: anena jñānasya āgantuka tva anumāne svū rūpa nirūpaka dharma bhinna tvam upādhiḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this, it is said that in the inference of cognition being adventitious, being different from the property of being the determiner of one's own nature is a limiting condition.

analyzed: atha tatra nidarśane hetu āsiddhim api āha sukha iti
translated: Now, in that example, he states the non-establishment of the reason also with happiness, etc.

analyzed: anukūla pratikūla jñānāni eva rāddhānte
translated: The knowledge of the favorable and unfavorable is established as the knowledge of the path.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha rūpāṇi
translated: The knowledge of what is agreeable and disagreeable are indeed of the nature of pleasure and pain, according to the conclusion (of the Vedānta).

analyzed: teṣām ca pakṣa antarbhāvāt na nidarśana tā
translated: And they are included in the category (of the soul), so they are not examples.

analyzed: jñāna viśeṣa atirikte ca sukha duḥkhe karaṇa pāṭava apāṭava lakṣaṇe
translated: And pleasure and pain, which are distinct from particular knowledge, are characterized by the sharpness and dullness of the instrument (of knowledge).

analyzed: tayoḥ ca na ātma guṇa tvam iti hetu asiddhiḥ dṛṣṭānte iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And it is not the quality of the self, so the reason is not established, the example is so, this is the idea.

analyzed: antimā iti
translated: The last (verse).

analyzed: svatas sukhī iti etad aṃśa samarthana avasare iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the occasion for establishing the part the self is naturally blissful, this is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu evam api rāga ādeḥ dṛṣṭānta tā syāt
translated: But even so, attachment and so on would be the example.

analyzed: ātma viśeṣa guṇa tvāt āgantuka tvāt ca iti atra āha rāga iti
translated: Because they are the special qualities of the self and because they are adventitious, to this he says attachment and so on.

analyzed: manaḥ vṛtti bhedāḥ rāga ādayaḥ na ātma dharmāḥ
translated: Attachment and so on are distinctions in the activity of the mind, they are not qualities of the self.

analyzed: kintu agni dharmasya auṣṇya ādeḥ tad saṃsṛṣṭa sthālyām iva manaḥ dharmāṇām ātmani kevalam pratītiḥ
translated: But just as the heat, which is a quality of fire, is perceived in a pot mixed with it, so the qualities of the mind are perceived in the self alone.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam nirvāṇa mayaḥ eva ayam ātmā jñāna mayaḥ malaḥ
translated: And thus it is said: This self is indeed made of liberation, made of knowledge, and pure.

analyzed: duḥkha ajñāna malāḥ dharmāḥ prakṛteḥ te na ca ātmanaḥ
translated: The qualities of pain, ignorance, and impurity belong to primordial matter, not to the self.

analyzed: iti bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the idea.

original: rāgāderantaḥkaraṇadharmatvaṃ śrutyāmapi pratīyata ityāha vijñāyata iti /
analyzed: rāga ādeḥ antaḥkaraṇa dharma tvam śrutyām api pratīyate iti āha vijñāyate iti
translated: It is understood in the scriptures also that attachment and so on are the qualities of the internal organ, he says it is known and so on.

analyzed: asmin arthe bhagavat vacanam api saṃvādayati gīyate ca iti
translated: In this matter, he also corroborates the statement of the Blessed Lord by saying it is sung.

analyzed: kṣetra āśrita tvāt antaḥkaraṇasya tad dharmāḥ rāga dayaḥ kṣetra dharma tvena uktāḥ
translated: Since the internal organ is based on the field, the qualities of that, such as attachment, are spoken of as the qualities of the field.

analyzed: nanu atra cetanā dhṛtiḥ iti api  paṭhyate
translated: But here, the support of consciousness is also recited.

analyzed: atas bodhasya api na ātma dharma tvam iti atra āha cetanā dhṛtiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, even consciousness is not a quality of the self. To this he says the support of consciousness.

analyzed: cetanā iti dhṛtiḥ iti ca na pada dvayam
translated: Consciousness and support are not two words.

analyzed: kintu cetanā dhṛtiḥ iti samastam
translated: But the support of consciousness is a compound.

original: cetanena /cetanayā vā ādhṛtiryasyeti cetanādhāryaṃ niyamataḥ śarīramiti śarīralakṣmocyate 'treti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: cetanena cetanayā vā ādhṛtiḥ yasya iti cetanā dhāryam niyamataḥ śarīram iti śarīra lakṣmā ucyate tra iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that here the definition of the body is stated as that which is necessarily the support of consciousness, that which has support by consciousness, or that which has support by consciousness.

analyzed: tat āha sva vṛtti iti
translated: He says this by having its own activity.

analyzed: vṛttiḥ sattā
translated: Activity is existence.

analyzed: pravṛttiḥ vā
translated: Or it is engagement.

analyzed: pravartamānam prakarṣeṇa vartamānam labdha sthitikam
translated: That which is engaged, which is engaged to the highest degree, which has attained stability,

analyzed: pravṛttimat vā
translated: or which has engagement.
The meaning that results is that the body has the general property of having its own existence and engagement dependent on the connection with the consciousness of the self.

analyzed: idam eva śarīra lakṣma sādhu
translated: This alone is the proper definition of the body.

analyzed: kara caraṇa ādimattva ādi lakṣaṇānām avyāpti ādi doṣāt iti hṛdaye nidhāya pṛthivī ādīnām paramātma śarīra tva para śrauta vacanāni upādatte atas eva iti
translated: Keeping in mind the faults such as over-extension etc. of the definitions such as having hands, feet etc., he cites the scriptural statements about the earth etc. being the body of the supreme self, beginning with for this very reason.

original: bhagavatsaṅkalpātmakajñānenaiva labdhasvarūpasthitipravṛttikatvātsarvasya taccharīratvaṃ śośruyate mukhyameveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: bhagavat saṅkalpa ātmaka jñānena eva labdha svarūpa sthiti pravṛttika tvāt sarvasya tat śarīra tvam śośruyate mukhyam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that everything is said to be the body of that [supreme self] because it exists, is established, and functions only by the knowledge which is of the nature of the Lord's will, and that this is the primary [meaning].

analyzed: kim iti nanu antaḥkaraṇa dharmeṣu dhīḥ api paṭhyate
translated: Why? [Objection:] But the word dhī is also recited among the qualities of the internal organ.

analyzed: tat na bodhasya ātma svabhāva tvam iti garbhitam codyam atra
translated: The implied objection here is that [the word dhī] does not indicate that knowledge is the intrinsic nature of the self.

analyzed: pariharati utprekṣā iti
translated: He answers with imagination.

analyzed: citta vṛtti viśeṣeṣu utprekṣā dhīḥ iti ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the specific modifications of the mind, imagination is called dhī.

analyzed: yadi api kāma ādikānām api matam ātma dharma tvam
translated: Although desire and so on are also considered to be qualities of the self,

analyzed: param na ete svābhāvikāḥ ātmanaḥ
translated: these are not natural to the self.

analyzed: kintu karma ādi upādhi nibandhanāḥ
translated: But they are based on adjuncts such as karma.

original: kāmāditattadbuddhivṛttihetuvyāpāravattayā ca manasastattadabhedanirdeśa aupacārikaḥ śrutau kṛta iti siddhāntaḥ /
analyzed: kāma ādi tad tad buddhi vṛtti hetu vyāpāravat tayā ca manasaḥ tad tad abheda nirdeśaḥ aupacārikaḥ śrutau kṛtaḥ iti siddhāntaḥ
translated: And the explanation in the scriptures that the mind is designated as such and such without distinction due to having the activity of being the cause of the various modifications of the mind such as desire is figurative. This is the conclusion.

analyzed: atha api avasthā viśeṣa viśiṣṭasya jñānasya eva rāga ādi rūpa tayā jñāna kādācitkatva anumāne
translated: Even if knowledge itself, qualified by a particular state, has the form of passion etc., and in the inference of the occasional nature of knowledge,

analyzed: na rāga ādeḥ dṛṣṭanta tā saṃbhavati
translated: the example of passion etc. is not possible.

analyzed: naca viśiṣṭa nidarśanena jñāna mātrasya āgantuka tvam sādhyam iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that by the illustration of the qualified, only the adventitious nature of mere knowledge is to be established.

analyzed: avasthā viśiṣṭasya eva upalabhyamāna tayā aviśiṣṭe jñāna mātre āgantuka tva sādhana ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible to establish the adventitious nature in mere unqualified knowledge, which is not perceived as qualified by a state.

original: tasya śrutisiddhatve ca tannityatvamapi śrutisiddhameveti dharmigrāhakamānabādhaḥ /
analyzed: tasya śruti siddha tve ca tad nitya tvam api śruti siddham eva iti dharmi grāhaka māna bādhaḥ
translated: And if its eternality is established by scripture, then its eternality is also established by scripture. Thus there is contradiction with the means of knowing the subject.

analyzed: asataḥ vasthā yogena ca jñāna nitya tvam eva yuktimat iti hārdam
translated: And the eternality of knowledge is reasonable, since a state cannot be related to a non-existent. This is the heart of the matter.

analyzed: yathāśrutam tu abhyupagama vādena
translated: But as it is heard, it is accepted as a statement of acceptance.

analyzed: jñāna nitya tve śrutim udāharati śrūyate hi iti
translated: In the eternality of knowledge, he cites a scripture: It is heard...

analyzed: vijñāti tva dṛṣṭi tva ādi avasthā bhājaḥ jñāna svarūpasya nitya tvam atra vivakṣitam
translated: Here, the eternality of the form of knowledge, which undergoes states such as being known, being seen, etc., is intended.

analyzed: viparilopaḥ vināśaḥ  nanu atra avināśi tvam eva uktam
translated: Peril means destruction.🔽But here, only non-destruction is stated.

analyzed: nānā ādi ananta tvam jñānasya iti atra āha jñātuḥ iti
translated: Not the beginninglessness and endlessness of knowledge. Here, he says of the knower...

original: svarūpanirūpakatvena nityātmasvarūpaprayuktasya jñānasya purātanatvamapi phalatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svarūpa nirūpaka tvena nitya ātma svarūpa prayuktasya jñānasya purātana tvam api phalati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the ancientness of the knowledge employed in the form of the eternal self, by virtue of its being the determiner of its own nature, also becomes fruitful.

analyzed: na ca iti
translated: And not so, etc.

analyzed: abhedena dṛṣṭi viśeṣaṇa tvam draṣṭṛ padasya na yuktam
translated: The qualification of vision by the word seer is not proper without difference.

original: tathāsati draṣṭhyā iti strīliṅganirdeśena hi bhāvyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā asati draṣṭhyāḥ iti strī liṅga nirdeśena hi bhāvyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in that case, the feminine form 'dṛṣṭyā' should be used.

analyzed: śabda virodham uktvā artha virodham āha hetoḥ ca iti
translated: Having stated the contradiction with the word, he states the contradiction with the meaning: and because of the reason, etc.

analyzed: sādhyasama tvam asiddha tvam
translated: Sameness of the probandum means unestablished.

analyzed: sarva kāla vartamānatā lakṣaṇa nitya tva rūpa sādhyasya iva avināśi tva rūpa hetoḥ api asiddhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as the probandum, which is characterized by being present at all times, is unestablished, so too the reason, which is characterized by indestructibility, is unestablished.

original: avināśitvasyaiva sādhyatayā tasyaiva hetutvāyoga iti vā /
analyzed: avināśi tvasya eva sādhya tayā tasya eva hetu tva ayogaḥ iti vā
translated: Or, because indestructibility itself is to be proved, it cannot be the reason.

analyzed: artha antara paratvam āśaṅkya pariharati draṣṭuḥ iti
translated: Suspecting that it refers to something else, he answers: of the seer, etc.

analyzed: atra yojanāyām dṛṣṭi padam bhāva pradhānam
translated: In this construction, the word 'vision' is predominant in meaning.

analyzed: jñāna tva ayoga vyavacchedaḥ draṣṭuḥ sādhyaḥ
translated: The probandum for the seer is the exclusion of the impossibility of being knowledge.

analyzed: atra ca aprayojaka tvena hetoḥ ahetu tvam asādhaka tvam duṣpariharam iti bāvaḥ
translated: And here, the reason being unjustifiable, the irrelevance of the reason, i.e. the inability to prove, is difficult to avoid - this is the idea.

analyzed: sva pakṣa iti
translated: In one's own position, etc.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ jñāna rūpa tva upagamaḥ āgantuka jñāna vādinā upasiddhāntaḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: if one accepts the knowledge of the self to be of the nature of knowledge, then for one who advocates adventitious knowledge, there is a contradiction with one's own doctrine.

analyzed: advaiti abhimate ca nirukta śruti arthe dūṣaṇam atra abhimatam
translated: And the fault in the meaning of the aforementioned Vedic text, which is accepted as non-dual, is accepted here.

analyzed: yathā ajñātuḥ jñāna svarūpa anatireke sādhye vyadhikaraṇa asiddha tvena ātma nitya tvasya ahetutvam
translated: If the nature of the knower is to be established as not separate from the nature of knowledge, then the eternality of the self is not a reason, due to being unestablished with respect to a different subject.

analyzed: jñātuḥ ahamartha iti
translated: And if the knower, the meaning of I, is accepted to be the self and to be indestructible, then there is a contradiction with one's own doctrine.

original: niruktaśruterabhimatamarthaṃ vaktuṃ viṣayaṃ viśodhayati vākyadvayena ātmanastviti /
analyzed: nirukta śruteḥ abhimatam artham vaktum viṣayam viśodhayati vākya dvayena ātmanaḥ tu iti
translated: In order to state the accepted meaning of the aforementioned Vedic text, he clarifies the subject with two sentences, beginning with of the self.

analyzed: nahi sati iti ca
translated: And with for it is not...

analyzed: nitya ātma svarūpa nirūpaka dharma tvam jñānasya nitya tve hetuḥ vākya dvayena samasūci
translated: The reason for the eternality of knowledge is indicated by the two sentences as being the quality that defines the nature of the eternal self.

analyzed: atha śruti vākya artham āha tena iti
translated: Now, he states the meaning of the Vedic text with Therefore...

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ iti vyadhikaraṇa viśeṣaṇam dṛṣṭeḥ jñānasya dharma bhūtasya
translated: Of the seer is a qualifier with a different subject, of the knowledge, which is the quality of seeing.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ nitya tvam avināśi tvāt ātmanaḥ iti uktam
translated: The eternality of the self is stated as of the self because of its indestructibility.

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ iti dharmi nirdeśāt ca ātma svarūpa nirūpaka dharma tvam jñānasya siddham
translated: And because of the seer is the statement of the subject, it is established that knowledge is the quality that defines the nature of the self.

original: tathā ca phalitaṃ hetumāha ātmasvabhāvabhūtāyā iti /
analyzed: tathā ca phalitam hetum āha ātma svabhāva bhūtāyāḥ iti
translated: And thus he states the inferred reason: of that which is of the nature of the Self.

analyzed: nitya ātma svabhāva tvam hetuḥ
translated: The reason is being of the nature of the eternal Self.

analyzed: etena vyadhikaraṇa asiddhi śaṅkā nirastā
translated: By this, the doubt of being unestablished with respect to a different subject is removed.

original: viṣayaviśeṣa saṃbandhaprakāraḥindriyādidvārakaprasṛtibhedādhīnacaitanyārthasaṃbandhav iśeṣalakṣaṇaḥ /🔽tena prāpto dṛṣṭyādivyapadeśo yayeti samāsaḥ /
analyzed: tena prāptaḥ dṛṣṭi ādi vyapadeśaḥ yayā iti samāsaḥ
translated: The mode of connection with a particular object is characterized by a special connection with the object of consciousness dependent on the differences of manifestation through the doors of the senses and so on.🔽By that, the designation of seeing and so on is obtained. That by which there is a compound.

analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ cākṣuṣam adhyakṣam  ghrātiḥ ghrāṇa jam
translated: Seeing is visual perception.🔽Smelling is olfactory.

analyzed: rasayatiḥ rāsanam
translated: Tasting is gustatory.
Speaking is verbal knowledge.

analyzed: śrutiḥ śrāvaṇam adhyakṣam
translated: Hearing is auditory perception.

analyzed: matiḥ anumānam
translated: Thinking is inference.

analyzed: spṛṣṭiḥ spārśanam adhyakṣam
translated: Touching is tactile perception.

analyzed: vijñātiḥ upāsanam
translated: Knowing is meditation.

analyzed: yoga jaḥ sākṣātkāraḥ vā
translated: Or it is yogic intuition.

analyzed: sva ātma avabhāsinyāḥ sva prakāśāyāḥ
translated: Of that which illuminates the Self, which is self-luminous.

original: jñānasyātmasvabhāvatve nityatve cānyā api śrutīrudāharati sa yatheti /
analyzed: jñānasya ātma svabhāva tve nitya tve ca anyāḥ api śrutīḥ udāharati sa yathā iti
translated: When knowledge is of the nature of the Self and eternal, he cites other Vedic passages: As he...

analyzed: anantaraḥ iti bāhyaḥ
translated: The next... is external.

analyzed: abāhyaḥ iti āntaraḥ ca pradeśaḥ sāmastyena  vivakṣitaḥ
translated: The internal... is the internal part, intended as a whole.

analyzed: kātsnaryam ca ātmanaḥ svarūpataḥ dharmataḥ ca
translated: And the completeness of the Self is in terms of its own nature and its qualities.

original: tathāca jñānasvarūpatvaṃ jñānasvabhāvatvaṃ cātmanaḥ sadā labhyate /
analyzed: tathā ca jñāna svarūpa tvam jñāna svabhāva tvam ca ātmanaḥ sadā labhyate
translated: And thus the nature of knowledge and the essence of knowledge are always obtained for the self.

original: ukter'the śrutyantaraṃ svena bhāsā svena jyotiṣeti /
analyzed: ukta ṛthe śruti antaram svena bhāsā svena jyotiṣā iti
translated: Regarding the stated meaning, another scriptural passage is by its own light, by its own radiance.

analyzed: svarūpataḥ dharmataḥ ca prakāśa rūpa tvam atrā ucyate
translated: Here, the nature of light is said to be in terms of its own nature and its qualities.

analyzed: ātma jyotiḥ iti api nirukta artham eva
translated: The light of the self also has the same etymological meaning.

analyzed: sūrya ādi jyotiḥ hi jyotiṣmat jyotiḥ rūpam ca
translated: For the light of the sun etc. is the light of the luminous, and has the form of light.

analyzed: tathā ātmā api
translated: So does the self.

analyzed: sūrya ādi jyotiṣaḥ prakāśaḥ iva
translated: Like the light of the sun etc. is the light,

original: ātmano jyotīrūpaṃ jñānaṃ svābhāvikamiti cātra vivakṣitam /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ jyotī rūpam jñānam svābhāvikam iti ca atra vivakṣitam
translated: and here it is intended that the knowledge which has the form of light is natural to the self.

analyzed: muktau jñāna anuvṛttau śrutim upakṣipati tathā apavarga iti
translated: He introduces a scriptural passage regarding the continuation of knowledge in liberation with Thus at the time of final release.

original: svābhāvikākārāvirbhāvalakṣaṇāyāṃ muktau jñānānuvṛttyā jñānasyātmasvabhāvānubandhitvaṃ prasidhyatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svābhāvika ākāra āvirbhāva lakṣaṇāyām muktau jñāna anuvṛttyā jñānasya ātma svabhāva anubandhi tvam prasidhyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in liberation, which is characterized by the manifestation of the natural form, the continuation of knowledge establishes that knowledge is connected with the nature of the self.

analyzed: svāpe jñāna anuvṛtti parām śrutim āha anyāḥ ca iti
translated: He cites a scriptural passage regarding the continuation of knowledge even in sleep with And others.

analyzed: sataḥ api jñānasya artha sannikarṣa abhāvāt svāpe na artha prakāśaḥ iti jānāti eva ityādeḥ arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of knows even is that although knowledge exists, in sleep there is no illumination of objects due to the absence of contact with objects.

original: nityatva ātmasvabhāvatve ca jñānasya smṛtīścodāharati nirvāṇeti /
analyzed: nitya tve ātma svabhāva tve ca jñānasya smṛtīḥ ca udāharati nirvāṇa iti
translated: And in the case of the eternality and self-nature of knowledge, he cites the Smritis beginning with nirvana.

analyzed: purāṇe śrīmati vaiṣṇave
translated: In the ancient Vishnu Purana.

analyzed: jñāna mayaḥ iti
translated: Knowledge-made.

analyzed: mayaṭ prācurye
translated: The suffix maya (in jnanamya) denotes abundance.

analyzed: eva kāraḥ tra api saṃbadhyate
translated: The word eva (in jnanamya eva) is also connected here.

analyzed: jñāna pracuraḥ eva iti avadhāraṇena nirukta artha lābhaḥ
translated: By the restriction knowledge-made only, the meaning of the Nirukta (etymology) is obtained.

analyzed: jyotiṣām api iti mahābhārate śrī bhagavadgītāyām
translated: Of the lights also in the Bhagavad Gita of the Mahabharata.

analyzed: jñāna nitya tva ādau sphuṭam śrī viṣṇudharma vacanam upakṣipati bhagavān ityādinā
translated: The Lord introduces the clear statement of Vishnu Dharma on the eternality etc. of knowledge, beginning with the Lord said.

original: āhetyadhyāhāryam /🔽uktārthe sūtramapi pramāṇamityāha ata eva hīti /
analyzed: āha iti adhyāhāryam  ukta arthe sūtram api pramāṇam iti āha atas eva hi iti
translated: Said is to be supplied.🔽He says that the aphorism is also a means of knowledge in the matter stated, with Therefore, indeed.

analyzed: atas śrutitas eva ātmā jñaḥ jñātā eva iti sūtra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the aphorism is: The self is known only, by the very Vedic text.

original: jña evetyanena nityatvamātmasvabhāvatvaṃ ca jñānasya sūtrakṛdabhimatam /
analyzed: jñaḥ eva iti anena nitya tvam ātma svabhāva tvam ca jñānasya sūtrakṛt abhimatam
translated: By known only, the author of the aphorism intends the eternality and self-nature of knowledge.

original: ata eva jñānanityatve svāpe 'pi prakāśaḥ syādityāśaṅkya parihṛtaṃ puṃstvādivadityanena /
analyzed: atas eva jñāna nitya tve svāpe pi prakāśaḥ syāt iti āśaṅkya parihṛtam puṃstva ādi vat iti anena
translated: Therefore, the doubt that if knowledge is eternal, there would be manifestation even in sleep is removed by like masculinity etc.

original: nanvevaṃ jñānasyātmadharmabhūtasya svābhāvikatve tasya saṃśayaniścayādibhedaḥ smṛtyanubhavabhedaśca katham /
analyzed: nanu evam jñānasya ātma dharma bhūtasya svābhāvika tve tasya saṃśaya niścaya ādi bhedaḥ smṛti anubhava bhedaḥ ca katham
translated: Now, if thus knowledge, which is a property of the self, is natural, how can there be a distinction of it into doubt, certainty, etc., and a distinction of memory and experience?

analyzed: tatra āha tat evam iti
translated: To that he says thus.

analyzed: yugapad jhaṭiti
translated: Simultaneously, instantly.

analyzed: nairantaryeṇa iti yāvat
translated: Without interruption, is what is meant.
The subtle part of knowledge, which is the impression dependent on the experience of the impressions of knowledge,
is the special connection of consciousness with the object.

analyzed: artha saṃśleṣa viśeṣa viśiṣṭam caitanyam eva vā saṃśaya niścaya ādi vyapadeśa bhāj iti uktam
translated: Or consciousness itself, qualified by the special connection with the object, is said to be the part that can be designated as doubt, certainty, etc.

analyzed: tatra prathama pakṣe śaṅkate na ca evam iti
translated: To that, he doubts in the first case thus.

original: saṃyogasya dviṣṭhatvena cityarthasaṃyogasya jñānatve viṣayasyāpi jñātṛtvaprasaṅga ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: saṃyogasya dviṣṭha tvena citi artha saṃyogasya jñāna tve viṣayasya api jñātṛ tva prasaṅgaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because conjunction is twofold, if the conjunction of consciousness with the object is knowledge, then the object would also be the knower.

analyzed: caitanyasya jñātṛ tva prasaṅge kathañcid iṣṭa āpatti sambhavāt viṣayasya jñātṛ tvam prasañjitam
translated: Since in the case of consciousness being the knower, the desired conclusion can somehow be established, the knowership of the object is implied.

analyzed: yat vā viṣayasya viṣaya āśrayasya
translated: Or, of the object, the support of the object.

analyzed: yathāśrute ātmanaḥ pi
translated: As heard, even the self

analyzed: tad tad jñāna āśraya tvam na syāt pakṣe smin
translated: would not be the support of that and that knowledge, in this view.

original: ataḥ svāśrayāśrayatvasaṃbandhena jñānavattvameva jñātṛtvamatra pakṣe vācyamiti viṣaye na jñātṛtvaprasaṅga iti /
analyzed: atas sva āśraya āśraya tva saṃbandhena jñānavat tvam eva jñātṛ tvam atra pakṣe vācyam iti viṣaye na jñātṛ tva prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, in this case, the knowledge of the object alone, which is the knower by virtue of its relation of being the substratum of the knowledge, should be stated as the probandum, and not the knowership of the object.

analyzed: pariharati viṣayeṇa iti  viṣayeṇa iti hetau tṛtīyā
translated: He answers: By the object, etc.🔽The instrumental case is used in the sense of cause.

analyzed: viṣaya śabdaḥ viṣaya vyāpāra paraḥ
translated: The word 'object' refers to the activity of the object.

analyzed: evam agre cātanyena iti atra api
translated: Similarly, in the following sentence 'by the instrument', etc.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥarthagrahaṇārthaṃ vyāpriyamāṇaṃ hi caitanyameva / tathāca
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ artha grahaṇa artham vyāpriyamāṇam hi caitanyam eva tathā ca
translated: The idea is this: Consciousness itself, which operates for the purpose of apprehending the object,

original: viṣayacaitanyasaṃyogasya tattadarthajñānatve 'pi tasya svānukūlavyāpṛtimaccaitanyāśrayatvasaṃbandhenātmanyeva sattvāttasyaiva jñātṛtvaṃ nārthāderityupalambhabalādvyavasthāpyam /
analyzed: viṣaya caitanya saṃyogasya tad tad artha jñāna tve pi tasya sva anukūla vyāpṛtimat caitanya āśraya tva saṃbandhena ātmani eva sattvāt tasya eva jñātṛ tvam na artha ādeḥ iti upalambha balāt vyavasthāpyam
translated: and although the conjunction of consciousness with the object is the knowledge of that particular object, still, because it exists only in the self by virtue of its relation of being the substratum of consciousness which is engaged in its own favorable activity, only that self is the knower, not the object, etc. This should be established by the force of perception.

original: yathā ālokārthasaṃyogasyaiva prakāśatve 'pi prakāśakatvaṃ svadharmabhūtālokaprasaraṇavaśātsūryādereva nārthasya tadvaditi /
analyzed: yathā āloka artha saṃyogasya eva prakāśa tve pi prakāśaka tvam sva dharma bhūta āloka prasaraṇa vaśāt sūrya ādeḥ eva na arthasya tadvat iti
translated: Just as although the conjunction of light and the object is itself illumination, the illuminating is only of the sun, etc., by virtue of the spread of light which is its own property, and not of the object.

analyzed: yat vā viṣaya anuyogika saṃyoga abhāvāt iti viṣayeṇa ityādeḥ arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning of 'by the object' etc. is because there is no conjunction with the object.

analyzed: tasya saṃyogaḥ viṣaya pratiyogika saṃyogaḥ
translated: Its conjunction is the conjunction with the object as its counter-entity.

original: evaṃ prathamaṃ pakṣamupapādya tattadarthasaṃbaddhaṃ caitanyameva tattadarthajñānamiti dvitīyaṃ pakṣaṃ śaṅkāsamādhānamukhena vyavasthāpayati
analyzed: evam prathamam pakṣam upapādya tad tad artha saṃbaddham caitanyam eva tad tad artha jñānam iti dvitīyam pakṣam śaṅkā samādhāna mukhena vyavasthāpayati  /
translated: Having thus established the first view, he establishes the second view that consciousness itself, connected with each object, is the knowledge of each object, by way of raising doubts and resolving them.

analyzed: atha iti
translated: Now, he says if it is argued etc.

analyzed: prakāśaḥ prakāśakaḥ
translated: Light is the illuminator.
Dependence on the sun etc. means having a nature and activity dependent on the sun etc., and having a qualifier not established separately from it.

original: tattadarthasaṃbaddhālokāśrayasyaiva sūryādeḥ prakāśakatvamiva tattadarthasaṃbaddhacaitanyavata ātmana eva jñātṛtvamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tad tad artha saṃbaddha āloka āśrayasya eva sūrya ādeḥ prakāśaka tvam iva tad tad artha saṃbaddha caitanyavataḥ ātmanaḥ eva jñātṛ tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as the sun etc., which are the basis of light connected with each object, are the illuminators, in the same way, only the self, which possesses consciousness connected with each object, is the knower. This is the meaning.

analyzed: ayam eva mukhyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: This alone is the primary view.

analyzed: jñātṛ tvasya sākṣāt ātmani saṅgateḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the nature of being a knower is directly connected with the self.

original: ananyasādhana ityuktamananyādhīnasiddhitvaṃ caitanyasvabhāvatvaṃ cātmano nigamayati tatsiddhamiti /
analyzed: ananya sādhanaḥ iti uktam ananya adhīna siddhi tvam caitanya svabhāva tvam ca ātmanaḥ nigamayati tat siddham iti
translated: Having stated that it is not accomplished by anything else, he concludes that the nature of the self is consciousness and that its existence is not dependent on anything else. He says that is established.

analyzed: caitanya svabhāvaḥ eva jñātṛ tva svabhāvaḥ eva
translated: Having consciousness as its nature means having the nature of being a knower.

analyzed: anena jñānasya āgantuka tvam nirastam
translated: By this, the adventitiousness of knowledge is refuted.

analyzed: ātmanam vidan eva āste nitya ananya adhīna sva prakāśavān eva āste
translated: The self exists only as knowing, eternally, with self-luminousness not dependent on anything else.

analyzed: anena ātmanaḥ prakāśasya āgantuka tvam
translated: By this, the adventitiousness of the self's manifestation

analyzed: jñāna prayukta tvam ca vyāvartitam
translated: and its dependence on knowledge are refuted.

analyzed: nimitta bheda anusāreṇa indriya liṅga ādi jñāna artha sannikarṣa upādhi anvaya vyatireka anuvidhānataḥ
translated: In accordance with the difference in causes, due to the conformity with the presence and absence of the limiting adjuncts such as sense organs, inferential marks, etc., which are the objects of knowledge.

analyzed: śiṣṭam spaṣṭam
translated: The rest is clear.

analyzed: svayam prakāśasya ātmanaḥ śābda ādi pramāṇa dhī gocara tvam api sādhayati tat evam ityādinā
translated: He also establishes the objectness of the self, which is self-luminous, with respect to the cognition of verbal testimony etc., with the words That being so... etc.

analyzed: asphuṭa prakāśe mīnaḥ nidarśanam
translated: In the case of indistinct manifestation, a fish is the example.

analyzed: a viveka grahaṇe ca kṣīram
translated: And in the apprehension of non-discrimination, milk is [the example].

analyzed: tad upapādana nyāya anugatāḥ ātma anātma viveka upapādaka avayava pañcaka ātmaka nyāya prayojyāḥ
translated: They are followed by the reasoning that establishes the distinction between the self and the non-self, which consists of five parts that are to be applied by reasoning.

analyzed: anumāna bhedāḥ anumāna viśeṣāḥ
translated: The varieties of inference are the particular types of inference.

analyzed: vacanāni pramāṇa vākyāni śāstra anugatāni
translated: The statements are the authoritative statements that follow from the scriptures.

analyzed: taiḥ api iti
translated: By those also.

original: anumānāgamānāṃ parokṣaikahetutvena prasphuṭaprakāśāsampādakatvāttāvanmātre 'paritoṣaḥ prasphuṭātmaprakāśākāṅkṣiṇāṃ yukta eva hi /
analyzed: anumāna āgamānām parokṣa eka hetu tvena prasphuṭa prakāśa a sampādaka tvāt tāvat mātre paritoṣaḥ prasphuṭa ātma prakāśa ākāṅkṣiṇām yuktaḥ eva hi
translated: Since inference and scripture are the sole causes of the imperceptible, and do not produce clear manifestation, it is indeed proper for those who desire clear self-manifestation to be dissatisfied with just that much.

original: mana ādigatajñānāvāraṇadoṣakṣapaṇaṃ yogāṅgānuṣṭhānena sampadyata iti yamaniyameti dyotitam /
translated: The removal of the fault of obstructing the knowledge obtained through the mind etc. is accomplished by practicing the limbs of yoga. This is indicated by the words restraint and observance.

analyzed: nirodha abhyāsaḥ yoga abhyāsaḥ
translated: Practice of cessation is the practice of yoga.

analyzed: yogāḥ citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ iti hi yoga sūtram
translated: For the Yoga Sutra says: Yoga is the cessation of the fluctuations of consciousness.

analyzed: yoga abhyāsa paripākataḥ rajaḥ tamaḥ kāluṣya nivṛttyā udrikta viśuddha sattve manasi ātma viveka sākṣātkāra yogya tā iti nirodha abhyāsa ityādeḥ arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of practice of cessation etc. is that by the perfection of the practice of yoga, by the cessation of the impurities of rajas and tamas, in the mind which is of increased pure sattva, there is the capacity for the direct realization of the discrimination of the self.

analyzed: vailakṣaṇyasya ātma gatasya a parokṣa jñānāya  prayatante ātma tattva cintana pravṛttim ācaranti
translated: For the direct knowledge of the distinctive nature of the self.

analyzed: bhāvanā iti
translated: They strive - they engage in the practice of constant meditation on the truth of the self, for the sake of its accomplishment.

analyzed: nirantara anucintana lakṣaṇe yoge bhāvanā prakarṣa paryante niṣpanne sati
translated: By the practice of meditation. By the perfection of the yoga characterized by constant meditation on the self,

analyzed: ca aparokṣa jñānam yoga ja dharma anugṛhīta viśuddha manaḥ janya ātma tattva sākṣātkāraḥ
translated: when the direct knowledge of the truth of the self arises, which is produced by the pure mind aided by the qualities born of yoga.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ  evam ātmā svatas siddhi anna āgamena anumānataḥ
translated: It arises - this is the meaning.

analyzed: yoga abhyāsa bhuvā spaṣṭam pratyakṣeṇa prakāśyate  iti ātma pramāṇa nirūpaṇa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus the self, though self-evident, is clearly revealed by perception aided by the practice of yoga, not by scripture or inference.🔽Thus ends the chapter on the examination of the means of knowing the self.

analyzed: atha asya kāla avaccheda parīkṣā
translated: Now, the examination of its temporal determination.

original: tatra sugatamatānusāriṇaḥ sanmātrānubandhinīṃ kṣaṇikatāmācakṣāṇā nityātmadarśanameva sarvānarthamūlaṃ manyamānāḥ kṣaṇabhaṅginamenaṃ saṅgirante /
analyzed: tatra sugata mata anusāriṇaḥ sanmātra anubandhinīm kṣaṇikatām ācakṣāṇāḥ nitya ātma darśanam eva sarva anartha mūlam manyamānāḥ kṣaṇabhaṅginam enam saṅgirante
translated: There, those who follow the doctrine of the Sugata (Buddha), teaching momentariness that is invariably concomitant with existence, considering the view of a permanent self to be the root of all evil, proclaim this (momentariness).

analyzed: yat sat tat kṣaṇikam
translated: What exists is momentary.

analyzed: san ca ayam ātmā iti
translated: And this self exists.

analyzed: katham punar sanmātra anubandhinī kṣaṇika tā
translated: How is momentariness invariably concomitant with mere existence?

analyzed: akṣaṇikasya sattā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because existence is not possible for what is not momentary.

analyzed: yat na kasmaicid kāryāya
translated: That which is not capable of producing any effect,

analyzed: antatas sārvajñya vijñāna gotara tvāya api na prabhavati
translated: not even for the sake of omniscient knowledge,

original: na tasya sadbhāvaḥ saṃbhāvyata ityarthakriyākāritaiva sattā bhāvānām /
analyzed: na tasya sadbhāvaḥ saṃbhāvyate iti artha kriyā kāritā eva sattā bhāvānām
translated: its existence is not conceivable. The meaning is that the capacity for effective action is itself the existence of things.

original: na ca sā svavyāpakabhūtakramayaugapadyavirahiṇyakṣaṇike saṃbhavinītyanyatra niravakāśatayā kṣaṇikatayaivānubadhyate /
analyzed: na ca sā sva vyāpaka bhūta krama yaugapadya virahiṇī akṣaṇike saṃbhavinī iti anyatra niravakāśa tayā kṣaṇika tayā eva anubadhyate
translated: And that is not possible for what is not momentary, which lacks the succession and simultaneity that are its (existence's) pervasion. Therefore, elsewhere, due to the lack of any other (explanation), it is invariably connected with momentariness.

analyzed: katham punar krama yaugapadyayoḥ arthakriyā vyāpaka tvam
translated: How, again, are succession and simultaneity the pervasion of effective action?

analyzed: katham vā tayoḥ akṣaṇikāt nivṛttiḥ śrūyatām
translated: Or how is their exclusion from what is not momentary? Listen.

analyzed: uktam artham saṅgṛhṇāti evam ātmā iti
translated: He summarizes the meaning stated (in the previous verse) with Thus, the self... and so on.

original: svaprakāśasyātmano dharmabhūtaṃ jñānaṃ viṣayādigrahaṇe dehādivailakṣaṇyagrahaṇe cātmana upayujyata ityetāvatā siddham /
analyzed: sva prakāśasya ātmanaḥ dharma bhūtam jñānam viṣaya ādi grahaṇe deha ādi vailakṣaṇya grahaṇe ca ātmanaḥ upayujyate iti etāvatā siddham
translated: It is established that the knowledge which is the property of the self, which is self-luminous, is useful to the self in apprehending objects etc. and in apprehending the difference from the body etc.

analyzed: evam ātmani pramāṇa parīkṣā vṛttā
translated: Thus ends the examination of the means of knowledge with regard to the self.

analyzed: atha nitya tvam vyavasthāvayitum vicāram upakramate atha asya iti
translated: Now, in order to establish eternality, he begins the discussion with Now, of this.

analyzed: asya ātmanaḥ
translated: Of this self.
The examination of the connection with time.

analyzed: pravartate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The discussion proceeds, this is the remainder.

analyzed: tatra iti
translated: There,

original: ātmanaḥ kālasaṃbandhe vicāraviṣaye kṣaṇamātrakālasaṃbandhinaṃ vināśinamātmānamāmananti kecana vādinaḥ saugatāḥ iti yāvat /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ kāla saṃbandhe vicāra viṣaye kṣaṇa mātra kāla saṃbandhinam vināśinam ātmānam āmananti kecana vādinaḥ saugatāḥ iti yāvat
translated: with regard to the examination of the connection of the self with time, some philosophers, namely the Buddhists, declare the self to be perishable, connected with time lasting only an instant.

analyzed: kāla saṃbandhaḥ kṣaṇikatva lakṣaṇaḥ eva iti amīṣām āśayaḥ
translated: Their idea is that the connection with time is characterized by momentariness itself.

analyzed: sattvāt kṣaṇika tvam ātmanaḥ iti uktam
translated: It is said that the self is momentary because it exists.

analyzed: sattvasya kṣaṇika tva vyāpya tve siddhe śobhanam idam
translated: This is splendid when the existence of the self is established as pervaded by momentariness.

analyzed: tat eva kuta
translated: How is that known?

analyzed: iti atas sattvam kṣaṇikatva vyāpti arham pariṣkaroti yat na iti
translated: Therefore, he refines the existence which deserves to be pervaded by momentariness, with That which does not do.

analyzed: arthakriyā kartṛ tvam eva sattvam
translated: Existence itself is the state of being an agent of effective action.

analyzed: tat ca kṣaṇikatva vyāpyam iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that that is pervaded by momentariness.

analyzed: sārvajñya vijñānam buddha jñānam
translated: Omniscience is the knowledge of a Buddha.

analyzed: kṣaṇikatva vyāptim eva upapādayati na ca sā iti
translated: He explains the pervasion by momentariness, saying and that is not possible etc.
Either sequence or simultaneity is pervaded by being an agent of effective action.

original: taccākṣaṇike sthire 'ghaṭamānaṃ kartṛtvaṃ kṣaṇike vyavaśtāpayatīti sattva kṣaṇikatvavyāpyamevetyāpatatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tat ca akṣaṇike sthire ghaṭamānam kartṛ tvam kṣaṇike vyavaśtāpayati iti sattva kṣaṇikatva vyāpyam eva iti āpatati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And that being impossible in a permanent thing, it establishes agency in a momentary thing. Thus it follows that existence is pervaded by momentariness. This is the idea.

analyzed: krama yaugapadya anyatarasya kartṛ tva vyāpaka tvam tasya
translated: Either sequence or simultaneity is pervaded by being an agent. That

analyzed: sthire sambhavam ca upapādayitum praśnaḥ katham punar iti
translated: To explain the impossibility of that in a permanent thing, he asks how again?

analyzed: uttaram śrūyatām ityādinā
translated: The answer begins with listen etc.

analyzed: artha kriyāsu bhāvānām kartṛ tvasya dvayī gatiḥ
translated: For entities, agency in effective actions has two modes:

analyzed: krameṇa yugapad vā iti na vidhā antara saṃbhavaḥ
translated: Either sequentially or simultaneously, there is no other possibility.

original: bhāvābhāvavadanayoranyataranivṛttāvanyataravyavasthānādarthakriyājanane bhāvānāṃ na tṛtīyaprakārasaṃbhava iti kramākramapratibaddhaivārthakriyā 🔽na cākṣa
analyzed: bhāva abhāva vat anayoḥ anyatara nivṛttau anyatara vyavasthānāt arthakriyā janane bhāvānām na tṛtīya prakāra saṃbhavaḥ iti kramākrama pratibaddhā eva arthakriyā  na ca akṣa
translated: Since the presence or absence of either is determined by the absence of the other, for entities generating effective actions, a third type is not possible. Thus effective action is necessarily bound by sequence or simultaneity.

analyzed: ṇike krama yaugapadye saṃbhavataḥ
translated: And sequence and simultaneity are not possible in a non-momentary thing.

analyzed: etāvān eva ātmasiddhi granthā bhāgaḥ upalabhyate  iti śrīmat viśiṣṭa advaita siddhānta pravartana dhurandhara parama ācārya
translated: This much of the text of the Atmasiddhi is available.🔽Thus ends the Atmasiddhi in the three Siddhis favored by the illustrious supreme teacher
Sri Bhagavad Yamuna Muni, the upholder of the banner of the propagation of the Vishishtadvaita doctrine.

analyzed: artha iti kiñcid artha kriyā karaṇam krameṇa
translated: In the object means the performance of some action gradually.

analyzed: kiñcid ca a krameṇa yugapad
translated: And some simultaneously, at once.

analyzed: yaugapadya asaṃbhave kramaḥ
translated: In the absence of simultaneity, there is sequence.

original: tadabhāve ca yaugapadyaṃ niyatamiti kramayaugapadyānyataravyāpyaivārthakriyā bhavatītyarthaḥ ///
analyzed: tad abhāve ca yaugapadyam niyatam iti krama yaugapadya anyatara vyāpyā eva arthakriyā bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: And in the absence of that, simultaneity is certain. The meaning is that the action is necessarily pervaded by either sequence or simultaneity.

analyzed: bhavatu evam
translated: Let it be so.

analyzed: athā api sthire katham na sā
translated: Even then, how is it not so in a permanent [object]?

analyzed: tatra āha na ca iti
translated: There he says 'not' etc.

analyzed: grantha bhāgaḥ grimaḥ kvāpi na itas samupalabhyate
translated: The next part of the text is not available anywhere from here.

original: vyākhyānaṃ vihitaṃ yāvadupalabdhasya sārataḥ //🔽iti śrīnāgapurī tirunāṅgūra
analyzed: vyākhyānam vihitam yāvat upalabdhasya sārataḥ  iti śrī nāgapurī tirunāṅgūra
translated: The commentary has been composed as far as the available essence.🔽Thus ends the Atmasiddhi in the three Siddhis favored by the illustrious supreme teacher🔽Sri Bhagavad Yamuna Muni, the upholder of the banner of the propagation of the Vishishtadvaita doctrine.🔽By the son-jewel of the illustrious teacher, the learned one who is an ornament of the lineage, the fearsome teacher of opponents,🔽the illustrious teacher named Sri Krishnamacharya,

analyzed: divya deśa abhijanena prativādi bhayaṅkara ācārya anvaya bhūṣaṇa vidvas varya śrī kṛṣṇam ācārya ākhya ācārya varya putra ratnena
translated: who was born in the divine land of Tirunangur in the city of Nagapuri,

analyzed: catur tantrī pārāvāra pārīṇa diganta viśrānta kīrti dayāmūrti śrīmat bhāṣyakāra divya vaṃśa avatīrṇa śrī bhūtapurī nivāsa rasika vidvat sārvabhauma hārīta śrīmadā sūri rāmānuja ācārya deśika indra caraṇa kamala varivasyā samadhigata pada vākya pramāṇa tantrahṛdayena  śrī vaiṣṇava dāsena prabhaaṇṇaṅgara ācāryeṇa nyāya vyākaraṇa śiromaṇinā ubhaya vedānta viduṣā

analyzed: praṇītam ātmasiddheḥ vyākhyānam siddhāñjanam jayatāt ciram
translated: By the illustrious Āsūrapurī-dwelling learned emperor Hari-Ananta, who is the embodiment of compassion, whose fame rests on the ends of the directions that are the four strings of the ocean, and who is descended from the divine lineage of the author of the Bhāṣya,🔽By the illustrious Āsūrapurī-dwelling learned emperor Hari-An
